these are the generations of Isaac, Abraham's son: Abraham begot Isaac.
Isaac was forty years old when he took Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Syrian of Paddan-aram, the sister of Laban the Syrian, to be his wife.
Isaac entreated Jehovah for his wife, because she was barren. And Jehovah was entreated by him,  Rebekah his wife conceived.
the children struggled together within her. And she said, If it be so, why do I live? And she went to inquire of Jehovah.
Jehovah said to her, Two nations are in thy womb,  two peoples shall be separated from thy bowels. And the one people shall be stronger than the other people. And the elder shall serve the younger.
when her days to be delivered were fulfilled, behold, there were twins in her womb.
the first came forth red all over like a hairy garment,  they called his name Esau.
after that his brother came forth,  his hand had hold on Esau's heel,  his name was called Jacob. And Isaac was sixty years old when she bore them.
the boys grew. And Esau was a skilful hunter, a man of the field. And Jacob was a quiet man, dwelling in tents.
Now Isaac loved Esau, because he ate of his venison. And Rebekah loved Jacob.
Jacob boiled pottage. And Esau came in from the field,  he was faint.
Esau said to Jacob, Feed me, I pray thee, with that same red pottage, for I am faint. Therefore his name was called Edom.
Jacob said, First sell me thy birthright.
Esau said, Behold, I am about to die,  what profit shall the birthright do to me?
Jacob said, Swear to me first. And he swore to him,  he sold his birthright to Jacob.
Jacob gave Esau bread and pottage of lentils. And he ate and drank,  rose up,  went his way. So Esau despised his birthright.
there was a famine in the land, besides the first famine that was in the days of Abraham. And Isaac went to Abimelech king of the Philistines, to Gerar.
Jehovah appeared to him,  said, Do not go down into Egypt. Dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of.
Sojourn in this land,  I will be with thee,  will bless thee. For to thee,  to thy seed, I will give all these lands,  I will establish the oath that I swore to Abraham thy father.
I will multiply thy seed as the stars of heaven,  will give to thy seed all these lands,  in thy seed all the nations of the earth shall be blessed,
because Abraham obeyed my voice,  kept my order, my commandments, my statutes,  my laws.
Isaac dwelt in Gerar.
the men of the place asked him of his wife. And he said, She is my sister. For he feared to say, My wife, Lest, the men of the place should kill me for Rebekah, because she was fair to look upon.
it came to pass, when he had been there a long time, that Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out at a window,  saw, , behold, Isaac was playing with Rebekah his wife.
Abimelech called Isaac,  said, Behold, she is certainly thy wife,  how did thou say, She is my sister? And Isaac said to him, Because I said, Lest I die because of her.
Abimelech said, What is this thou have done to us? One of the people might easily have lain with thy wife,  thou would have brought guiltiness upon us.
Abimelech ordered all the people, saying, He who touches this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.
Isaac sowed in that land,  found in the same year a hundredfold. And Jehovah blessed him.
the man became great,  grew more and more until he became very great.
he had possessions of flocks,  possessions of herds,  a great household. And the Philistines envied him.
Now all the wells which his father's servants had dug in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines had stopped,  filled with soil.
Abimelech said to Isaac, Go from us, for thou are much mightier than we.
Isaac departed from there,  encamped in the valley of Gerar,  dwelt there.
Isaac again dug the wells of water, which they had dug in the days of Abraham his father. For the Philistines had stopped them after the death of Abraham. And he called their names after the names by which his father had called them.
Isaac's servants dug in the valley,  found there a well of springing water.
the herdsmen of Gerar strove with Isaac's herdsmen, saying, The water is ours. And he called the name of the well Esek, because they contended with him.
they dug another well,  they strove for that also. And he called the name of it Sitnah.
he moved from there,  dug another well,  they did not strive for that. And he called the name of it Rehoboth. And he said, For now Jehovah has made room for us,  we shall be fruitful in the land.
he went up from there to Beersheba.
Jehovah appeared to him the same night,  said, I am the God of Abraham thy father. Fear not, for I am with thee,  will bless thee,  multiply thy seed for my servant Abraham's sake.
he built an altar there,  called upon the name of Jehovah,  pitched his tent there. And there Isaac's servants dug a well.
Then Abimelech went to him from Gerar,  Ahuzzath his friend,  Phicol the captain of his army.
Isaac said to them, Why have ye come to me, seeing ye hate me,  have sent me away from you?
they said, We saw plainly that Jehovah was with thee. And we said, Let there now be an oath between us, even between us and thee. And let us make a covenant with thee,
that thou will do us no hurt, as we have not touched thee,  as we have done to thee nothing but good,  have sent thee away in peace. Thou are now the blessed of Jehovah.
he made a feast for them,  they ate and drank.
they rose up promptly in the morning,  swore one to another. And Isaac sent them away,  they departed from him in peace.
it came to pass the same day, that Isaac's servants came,  told him concerning the well which they had dug,  said to him, We have found water.
he called it Shibah. Therefore the name of the city is Beersheba to this day.
when Esau was forty years old he took to wife Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite,  Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
they were a bitterness of spirit to Isaac and to Rebekah.
it came to pass, that when Isaac was old,  his eyes were dim, so that he could not see, he called Esau his elder son,  said to him, My son. And he said to him, Here I am.
he said, Behold now, I am old, I know not the day of my death.
Now therefore take, I pray thee, thy weapons, thy quiver and thy bow,  go out to the field,  take venison for me.
make savory food for me, such as I love,  bring it to me, that I may eat, that my soul may bless thee before I die.
Rebekah heard when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. And Esau went to the field to hunt for venison,  to bring it.
Rebekah spoke to Jacob her son, saying, Behold, I heard thy father speak to Esau thy brother, saying,
Bring venison for me,  make savory food for me, that I may eat,  bless thee before Jehovah before my death.
Now therefore, my son, obey my voice according to that which I command thee.
Go now to the flock,  fetch me two good kids of the goats from there. And I will make them savory food for thy father, such as he loves.
thou shall bring it to thy father, that he may eat, so that he may bless thee before his death.
Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, Behold, Esau my brother is a hairy man,  I am a smooth man.
My father will perhaps feel me,  I shall seem to him as a deceiver. And I shall bring a curse upon me,  not a blessing.
his mother said to him, Upon me be thy curse, my son. Only obey my voice,  go fetch them for me.
he went,  fetched,  brought them to his mother. And his mother made savory food, such as his father loved.
Rebekah took the goodly garments of Esau her elder son, which were with her in the house,  put them upon Jacob her younger son.
she put the skins of the kids of the goats upon his hands,  upon the smooth of his neck.
she gave the savory food and the bread, which she had prepared, into the hand of her son Jacob.
he came to his father,  said, My father. And he said, Here I am. Who are thou, my son?
Jacob said to his father, I am Esau thy firstborn. I have done according as thou bade me. Arise, I pray thee, sit and eat of my venison, that thy soul may bless me.
Isaac said to his son, How is it that thou have found it so quickly, my son? And he said, Because Jehovah thy God sent me good speed.
Isaac said to Jacob, Come near, I pray thee, that I may feel thee, my son, whether thou be my very son Esau or not.
Jacob went near to Isaac his father. And he felt him,  said, The voice is Jacob's voice,  the hands are the hands of Esau.
he did not discern him, because his hands were hairy as his brother Esau's hands. So he blessed him.
he said, Are thou my very son Esau? And he said, I am.
he said, Bring it near to me,  I will eat of my son's venison, that my soul may bless thee. And he brought it near to him,  he ate. And he brought wine to him,  he drank.
his father Isaac said to him, Come near now,  kiss me, my son.
he came near,  kissed him. And he smelled the smell of his raiment,  blessed him,  said, See, the smell of my son is as the smell of a field that Jehovah has blessed.
God give thee of the dew of heaven,  of the fatness of the earth,  plenty of grain and new wine.
Let peoples serve thee,  nations bow down to thee. Be lord over thy brothers,  let thy mother's sons bow down to thee. Cursed be he who curses thee,  blessed be he who blesses thee.
it came to pass, as soon as Isaac had made an end of blessing Jacob,  Jacob was yet scarcely gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, that Esau his brother came in from his hunting.
he also made savory food,  brought it to his father. And he said to his father, Let my father arise,  eat of his son's venison, that thy soul may bless me.
Isaac his father said to him, Who are thou? And he said, I am thy son, thy firstborn, Esau.
Isaac trembled very exceedingly,  said, Who then is he who has taken venison,  brought it me,  I have eaten of all before thou came,  have blessed him? Yea, he shall be blessed.
When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with an exceedingly great and bitter cry,  said to his father, Bless me, even me also, O my father.
he said, Thy brother came with guile,  has taken away thy blessing.
he said, Is not he rightly name Jacob? For he has supplanted me these two times. He took away my birthright, , behold, now he has taken away my blessing. And he said, Have thou not reserved a blessing for me?
Isaac answered and said to Esau, Behold, I have made him thy lord,  all his brothers I have given to him for servants,  I have sustained him with grain and new wine. And what then shall I do for thee, my son?
Esau said to his father, Have thou but one blessing, my father? Bless me, even me also, O my father. And Esau lifted up his voice,  wept.
Isaac his father answered and said to him, Behold, of the fatness of the earth shall be thy dwelling,  of the dew of heaven from above.
by thy sword thou shall live,  thou shall serve thy brother. And it shall come to pass, when thou shall break loose, that thou shall shake his yoke from off thy neck.
Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father blessed him. And Esau said in his heart, The days of mourning for my father are at hand. Then I will kill my brother Jacob.
the words of Esau her elder son were told to Rebekah. And she sent and called Jacob her younger son,  said to him, Behold, thy brother Esau comforts himself concerning thee, to kill thee.
Now therefore, my son, obey my voice,  arise, flee thou to Laban my brother to Haran.
tarry with him a few days, until thy brother's fury turns away,
until thy brother's anger turns away from thee,  he forgets that which thou have done to him. Then I will send,  fetch thee from there. Why should I be bereaved of you both in one day?
Rebekah said to Isaac, I am weary of my life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes a wife of the daughters of Heth, such as these, of the daughters of the land, what good shall my life do me?
Isaac called Jacob,  blessed him,  ordered him,  said to him, Thou shall not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan.
Arise, go to Paddan-aram, to the house of Bethuel thy mother's father,  take thee a wife from there of the daughters of Laban thy mother's brother.
God Almighty bless thee,  make thee fruitful,  multiply thee, that thou may be a company of peoples,
give thee the blessing of Abraham, to thee,  to thy seed with thee, that thou may inherit the land of thy sojourning, which God gave to Abraham.
Isaac sent Jacob away. And he went to Paddan-aram to Laban, son of Bethuel the Syrian, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob's and Esau's mother.
Now Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him away to Paddan-aram, to take for him a wife from there,  that as he blessed him he gave him an order, saying, Thou shall not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan,
that Jacob obeyed his father and his mother,  was gone to Paddan-aram.
Esau saw that the daughters of Canaan did not please Isaac his father.
Esau went to Ishmael,  took, besides the wives that he had, Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael Abraham's son, the sister of Nebaioth, to be his wife.
Jacob went out from Beersheba,  went toward Haran.
he touched upon a certain place,  tarried there all night, because the sun was set. And he took one of the stones of the place,  put it under his head,  lay down in that place to sleep.
he dreamed, , behold, a ladder set up on the earth,  the top of it reached to heaven. And, behold, the agents of God ascending and descending on it.
And, behold, Jehovah stood above it,  said, I am Jehovah, the God of Abraham thy father,  the God of Isaac. The land on which thou lie, to thee I will give it,  to thy seed.
thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth,  thou shall spread abroad to the west,  to the east,  to the north,  to the south. And in thee and in thy seed shall all the families of the earth be blessed.
And, behold, I am with thee,  will keep thee wherever thou go,  will bring thee again into this land. For I will not leave thee, until I have done that which I have spoken to thee of.
Jacob awoke out of his sleep,  he said, Surely Jehovah is in this place,  I did not know it.
he was afraid,  said, How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God,  this is the gate of heaven.
Jacob rose up early in the morning,  took the stone that he had put under his head,  set it up for a pillar,  poured oil upon the top of it.
he called the name of that place Bethel,  the name of the city was Luz at first.
Jacob vowed a vow, saying, If God will be with me,  will keep me in this way that I go,  will give me bread to eat,  raiment to put on,
so that I come again to my father's house in peace,  Jehovah will be my God,
then this stone, which I have set up for a pillar, shall be God's house. And of all that thou shall give me I will surely give the tenth to thee.
Then Jacob went on his journey,  came to the land of the sons of the east.
he looked, , behold, a well in the field. And, lo, three flocks of sheep were lying there by it, for they watered the flocks out of that well. And the stone upon the well's mouth was great.
all the flocks were gathered there. And they rolled the stone from the well's mouth,  watered the sheep,  put the stone again upon the well's mouth in its place.
Jacob said to them, My brothers, where are ye from? And they said, We are of Haran.
he said to them, Do ye know Laban the son of Nahor? And they said, We know him.
he said to them, Is it well with him? And they said, It is well. And, behold, Rachel his daughter comes with the sheep.
he said, Lo, it is yet high day, neither is it time that the cattle should be gathered together. Water ye the sheep,  go and feed them.
they said, We cannot until all the flocks be gathered together,  they roll the stone from the well's mouth. Then we water the sheep.
While he was yet speaking with them, Rachel came with her father's sheep, for she kept them.
it came to pass, when Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of Laban his mother's brother,  the sheep of Laban his mother's brother, that Jacob went near,  rolled the stone from the well's mouth,  watered the flock of Laban his mother's brother.
Jacob kissed Rachel,  lifted up his voice,  wept.
Jacob told Rachel that he was her father's brother,  that he was Rebekah's son. And she ran and told her father.
it came to pass, when Laban heard the news of Jacob his sister's son, that he ran to meet him,  embraced him,  kissed him,  brought him to his house. And he told Laban all these things.
Laban said to him, Surely thou are my bone and my flesh. And he abode with him the space of a month.
Laban said to Jacob, Because thou are my brother, should thou therefore serve me for nothing? Tell me, what shall thy wages be?
Laban had two daughters. The name of the elder was Leah,  the name of the younger was Rachel.
Leah's eyes were weak,  Rachel was beautiful and well favored.
Jacob loved Rachel,  he said, I will serve thee seven years for Rachel thy younger daughter.
Laban said, It is better that I give her to thee, than that I should give her to another man. Abide with me.
Jacob served seven years for Rachel. And they seemed to him but a few days, for the love he had for her.
Jacob said to Laban, Give me my wife, for my days are fulfilled, that I may go in to her.
Laban gathered together all the men of the place,  made a feast.
it came to pass in the evening, that he took Leah his daughter,  brought her to him. And he went in to her.
Laban gave Zilpah his handmaid to his daughter Leah for a handmaid.
it came to pass in the morning that, behold, it was Leah. And he said to Laban, What is this thou have done to me? Did I not serve with thee for Rachel? Why then have thou beguiled me?
Laban said, It is not so done in our place, to give the younger before the firstborn.
Fulfill the week of this one,  we will give thee the other also for the service which thou shall serve with me yet seven other years.
Jacob did so,  fulfilled her week. And he gave him Rachel his daughter to wife.
Laban gave to Rachel, his daughter, Bilhah his handmaid to be her handmaid.
he also went in to Rachel,  also he loved Rachel more than Leah,  served with him yet seven other years.
Jehovah saw that Leah was regarded inferior,  he opened her womb,  Rachel was barren.
Leah conceived,  bore a son,  she called his name Reuben. For she said, Because Jehovah has looked upon my affliction, for now my husband will love me.
she conceived again,  bore a son,  said, Because Jehovah has heard that I am regarded inferior, he has therefore given me this son also. And she called his name Simeon.
she conceived again,  bore a son,  said, Now this time my husband will be joined to me, because I have borne him three sons. Therefore his name was called Levi.
she conceived again,  bore a son. And she said, This time I will praise Jehovah. Therefore she called his name Judah. And she left off bearing.
when Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no sons, Rachel envied her sister,  she said to Jacob, Give me sons, or else I die.
Jacob's anger was kindled against Rachel,  he said, Am I in God's stead, who has withheld from thee the fruit of the womb?
she said, Behold, my maid Bilhah, go in to her, that she may bear upon my knees,  I also may obtain sons by her.
she gave him Bilhah her handmaid to wife,  Jacob went in to her.
Bilhah conceived,  bore Jacob a son.
Rachel said, God has judged me,  has also heard my voice,  has given me a son. Therefore she called his name Dan.
Bilhah Rachel's handmaid conceived again,  bore Jacob a second son.
Rachel said, With mighty wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister,  have prevailed. And she called his name Naphtali.
When Leah saw that she had left off bearing, she took Zilpah her handmaid,  gave her to Jacob to wife.
Zilpah Leah's handmaid bore Jacob a son.
Leah said, Fortunate! And she called his name Gad.
Zilpah Leah's handmaid bore Jacob a second son.
Leah said, Happy am I! For the daughters will call me happy. And she called his name Asher.
Reuben went in the days of wheat harvest,  found mandrakes in the field,  brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, Give me, I pray thee, of thy son's mandrakes.
she said to her, Is it a small matter that thou have taken away my husband? And would thou take away my son's mandrakes also? And Rachel said, Therefore he shall lie with thee tonight for thy son's mandrakes.
Jacob came from the field in the evening,  Leah went out to meet him,  said, Thou must come in to me, for I have surely hired thee with my son's mandrakes. And he lay with her that night.
God hearkened to Leah,  she conceived,  bore Jacob a fifth son.
Leah said, God has given me my hire, because I gave my handmaid to my husband. And she called his name Issachar.
Leah conceived again,  bore a sixth son to Jacob.
Leah said, God has endowed me with a good dowry. Now my husband will dwell with me, because I have borne him six sons. And she called his name Zebulun.
afterwards she bore a daughter,  called her name Dinah.
God remembered Rachel. And God hearkened to her,  opened her womb.
she conceived,  bore a son,  said, God has taken away my reproach.
she called his name Joseph, saying, Jehovah adds another son to me.
it came to pass, when Rachel had borne Joseph, that Jacob said to Laban, Send me away, that I may go to my own place,  to my country.
Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served thee,  let me go, for thou know my service with which I have served thee.
Laban said to him, If now I have found favor in thine eyes, tarry, for I have learned by experience that Jehovah has blessed me for thy sake.
he said, Appoint for me thy wages,  I will give it.
he said to him, Thou know how I have served thee,  how thy cattle have fared with me.
For it was little which thou had before I came,  it has increased to a multitude,  Jehovah has blessed thee wherever I turned. And now when shall I provide for my own house also?
he said, What shall I give thee? And Jacob said, Thou shall not give me anything. If thou will do this thing for me, I will again feed thy flock and keep it.
I will pass through all thy flock today, removing from there every speckled and spotted one,  every black one among the sheep,  the spotted and speckled among the goats,  of such shall be my hire.
So shall my righteousness answer for me after this, when thou shall come concerning my hire that is before thee. Every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats,  black among the sheep, that is with me, shall be considered stolen.
Laban said, Behold, O that it might be according to thy word.
he removed that day the he-goats that were ringstreaked and spotted,  all the she-goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had white in it,  all the black ones among the sheep,  gave them into the hand of his sons.
he set three days' journey between himself and Jacob. And Jacob fed the rest of Laban's flocks.
Jacob took for him rods of fresh poplar,  of the almond and of the plane tree,  peeled white streaks in them,  made the white which was in the rods appear.
he set the rods which he had peeled before the flocks in the gutters in the watering troughs where the flocks came to drink. And they conceived when they came to drink.
the flocks conceived before the rods,  the flocks brought forth ringstreaked, speckled,  spotted.
Jacob separated the lambs,  set the faces of the flocks toward the ringstreaked and all the black in the flock of Laban. And he put his own herds apart,  did not put them near Laban's flock.
it came to pass, whenever the stronger of the flock conceived, that Jacob laid the rods before the eyes of the flock in the gutters, that they might conceive among the rods,
but when the flock were weak, he did not put them in. So the weaker were Laban's,  the stronger Jacob's.
the man increased exceedingly,  had large flocks,  maid-servants and men-servants,  camels and donkeys.
he heard the words of Laban's sons, saying, Jacob has taken away all that was our father's,  he has gotten all this glory of that which was our father's.
Jacob beheld the countenance of Laban, , behold, it was not toward him as beforetime.
Jehovah said to Jacob, Return to the land of thy fathers,  to thy kindred,  I will be with thee.
Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field to his flock,
said to them, I see your father's countenance, that it is not toward me as beforetime,  the God of my father has been with me.
ye know that with all my power I have served your father.
your father has deceived me,  changed my wages ten times,  God did not allow him to hurt me.
If he said thus, The speckled shall be thy wages, then all the flock bore speckled,  if he said thus, The ringstreaked shall be thy wages, then all the flock bore ringstreaked.
Thus God has taken away the cattle of your father,  given them to me.
it came to pass at the time that the flock conceive, that I lifted up my eyes,  saw in a dream, , behold, the he-goats which leaped upon the flock were ringstreaked, speckled,  grizzled.
the agent of God said to me in the dream, Jacob. And I said, Here I am.
he said, Lift up now thine eyes,  see, all the he-goats which leap upon the flock are ringstreaked, speckled,  grizzled, for I have seen all that Laban does to thee.
I am the God of Bethel, where thou anointed a pillar, where thou vowed a vow to me. Now arise, get thee out from this land,  return to the land of thy nativity.
Rachel and Leah answered and said to him, Is there yet any portion or inheritance for us in our father's house?
Are we not accounted by him as foreigners? For he has sold us,  has also quite devoured our money.
For all the riches which God has taken away from our father, that is ours and our children's. Now then, whatever God has said to thee, do.
Then Jacob rose up,  set his sons and his wives upon the camels.
he carried away all his cattle,  all his substance which he had gathered, the cattle of his getting, which he had gathered in Paddan-aram, to go to Isaac his father to the land of Canaan.
Now Laban was gone to shear his sheep,  Rachel stole the teraphim that were her father's.
Jacob slipped away unawares to Laban the Syrian, in that he did not tell him that he fled.
So he fled with all that he had. And he rose up,  passed over the River,  set his face toward the mountain of Gilead.
it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob had fled.
he took his brothers with him,  pursued after him seven days' journey,  he overtook him in the mountain of Gilead.
God came to Laban the Syrian in a dream of the night,  said to him, Take heed to thyself that thou not speak to Jacob either good or bad.
Laban came up with Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain. And Laban encamped with his brothers in the mountain of Gilead.
Laban said to Jacob, What have thou done, that thou have slipped away unawares to me,  carried away my daughters as captives of the sword?
Why did thou flee secretly,  creep away from me,  did not tell me, that I might have sent thee away with mirth and with songs, with tambourine and with harp,
did not allow me to kiss my sons and my daughters? Now thou have done foolishly.
It is in the power of my hand to do you harm,  the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, Take heed to thyself that thou not speak to Jacob either good or bad.
now, though thou have certainly gone, because thou have been very desirous for thy father's house, yet why have thou stolen my gods?
Jacob answered and said to Laban, Because I was afraid, for I said, Lest thou should take thy daughters from me by force.
With whomever thou find thy gods, he shall not live. Before our brothers discern thou what is thine with me,  take it to thee. For Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.
Laban went into Jacob's tent,  into Leah's tent,  into the tent of the two maid-servants,  he did not find them. And he went out of Leah's tent,  entered into Rachel's tent.
Now Rachel had taken the teraphim,  put them in the camel's saddle,  sat upon them. And Laban felt around all the tent,  did not find them.
she said to her father, Let not my lord be angry that I cannot rise up before thee, for the manner of women is upon me. And he searched,  did not find the teraphim.
Jacob was angry,  chided with Laban. And Jacob answered and said to Laban, What is my trespass? What is my sin that thou have hotly pursued after me?
Whereas thou have felt around all my stuff, what have thou found of all thy household stuff? Set it here before my brothers and thy brothers, that they may judge between us two.
These twenty years I have been with thee, thy ewes and thy she-goats have not cast their young,  I have not eaten the rams of thy flocks.
I did not bring to thee that which was torn by beasts; I bore the loss of it, of my hand thou required it, whether stolen by day or stolen by night.
Thus I was; in the day the drought consumed me,  the frost by night,  my sleep fled from my eyes.
These twenty years I have been in thy house. I served thee fourteen years for thy two daughters,  six years for thy flock. And thou have changed my wages ten times.
Unless the God of my father, the God of Abraham,  the fear of Isaac, had been with me, surely now thou would have sent me away empty. God has seen my affliction and the labor of my hands,  rebuked thee last night.
Laban answered and said to Jacob, The daughters are my daughters,  the sons are my sons,  the flocks are my flocks,  all that thou see is mine. And what can I do this day to these my daughters, or to their sons whom they have borne?
now come, let us make a covenant, I and thou,  let it be for a witness between me and thee.
Jacob took a stone,  set it up for a pillar.
Jacob said to his brothers, Gather stones,  they took stones,  made a heap. And they ate there by the heap.
Laban called it Jegar-saha-dutha,  Jacob called it Galeed.
Laban said, This heap is witness between me and thee this day. Therefore the name of it was called Galeed,
Mizpah. For he said, May Jehovah watch between me and thee, when we are absent one from another,
if thou will afflict my daughters,  if thou will take wives besides my daughters, no man is with us, see, God is witness between me and thee.
Laban said to Jacob, Behold this heap,  behold the pillar, which I have set between me and thee.
This heap is witness,  the pillar is witness, that I will not pass over this heap to thee,  that thou shall not pass over this heap and this pillar to me, for harm.
The God of Abraham,  the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us. And Jacob swore by the fear of his father Isaac.
Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain,  called his brothers to eat bread. And they ate bread,  tarried all night on the mountain.
early in the morning Laban rose up,  kissed his sons and his daughters,  blessed them. And Laban departed and returned to his place.
Jacob went on his way,  the agents of God met him.
Jacob said when he saw them, This is God's camp. And he called the name of that place Mahanaim.
Jacob sent messengers before him to Esau his brother to the land of Seir, the field of Edom.
he commanded them, saying, Thus shall ye say to my lord Esau, Thus says thy servant Jacob, I have sojourned with Laban,  stayed until now.
I have oxen,  donkeys, flocks,  men-servants,  maid-servants. And I have sent to tell my lord, that I may find favor in thy sight.
the messengers returned to Jacob, saying, We came to thy brother Esau,  moreover he comes to meet thee,  four hundred men with him.
Then Jacob was greatly afraid and was distressed. And he divided the people that were with him,  the flocks,  the herds,  the camels, into two companies.
he said, If Esau comes to the one company,  smites it, then the company which is left shall escape.
Jacob said, O God of my father Abraham,  God of my father Isaac, O Jehovah, who said to me, Return to thy country,  to thy kindred,  I will do thee good,
I am not worthy of the least of all the loving kindnesses,  of all the truth, which thou have shown to thy servant, for with my staff I passed over this Jordan,  now I have become two companies.
Deliver me, I pray thee, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau. For I fear him, lest he comes and smites me, the mother with the sons.
thou said, I will surely do thee good,  make thy seed as the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.
he lodged there that night,  took of that which he had with him a present for Esau his brother:
two hundred she-goats and twenty he-goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
thirty milk camels and their colts, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty she-donkeys and ten foals.
he delivered them into the hand of his servants, every herd by itself,  said to his servants, Pass over before me,  put a space between herd and herd.
he commanded the foremost, saying, When Esau my brother meets thee,  asks thee, saying, Whose are thou? And where do thou go? And whose are these before thee?
Then thou shall say, Thy servant Jacob's. It is a present sent to my lord Esau. And, behold, he also is behind us.
he commanded also the second,  the third,  all who followed the herds, saying, On this manner shall ye speak to Esau when ye find him,
ye shall say, Moreover, behold, thy servant Jacob is behind us. For he said, I will appease him with the present that goes before me,  afterward I will see his face. Perhaps he will accept me.
So the present passed over before him,  he himself lodged that night in the company.
he rose up that night,  took his two wives,  his two handmaids,  his eleven sons,  passed over the ford of the Jabbok.
he took them,  sent them over the stream,  sent over that which he had.
Jacob was left alone,  a man wrestled with him until the breaking of the day.
when he saw that he did not prevail against him, he touched the hollow of his thigh,  the hollow of Jacob's thigh was strained as he wrestled with him.
he said, Let me go, for the day breaks. And he said, I will not let thee go unless thou bless me.
he said to him, What is thy name? And he said, Jacob.
he said, Thy name shall no more be called Jacob,  Israel, for thou have striven with God and with men,  have prevailed.
Jacob asked him,  said, Tell me, I pray thee, thy name. And he said, Why is it that thou ask for my name? And he blessed him there.
Jacob called the name of the place Peniel, for, I have seen God face to face,  my life is preserved.
the sun rose upon him as he passed over Penuel,  he limped upon his thigh.
Therefore the sons of Israel do not eat the sinew of the hip which is upon the hollow of the thigh, to this day, because he touched the hollow of Jacob's thigh in the sinew of the hip.
Jacob lifted up his eyes,  looked, , behold, Esau was coming,  four hundred men with him. And he divided the children to Leah,  to Rachel,  to the two handmaids.
he put the handmaids and their children foremost,  Leah and her children after,  Rachel and Joseph hindmost.
he himself passed over before them,  bowed himself to the ground seven times, until he came near to his brother.
Esau ran to meet him,  embraced him,  fell on his neck,  kissed him,  they wept.
he lifted up his eyes,  saw the women and the children,  said, Who are these with thee? And he said, The children whom God has graciously given thy servant.
Then the handmaids came near, they and their children,  they bowed themselves.
Leah also and her children came near,  bowed themselves. And afterward Joseph came near and Rachel,  they bowed themselves.
he said, What do thou mean by all this company which I met? And he said, To find favor in the sight of my lord.
Esau said, I have enough, my brother, let that which thou have be thine.
Jacob said, No, I pray thee, if now I have found favor in thy sight, then receive my present at my hand, inasmuch as I have seen thy face, as any man would see the face of God,  thou were pleased with me.
Take, I pray thee, my gift that is brought to thee, because God has dealt graciously with me,  because I have enough. And he urged him,  he took it.
he said, Let us take our journey,  let us go,  I will go before thee.
he said to him, My lord knows that the children are tender,  that the flocks and herds with me have their young,  if they overdrive them one day, all the flocks will die.
Let my lord, I pray thee, pass over before his servant,  I will lead on gently, according to the pace of the cattle that are before me and according to the pace of the children, until I come to my lord to Seir.
Esau said, Let me now leave with thee some of the folks that are with me. And he said, What need is it? Let me find favor in the sight of my lord.
So Esau returned that day on his way to Seir.
Jacob journeyed to Succoth,  built for him a house,  made booths for his cattle. Therefore the name of the place is called Succoth.
Jacob came in peace to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, when he came from Paddan-aram,  encamped before the city.
he bought the parcel of ground, where he had spread his tent, at the hand of the sons of Hamor, Shechem's father, for a hundred lambs.
he erected an altar there,  called it El-Elohe-Israel.
Dinah the daughter of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob, went out to see the daughters of the land.
Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the land, saw her. And he took her,  lay with her,  humbled her.
his soul clung to Dinah the daughter of Jacob,  he loved the damsel,  spoke kindly to the damsel.
Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, Get me this damsel to wife.
Now Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter. And his sons were with his cattle in the field,  Jacob held his peace until they came.
Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to converse with him.
the sons of Jacob came in from the field when they heard it. And the men were grieved,  they were very angry, because he had wrought folly in Israel in lying with Jacob's daughter, which thing ought not to be done.
Hamor conversed with them, saying, The soul of my son Shechem longs for your daughter. I pray you, give her to him to wife.
make ye marriages with us; give your daughters to us,  take our daughters to you.
ye shall dwell with us,  the land shall be before you. Dwell and trade ye in it,  get possessions for you in it.
Shechem said to her father and to her brothers, Let me find favor in your eyes,  what ye shall say to me I will give.
Ask me never so much dowry and gift,  I will give according as ye shall say to me,  give me the damsel to wife.
the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father with guile,  spoke, because he had defiled Dinah their sister,
said to them, We cannot do this thing, to give our sister to a man who is uncircumcised, for that is a reproach to us.
Only on this condition will we consent to you: If ye will be as we are, that every male of you be circumcised.
Then we will give our daughters to you,  we will take your daughters to us. And we will dwell with you,  we will become one people.
But if ye will not hearken to us, to be circumcised, then will we take our daughter,  we will be gone.
their words pleased Hamor,  Shechem Hamor's son.
the young man did not delay to do the thing, because he had delight in Jacob's daughter. And he was honored above all the house of his father.
Hamor and Shechem his son came to the gate of their city,  conversed with the men of their city, saying,
These men are peaceable with us, therefore let them dwell in the land,  trade in it, for, behold, the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters to us for wives,  let us give them our daughters.
Only on this condition will the men consent to us to dwell with us, to become one people, if every male among us be circumcised, as they are circumcised.
Shall not their cattle and their substance and all their beasts be ours? Only let us consent to them,  they will dwell with us.
all who went out of the gate of his city hearkened to Hamor and to Shechem his son,  every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.
it came to pass on the third day, when they were sore, that two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brothers, took each man his sword,  came upon the city unawares,  killed all the males.
they killed Hamor and Shechem his son with the edge of the sword,  took Dinah out of Shechem's house,  went forth.
The sons of Jacob came upon the slain,  plundered the city, because they had defiled their sister.
They took their flocks and their herds and their donkeys,  that which was in the city,  that which was in the field,
all their wealth,  all their little ones and their wives, they took captive and made a prey, even all that was in the house.
Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, Ye have troubled me, to make me odious to the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the Perizzites. And, I being few in number, they will gather themselves together against me and smite me,  I shall be destroyed, I and my house.
they said, Should he deal with our sister as with a harlot?
God said to Jacob, Arise, go up to Bethel,  dwell there,  make an altar there to God, who appeared to thee when thou fled from the face of Esau thy brother.
Then Jacob said to his household,  to all who were with him, Put away the foreign gods that are among you,  purify yourselves,  change your garments.
let us arise,  go up to Bethel,  I will make there an altar to God, who answered me in the day of my distress,  was with me on the way which I went.
they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods which were in their hand,  the rings which were in their ears. And Jacob hid them under the oak that was by Shechem.
they journeyed,  a terror of God was upon the cities that were round about them,  they did not pursue after the sons of Jacob.
So Jacob came to Luz, which is in the land of Canaan (the same is Bethel), he and all the people that were with him.
he built there an altar,  called the place El-bethel, because God was revealed to him there, when he fled from the face of his brother.
Deborah Rebekah's nurse died,  she was buried below Bethel under the oak. And the name of it was called Allon-bacuth.
God appeared to Jacob again, when he came from Paddan-aram,  blessed him.
God said to him, Thy name is Jacob. Thy name shall not be called any more Jacob,  Israel shall be thy name. And he called his name Israel.
God said to him, I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. A nation and a company of nations shall be of thee,  kings shall come out of thy loins.
the land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give it to thee,  I will give the land to thy seed after thee.
God went up from him in the place where he spoke with him.
Jacob set up a pillar in the place where he spoke with him, a pillar of stone. And he poured out a drink offering on it,  poured oil on it.
Jacob called the name of the place where God spoke with him, Bethel.
they journeyed from Bethel. And there was still some distance to come to Ephrath,  Rachel travailed,  she had hard labor.
it came to pass, when she was in hard labor, that the midwife said to her, Fear not, for now thou shall have another son.
it came to pass, as her soul was departing (for she died), that she called his name Ben-oni,  his father called him Benjamin.
Rachel died,  was buried on the way to Ephrath (the same is Bethlehem).
Jacob set up a pillar upon her grave, the same is the Pillar of Rachel's grave to this day.
Israel journeyed,  spread his tent beyond the tower of Eder.
it came to pass, while Israel dwelt in that land, that Reuben went and lay with Bilhah his father's concubine,  Israel heard of it. Now the sons of Jacob were twelve.
The sons of Leah: Reuben, Jacob's firstborn,  Simeon,  Levi,  Judah,  Issachar,  Zebulun.
The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
the sons of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid: Dan and Naphtali.
the sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid: Gad and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob, who were born to him in Paddan-aram.
Jacob came to Isaac his father to Mamre, to Kiriath-arba (the same is Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac sojourned.
the days of Isaac were a hundred and eighty years.
Isaac gave up the spirit,  died,  was gathered to his people, old and full of days. And Esau and Jacob his sons buried him.
Now these are the generations of Esau (the same is Edom).
Esau took his wives of the daughters of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite,  Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite,
Basemath Ishmael's daughter, sister of Nebaioth.
Adah bore to Esau Eliphaz,  Basemath bore Reuel,
Oholibamah bore Jeush,  Jalam,  Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
Esau took his wives,  his sons,  his daughters,  all the souls of his house,  his cattle,  all his beasts,  all his possessions, which he had gathered in the land of Canaan,  went into a land away from his brother Jacob.
For their substance was too great for them to dwell together,  the land of their sojourning could not bear them because of their cattle.
Esau dwelt in mount Seir. Esau is Edom.
these are the generations of Esau the father of the Edomites in mount Seir:
These are the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz the son of Adah the wife of Esau, Reuel the son of Basemath the wife of Esau.
the sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho,  Gatam,  Kenaz.
Timna was concubine to Eliphaz Esau's son,  she bore to Eliphaz Amalek. These are the sons of Adah, Esau's wife.
these are the sons of Reuel: Nahath,  Zerah, Shammah,  Mizzah, These were the sons of Basemath, Esau's wife.
these were the sons of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon, Esau's wife: and she bore to Esau Jeush,  Jalam,  Korah.
These are the chiefs of the sons of Esau: The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau: chief Teman, chief Omar, chief Zepho, chief Kenaz,
chief Korah, chief Gatam, chief Amalek. These are the chiefs that came by Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Adah.
these are the sons of Reuel, Esau's son: chief Nahath, chief Zerah, chief Shammah, chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs that came by Reuel in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Basemath, Esau's wife.
these are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau's wife: chief Jeush, chief Jalam, chief Korah. These are the chiefs that came by Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, Esau's wife.
These are the sons of Esau,  these are their chiefs. The same is Edom.
These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan and Shobal and Zibeon and Anah,
Dishon and Ezer and Dishan. These are the chiefs that came of the Horites, the sons of Seir in the land of Edom.
the sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman. And Lotan's sister was Timna.
these are the sons of Shobal: Alvan and Manahath and Ebal, Shepho and Onam.
these are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is Anah who found the hot springs in the wilderness, as he fed the donkeys of Zibeon his father.
these are the children of Anah: Dishon,  Oholibamah the daughter of Anah.
these are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan and Eshban and Ithran and Cheran.
These are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan and Zaavan and Akan.
These are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
These are the chiefs that came from the Horites: chief Lotan, chief Shobal, chief Zibeon, chief Anah,
chief Dishon, chief Ezer, chief Dishan. These are the chiefs that came from the Horites, according to their chiefs in the land of Seir.
these are the kings that reigned in the land of Edom, before any king reigned over the sons of Israel.
Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom,  the name of his city was Dinhabah.
Bela died,  Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead.
Jobab died,  Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his stead.
Husham died,  Hadad the son of Bedad, who smote Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his stead. And the name of his city was Avith.
Hadad died,  Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead.
Samlah died,  Shaul of Rehoboth by the River reigned in his stead.
Shaul died,  Baal-hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his stead.
Baal-hanan the son of Achbor died,  Hadar reigned in his stead. And the name of his city was Pau,  his wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-zahab.
these are the names of the chiefs that came of Esau, according to their families, after their places, by their names: chief Timnah, chief Alvah, chief Jetheth,
chief Aholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon,
chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar,
chief Magdiel, chief Iram. These are the chiefs of Edom, according to their habitations in the land of their possession. This is Esau, the father of the Edomites.
Jacob dwelt in the land of his father's sojourning, in the land of Canaan.
These are the generations of Jacob. Joseph, being seventeen years old, was feeding the flock with his brothers. And he was a lad with the sons of Bilhah,  with the sons of Zilpah, his father's wives,  Joseph brought the evil report of them to their father.
Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons, because he was the son of his old age. And he made for him a coat of many colors.
his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers. And they hated him,  could not speak peaceably to him.
Joseph dreamed a dream,  he told it to his brothers,  they hated him yet the more.
he said to them, Hear, I pray you, this dream which I have dreamed.
For, behold, we were binding sheaves in the field, , lo, my sheaf arose,  also stood upright. And, behold, your sheaves came round about,  made obeisance to my sheaf.
his brothers said to him, Shall thou indeed reign over us? Or shall thou indeed have dominion over us? And they hated him yet the more for his dreams,  for his words.
he dreamed yet another dream,  told it to his brothers. And said, Behold, I have dreamed a dream again. And, behold, the sun and the moon and eleven stars made obeisance to me.
he told it to his father,  to his brothers. And his father rebuked him,  said to him, What is this dream that thou have dreamed? Shall I and thy mother and thy brothers indeed come to bow down ourselves to thee to the earth?
his brothers envied him,  his father kept the saying in mind.
his brothers went to feed their father's flock in Shechem.
Israel said to Joseph, Are not thy brothers feeding the flock in Shechem? Come,  I will send thee to them. And he said to him, Here I am.
he said to him, Go now, see whether it is well with thy brothers,  well with the flock,  bring me word again. So he sent him out of the valley of Hebron,  he came to Shechem.
a certain man found him, , behold, he was wandering in the field. And the man asked him, saying, What do thou seek?
he said, I am seeking my brothers. Tell me, I pray thee, where they are feeding.
the man said, They are departed from here, for I heard them say, Let us go to Dothan. And Joseph went after his brothers,  found them in Dothan.
they saw him afar off. And before he came near to them, they conspired against him to kill him.
they said one to another, Behold, this dreamer comes.
Come now therefore,  let us kill him,  cast him into one of the pits. And we will say, An evil beast has devoured him. And we shall see what will become of his dreams.
Reuben heard it,  delivered him out of their hand,  said, Let us not take his life.
Reuben said to them, Shed no blood. Cast him into this pit that is in the wilderness,  lay no hand upon him, that he might deliver him out of their hand, to restore him to his father.
it came to pass, when Joseph came to his brothers, that they stripped Joseph of his coat, the coat of many colors that was on him,
they took him,  cast him into the pit. And the pit was empty; there was no water in it.
they sat down to eat bread. And they lifted up their eyes and looked, , behold, a caravan of Ishmaelites was coming from Gilead, with their camels bearing spicery and balm and myrrh, going to carry it down to Egypt.
Judah said to his brothers, What profit is it if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?
Come,  let us sell him to the Ishmaelites,  let not our hand be upon him, for he is our brother, our flesh. And his brothers hearkened to him.
there passed by Midianites, merchantmen,  they drew and lifted Joseph up out of the pit,  sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. And they brought Joseph into Egypt.
Reuben returned to the pit, , behold, Joseph was not in the pit. And he tore his clothes,
he returned to his brothers,  said, The child is not,  I, where shall I go?
they took Joseph's coat,  killed a he-goat,  dipped the coat in the blood.
they sent the coat of many colors,  they brought it to their father,  said, We have found this. Know now whether it is thy son's coat or not.
he knew it,  said, It is my son's coat. An evil beast has devoured him; Joseph is without doubt torn in pieces.
Jacob tore his garments,  put sackcloth upon his loins,  mourned for his son many days.
all his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him,  he refused to be comforted,  he said, For I will go down to Sheol to my son mourning. And his father wept for him.
the Midianites sold him into Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh's, the captain of the guard.
it came to pass at that time, that Judah went down from his brothers,  turned in to a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.
Judah saw there a daughter of a certain Canaanite whose name was Shua. And he took her,  went in to her.
she conceived,  bore a son,  he called his name Er.
she conceived again,  bore a son,  she called his name Onan.
she yet again bore a son,  called his name Shelah. And he was at Chezib, when she bore him.
Judah took a wife for Er his firstborn,  her name was Tamar.
Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of Jehovah,  Jehovah killed him.
Judah said to Onan, Go in to thy brother's wife,  perform the duty of a husband's brother to her,  raise up seed to thy brother.
Onan knew that the seed would not be his. And it came to pass, when he went in to his brother's wife, that he spilled it on the ground, lest he should give seed to his brother.
the thing which he did was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  he killed him also.
Then Judah said to Tamar his daughter-in-law, Remain a widow in thy father's house, till Shelah my son be grown up, for he said, Lest he also die, like his brothers. And Tamar went and dwelt in her father's house.
in process of time Shua's daughter, the wife of Judah, died. And Judah was comforted,  went up to his sheep shearers to Timnah, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.
it was told Tamar, saying, Behold, thy father-in-law goes up to Timnah to shear his sheep.
she put the garments of her widowhood off from her,  covered herself with her veil,  wrapped herself,  sat in the gate of Enaim, which is by the way to Timnah, for she saw that Shelah was grown up,  she was not given to him to wife.
When Judah saw her, he thought her to be a harlot, for she had covered her face.
he turned to her by the way,  said, Come, I pray thee, let me come in to thee, for he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law. And she said, What will thou give me, that thou may come in to me?
he said, I will send thee a kid of the goats from the flock. And she said, Will thou give me a pledge, till thou send it?
he said, What pledge shall I give thee? And she said, Thy signet and thy cord,  thy staff that is in thy hand. And he gave them to her,  came in to her,  she conceived by him.
she arose,  went away,  put off her veil from her,  put on the garments of her widowhood.
Judah sent the kid of the goats by the hand of his friend the Adullamite, to receive the pledge from the woman's hand,  he did not find her.
Then he asked the men of her place, saying, Where is the prostitute, who was at Enaim by the wayside? And they said, There has been no prostitute here.
he returned to Judah,  said, I have not found her,  also the men of the place said, There has been no prostitute here.
Judah said, Let her take it to her, lest we be put to shame. Behold, I sent this kid,  thou have not found her.
it came to pass about three months after, that it was told Judah, saying, Tamar thy daughter-in-law has played the harlot,  moreover, behold, she is with child by whoredom. And Judah said, Bring her forth,  let her be burnt.
When she was brought forth, she sent to her father-in-law, saying, By the man, whose these are, I am with child. And she said, Discern, I pray thee, whose these are, the signet,  the cords,  the staff.
Judah acknowledged them,  said, She is more righteous than I, inasmuch as I did not give her to Shelah my son. And he knew her again no more.
it came to pass in the time of her travail, that, behold, twins were in her womb.
it came to pass, when she travailed, that one put out a hand. And the midwife took and bound upon his hand a scarlet thread, saying, This came out first.
it came to pass, as he drew back his hand, that, behold, his brother came out. And she said, Why have thou made a breach for thyself? Therefore his name was called Perez.
afterward his brother came out, who had the scarlet thread upon his hand. And his name was called Zerah.
Joseph was brought down to Egypt. And Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh's, the captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the hand of the Ishmaelites, who had brought him down there.
Jehovah was with Joseph. And he was a man who succeeds. And he was in the house of his master the Egyptian.
his master saw that Jehovah was with him,  that Jehovah made all that he did to prosper in his hand.
Joseph found favor in his sight,  he ministered to him. And he made him overseer over his house,  all that he had he put into his hand.
it came to pass from the time that he made him overseer in his house,  over all that he had, that Jehovah blessed the Egyptian's house for Joseph's sake. And the blessing of Jehovah was upon all that he had, in the house and in the field.
he left all that he had in Joseph's hand,  he knew nothing that was with him, save the bread which he ate. And Joseph was comely,  well-favored.
it came to pass, after these things, that his master's wife cast her eyes upon Joseph,  she said, Lie with me.
But he refused,  said to his master's wife, Behold, my master does not know what is with me in the house,  he has put all that he has into my hand.
He is not greater in this house than I, nor has he kept back anything from me but thee, because thou are his wife. How then can I do this great wickedness,  sin against God?
it came to pass, as she spoke to Joseph day by day, that he did not hearken to her, to lie by her, or to be with her.
it came to pass, about this time, that he went into the house to do his work,  there was none of the men of the house there inside.
she caught him by his garment, saying, Lie with me. And he left his garment in her hand,  fled,  got out.
it came to pass, when she saw that he had left his garment in her hand,  was fled forth,
that she called to the men of her house,  spoke to them, saying, See, he has brought in a Hebrew to us to mock us. He came in to me to lie with me,  I cried with a loud voice.
it came to pass, when he heard that I lifted up my voice and cried, that he left his garment by me,  fled,  got out.
she laid up his garment by her until his master came home.
she spoke to him according to these words, saying, The Hebrew servant, whom thou have brought to us, came in to me to mock me.
it came to pass, as I lifted up my voice and cried, that he left his garment by me,  fled out.
it came to pass, when his master heard the words of his wife, which she spoke to him, saying, After this manner did thy servant to me, that his wrath was kindled.
Joseph's master took him,  put him into the prison, the place where the king's prisoners were bound. And he was there in the prison.
But Jehovah was with Joseph,  showed kindness to him,  gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison.
the keeper of the prison committed to Joseph's hand all the prisoners who were in the prison. And whatever they did there, he was the doer of it.
The keeper of the prison did not look to anything that was under his hand, because Jehovah was with him,  that which he did, Jehovah made it prosper.
it came to pass after these things, that the butler of the king of Egypt,  his baker, offended their lord the king of Egypt.
Pharaoh was angry against his two officers, against the chief of the butlers,  against the chief of the bakers.
he put them in ward in the house of the captain of the guard, into the prison, the place where Joseph was bound.
the captain of the guard charged Joseph with them,  he ministered to them. And they continued a season in ward.
they dreamed a dream both of them, each man his dream, in one night, each man according to the interpretation of his dream, the butler and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were bound in the prison.
Joseph came in to them in the morning,  saw them, , behold, they were sad.
he asked Pharaoh's officers who were with him in ward in his master's house, saying, Why do ye look so sad today?
they said to him, We have dreamed a dream,  there is no man who can interpret it. And Joseph said to them, Do not interpretations belong to God? Tell it to me, I pray you.
the chief butler told his dream to Joseph,  said to him, In my dream, behold, a vine was before me.
in the vine were three branches. And it was as though it budded,  its blossoms shot forth,  the clusters of it brought forth ripe grapes.
Pharaoh's cup was in my hand,  I took the grapes,  pressed them into Pharaoh's cup,  I gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand.
Joseph said to him, This is the interpretation of it: The three branches are three days.
Within yet three days Pharaoh shall lift up thy head,  restore thee to thine office. And thou shall give Pharaoh's cup into his hand, after the former manner when thou was his butler.
But have me in thy remembrance when it shall be well with thee,  show kindness, I pray thee, to me,  make mention of me to Pharaoh,  bring me out of this house.
For indeed I was stolen away out of the land of the Hebrews,  here also I have done nothing that they should put me into the dungeon.
When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was good, he said to Joseph, I also was in my dream, , behold, three baskets of white bread were on my head.
in the uppermost basket there was of all manner of baked food for Pharaoh,  the birds ate them out of the basket upon my head.
Joseph answered and said, This is the interpretation of it: The three baskets are three days.
Within yet three days Pharaoh shall lift up thy head from off thee,  shall hang thee on a tree,  the birds shall eat thy flesh from off thee.
it came to pass the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, that he made a feast to all his servants. And he lifted up the head of the chief butler and the head of the chief baker among his servants.
he restored the chief butler to his butlership again,  he gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand,
but he hanged the chief baker, as Joseph had interpreted to them.
Yet the chief butler did not remember Joseph,  forgot him.
it came to pass at the end of two full years, that Pharaoh dreamed. And, behold, he stood by the river.
And, behold, there came up out of the river seven cows, well-favored and fat-fleshed,  they fed in the reed grass.
And, behold, seven other cows came up after them out of the river, ill-favored and lean-fleshed,  stood by the other cows upon the brink of the river.
the ill-favored and lean-fleshed cows ate up the seven well-favored and fat cows. So Pharaoh awoke.
he slept and dreamed a second time. And, behold, seven ears of grain came up upon one stalk, fat and good.
And, behold, seven ears, thin and blasted with the east wind, sprung up after them.
the thin ears swallowed up the seven fat and full ears. And Pharaoh awoke, , behold, it was a dream.
it came to pass in the morning, that his spirit was troubled,  he sent and called for all the magicians of Egypt,  all the wise men of it. And Pharaoh told them his dream,  there was no man who could interpret them to Pharaoh.
Then the chief butler spoke to Pharaoh, saying, I do remember my faults this day.
Pharaoh was angry with his servants,  put me in ward in the house of the captain of the guard, me and the chief baker.
we dreamed a dream in one night, I and he, we dreamed each man according to the interpretation of his dream.
there was a young man with us there, a Hebrew, servant to the captain of the guard,  we told him. And he interpreted to us our dreams. He interpreted to each man according to his dream.
it came to pass, as he interpreted to us, so it was; he restored me to my office,  he hanged him.
Then Pharaoh sent and called Joseph. And they brought him hastily out of the dungeon,  he shaved himself,  changed his raiment,  came in to Pharaoh.
Pharaoh said to Joseph, I have dreamed a dream,  there is no man who can interpret it. And I have heard say of thee, that when thou hear a dream thou can interpret it.
Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, It is not in me. God will give Pharaoh an answer of peace.
Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, In my dream, behold, I stood upon the brink of the river.
And, behold, there came up out of the river seven cows, fat-fleshed and well-favored,  they fed in the reed grass.
And, behold, seven other cows came up after them, poor and very ill-favored and lean-fleshed, such as I never saw in all the land of Egypt for badness.
the lean and ill-favored cows ate up the first seven fat cows.
when they had eaten them up, it could not be known that they had eaten them,  they were still ill-favored, as at the beginning. So I awoke.
I saw in my dream, , behold, seven ears came up upon one stalk, full and good.
And, behold, seven ears, withered, thin,  blasted with the east wind, sprung up after them,
the thin ears swallowed up the seven good ears. And I told it to the magicians,  there was no man who could declare it to me.
Joseph said to Pharaoh, The dream of Pharaoh is one; what God is about to do he has declared to Pharaoh.
The seven good cows are seven years,  the seven good ears are seven years; the dream is one.
the seven lean and ill-favored cows that came up after them are seven years,  also the seven empty ears blasted with the east wind, they shall be seven years of famine.
That is the thing which I spoke to Pharaoh. What God is about to do he has shown to Pharaoh.
Behold, there come seven years of great plenty throughout all the land of Egypt,
there shall arise after them seven years of famine. And all the plenty shall be forgotten in the land of Egypt,  the famine shall consume the land.
the plenty shall not be known in the land because of that famine which follows, for it shall be very grievous.
because the dream was doubled to Pharaoh, it is because the thing is established by God,  God will shortly bring it to pass.
Now therefore let Pharaoh look out for a man discreet and wise,  set him over the land of Egypt.
Let Pharaoh do this,  let him appoint overseers over the land,  take up the fifth part of the land of Egypt in the seven plentiful years.
let them gather all the food of these good years that come,  lay up grain under the hand of Pharaoh for food in the cities,  let them keep it.
the food shall be for a store to the land against the seven years of famine, which shall be in the land of Egypt, that the land not perish through the famine.
the thing was good in the eyes of Pharaoh,  in the eyes of all his servants.
Pharaoh said to his servants, Can we find such a one as this, a man in whom is the spirit of God?
Pharaoh said to Joseph, Inasmuch as God has shown thee all of this, there is none so discreet and wise as thou.
Thou shall be over my house,  according to thy word all my people shall be ruled. Only in the throne I will be greater than thou.
Pharaoh said to Joseph, See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt.
Pharaoh took his signet ring from off his hand,  put it upon Joseph's hand,  arrayed him in vestures of fine linen,  put a gold chain about his neck.
he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had,  they cried before him, Bow the knee. And he set him over all the land of Egypt.
Pharaoh said to Joseph, I am Pharaoh,  without thee no man shall lift up his hand or his foot in all the land of Egypt.
Pharaoh called Joseph's name Zaphenath-paneah,  he gave him Asenath, the daughter of Poti-phera priest of On, for a wife. And Joseph went out over the land of Egypt.
Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh,  went throughout all the land of Egypt.
in the seven plenteous years the earth brought forth by handfuls.
he gathered up all the food of the seven years which were in the land of Egypt,  laid up the food in the cities. The food of the field, which was round about every city, he laid up in the same.
Joseph laid up grain as the sand of the sea, very much, until he left off numbering, for it was without number.
two sons were born to Joseph before the year of famine came, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, bore to him.
Joseph called the name of the firstborn Manasseh, for God has made me forget all my toil,  all my father's house.
the name of the second he called Ephraim, for God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.
the seven years of plenty, that was in the land of Egypt, came to an end.
the seven years of famine began to come, according as Joseph had said. And there was famine in all lands,  in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread. And Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, Go to Joseph; what he says to you, do.
the famine was over all the face of the earth. And Joseph opened all the storehouses,  sold to the Egyptians. And the famine was severe in the land of Egypt.
all countries came into Egypt to Joseph to buy grain, because the famine was severe on all the earth.
Now Jacob saw that there was grain in Egypt. And Jacob said to his sons, Why do ye look one upon another?
he said, Behold, I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Get you down there,  buy for us from there, that we may live,  not die.
Joseph's ten brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
But Benjamin, Joseph's brother, Jacob did not send with his brothers, for he said, Lest perhaps harm befall him.
the sons of Israel came to buy among those who came, for the famine was in the land of Canaan.
Joseph was the governor over the land. It was he who sold to all the people of the land. And Joseph's brothers came,  bowed down themselves to him with their faces to the earth.
Joseph saw his brothers,  he knew them,  made himself foreign to them,  spoke roughly with them. And he said to them. From where come ye? And they said, From the land of Canaan to buy food.
Joseph knew his brothers,  they did not know him.
Joseph remembered the dreams which he dreamed of them. And said to them, Ye are spies; ye have come to see the nakedness of the land.
they said to him, No, my lord,  thy servants have come to buy food.
We are all one man's sons. We are true men. Thy servants are no spies.
he said to them, No,  ye have come to see the nakedness of the land.
they said, We thy servants are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. And, behold, the youngest is this day with our father,  one is not.
Joseph said to them, This is that which I spoke to you, saying, Ye are spies.
By this ye shall be proved: By the life of Pharaoh ye shall not go forth from here unless your youngest brother comes here.
Send one of you,  let him fetch your brother. And ye shall be bound, that your words may be proved, whether there be truth in you, or else by the life of Pharaoh surely ye are spies.
he put them all together into ward three days.
Joseph said to them the third day, This do,  live, for I fear God:
If ye be true men, let one of your brothers be bound in your prison house,  go ye, carry grain for the famine of your houses,
bring your youngest brother to me. So shall your words be verified,  ye shall not die. And they did so.
they said one to another, We are truly guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the distress of his soul when he besought us,  we would not hear. Therefore this distress has come upon us.
Reuben answered them, saying, Did I not speak to you, saying, Sin not against the child,  ye would not hear? Therefore also, behold, his blood is required.
they did not know that Joseph understood them, for there was an interpreter between them.
he turned himself around from them,  wept. And he returned to them,  spoke to them,  took Simeon from among them,  bound him before their eyes.
Then Joseph commanded to fill their vessels with grain,  to restore every man's money into his sack,  to give them provisions for the way. And thus it was done to them.
they loaded their donkeys with their grain,  departed from there.
as one of them opened his sack to give his donkey provender in the lodging place, he saw his money, , behold, it was in the mouth of his sack.
he said to his brothers, My money is restored, , lo, it is even in my sack. And their heart failed them,  they turned trembling one to another, saying, What is this that God has done to us?
they came to Jacob their father to the land of Canaan,  told him all that had befallen them, saying,
The man, the lord of the land, spoke roughly with us,  took us for spies of the country.
we said to him, We are true men,  we are no spies.
We are twelve brothers, sons of our father. One is not,  the youngest is this day with our father in the land of Canaan.
the man, the lord of the land, said to us, By this I shall know that ye are true men. Leave one of your brothers with me,  take grain for the famine of your houses,  go your way,
bring your youngest brother to me. Then I shall know that ye are no spies,  that ye are true men. So I will deliver your brother to you,  ye shall trade in the land.
it came to pass as they emptied their sacks, that, behold, every man's bundle of money was in his sack. And when they and their father saw their bundles of money, they were afraid.
Jacob their father said to them, Ye have bereaved me of my sons. Joseph is not,  Simeon is not,  ye will take Benjamin away. All these things are against me.
Reuben spoke to his father, saying, Kill my two sons if I do not bring him to thee. Deliver him into my hand,  I will bring him to thee again.
he said, My son shall not go down with you, for his brother is dead,  he only is left. If harm befalls him by the way in which ye go, then ye will bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to Sheol.
the famine was severe in the land.
it came to pass, when they had eaten up the grain which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said to them, Go again, buy us a little food.
Judah spoke to him, saying, The man solemnly protested to us, saying, Ye shall not see my face unless your brother be with you.
If thou will send our brother with us, we will go down and buy food for thee,
but if thou will not send him, we will not go down. For the man said to us, Ye shall not see my face unless your brother be with you.
Israel said, Why did ye deal so ill with me, as to tell the man whether ye had yet a brother?
they said, The man asked diligently concerning ourselves,  concerning our kindred, saying, Is your father yet alive? Have ye another brother? And we told him according to the tenor of these words. Could we in any way know that he would say, Bring your brother down?
Judah said to Israel his father, Send the young man with me,  we will arise and go, that we may live,  not die, both we,  thou,  also our little ones.
I will be surety for him, of my hand shall thou require him. If I do not bring him to thee,  set him before thee, then let me bear the blame forever.
For unless we had lingered, surely we would have now returned a second time.
their father Israel said to them, If it be so now, do this: Take of the choice fruits of the land in your vessels,  carry a present down to the man, a little balm,  a little honey, spicery and myrrh, nuts,  almonds.
take double money in your hand,  the money that was returned in the mouth of your sacks carry again in your hand. Perhaps it was an oversight.
Also take your brother,  arise, go again to the man.
God Almighty give you mercy before the man, that he may release to you your other brother and Benjamin. And if I be bereaved of my sons, I am bereaved.
the men took that present,  they took double money in their hand,  Benjamin,  rose up,  went down to Egypt,  stood before Joseph.
when Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the steward of his house, Bring the men into the house,  kill,  make ready, for the men shall dine with me at noon.
the man did as Joseph bade,  the man brought the men to Joseph's house.
the men were afraid, because they were brought to Joseph's house,  they said, We are brought in because of the money that was returned in our sacks at the first time, that he may seek occasion against us,  fall upon us,  take us for bondmen,  our donkeys.
they came near to the steward of Joseph's house,  they spoke to him at the door of the house,
said, Oh, my lord, we indeed came down at the first time to buy food.
it came to pass, when we came to the lodging place, that we opened our sacks, , behold, every man's money was in the mouth of his sack, our money in full weight. And we have brought it again in our hand.
we have brought other money down in our hand to buy food. We know not who put our money in our sacks.
he said, Peace be to you, fear not. Your God,  the God of your father, has given you treasure in your sacks. I had your money. And he brought Simeon out to them.
the man brought the men into Joseph's house,  gave them water,  they washed their feet. And he gave their donkeys provender.

he asked them of their welfare,  said, Is your father well, the old man of whom ye spoke? Is he yet alive?
they said, Thy servant our father is well; he is yet alive. And they bowed the head,  made obeisance.
he lifted up his eyes,  saw Benjamin his brother, his mother's son,  said, Is this your youngest brother, of whom ye spoke to me? And he said, God be gracious to thee, my son.

he washed his face,  came out. And he restrained himself,  said, Set on bread.
they set on for him by himself,  for them by themselves,  for the Egyptians, who ate with him, by themselves, because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews, for that is an abomination to the Egyptians.
they sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright,  the youngest according to his youth. And the men marveled one with another.
he took and sent portions to them from before him,  Benjamin's portion was five times so much as any of theirs. And they drank,  were merry with him.
he commanded the steward of his house, saying, Fill the men's sacks with food, as much as they can carry,  put every man's money in his sack's mouth.
