Judg. And Jehovah was with Judah,  drove out those of the hill-country. But they could not drive out the inhabitants of the valley because they had chariots of iron.
Judg. And they gave Hebron to Caleb, as Moses had spoken,  he drove out the three sons of Anak from there.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who inhabited Jerusalem,  the Jebusites dwell with the sons of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day.
Judg. And the house of Joseph, they also went up against Bethel,  Jehovah was with them.
Judg. And the house of Joseph sent to spy out Bethel. (Now the name of the city was formerly Luz.)
Judg. And the spies saw a man come forth out of the city,  they said to him, Show us, we pray thee, the entrance into the city,  we will deal kindly with thee.
Judg. And he showed them the entrance into the city. And they smote the city with the edge of the sword,  they let the man go and all his family.
Judg. And the man went into the land of the Hittites,  built a city,  called the name of it Luz, which is the name of it to this day.
Judg. And Manasseh did not drive out those of Beth-shean and its towns, nor of Taanach and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Ibleam and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Megiddo and its towns,  the Canaanites would dwell in that land.
Judg. And it came to pass, when Israel grew strong, that they put the Canaanites to task work,  did not utterly drive them out.
Judg. And Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites who dwelt in Gezer,  the Canaanites dwelt in Gezer among them.
Judg. Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron, nor the inhabitants of Nahalol,  the Canaanites dwelt among them,  became subject to task work.
Judg. Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, nor the inhabitants of Sidon, nor of Ahlab, nor of Achzib, nor of Helbah, nor of Aphik, nor of Rehob,
Judg. but the Asherites dwelt among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, for they did not drive them out.
Judg. Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh, nor the inhabitants of Beth-anath,  he dwelt among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land. Nevertheless the inhabitants of Beth-shemesh and of Beth-anath became subject to task work.
Judg. And the Amorites forced the sons of Dan into the hill-country, for they would not allow them to come down to the valley,
Judg. but the Amorites would dwell in mount Heres, in Aijalon,  in Shaalbim. Yet the hand of the house of Joseph prevailed, so that they became subject to task work.
Judg. And the border of the Amorites was from the ascent of Akrabbim, from the rock,  upward.
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah came up from Gilgal to Bochim. And he said, I made you go up out of Egypt,  have brought you to the land which I swore to your fathers. And I said, I will never break my covenant with you.
Judg. And ye shall make no covenant with the inhabitants of this land. Ye shall break down their altars. But ye have not hearkened to my voice. Why have ye done this?
Judg. Therefore I also said, I will not drive them out from before you,  they shall be as thorns in your sides,  their gods shall be a snare to you.
Judg. And it came to pass, when the agent of Jehovah spoke these words to all the sons of Israel, that the people lifted up their voice,  wept.
Judg. And they called the name of that place Bochim,  they sacrificed there to Jehovah.
Judg. Now when Joshua had sent the people away, the sons of Israel went every man to his inheritance to possess the land.
Judg. And the people served Jehovah all the days of Joshua,  all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua, who had seen all the great work of Jehovah that he had wrought for Israel.
Judg. And Joshua the son of Nun, the servant of Jehovah, died, being a hundred and ten years old.
Judg. And they buried him in the border of his inheritance in Timnath-heres, in the hill-country of Ephraim, on the north of the mountain of Gaash.
Judg. And also all that generation were gathered to their fathers. And there arose another generation after them that did not know Jehovah, nor yet the work which he had wrought for Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Israel did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  served the Baalim.
Judg. And they forsook Jehovah, the God of their fathers, who brought them out of the land of Egypt,  followed other gods, of the gods of the peoples that were round about them,  bowed themselves down to them. And they provoked Jehovah to anger.
Judg. And they forsook Jehovah,  served Baal and the Ashtaroth.
Judg. And the anger of Jehovah was kindled against Israel,  he delivered them into the hands of spoilers that despoiled them. And he sold them into the hands of their enemies round about, so that they could not any longer stand before their enemies.
Judg. Wherever they went out, the hand of Jehovah was against them for evil, as Jehovah had spoken,  as Jehovah had sworn to them. And they were exceedingly distressed.
Judg. And Jehovah raised up judges who saved them out of the hand of those who despoiled them.
Judg. And yet they did not hearken to their judges, for they played the harlot after other gods,  bowed themselves down to them. They turned aside quickly out of the way in which their fathers walked, obeying the commandments of Jehovah. They did not do so.
Judg. And when Jehovah raised up judges for them, then Jehovah was with the judge,  saved them out of the hand of their enemies all the days of the judge. For Jehovah regretted because of their groaning because of those who oppressed them and vexed them.
Judg. But it came to pass, when the judge was dead, that they turned back,  dealt more corruptly than their fathers, in following other gods to serve them,  to bow down to them. They did not cease from their doings, nor from their stubborn way.
Judg. And the anger of Jehovah was kindled against Israel,  he said, Because this nation has transgressed my covenant which I commanded their fathers,  has not hearkened to my voice,
Judg. I also will not henceforth drive out any from before them of the nations that Joshua left when he died,
Judg. that by them I may prove Israel, whether they will keep the way of Jehovah to walk in it, as their fathers kept it, or not.
Judg. So Jehovah left those nations, without driving them out quickly. Neither did he deliver them into the hand of Joshua.
Judg. Now these are the nations which Jehovah left to prove Israel by them, (even as many of Israel as had not known all the wars of Canaan,
Judg. only that the generations of the sons of Israel might know, to teach them war, at least to such as formerly knew nothing of that):
Judg. namely, the five lords of the Philistines,  all the Canaanites,  the Sidonians,  the Hivites that dwelt in mount Lebanon, from mount Baal-hermon to the entrance of Hamath.
Judg. And they were left, to prove Israel by them, to know whether they would hearken to the commandments of Jehovah, which he commanded their fathers by Moses.
Judg. And the sons of Israel dwelt among the Canaanites, the Hittites,  the Amorites,  the Perizzites,  the Hivites,  the Jebusites.
Judg. And they took their daughters to be their wives,  gave their own daughters to their sons and served their gods.
Judg. And the sons of Israel did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  forgot Jehovah their God,  served the Baalim and the Asheroth.
Judg. Therefore the anger of Jehovah was kindled against Israel,  he sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia, And the sons of Israel served Cushan-rishathaim eight years.
Judg. And when the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah, Jehovah raised up a savior to the sons of Israel, who saved them, even Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother.
Judg. And the Spirit of Jehovah came upon him,  he judged Israel. And he went out to war,  Jehovah delivered Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia into his hand,  his hand prevailed against Cushan-rishathaim.
Judg. And the land had rest forty years. And Othniel the son of Kenaz died.
Judg. And the sons of Israel again did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah. And Jehovah strengthened Eglon the king of Moab against Israel because they had done that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah.
Judg. And he gathered to him the sons of Ammon and Amalek,  he went and smote Israel,  they possessed the city of palm trees.
Judg. And the sons of Israel served Eglon the king of Moab eighteen years.
Judg. But when the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah, Jehovah raised up for them a savior, Ehud the son of Gera, the Benjamite, a left-handed man. And the sons of Israel sent tribute by him to Eglon the king of Moab.
Judg. And Ehud made for himself a sword which had two edges, a cubit in length. And he girded it under his raiment upon his right thigh.
Judg. And he offered the tribute to Eglon king of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man.
Judg. And when he had made an end of offering the tribute, he sent away the men who bore the tribute.
Judg. But he himself turned back from the quarries that were by Gilgal,  said, I have a secret errand to thee, O king. And he said, Keep silence. And all who stood by him went out from him.
Judg. And Ehud came to him. And he was sitting by himself alone in the cool upper room. And Ehud said, I have a message from God to thee. And he arose out of his seat.
Judg. And Ehud put forth his left hand,  took the sword from his right thigh,  thrust it into his body.
Judg. And the handle also went in after the blade,  the fat closed upon the blade, for he did not draw the sword out of his body,  it came out behind.
Judg. Then Ehud went forth into the porch,  shut the doors of the upper room upon him,  locked them.
Judg. Now when he was gone out, his servants came,  they saw, , behold, the doors of the upper room were locked. And they said, Surely he is covering his feet in the upper chamber.
Judg. And they delayed till they were ashamed, , behold, he did not open the doors of the upper room. Therefore they took the key,  opened, , behold, their lord was fallen down dead on the earth.
Judg. And Ehud escaped while they delayed,  passed beyond the quarries,  escaped to Seirah.
Judg. And it came to pass, when he came, that he blew a trumpet in the hill-country of Ephraim. And the sons of Israel went down with him from the hill-country,  he before them.
Judg. And he said to them, Follow after me, for Jehovah has delivered your enemies the Moabites into your hand. And they went down after him,  took the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites,  did not allow a man to pass over.
Judg. And they smote about ten thousand men of Moab at that time, every robust man,  every man of valor,  there escaped not a man.
Judg. So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest eighty years.
Judg. And after him was Shamgar the son of Anath, who smote six hundred men of the Philistines with an ox-goad,  he also saved Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Israel again did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah, when Ehud was dead.
Judg. And Jehovah sold them into the hand of Jabin king of Canaan who reigned in Hazor, the captain of whose army was Sisera who dwelt in Harosheth of the Gentiles.
Judg. And the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah, for he had nine hundred chariots of iron,  he mightily oppressed the sons of Israel twenty years.
Judg. Now Deborah, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth, she judged Israel at that time.
Judg. And she dwelt under the palm tree of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill-country of Ephraim,  the sons of Israel came up to her for judgment.
Judg. And she sent and called Barak the son of Abinoam out of Kedesh-naphtali,  said to him, Has not Jehovah, the God of Israel, commanded, saying, Go and approach to mount Tabor,  take with thee ten thousand men of the sons of Naphtali and of the sons of Zebulun?
Judg. And I will draw Sisera, the captain of Jabin's army, to thee, to the river Kishon, with his chariots and his multitude,  I will deliver him into thy hand.
Judg. And Barak said to her, If thou will go with me, then I will go,  if thou will not go with me, I will not go.
Judg. And she said, I will surely go with thee. Notwithstanding, the journey that thou take shall not be for thine honor, for Jehovah will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman. And Deborah arose,  went with Barak to Kedesh.
Judg. And Barak called Zebulun and Naphtali together to Kedesh. And there went up ten thousand men at his feet,  Deborah went up with him.
Judg. Now Heber the Kenite had separated himself from the Kenites, even from the sons of Hobab the brother-in-law of Moses,  had pitched his tent as far as the oak in Zaanannim, which is by Kedesh.
Judg. And they told Sisera that Barak the son of Abinoam was gone up to mount Tabor.
Judg. And Sisera gathered together all his chariots, even nine hundred chariots of iron,  all the people that were with him, from Harosheth of the Gentiles, to the river Kishon.
Judg. And Deborah said to Barak, Up, for this is the day in which Jehovah has delivered Sisera into thy hand. Has not Jehovah gone out before thee? So Barak went down from mount Tabor,  ten thousand men after him.
Judg. And Jehovah discomfited Sisera,  all his chariots,  all his army, with the edge of the sword before Barak. And Sisera alighted from his chariot,  fled away on his feet.
Judg. But Barak pursued after the chariots,  after the army, to Harosheth of the Gentiles. And all the army of Sisera fell by the edge of the sword. There was not a man left.
Judg. However Sisera fled away on his feet to the tent of Jael the wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between Jabin the king of Hazor and the house of Heber the Kenite.
Judg. And Jael went out to meet Sisera,  said to him, Turn in, my lord, turn in to me; fear not. And he turned in to her into the tent,  she covered him with a rug.
Judg. And he said to her, Give me, I pray thee, a little water to drink, for I am thirsty. And she opened a bottle of milk,  gave him drink,  covered him.
Judg. And he said to her, Stand in the door of the tent,  it shall be, when any man comes and inquires of thee,  says, Is there any man here? that thou shall say, No.
Judg. Then Jael Heber's wife took a tent-pin,  took a hammer in her hand,  went softly to him,  struck the pin into his temples,  it pierced through into the ground, for he was in a deep sleep, so he fainted and died.
Judg. And, behold, as Barak pursued Sisera, Jael came out to meet him,  said to him, Come,  I will show thee the man whom thou seek. And he came to her, , behold, Sisera lay dead,  the tent-pin was in his temples.
Judg. So God subdued on that day Jabin the king of Canaan before the sons of Israel.
Judg. And the hand of the sons of Israel prevailed more and more against Jabin the king of Canaan until they had destroyed Jabin king of Canaan.
Judg. Then Deborah and Barak the son of Abinoam sang on that day, saying,
Judg. That the leaders took the lead in Israel, that the people offered themselves willingly, bless ye Jehovah.
Judg. Hear, O ye kings. Give ear, O ye rulers. I, even I, will sing to Jehovah. I will sing praise to Jehovah, the God of Israel.
Judg. Jehovah, when thou went forth out of Seir, when thou marched out of the field of Edom, the earth trembled, the heavens also dropped, yea, the clouds dropped water.
Judg. The mountains quaked at the presence of Jehovah, even yon Sinai at the presence of Jehovah, the God of Israel.
Judg. In the days of Shamgar the son of Anath, in the days of Jael, the highways were unoccupied,  the travelers walked through byways.
Judg. The rulers ceased in Israel, they ceased, until that I, Deborah, arose, that I arose a mother in Israel.
Judg. They chose new gods, then war was in the gates. Was there a shield or spear seen among forty thousand in Israel?
Judg. My heart is toward the governors of Israel, who offered themselves willingly among the people. Bless ye Jehovah.
Judg. Tell, ye who ride on white donkeys, ye who sit on rich carpets,  ye who walk by the way.
Judg. Far from the noise of archers, in the places of drawing water, there they shall rehearse the righteous acts of Jehovah, the righteous acts of his rule in Israel. Then the people of Jehovah went down to the gates.
Judg. Awake, awake, Deborah, awake, awake, utter a song. Arise, Barak,  lead away thy captives, thou son of Abinoam.
Judg. Then a remnant of the nobles and the people came down. Jehovah came down for me against the mighty.
Judg. Out of Ephraim, those whose root is in Amalek, after thee, Benjamin, among thy peoples, out of Machir, came down governors,  out of Zebulun those who handle the marshal's staff.
Judg. And the princes of Issachar were with Deborah, as was Issachar, so was Barak, into the valley they rushed forth at his feet. By the watercourses of Reuben there were great resolves of heart.
Judg. Why did thou sit among the sheepfolds, to hear the pipings for the flocks? At the watercourses of Reuben there were great searchings of heart.
Judg. Gilead abode beyond the Jordan. And Dan, why did he remain in ships? Asher sat still at the haven of the sea,  abode by his creeks.
Judg. Zebulun was a people who jeopardized their lives to the death,  Naphtali, upon the high places of the field.
Judg. The kings came and fought. Then the kings of Canaan fought in Taanach by the waters of Megiddo. They took no gain of money.
Judg. From heaven the stars fought; from their courses they fought against Sisera.
Judg. The river Kishon swept them away, that ancient river, the river Kishon. O my soul, march on with strength.
Judg. Then the horse hoofs stamped by reason of the prancings, the prancings of their strong ones.
Judg. Curse ye Meroz, said the agent of Jehovah. Curse ye bitterly the inhabitants of it, because they did not come to the help of Jehovah, to the help of Jehovah against the mighty.
Judg. Blessed above women shall Jael be, the wife of Heber the Kenite. Blessed shall she be above women in the tent.
Judg. He asked water. She gave him milk. She brought him butter in a lordly dish.
Judg. She put her hand to the tent-pin,  her right hand to the workmen's hammer. And with the hammer she smote Sisera; she struck through his head. Yea, she pierced and struck through his temples.
Judg. At her feet he bowed, he fell, he lay. At her feet he bowed, he fell. Where he bowed, there he fell down dead.
Judg. Through the window she looked forth,  cried-the mother of Sisera through the lattice-Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why do the wheels of his chariots delay?
Judg. Her wise ladies answered her, yea, she returned answer to herself,
Judg. Have they not found, have they not divided the spoil? A damsel, two damsels to every man, to Sisera a spoil of dyed garments, a spoil of dyed garments embroidered, of dyed garments embroidered on both sides, on the necks of the spoil?
Judg. So let all thine enemies perish, O Jehovah,  let those who love him be as the sun when he goes forth in his might. And the land had rest forty years.
Judg. And the sons of Israel did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  Jehovah delivered them into the hand of Midian seven years.
Judg. And the hand of Midian prevailed against Israel. And because of Midian the sons of Israel made for themselves the dens which are in the mountains,  the caves,  the strongholds.
Judg. And so it was, when Israel had sown, that the Midianites came up,  the Amalekites,  the sons of the east, they came up against them.
Judg. And they encamped against them,  destroyed the increase of the earth, till thou come to Gaza,  left no sustenance in Israel, neither sheep, nor ox, nor donkey.
Judg. For they came up with their cattle and their tents. They came in as locusts for multitude. Both they and their camels were without number,  they came into the land to destroy it.
Judg. And Israel was brought very low because of Midian,  the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah.
Judg. And it came to pass, when the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah because of Midian,
Judg. that Jehovah sent a prophet to the sons of Israel. And he said to them, Thus says Jehovah, the God of Israel, I brought you up from Egypt,  brought you forth out of the house of bondage.
Judg. And I delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians,  out of the hand of all that oppressed you,  drove them out from before you,  gave you their land.
Judg. And I said to you, I am Jehovah your God. Ye shall not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land ye dwell,  ye have not hearkened to my voice.
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah came,  sat under the oak which was in Ophrah that pertained to Joash the Abiezrite. And his son Gideon was beating out wheat in the winepress, to hide it from the Midianites.
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah appeared to him,  said to him, Jehovah is with thee, thou mighty man of valor.
Judg. And Gideon said to him, Oh, my lord, if Jehovah is with us, then why has all this befallen us? And where are all his wondrous works which our fathers told us of, saying, Did not Jehovah bring us up from Egypt? But now Jehovah has cast us off,  delivered us into the hand of Midian.
Judg. And Jehovah looked upon him,  said, Go in this thy might,  save Israel from the hand of Midian. Have I not sent thee?
Judg. And he said to him, Oh, Lord, with what shall I save Israel? Behold, my family is the poorest in Manasseh,  I am the least in my father's house.
Judg. And Jehovah said to him, Surely I will be with thee,  thou shall smite the Midianites as one man.
Judg. And he said to him, If now I have found favor in thy sight, then show me a sign that it is thou who talk with me.
Judg. Depart not from here, I pray thee, until I come to thee,  bring forth my present,  lay it before thee. And he said, I will tarry until thou come again.
Judg. And Gideon went in,  made ready a kid,  unleavened cakes of an ephah of meal. He put the flesh in a basket,  he put the broth in a pot,  brought it out to him under the oak,  presented it.
Judg. And the agent of God said to him, Take the flesh and the unleavened cakes,  lay them upon this rock,  pour out the broth. And he did so.
Judg. Then the agent of Jehovah put forth the end of the staff that was in his hand,  touched the flesh and the unleavened cakes. And there went up fire out of the rock,  consumed the flesh and the unleavened cakes. And the agent of Jehovah departed out of his sight.
Judg. And Gideon saw that he was the agent of Jehovah. And Gideon said, Alas, O lord Jehovah! Inasmuch as I have seen the agent of Jehovah face to face.
Judg. And Jehovah said to him, Peace be to thee. Fear not; thou shall not die.
Judg. Then Gideon built an altar there to Jehovah,  called it Jehovah-shalom. To this day it is yet in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
Judg. And it came to pass the same night, that Jehovah said to him, Take thy father's bullock, even the second bullock seven years old,  throw down the altar of Baal that thy father has,  cut down the Asherah that is by it.
Judg. And build an altar to Jehovah thy God upon the top of this stronghold, in the orderly manner,  take the second bullock,  offer a burnt offering with the wood of the Asherah which thou shall cut down.
Judg. Then Gideon took ten men of his servants,  did as Jehovah had spoken to him. And it came to pass, because he feared his father's household and the men of the city, so that he could not do it by day, that he did it by night.
Judg. And when the men of the city arose early in the morning, behold, the altar of Baal was broken down,  the Asherah was cut down that was by it,  the second bullock was offered upon the altar that was built.
Judg. And they said one to another, Who has done this thing? And when they inquired and asked, they said, Gideon the son of Joash has done this thing.
Judg. Then the men of the city said to Joash, Bring out thy son, that he may die, because he has broken down the altar of Baal,  because he has cut down the Asherah that was by it.
Judg. And Joash said to all who stood against him, Will ye contend for Baal? Or will ye save him? He who will contend for him, let him be put to death while it is morning. If he be a god, let him contend for himself because he has broken down his altar.
Judg. Therefore on that day he called him Jerubbaal, saying, Let Baal contend against him because he has broken down his altar.
Judg. Then all the Midianites and the Amalekites and the sons of the east assembled themselves together. And they passed over,  encamped in the valley of Jezreel.
Judg. But the Spirit of Jehovah came upon Gideon,  he blew a trumpet,  Abiezer was gathered together after him.
Judg. And he sent messengers throughout all Manasseh,  they also were gathered together after him. And he sent messengers to Asher,  to Zebulun,  to Naphtali,  they came up to meet them.
Judg. And Gideon said to God, If thou will save Israel by my hand, as thou have spoken,
Judg. behold, I will put a fleece of wool on the threshing-floor. If there be dew on the fleece only,  it be dry upon all the ground, then I shall know that thou will save Israel by my hand as thou have spoken.
Judg. And it was so, for he rose up early on the morrow,  pressed the fleece together,  wrung the dew out of the fleece, a bowlful of water.
Judg. And Gideon said to God, Let not thine anger be kindled against me,  I will speak but this once. Let me make trial, I pray thee,  this once with the fleece. Let it now be dry only upon the fleece,  upon all the ground let there be dew.
Judg. And God did so that night, for it was dry upon the fleece only,  there was dew on all the ground.
Judg. Then Jerubbaal, who is Gideon,  all the people who were with him, rose up early,  encamped beside the spring of Harod. And the camp of Midian was on the north side of them, by the hill of Moreh, in the valley.
Judg. And Jehovah said to Gideon, The people who are with thee are too many for me to give the Midianites into their hand, lest Israel vaunt themselves against me, saying, My own hand has saved me.
Judg. Now therefore proclaim in the ears of the people, saying, Whoever is fearful and trembling, let him return and depart from mount Gilead. And there returned of the people twenty-two thousand,  there remained ten thousand.
Judg. And Jehovah said to Gideon, The people are yet too many. Bring them down to the water,  I will try them for thee there. And it shall be, that of whom I say to thee, This man shall go with thee, the same shall go with thee,  of whomever I say to thee, This man shall not go with thee, the same shall not go.
Judg. So he brought down the people to the water. And Jehovah said to Gideon, Everyone who laps of the water with his tongue, as a dog laps, him thou shall set by himself. Likewise everyone who bows down upon his knees to drink.
Judg. And the number of those who lapped, putting their hand to their mouth, was three hundred men,  all the rest of the people bowed down upon their knees to drink water.
Judg. And Jehovah said to Gideon, By the three hundred men who lapped I will save you,  deliver the Midianites into thy hand. And let all the people go every man to his place.
Judg. So the people took provision in their hand,  their trumpets. And he sent all the men of Israel every man to his tent,  retained the three hundred men. And the camp of Midian was beneath him in the valley.
Judg. And it came to pass the same night, that Jehovah said to him, Arise, get thee down into the camp, for I have delivered it into thy hand.
Judg. But if thou fear to go down, go thou with Purah thy servant down to the camp.
Judg. And thou shall hear what they say,  afterward thy hands shall be strengthened to go down into the camp. Then he went down with Purah his servant to the outermost part of the armed men who were in the camp.
Judg. And the Midianites and the Amalekites and all the sons of the east lay along in the valley like locusts for multitude,  their camels were without number, as the sand which is upon the sea-shore for multitude.
Judg. And when Gideon came, behold, there was a man telling a dream to his fellow. And he said, Behold, I dreamed a dream. And, lo, a cake of barley bread tumbled into the camp of Midian,  came to the tent,  smote it so that it fell,  turned it upside down so that the tent lay flat.
Judg. And his fellow answered and said, This is nothing else except the sword of Gideon the son of Joash, a man of Israel. Into his hand God has delivered Midian,  all the army.
Judg. And it was so, when Gideon heard the telling of the dream,  the interpretation of it, that he worshiped. And he returned into the camp of Israel,  said, Arise, for Jehovah has delivered the army of Midian into your hand.
Judg. And he divided the three hundred men into three companies,  he put trumpets into the hands of all of them,  empty pitchers, with torches inside the pitchers.
Judg. And he said to them, Look on me,  do likewise, , behold, when I come to the outermost part of the camp, it shall be that, as I do, so ye shall do.
Judg. When I blow the trumpet, I and all who are with me, then blow ye the trumpets also on every side of all the camp,  say, For Jehovah and for Gideon.
Judg. So Gideon,  the hundred men who were with him, came to the outermost part of the camp in the beginning of the middle watch when they had but newly set the watch. And they blew the trumpets,  broke in pieces the pitchers that were in their hands.
Judg. And the three companies blew the trumpets,  broke the pitchers,  held the torches in their left hands,  the trumpets in their right hands with which to blow. And they cried out, The sword of Jehovah and of Gideon.
Judg. And they stood every man in his place round about the camp. And all the army ran,  they shouted,  put them to flight.
Judg. And they blew the three hundred trumpets,  Jehovah set every man's sword against his fellow,  against all the army. And the army fled as far as Beth-shittah toward Zererah, as far as the border of Abel-meholah, by Tabbath.
Judg. And the men of Israel were gathered together out of Naphtali,  out of Asher,  out of all Manasseh,  pursued after Midian.
Judg. And Gideon sent messengers throughout all the hill-country of Ephraim, saying, Come down against Midian,  take before them the waters, as far as Beth-barah, even the Jordan. So all the men of Ephraim were gathered together,  took the waters as far as Beth-barah, even the Jordan.
Judg. And they took the two princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb. And they killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb,  Zeeb they killed at the winepress of Zeeb,  pursued Midian. And they brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon beyond the Jordan.
Judg. And the men of Ephraim said to him, Why have thou done thus to us, that thou did not call us when thou went to fight with Midian? And they chided with him sharply.
Judg. And he said to them, What have I now done in comparison with you? Is not the gleaning of the grapes of Ephraim better than the vintage of Abiezer?
Judg. God has delivered into your hand the rulers of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb,  what was I able to do in comparison with you? Then their anger was abated toward him when he had said that.
Judg. And Gideon came to the Jordan,  passed over, he,  the three hundred men who were with him, faint, yet pursuing.
Judg. And he said to the men of Succoth, Give, I pray you, loaves of bread to the people who follow me, for they are faint,  I am pursuing after Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian.
Judg. And the rulers of Succoth said, Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in thy hand that we should give bread to thine army?
Judg. And Gideon said, Therefore when Jehovah has delivered Zebah and Zalmunna into my hand, then I will tear your flesh with the thorns of the wilderness and with briers.
Judg. And he went up from there to Penuel,  spoke to them in like manner,  the men of Penuel answered him as the men of Succoth had answered.
Judg. And he spoke also to the men of Penuel, saying, When I come again in peace, I will break down this tower.
Judg. Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor,  their armies with them, about fifteen thousand men, all who were left of all the army of the sons of the east, for there fell a hundred and twenty thousand men who drew a sword.
Judg. And Gideon went up by the way of those who dwelt in tents on the east of Nobah and Jogbehah,  smote the army, for the army was confident.
Judg. And Zebah and Zalmunna fled,  he pursued after them. And he took the two kings of Midian, Zebah and Zalmunna,  discomfited all the army.
Judg. And Gideon the son of Joash returned from the battle from the ascent of Heres.
Judg. And he caught a young man of the men of Succoth,  inquired of him. And he described for him the rulers of Succoth,  the elders of it, seventy-seven men.
Judg. And he came to the men of Succoth,  said, Behold Zebah and Zalmunna, concerning whom ye taunted me, saying, Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in thy hand, that we should give bread to thy men who are weary?
Judg. And he took the elders of the city,  thorns of the wilderness and briers,  with them he taught the men of Succoth.
Judg. And he broke down the tower of Penuel,  killed the men of the city.
Judg. Then he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, What manner of men were they whom ye killed at Tabor? And they answered, As thou are, so were they. Each one resembled the sons of a king.
Judg. And he said, They were my brothers, the sons of my mother. As Jehovah lives, if ye had saved them alive, I would not kill you.
Judg. And he said to Jether his firstborn, Up,  kill them. But the youth did not draw his sword, for he feared because he was yet a youth.
Judg. Then Zebah and Zalmunna said, Rise thou,  fall upon us, for as the man is, so is his strength. And Gideon arose,  killed Zebah and Zalmunna,  took the crescents that were on their camels' necks.
Judg. Then the men of Israel said to Gideon, Rule thou over us, both thou,  thy son,  thy son's son also, for thou have saved us out of the hand of Midian.
Judg. And Gideon said to them, I will not rule over you, neither shall my son rule over you. Jehovah shall rule over you.
Judg. And Gideon said to them, I would make a request of you, that ye would give me every man the earrings of his spoil. (For they had golden earrings, because they were Ishmaelites.)
Judg. And they answered, We will willingly give them. And they spread a garment,  cast in it every man the earrings of his spoil.
Judg. And the weight of the golden earrings that he requested was a thousand and seven hundred shekels of gold, besides the crescents,  the pendants,  the purple raiment that was on the kings of Midian,  besides the chains that were about their camels' necks.
Judg. And Gideon made an ephod of it,  put it in his city, even in Ophrah. And all Israel played the harlot after it there,  it became a snare to Gideon,  to his house.
Judg. So Midian was subdued before the sons of Israel,  they lifted up their heads no more. And the land had rest forty years in the days of Gideon.
Judg. And Jerubbaal the son of Joash went and dwelt in his own house.
Judg. And Gideon had seventy sons begotten from his body, for he had many wives.
Judg. And his concubine who was in Shechem, she also bore him a son,  he called his name Abimelech.
Judg. And Gideon the son of Joash died in a good old age,  was buried in the sepulcher of Joash his father, in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
Judg. And it came to pass, as soon as Gideon was dead, that the sons of Israel turned again,  played the harlot after the Baalim,  made Baal-berith their god.
Judg. And the sons of Israel did not remember Jehovah their God, who had delivered them out of the hand of all their enemies on every side,
Judg. neither did they show kindness to the house of Jerubbaal, who is Gideon, according to all the goodness which he had shown to Israel.
Judg. And Abimelech the son of Jerubbaal went to Shechem to his mother's brothers,  spoke with them,  with all the family of the house of his mother's father, saying,
Judg. Speak, I pray you, in the ears of all the men of Shechem, Which is better for you, that all the sons of Jerubbaal, who are seventy men, rule over you, or that one rule over you? Remember also that I am your bone and your flesh.
Judg. And his mother's brothers spoke of him in the ears of all the men of Shechem all these words. And their hearts inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, He is our brother.
Judg. And they gave him seventy pieces of silver out of the house of Baal-berith, with which Abimelech hired vain and unstable fellows who followed him.
Judg. And he went to his father's house at Ophrah,  killed his brothers the sons of Jerubbaal, being seventy men, upon one stone,  Jotham the youngest son of Jerubbaal was left, for he hid himself.
Judg. And all the men of Shechem assembled themselves together,  all the house of Millo,  went and made Abimelech king by the oak of the pillar that was in Shechem.
Judg. And when they told it to Jotham, he went and stood on the top of mount Gerizim,  lifted up his voice,  cried out,  said to them, Hearken to me, ye men of Shechem, that God may hearken to you.
Judg. The trees went forth a time to anoint a king over them. And they said to the olive tree, Reign thou over us.
Judg. But the olive tree said to them, Should I leave my fatness with which by me they honor God and man,  go to wave to and fro over the trees?
Judg. And the trees said to the fig tree, Come thou,  reign over us.
Judg. But the fig tree said to them, Should I leave my sweetness,  my good fruit,  go to wave to and fro over the trees?
Judg. And the trees said to the vine, Come thou,  reign over us.
Judg. And the vine said to them, Should I leave my new wine, which cheers God and man,  go to wave to and fro over the trees?
Judg. Then all the trees said to the bramble, Come thou,  reign over us.
Judg. And the bramble said to the trees, If in truth ye anoint me king over you, then come and take refuge in my shade,  if not, let fire come out of the bramble,  devour the cedars of Lebanon.
Judg. Now therefore, if ye have dealt truly and uprightly, in that ye have made Abimelech king,  if ye have dealt well with Jerubbaal and his house,  have done to him according to the deed of his hands
Judg. (for my father fought for you,  ventured his life,  delivered you out of the hand of Midian,
Judg. and ye have risen up against my father's house this day,  have slain his sons, seventy men, upon one stone,  have made Abimelech, the son of his maid-servant, king over the men of Shechem because he is your brother),
Judg. if ye then have dealt truly and uprightly with Jerubbaal and with his house this day, then rejoice ye in Abimelech,  let him also rejoice in you.
Judg. But if not, let fire come out from Abimelech,  devour the men of Shechem,  the house of Millo,  let fire come out from the men of Shechem,  from the house of Millo,  devour Abimelech.
Judg. And Jotham ran away,  fled,  went to Beer,  dwelt there, for fear of Abimelech his brother.
Judg. And Abimelech was ruler over Israel three years.
Judg. And God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the men of Shechem,  the men of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech,
Judg. that the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal might come,  that their blood might be laid upon Abimelech their brother who killed them,  upon the men of Shechem who strengthened his hands to kill his brothers.
Judg. And the men of Shechem set ambushes for him on the tops of the mountains,  they robbed all who came along that way by them,  it was told Abimelech.
Judg. And Gaal the son of Ebed came with his brothers,  went over to Shechem,  the men of Shechem put their trust in him.
Judg. And they went out into the field,  gathered their vineyards,  trod the grapes,  held festival,  went into the house of their god,  ate and drank,  cursed Abimelech.
Judg. And Gaal the son of Ebed said, Who is Abimelech,  who is Shechem, that we should serve him? Is not he the son of Jerubbaal,  Zebul his officer? Serve ye the men of Hamor the father of Shechem,  why should we serve him?
Judg. And would that this people were under my hand! Then I would remove Abimelech. And he said to Abimelech, Increase thine army,  come out.
Judg. And when Zebul the ruler of the city heard the words of Gaal the son of Ebed, his anger was kindled.
Judg. And he sent messengers to Abimelech privately, saying, Behold, Gaal the son of Ebed and his brothers have come to Shechem, , behold, they are fortifying the city against thee.
Judg. Now therefore, up by night, thou and the people who are with thee,  lie in wait in the field.
Judg. And it shall be, that in the morning, as soon as the sun is up, thou shall rise early,  rush upon the city, , behold, when he and the people who are with him come out against thee, then thou may do to them as thou shall find occasion.
Judg. And Abimelech rose up,  all the people who were with him, by night,  they laid wait against Shechem in four companies.
Judg. And Gaal the son of Ebed went out,  stood in the entrance of the gate of the city. And Abimelech rose up,  the people who were with him, from the ambushment.
Judg. And when Gaal saw the people, he said to Zebul, Behold, there comes a people down from the tops of the mountains. And Zebul said to him, Thou see the shadow of the mountains as if they were men.
Judg. And Gaal spoke again and said, See, there comes a people down by the middle of the land,  one company comes by the way of the oak of Meonenim.
Judg. Then Zebul said to him, Where is now thy mouth, that thou said, Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him? Is not this the people that thou have despised? Go out now, I pray,  fight with them.
Judg. And Gaal went out before the men of Shechem,  fought with Abimelech.
Judg. And Abimelech chased him,  he fled before him,  there fell many wounded, even to the entrance of the gate.
Judg. And Abimelech dwelt at Arumah,  Zebul drove out Gaal and his brothers, that they should not dwell in Shechem.
Judg. And it came to pass on the morrow, that the people went out into the field,  they told Abimelech.
Judg. And he took the people,  divided them into three companies,  laid wait in the field. And he looked, , behold, the people came forth out of the city. And he rose up against them,  smote them.
Judg. And Abimelech,  the companies who were with him, rushed forward,  stood in the entrance of the gate of the city,  the two companies rushed upon all who were in the field,  smote them.
Judg. And Abimelech fought against the city all that day. And he took the city,  killed the people that were in it,  he beat down the city,  sowed it with salt.
Judg. And when all the men of the tower of Shechem heard of it, they entered into the stronghold of the house of El-berith.
Judg. And it was told Abimelech that all the men of the tower of Shechem were gathered together.
Judg. And Abimelech got up to mount Zalmon, he and all the people who were with him. And Abimelech took an axe in his hand,  cut down a bough from the trees,  took it up,  laid it on his shoulder. And he said to the people who were with him, What ye have seen me do, make haste,  do as I have done.
Judg. And all the people likewise cut down every man his bough,  followed Abimelech,  put them to the stronghold,  set the stronghold on fire upon them, so that all the men of the tower of Shechem died also, about a thousand men and women.
Judg. Then Abimelech went to Thebez,  encamped against Thebez,  took it.
Judg. But there was a strong tower inside the city. And all the men and women fled,  all those of the city,  shut themselves in,  got up to the roof of the tower.
Judg. And Abimelech came to the tower,  fought against it,  drew near to the door of the tower to burn it with fire.
Judg. And a certain woman cast an upper millstone upon Abimelech's head,  broke his skull.
Judg. Then he called hastily to the young man his armor bearer,  said to him, Draw thy sword,  kill me, that men not say of me, A woman killed him. And his young man thrust him through,  he died.
Judg. And when the men of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, they departed every man to his place.
Judg. Thus God requited the wickedness of Abimelech, which he did to his father, in slaying his seventy brothers.
Judg. And God requited all the wickedness of the men of Shechem upon their heads. And the curse of Jotham the son of Jerubbaal came upon them.
Judg. And after Abimelech there arose Tola the son of Puah, the son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, to save Israel,  he dwelt in Shamir in the hill-country of Ephraim.
Judg. And he judged Israel twenty-three years,  died,  was buried in Shamir.
Judg. And after him arose Jair, the Gileadite,  he judged Israel twenty-two years.
Judg. And he had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkey colts,  they had thirty cities, which are called Havvoth-jair to this day, which are in the land of Gilead.
Judg. And Jair died,  was buried in Kamon.
Judg. And the sons of Israel again did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  served the Baalim,  the Ashtaroth,  the gods of Syria,  the gods of Sidon,  the gods of Moab,  the gods of the sons of Ammon,  the gods of the Philistines. And they forsook Jehovah,  did not serve him.
Judg. And the anger of Jehovah was kindled against Israel,  he sold them into the hand of the Philistines,  into the hand of the sons of Ammon.
Judg. And they vexed and oppressed the sons of Israel that year. Eighteen years they oppressed all the sons of Israel who were beyond the Jordan in the land of the Amorites, which is in Gilead.
Judg. And the sons of Ammon passed over the Jordan to also fight against Judah,  against Benjamin,  against the house of Ephraim, so that Israel was exceedingly distressed.
Judg. And the sons of Israel cried to Jehovah, saying, We have sinned against thee, even because we have forsaken our God,  have served the Baalim.
Judg. And Jehovah said to the sons of Israel, Did not I save you from the Egyptians,  from the Amorites, from the sons of Ammon,  from the Philistines?
Judg. The Sidonians also,  the Amalekites,  the Maonites, oppressed you. And ye cried to me,  I saved you out of their hand.
Judg. Yet ye have forsaken me,  served other gods. Therefore I will save you no more.
Judg. Go and cry to the gods which ye have chosen. Let them save you in the time of your distress.
Judg. And the sons of Israel said to Jehovah, We have sinned. Do thou to us whatever seems good to thee, only deliver us, we pray thee, this day.
Judg. And they put away the foreign gods from among them,  served Jehovah. And his soul was grieved for the misery of Israel.
Judg. Then the sons of Ammon were gathered together,  encamped in Gilead. And the sons of Israel assembled themselves together,  encamped in Mizpah.
Judg. And the people, the rulers of Gilead, said one to another, What man is he who will begin to fight against the sons of Ammon? He shall be head over all the inhabitants of Gilead.
Judg. Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty man of valor,  he was the son of a harlot,  Gilead begot Jephthah.
Judg. And Gilead's wife bore sons to him. And when his wife's sons grew up, they drove out Jephthah,  said to him, Thou shall not inherit in our father's house, for thou are the son of another woman.
Judg. Then Jephthah fled from his brothers,  dwelt in the land of Tob. And vain fellows were gathered to Jephthah,  they went out with him.
Judg. And it came to pass after a while, that the sons of Ammon made war against Israel.
Judg. And it was so, that, when the sons of Ammon made war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to fetch Jephthah out of the land of Tob.
Judg. And they said to Jephthah, Come and be our chief, that we may fight with the sons of Ammon.
Judg. And Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, Did ye not hate me,  drive me out of my father's house? And why have ye come to me now when ye are in distress?
Judg. And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, For that reason we turned again to thee now, that thou may go with us,  fight with the sons of Ammon. And thou shall be our head over all the inhabitants of Gilead.
Judg. And Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, If ye bring me home again to fight with the sons of Ammon,  Jehovah delivers them before me, shall I be your head?
Judg. And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, Jehovah shall be witness between us. Surely according to thy word so will we do.
Judg. Then Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead,  the people made him head and chief over them. And Jephthah spoke all his words before Jehovah in Mizpah.
Judg. And Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the sons of Ammon, saying, What have thou to do with me, that thou have come to me to fight against my land?
Judg. And the king of the sons of Ammon answered to the messengers of Jephthah, Because Israel took away my land when he came up out of Egypt, from the Arnon even to the Jabbok,  to the Jordan. Now therefore restore those lands again peaceably.
Judg. And Jephthah sent messengers again to the king of the sons of Ammon.
Judg. And he said to him, Thus says Jephthah: Israel did not take away the land of Moab, nor the land of the sons of Ammon,
Judg. but when they came up from Egypt,  Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea,  came to Kadesh,
Judg. then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, Let me, I pray thee, pass through thy land,  the king of Edom did not hearken. And in like manner he sent to the king of Moab,  he would not. And Israel abode in Kadesh.
Judg. Then they went through the wilderness,  went around the land of Edom,  the land of Moab,  came by the east side of the land of Moab. And they encamped on the other side of the Arnon,  they did not come within the border of Moab, for the Arnon was the border of Moab.
Judg. And Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, the king of Heshbon. And Israel said to him, Let us pass, we pray thee, through thy land to my place.
Judg. But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his border,  Sihon gathered all his people together,  encamped in Jahaz,  fought against Israel.
Judg. And Jehovah, the God of Israel, delivered Sihon and all his people into the hand of Israel,  they smote them. So Israel possessed all the land of the Amorites, the inhabitants of that country.
Judg. And they possessed all the border of the Amorites, from the Arnon even to the Jabbok,  from the wilderness even to the Jordan.
Judg. So now Jehovah, the God of Israel, has dispossessed the Amorites from before his people Israel,  should thou possess them?
Judg. Will thou not possess that which Chemosh thy god gives thee to possess? So whomever Jehovah our God has dispossessed from before us, them will we possess.
Judg. And now are thou anything better than Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever strive against Israel, or did he ever fight against them?
Judg. While Israel dwelt in Heshbon and its towns,  in Aroer and its towns,  in all the cities that are along by the side of the Arnon, three hundred years, why did ye not recover them within that time?
Judg. I therefore have not sinned against thee,  thou do me wrong to war against me. Jehovah, the Judge, be judge this day between the sons of Israel and the sons of Ammon.
Judg. However the king of the sons of Ammon did not hearken to the words of Jephthah which he sent him.
Judg. Then the Spirit of Jehovah came upon Jephthah,  he passed over Gilead and Manasseh,  passed over Mizpeh of Gilead,  from Mizpeh of Gilead he passed over to the sons of Ammon.
Judg. And Jephthah vowed a vow to Jehovah,  said, If thou will indeed deliver the sons of Ammon into my hand,
Judg. then it shall be, that whatever comes forth from the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the sons of Ammon, it shall be Jehovah's,  I will offer it up for a burnt offering.
Judg. So Jephthah passed over to the sons of Ammon to fight against them,  Jehovah delivered them into his hand.
Judg. And he smote them from Aroer until thou come to Minnith, even twenty cities,  to Abelcheramim, with a very great slaughter. So the sons of Ammon were subdued before the sons of Israel.
Judg. And Jephthah came to Mizpah to his house, , behold, his daughter came out to meet him with timbrels and with dances. And she was his only child. Besides her he had neither son nor daughter.
Judg. And it came to pass, when he saw her, that he tore his clothes,  said, Alas, my daughter! Thou have brought me very low,  thou are one of those who trouble me, for I have opened my mouth to Jehovah,  I cannot go back.
Judg. And she said to him, My father, thou have opened thy mouth to Jehovah. Do to me according to that which has proceeded out of thy mouth, inasmuch as Jehovah has taken vengeance for thee on thine enemies, even on the sons of Ammon.
Judg. And she said to her father, Let this thing be done for me: Let me alone two months, that I may depart and go down upon the mountains,  bewail my virginity, I and my companions.
Judg. And he said, Go. And he sent her away for two months. And she departed, she and her companions,  bewailed her virginity upon the mountains.
Judg. And it came to pass at the end of two months, that she returned to her father, who did with her according to his vow which he had vowed,  she knew no man. And it was a custom in Israel,
Judg. that the daughters of Israel went yearly to celebrate the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in a year.
Judg. And the men of Ephraim were gathered together,  passed northward. And they said to Jephthah, Why did thou pass over to fight against the sons of Ammon,  did not call us to go with thee? We will burn thy house upon thee with fire.
Judg. And Jephthah said to them, I and my people were at great strife with the sons of Ammon,  when I called you, ye did not save me out of their hand.
Judg. And when I saw that ye did not save me, I put my life in my hand,  passed opposite the sons of Ammon,  Jehovah delivered them into my hand. Why then have ye come up to me this day, to fight against me?
Judg. Then Jephthah gathered together all the men of Gilead,  fought with Ephraim. And the men of Gilead smote Ephraim, because they said, Ye are fugitives of Ephraim, ye Gileadites, in the midst of Ephraim,  in the midst of Manasseh.
Judg. And the Gileadites took the fords of the Jordan against the Ephraimites. And it was so, that, when any of the fugitives of Ephraim said, Let me go over, the men of Gilead said to him, Are thou an Ephraimite? If he said, No,
Judg. then they said to him, Say now Shibboleth,  he said Sibboleth, for he could not frame to pronounce it right, then they laid hold on him,  killed him at the fords of the Jordan. And there fell at that time of Ephraim forty-two thousand.
Judg. And Jephthah judged Israel six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died,  was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
Judg. And after him Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel.
Judg. And he had thirty sons. And he sent abroad thirty daughters,  thirty daughters he brought in from abroad for his sons. And he judged Israel seven years.
Judg. And Ibzan died,  was buried at Bethlehem.
Judg. And after him Elon the Zebulunite judged Israel,  he judged Israel ten years.
Judg. And Elon the Zebulunite died,  was buried in Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
Judg. And after him Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite judged Israel.
Judg. And he had forty sons and thirty sons' sons who rode on seventy donkey colts,  he judged Israel eight years.
Judg. And Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite died,  was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill-country of the Amalekites.
Judg. And the sons of Israel again did that which was evil in the sight of Jehovah,  Jehovah delivered them into the hand of the Philistines forty years.
Judg. And there was a certain man of Zorah, of the family of the Danites, whose name was Manoah,  his wife was barren,  did not bear.
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah appeared to the woman,  said to her, Behold now, thou are barren,  do not bear,  thou shall conceive,  bear a son.
Judg. Now therefore beware, I pray thee,  drink no wine nor strong drink,  do not eat any unclean thing,
Judg. for, lo, thou shall conceive,  bear a son. And no razor shall come upon his head, for the child shall be a Nazirite to God from the womb. And he shall begin to save Israel out of the hand of the Philistines.
Judg. Then the woman came and told her husband, saying, A man of God came to me,  his countenance was like the countenance of the agent of God, very awesome. And I did not ask him from where he was, neither did he tell me his name,
Judg. but he said to me, Behold, thou shall conceive,  bear a son. And now drink no wine nor strong drink,  do not eat any unclean thing, for the child shall be a Nazirite to God from the womb to the day of his death.
Judg. Then Manoah entreated Jehovah,  said, Oh, Lord, I pray thee, let the man of God whom thou sent come again to us,  teach us what we shall do to the child that shall be born.
Judg. And God hearkened to the voice of Manoah,  the agent of God came again to the woman as she sat in the field,  Manoah her husband was not with her.
Judg. And the woman made haste,  ran,  told her husband,  said to him, Behold, the man has appeared to me, who came to me the other day.
Judg. And Manoah arose,  went after his wife,  came to the man,  said to him, Are thou the man who spoke to the woman? And he said, I am.
Judg. And Manoah said, Now let thy words come to pass. What shall be the ordering of the child,  what shall we do to him?
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah said to Manoah, Of all that I said to the woman let her beware.
Judg. She may not eat of anything that comes of the vine, neither let her drink wine or strong drink, nor eat any unclean thing. All that I commanded her let her observe.
Judg. And Manoah said to the agent of Jehovah, I pray thee, let us detain thee, that we may make ready a kid for thee.
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah said to Manoah, Though thou detain me, I will not eat of thy bread,  if thou will make ready a burnt offering, thou must offer it to Jehovah. For Manoah did not know that he was the agent of Jehovah.
Judg. And Manoah said to the agent of Jehovah, What is thy name, that, when thy words come to pass, we may do thee honor?
Judg. And the agent of Jehovah said to him, Why do thou ask after my name, seeing it is wonderful?
Judg. So Manoah took the kid with the meal offering,  offered it upon the rock to Jehovah. And the agent did wondrously,  Manoah and his wife looked on,
Judg. for it came to pass, when the flame went up toward heaven from off the altar, that the agent of Jehovah ascended in the flame of the altar. And Manoah and his wife looked on,  they fell on their faces to the ground.
Judg. But the agent of Jehovah appeared no more to Manoah or to his wife. Then Manoah knew that he was the agent of Jehovah.
Judg. And Manoah said to his wife, We shall surely die, because we have seen God.
Judg. But his wife said to him, If Jehovah were pleased to kill us, he would not have received a burnt offering and a meal offering at our hand, neither would he have shown us all these things, nor would at this time have told such things as these.
Judg. And the woman bore a son,  called his name Samson. And the child grew,  Jehovah blessed him.
Judg. And the Spirit of Jehovah began to move him in Mahaneh-dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
Judg. And Samson went down to Timnah,  saw a woman in Timnah of the daughters of the Philistines.
Judg. And he came up,  told his father and his mother,  said, I have seen a woman in Timnah of the daughters of the Philistines. Now therefore get her for me to wife.
Judg. Then his father and his mother said to him, Is there never a woman among the daughters of thy brothers, or among all my people, that thou go to take a wife of the uncircumcised Philistines? And Samson said to his father, Get her for me, for she pleases me well.
Judg. But his father and his mother knew not that it was of Jehovah, for he sought an occasion against the Philistines. Now at that time the Philistines had rule over Israel.
Judg. Then Samson went down,  his father and his mother, to Timnah,  came to the vineyards of Timnah. And, behold, a young lion roared against him.
Judg. And the Spirit of Jehovah came mightily upon him,  he tore him apart as he would have torn a kid,  he had nothing in his hand. But he did not tell his father or his mother what he had done.
Judg. And he went down,  talked with the woman,  she pleased Samson well.
Judg. And after a while he returned to take her. And he turned aside to see the carcass of the lion, , behold, there was a swarm of bees in the body of the lion,  honey.
Judg. And he took it into his hands,  went on, eating as he went. And he came to his father and mother,  gave to them,  they ate,  he did not tell them that he had taken the honey out of the body of the lion.
Judg. And his father went down to the woman,  Samson made a feast there, for so the young men used to do.
Judg. And it came to pass, when they saw him, that they brought thirty companions to be with him.
Judg. And Samson said to them, Let me now put forth a riddle to you. If ye can declare it to me within the seven days of the feast,  find it out, then I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty changes of raiment,
Judg. but if ye cannot declare it to me, then ye shall give me thirty linen garments and thirty changes of raiment. And they said to him, Put forth thy riddle, that we may hear it.
Judg. And he said to them, Out of the eater came forth food,  out of the strong came forth sweetness. And they could not in three days declare the riddle.
Judg. And it came to pass on the seventh day, that they said to Samson's wife, Entice thy husband, that he may declare to us the riddle, lest we burn thee and thy father's house with fire. Have ye called us to impoverish us? Is it not so?
Judg. And Samson's wife wept before him,  said, Thou do but hate me,  not love me. Thou have put forth a riddle to the sons of my people,  have not told it to me. And he said to her, Behold, I have not told it to my father nor my mother,  shall I tell thee?
Judg. And she wept before him the seven days, while their feast lasted. And it came to pass on the seventh day, that he told her because she pressed him greatly. And she told the riddle to the sons of her people.
Judg. And the men of the city said to him on the seventh day before the sun went down, What is sweeter than honey? and what is stronger than a lion? And he said to them, If ye had not plowed with my heifer, ye would not have found out my riddle.
Judg. And the Spirit of Jehovah came mightily upon him,  he went down to Ashkelon,  smote thirty men of them,  took their spoil,  gave the changes of raiment to those who declared the riddle. And his anger was kindled,  he went up to his father's house.
Judg. But Samson's wife was given to his companion, whom he had used as his friend.
Judg. But it came to pass after a while, in the time of wheat harvest, that Samson visited his wife with a kid. And he said, I will go in to my wife into the chamber,  her father would not allow him to go in.
Judg. And her father said, I truly thought that thou had utterly hated her, therefore I gave her to thy companion. Is not her younger sister fairer than she? Take her, I pray thee, instead of her.
Judg. And Samson said to them, This time I shall be blameless in regard of the Philistines when I do them a mischief.
Judg. And Samson went and caught three hundred foxes,  took firebrands,  turned tail to tail,  put a firebrand in the midst between every two tails.
Judg. And when he had set the brands on fire, he let them go into the standing grain of the Philistines,  burnt up both the shocks and the standing grain,  also the oliveyards.
Judg. Then the Philistines said, Who has done this? And they said, Samson, the son-in-law of the Timnite, because he has taken his wife,  given her to his companion. And the Philistines came up,  burnt her and her father with fire.
Judg. And Samson said to them, If ye do after this manner, surely I will be avenged of you,  after that I will cease.
Judg. And he smote them hip and thigh with a great slaughter. And he went down and dwelt in the cleft of the rock of Etam.
Judg. Then the Philistines went up,  encamped in Judah,  spread themselves in Lehi.
Judg. And the men of Judah said, Why have ye come up against us? And they said, We come up to bind Samson, to do to him as he has done to us.
Judg. Then three thousand men of Judah went down to the cleft of the rock of Etam,  said to Samson, Know thou not that the Philistines are rulers over us? What then is this that thou have done to us? And he said to them, As they did to me, so have I done to them.
Judg. And they said to him, We have come down to bind thee, that we may deliver thee into the hand of the Philistines. And Samson said to them, Swear to me, that ye will not fall upon me yourselves.
Judg. And they spoke to him, saying, No,  we will bind thee fast,  deliver thee into their hand,  truly we will not kill thee. And they bound him with two new ropes,  brought him up from the rock.
Judg. When he came to Lehi, the Philistines shouted as they met him. And the Spirit of Jehovah came mightily upon him,  the ropes that were upon his arms became as flax that was burnt with fire,  his bands dropped from off his hands.
Judg. And he found a fresh jawbone of a donkey,  put forth his hand,  took it,  smote a thousand men with it.
Judg. And Samson said, With the jawbone of a donkey, heaps upon heaps, with the jawbone of a donkey I have smitten a thousand men.
Judg. And it came to pass, when he had made an end of speaking, that he cast away the jawbone out of his hand. And that place was called Ramath-lehi.
Judg. And he was very thirsty,  called on Jehovah,  said, Thou have given this great deliverance by the hand of thy servant,  now shall I die for thirst,  fall into the hand of the uncircumcised?
Judg. But God split the hollow place that is in Lehi,  water came out there. And when he had drunk his spirit came again,  he revived. Therefore the name of it was called En-hakkore, which is in Lehi to this day.
Judg. And he judged Israel in the days of the Philistines twenty years.
Judg. And Samson went to Gaza,  saw a harlot there,  went in to her.
Judg. And it was told the Gazites, saying, Samson has come here. And they encompassed him in,  laid wait for him all night in the gate of the city,  were quiet all the night, saying, Not till morning light, then we will kill him.
Judg. And Samson lay till midnight,  arose at midnight,  laid hold of the doors of the gate of the city,  the two posts,  plucked them up, bar and all,  put them upon his shoulders,  carried them up to the top of the mountain that is before Hebron.
Judg. And it came to pass afterward, that he loved a woman in the valley of Sorek, whose name was Delilah.
Judg. And the lords of the Philistines came up to her,  said to her, Entice him,  see in what his great strength lies,  by what means we may prevail against him, that we may bind him to afflict him. And we will give thee every one of us eleven hundred pieces of silver.
Judg. And Delilah said to Samson, Tell me, I pray thee, in what thy great strength lies,  with what thou might be bound to afflict thee.
Judg. And Samson said to her, If they bind me with seven green withes that were never dried, then I shall become weak,  be as another man.
Judg. Then the lords of the Philistines brought up to her seven green withes which had not been dried,  she bound him with them.
Judg. Now she had an ambush abiding in the inner chamber. And she said to him, The Philistines are upon thee, Samson. And he broke the withes, as a string of tow is broken when it touches the fire. So his strength was not known.
Judg. And Delilah said to Samson, Behold, thou have mocked me,  told me lies. Now tell me, I pray thee, with what thou might be bound.
Judg. And he said to her, If they only bind me with new ropes with which no work has been done, then I shall become weak,  be as another man.
Judg. So Delilah took new ropes,  bound him with it,  said to him, The Philistines are upon thee, Samson. And the ambushment was abiding in the inner chamber. And he broke them off his arms like a thread.
Judg. And Delilah said to Samson, Until now thou have mocked me,  told me lies. Tell me with what thou might be bound. And he said to her, If thou weave the seven locks of my head with the web.
Judg. And she fastened it with the pin,  said to him, The Philistines are upon thee, Samson. And he awoke out of his sleep,  plucked away the pin of the beam,  the web.
Judg. And she said to him, How can thou say, I love thee, when thy heart is not with me? Thou have mocked me these three times,  have not told me with what thy great strength lies.
Judg. And it came to pass, when she pressed him daily with her words,  urged him, that his soul was vexed to death.
Judg. And he told her all his heart,  said to her, There has not come a razor upon my head, for I have been a Nazirite to God from my mother's womb. If I be shaven, then my strength will go from me,  I shall become weak,  be like any other man.
Judg. And when Delilah saw that he had told her all his heart, she sent and called for the lords of the Philistines, saying, Come up this once, for he has told me all his heart. Then the lords of the Philistines came up to her,  brought the money in their hand.
Judg. And she made him sleep upon her knees,  she called for a man,  shaved off the seven locks of his head. And she began to afflict him,  his strength went from him.
Judg. And she said, The Philistines are upon thee, Samson. And he awoke out of his sleep,  said, I will go out as at other times,  shake myself free,  he knew not that Jehovah was departed from him.
Judg. And the Philistines laid hold on him,  put out his eyes. And they brought him down to Gaza,  bound him with fetters of brass,  he did grinding in the prison-house.
Judg. However the hair of his head began to grow again after he was shaven.
Judg. And the lords of the Philistines gathered together to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god,  to rejoice, for they said, Our god has delivered Samson our enemy into our hand.
Judg. And when the people saw him, they praised their god, for they said, Our god has delivered into our hand our enemy,  the destroyer of our country who has slain many of us.
Judg. And it came to pass, when their hearts were merry, that they said, Call for Samson, that he may make sport to us. And they called for Samson out of the prison-house,  he made sport before them. And they set him between the pillars.
Judg. And Samson said to the lad who held him by the hand, Allow me that I may feel the pillars upon which the house rests, that I may lean upon them.
Judg. Now the house was full of men and women,  all the lords of the Philistines were there. And there were upon the roof about three thousand men and women, who beheld while Samson made sport.
Judg. And Samson called to Jehovah,  said, O lord Jehovah, remember me, I pray thee,  strengthen me, I pray thee, only this once, O God, that I may be at once avenged of the Philistines for my two eyes.
Judg. And Samson took hold of the two middle pillars upon which the house rested,  leaned upon them, the one with his right hand,  the other with his left.
Judg. And Samson said, Let me die with the Philistines. And he bowed himself with all his might,  the house fell upon the lords,  upon all the people that were in it. So the dead that he killed at his death were more than those that he killed in his life.
Judg. Then his brothers and all the house of his father came down,  took him,  brought him up,  buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the burying-place of Manoah his father. And he judged Israel twenty years.
Judg. And there was a man of the hill-country of Ephraim, whose name was Micah.
Judg. And he said to his mother, The eleven hundred pieces of silver that were taken from thee, about which thou uttered a curse,  also spoke it in my ears, behold, the silver is with me. I took it. And his mother said, Blessed be my son from Jehovah.
Judg. And he restored the eleven hundred pieces of silver to his mother. And his mother said, I verily dedicate the silver to Jehovah from my hand for my son to make a graven image and a molten image. Now therefore I will restore it to thee.
Judg. And when he restored the money to his mother, his mother took two hundred pieces of silver,  gave them to the founder, who made of it a graven image and a molten image. And it was in the house of Micah.
Judg. And the man Micah had a house of gods,  he made an ephod,  teraphim,  consecrated one of his sons, who became his priest.
Judg. In those days there was no king in Israel. Every man did that which was right in his own eyes.
Judg. And there was a young man out of Bethlehem-judah, of the family of Judah, who was a Levite,  he sojourned there.
Judg. And the man departed out of the city, out of Bethlehem-judah, to sojourn where he could find a place. And he came to the hill-country of Ephraim to the house of Micah, as he journeyed.
Judg. And Micah said to him, From where come thou? And he said to him, I am a Levite of Bethlehem-judah,  I go to sojourn where I may find a place.
Judg. And Micah said to him, Dwell with me,  be to me a father and a priest,  I will give thee ten pieces of silver by the year,  a suit of apparel,  thy food. So the Levite went in.
Judg. And the Levite was content to dwell with the man,  the young man was to him as one of his sons.
Judg. And Micah consecrated the Levite,  the young man became his priest,  was in the house of Micah.
Judg. Then Micah said, Now I know that Jehovah will do me good, seeing I have a Levite for my priest.
Judg. In those days there was no king in Israel. And in those days the tribe of the Danites sought for them an inheritance to dwell in, for to that day their inheritance had not fallen to them among the tribes of Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Dan sent of their family five men from their whole number, men of valor, from Zorah,  from Eshtaol, to spy out the land,  to search it. And they said to them, Go, search the land. And they came to the hill-country of Ephraim to the house of Micah,  lodged there.
Judg. When they were by the house of Micah, they recognized the voice of the young man the Levite. And they turned aside there,  said to him, Who brought thee here? And what are thou doing in this place? And what have thou here?
Judg. And he said to them, Thus and thus has Micah dealt with me,  he has hired me,  I have become his priest.
Judg. And they said to him, Ask counsel, we pray thee, of God, that we may know whether our way which we go shall be prosperous.
Judg. And the priest said to them, Go in peace. Your way is before Jehovah in which ye go.
Judg. Then the five men departed,  came to Laish,  saw the people that were in it, how they dwelt in security, according to the manner of the Sidonians, quiet and secure, for there was none in the land possessing authority, that might put them to shame in anything. And they were far from the Sidonians,  had no dealings with any man.
Judg. And they came to their brothers to Zorah and Eshtaol. And their brothers said to them, What say ye?
Judg. And they said, Arise,  let us go up against them, for we have seen the land, , behold, it is very good,  are ye idle? Be not slothful to go and to enter in to possess the land.
Judg. When ye go, ye shall come to a people secure. And the land is large, for God has given it into your hand, a place where there is no want of anything that is on the earth.
Judg. And there set forth from there of the family of the Danites, out of Zorah and out of Eshtaol, six hundred men girded with weapons of war.
Judg. And they went up,  encamped in Kiriath-jearim, in Judah. Therefore they called that place Mahaneh-dan, to this day. Behold, it is behind Kiriath-jearim.
Judg. And they passed from there to the hill-country of Ephraim,  came to the house of Micah.
Judg. Then the five men who went to spy out the country of Laish, answered and said to their brothers, Do ye know that there is in these houses an ephod,  teraphim,  a graven image,  a molten image? Now therefore consider what ye have to do.
Judg. And they turned aside there,  came to the house of the young man the Levite, even to the house of Micah,  asked him of his welfare.
Judg. And the six hundred men girded with their weapons of war, who were of the sons of Dan, stood by the entrance of the gate.
Judg. And the five men who went to spy out the land went up,  came in there,  took the graven image,  the ephod,  the teraphim,  the molten image. And the priest stood by the entrance of the gate with the six hundred men girded with weapons of war.
Judg. And when these went into Micah's house,  fetched the graven image, the ephod,  the teraphim,  the molten image, the priest said to them, What do ye?
Judg. And they said to him, Hold thy peace, lay thy hand upon thy mouth,  go with us,  be to us a father and a priest. Is it better for thee to be priest to the house of one man, or to be priest to a tribe and a family in Israel?
Judg. And the priest's heart was glad,  he took the ephod,  the teraphim,  the graven image,  went in the midst of the people.
Judg. So they turned and departed,  put the little ones and the cattle and the goods before them.
Judg. When they were a good way from the house of Micah, the men who were in the houses near to Micah's house were gathered together,  overtook the sons of Dan.
Judg. And they cried out to the sons of Dan. And they turned their faces,  said to Micah, What troubles thee that thou come with such a company?
Judg. And he said, ye have taken away my gods which I made,  the priest,  have gone away,  what have I more? And how do ye then say to me, What troubles thee?
Judg. And the sons of Dan said to him, Let not thy voice be heard among us, lest angry fellows fall upon you,  thou lose thy life, with the lives of thy household.
Judg. And the sons of Dan went their way. And when Micah saw that they were too strong for him, he turned and went back to his house.
Judg. And they took that which Micah had made,  the priest whom he had,  came to Laish, to a people quiet and secure,  smote them with the edge of the sword,  they burnt the city with fire.
Judg. And there was no deliverer because it was far from Sidon,  they had no dealings with any man,  it was in the valley that lies by Beth-rehob. And they built the city,  dwelt in it.
Judg. And they called the name of the city Dan, after the name of Dan their father who was born to Israel. However the name of the city was Laish at first.
Judg. And the sons of Dan set up for themselves the graven image. And Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Moses, he and his sons were priests to the tribe of the Danites until the day of the captivity of the land.
Judg. So they set up for them Micah's graven image which he made, all the time that the house of God was in Shiloh.
Judg. And it came to pass in those days, when there was no king in Israel, that there was a certain Levite sojourning on the farther side of the hill-country of Ephraim, who took to him a concubine out of Bethlehem-judah.
Judg. And his concubine played the harlot against him,  went away from him to her father's house to Bethlehem-judah,  was there the space of four months.
Judg. And her husband arose,  went after her, to speak kindly to her, to bring her again, having his servant with him,  a couple of donkeys. And she brought him into her father's house,  when the father of the damsel saw him, he rejoiced to meet him.
Judg. And his father-in-law, the damsel's father, retained him,  he abode with him three days. So they ate and drank,  lodged there.
