Judg. And it came to pass on the fourth day, that they arose early in the morning,  he rose up to depart. And the damsel's father said to his son-in-law, Strengthen thy heart with a morsel of bread,  afterward ye shall go your way.
Judg. So they sat down,  ate and drank, both of them together. And the damsel's father said to the man, Be pleased, I pray thee, to tarry all night,  let thy heart be merry.
Judg. And the man rose up to depart,  his father-in-law urged him,  he lodged there again.
Judg. And he arose early in the morning on the fifth day to depart. And the damsel's father said, Strengthen thy heart, I pray thee,  tarry ye until the day declines. And they ate, both of them.
Judg. And when the man rose up to depart, he,  his concubine,  his servant, his father-in-law, the damsel's father, said to him, Behold, now the day draws toward evening, I pray you tarry all night. Behold, the day grows to an end, lodge here that thy heart may be merry,  tomorrow get early on your way that thou may go home.
Judg. But the man would not tarry that night,  he rose up and departed,  came opposite Jebus (the same is Jerusalem). And there were with him a couple of saddled donkeys. His concubine was also with him.
Judg. When they were by Jebus, the day was far spent,  the servant said to his master, Come, I pray thee,  let us turn aside into this city of the Jebusites,  lodge in it.
Judg. And his master said to him, We will not turn aside into the city of a foreigner that is not of the sons of Israel,  we will pass over to Gibeah.
Judg. And he said to his servant, Come and let us draw near to one of these places,  we will lodge in Gibeah, or in Ramah.
Judg. So they passed on and went their way. And the sun went down upon them near to Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin.
Judg. And they turned aside there, to go in to lodge in Gibeah. And he went in,  sat down in the street of the city, for there was no man that took them into his house to lodge.
Judg. And, behold, there came an old man from his work out of the field at evening. Now the man was of the hill-country of Ephraim,  he sojourned in Gibeah,  the men of the place were Benjamites.
Judg. And he lifted up his eyes,  saw the wayfaring man in the street of the city. And the old man said, Where do thou go? And from where do thou come?
Judg. And he said to him, We are passing from Bethlehem-judah to the farther side of the hill-country of Ephraim. I am from there,  I went to Bethlehem-judah. And I am now going to the house of Jehovah,  there is no man that takes me into his house.
Judg. Yet there is both straw and provender for our donkeys,  there is bread and wine also for me,  for thy handmaid,  for the young man who is with thy servants. There is no want of anything.
Judg. And the old man said, Peace be to thee. However let all thy wants lie upon me, only do not lodge in the street.
Judg. So he brought him into his house,  gave the donkeys fodder. And they washed their feet,  ate and drank.
Judg. As they were making their hearts merry, behold, the men of the city, certain base fellows, beset the house round about, beating at the door. And they spoke to the master of the house, the old man, saying, Bring forth the man who came into thy house, that we may know him.
Judg. And the man, the master of the house, went out to them,  said to them, No, my brothers, I pray you, do not so wickedly, seeing that this man has come into my house. Do not this folly.
Judg. Behold, here is my daughter a virgin,  his concubine. I will bring them out now,  humble ye them,  do with them what seems good to you,  to this man do not any such folly.
Judg. But the men would not hearken to him. So the man laid hold on his concubine,  brought her forth to them. And they knew her,  abused her all the night until the morning,  when the day began to spring, they let her go.
Judg. Then the woman came in the dawning of the day,  fell down at the door of the man's house where her lord was, till it was light.
Judg. And her lord rose up in the morning,  opened the doors of the house,  went out to go his way, , behold, the woman his concubine was fallen down at the door of the house, with her hands upon the threshold.
Judg. And he said to her, Up,  let us be going,  there was no answering. Then he took her up upon the donkey,  the man rose up,  got to his place.
Judg. And when he came into his house, he took a knife,  laid hold on his concubine,  divided her, limb by limb, into twelve pieces,  sent her throughout all the borders of Israel.
Judg. And it was so, that all who saw it said, There was no such deed done nor seen from the day that the sons of Israel came up out of the land of Egypt to this day. Consider it, take counsel,  speak.
Judg. Then all the sons of Israel went out. And the congregation was assembled as one man, from Dan even to Beersheba, with the land of Gilead, to Jehovah at Mizpah.
Judg. And the chiefs of all the people, even of all the tribes of Israel, presented themselves in the assembly of the people of God, four hundred thousand footmen who drew a sword.
Judg. (Now the sons of Benjamin heard that the sons of Israel had gone up to Mizpah.) And the sons of Israel said, Tell us, how was this wickedness brought to pass?
Judg. And the Levite, the husband of the woman who was murdered, answered and said, I came into Gibeah that belongs to Benjamin, I and my concubine, to lodge.
Judg. And the men of Gibeah rose against me,  beset the house round about me by night. They thought to have me slain,  they forced my concubine,  she is dead.
Judg. And I took my concubine,  cut her in pieces,  sent her throughout all the country of the inheritance of Israel, for they have committed lewdness and folly in Israel.
Judg. Behold, ye sons of Israel, all of you, give here your advice and counsel.
Judg. And all the people arose as one man, saying, We will not any of us go to his tent, neither will we any of us turn to his house.
Judg. But now this is the thing which we will do to Gibeah: We will go up against it by lot,
Judg. and we will take ten men of a hundred throughout all the tribes of Israel,  a hundred of a thousand,  a thousand out of ten thousand, to fetch provision for the people, that they may do, when they come to Gibeah of Benjamin, according to all the folly that they have wrought in Israel.
Judg. So all the men of Israel were gathered against the city, knit together as one man.
Judg. And the tribes of Israel sent men through all the tribe of Benjamin, saying, What wickedness is this that has come to pass among you?
Judg. Now therefore deliver up the men, the base fellows, who are in Gibeah, that we may put them to death,  put away evil from Israel. But Benjamin would not hearken to the voice of their brothers the sons of Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin gathered themselves together out of the cities to Gibeah, to go out to battle against the sons of Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin were numbered on that day out of the cities twenty-six thousand men who drew a sword, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah, who were numbered seven hundred chosen men.
Judg. Among all this people there were seven hundred chosen men left-handed. Every one could sling stones at a hair-breadth,  not miss.
Judg. And the men of Israel, besides Benjamin, were numbered four hundred thousand men who drew a sword. All these were men of war.
Judg. And the sons of Israel arose,  went up to Bethel,  asked counsel of God. And they said, Who shall go up for us first to battle against the sons of Benjamin? And Jehovah said, Judah first.
Judg. And the sons of Israel rose up in the morning,  encamped against Gibeah.
Judg. And the men of Israel went out to battle against Benjamin. And the men of Israel set the battle in array against them at Gibeah.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin came forth out of Gibeah,  destroyed down to the ground of the Israelites on that day twenty-two thousand men.
Judg. And the people, the men of Israel, encouraged themselves,  set the battle again in array in the place where they set themselves in array the first day.
Judg. And the sons of Israel went up and wept before Jehovah until evening. And they asked of Jehovah, saying, Shall I again draw near to battle against the sons of Benjamin my brother? And Jehovah said, Go up against him.
Judg. And the sons of Israel came near against the sons of Benjamin the second day.
Judg. And Benjamin went forth against them out of Gibeah the second day,  destroyed down to the ground of the sons of Israel again eighteen thousand men. All these drew the sword.
Judg. Then all the sons of Israel,  all the people, went up,  came to Bethel,  wept,  sat there before Jehovah,  fasted that day until evening,  they offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before Jehovah.
Judg. And the sons of Israel asked of Jehovah (for the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days,
Judg. and Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it in those days), saying, Shall I yet again go out to battle against the sons of Benjamin my brother, or shall I cease? And Jehovah said, Go up, for tomorrow I will deliver him into thy hand.
Judg. And Israel set an ambushment against Gibeah round about.
Judg. And the sons of Israel went up against the sons of Benjamin on the third day,  set themselves in array against Gibeah, as at other times.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin went out against the people,  were drawn away from the city. And they began to smite and kill of the people as at other times, in the highways, of which one goes up to Bethel,  the other to Gibeah, in the field about thirty men of Israel.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin said, They are smitten down before us as at the first. But the sons of Israel said, Let us flee,  draw them away from the city to the highways.
Judg. And all the men of Israel rose up out of their place,  set themselves in array at Baal-tamar,  the ambushment of Israel broke forth out of their place, even out of Maareh-geba.
Judg. And there came opposite Gibeah ten thousand chosen men out of all Israel,  the battle was severe,  they knew not that evil was close upon them.
Judg. And Jehovah smote Benjamin before Israel,  the sons of Israel destroyed of Benjamin that day twenty-five thousand and a hundred men. All these drew the sword.
Judg. So the sons of Benjamin saw that they were smitten, for the men of Israel gave place to Benjamin because they trusted to the ambushment whom they had set against Gibeah.
Judg. And the ambushment hastened,  rushed upon Gibeah. And the ambushment drew themselves along,  smote all the city with the edge of the sword.
Judg. Now the appointed sign between the men of Israel and the ambushment was, that they should make a great cloud of smoke rise up out of the city.
Judg. And the men of Israel turned in the battle,  Benjamin began to smite and kill of the men of Israel about thirty persons, for they said, Surely they are smitten down before us as in the first battle.
Judg. But when the cloud began to arise up out of the city in a pillar of smoke, the Benjamites looked behind them, , behold, the whole of the city went up in smoke to heaven.
Judg. And the men of Israel turned,  the men of Benjamin were dismayed, for they saw that evil had come upon them.
Judg. Therefore they turned their backs before the men of Israel to the way of the wilderness. But the battle followed hard after them,  those who came out of the cities destroyed them in the midst of it.
Judg. They enclosed the Benjamites round about,  chased them,  trod them down at their resting-place, as far as opposite Gibeah toward the sunrise.
Judg. And there fell of Benjamin eighteen thousand men. All these were men of valor.
Judg. And they turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon. And they gleaned of them in the highways five thousand men,  followed hard after them to Gidom,  smote of them two thousand men.
Judg. So that all who fell that day of Benjamin were twenty-five thousand men who drew the sword. All these were men of valor.
Judg. But six hundred men turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon,  abode in the rock of Rimmon four months.
Judg. And the men of Israel turned again upon the sons of Benjamin,  smote them with the edge of the sword, both the entire city,  the cattle,  all that they found. Moreover they set on fire all the cities which they found.
Judg. Now the men of Israel had sworn in Mizpah, saying, There shall not any of us give his daughter to Benjamin to wife.
Judg. And the people came to Bethel,  sat there till evening before God,  lifted up their voices,  wept bitterly.
Judg. And they said, O Jehovah, the God of Israel, why has this come to pass in Israel, that there should be today one tribe lacking in Israel?
Judg. And it came to pass on the morrow, that the people rose early,  built there an altar,  offered burnt offerings and peace offerings.
Judg. And the sons of Israel said, Who is there among all the tribes of Israel that did not come up in the assembly to Jehovah? For they had made a great oath concerning him who did not come up to Jehovah to Mizpah, saying, He shall surely be put to death.
Judg. And the sons of Israel regretted for Benjamin their brother,  said, There is one tribe cut off from Israel this day.
Judg. What shall we do for wives for those who remain, since we have sworn by Jehovah that we will not give them of our daughters to wives?
Judg. And they said, Which one is there of the tribes of Israel that did not come up to Jehovah to Mizpah? And, behold, there came none to the camp from Jabesh-gilead to the assembly.
Judg. For when the people were numbered, behold, there were none of the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead there.
Judg. And the congregation sent there twelve thousand men of the most valiant,  commanded them, saying, Go and smite the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead with the edge of the sword, with the women and the little ones.
Judg. And this is the thing that ye shall do: Ye shall utterly destroy every male,  every woman that has lain by man.
Judg. And they found among the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead four hundred young virgins who had not known man by lying with him,  they brought them to the camp to Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan.
Judg. And the whole congregation sent and spoke to the sons of Benjamin who were in the rock of Rimmon,  proclaimed peace to them.
Judg. And Benjamin returned at that time,  they gave them the women whom they had saved alive of the women of Jabesh-gilead. And even so they were not sufficient for them.
Judg. And the people regretted for Benjamin, because Jehovah had made a breach in the tribes of Israel.
Judg. Then the elders of the congregation said, What shall we do for wives for those who remain, since the women are destroyed out of Benjamin?
Judg. And they said, There must be an inheritance for those who are escaped of Benjamin, that a tribe be not blotted out from Israel.
Judg. However we may not give them wives of our daughters, for the sons of Israel had sworn, saying, Cursed be he who gives a wife to Benjamin.
Judg. And they said, Behold, there is a feast of Jehovah from year to year in Shiloh, which is on the north of Bethel, on the east side of the highway that goes up from Bethel to Shechem,  on the south of Lebonah.
Judg. And they commanded the sons of Benjamin, saying, Go and lie in wait in the vineyards,
Judg. and watch. And, behold, if the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance in the dances, then come ye out of the vineyards,  catch for you every man his wife from the daughters of Shiloh,  go to the land of Benjamin.
Judg. And it shall be, when their fathers or their brothers come to complain to us, that we will say to them, Grant them graciously to us, because we took not for each man of them his wife in battle, neither did ye give them to them, else ye would now be guilty.
Judg. And the sons of Benjamin did so,  took for them wives, according to their number, of those who danced, whom they carried off. And they went and returned to their inheritance,  built the cities,  dwelt in them.
Judg. And the sons of Israel departed from there at that time, every man to his tribe and to his family,  they went out from there every man to his inheritance.
Judg. In those days there was no king in Israel. Every man did that which was right in his own eyes.
Ruth
Ruth. And it came to pass in the days when the judges judged, that there was a famine in the land. And a certain man of Bethlehem-judah went to sojourn in the country of Moab, he,  his wife,  his two sons.
Ruth. And the name of the man was Elimelech,  the name of his wife Naomi,  the name of his two sons Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites of Bethlehem-judah. And they came into the country of Moab,  continued there.
Ruth. And Elimelech, Naomi's husband, died,  she was left,  her two sons.
Ruth. And they took wives for them of the women of Moab. The name of the one was Orpah,  the name of the other Ruth,  they dwelt there about ten years.
Ruth. And Mahlon and Chilion died, both of them,  the woman was left of her two children and of her husband.
Ruth. Then she arose with her daughters-in-law that she might return from the country of Moab, for she had heard in the country of Moab how that Jehovah had visited his people in giving them bread.
Ruth. And she went forth out of the place where she was,  her two daughters-in-law with her,  they went on the way to return to the land of Judah.
Ruth. And Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, Go, return each of you to her mother's house. Jehovah deal kindly with you, as ye have dealt with the dead,  with me.
Ruth. Jehovah grant you that ye may find rest, each of you in the house of her husband. Then she kissed them,  they lifted up their voices,  wept.
Ruth. And they said to her, No,  we will return with thee to thy people.
Ruth. And Naomi said, Turn again, my daughters. Why will ye go with me? Have I yet sons in my womb, that they may be your husbands?
Ruth. Turn again, my daughters. Go your way, for I am too old to have a husband. If I should say, I have hope. If I should even have a husband tonight,  should also bear sons,
Ruth. would ye therefore delay till they were grown? Would ye therefore stay from having husbands? No, my daughters, for it grieves me much for your sakes, for the hand of Jehovah has gone forth against me.
Ruth. And they lifted up their voices,  wept again. And Orpah kissed her mother-in-law,  Ruth clung to her.
Ruth. And she said, Behold, thy sister-in-law has gone back to her people,  to her god. Return thou after thy sister-in-law.
Ruth. And Ruth said, Entreat me not to leave thee,  to return from following after thee, for where thou go, I will go,  where thou lodge, I will lodge. Thy people shall be my people,  thy God my God.
Ruth. Where thou die, I will die,  there I will be buried. Jehovah do so to me,  more also, if anything but death parts thee and me.
Ruth. And when she saw that she was steadfastly minded to go with her, she left off speaking to her.
Ruth. So those two went until they came to Bethlehem. And it came to pass, when they came to Bethlehem, that all the city was moved about them,  the women said, Is this Naomi?
Ruth. And she said to them, Call me not Naomi. Call me Mara, for the Almighty has dealt very bitterly with me.
Ruth. I went out full,  Jehovah has brought me home again empty. Why do ye call me Naomi, seeing Jehovah has testified against me,  the Almighty has afflicted me?
Ruth. So Naomi returned,  Ruth the Moabitess, her daughter-in-law, with her, who returned out of the country of Moab. And they came to Bethlehem in the beginning of barley harvest.
Ruth. And Naomi had a kinsman of her husband's, a mighty man of wealth, of the family of Elimelech,  his name was Boaz.
Ruth. And Ruth the Moabitess said to Naomi, Let me now go to the field,  glean among the ears of grain after him in whose sight I shall find favor. And she said to her, Go, my daughter.
Ruth. And she went,  came and gleaned in the field after the reapers. And her chance was to land on the portion of the field belonging to Boaz, who was of the family of Elimelech.
Ruth. And, behold, Boaz came from Bethlehem,  said to the reapers, Jehovah be with you. And they answered him, Jehovah bless thee.
Ruth. Then Boaz said to his servant who was set over the reapers, Whose damsel is this?
Ruth. And the servant who was set over the reapers answered and said, It is the Moabite damsel who came back with Naomi out of the country of Moab.
Ruth. And she said, Let me glean, I pray you,  gather behind the reapers among the sheaves. So she came,  has continued even from the morning until now, except that she tarried a little in the house.
Ruth. Then Boaz said to Ruth, Do thou not hear, my daughter? Go not to glean in another field, neither pass from here,  abide here close by my maidens.
Ruth. Let thine eyes be on the field that they reap,  go thou after them. Have I not charged the young men that they shall not touch thee? And when thou are thirsty, go to the vessels,  drink of that which the young men have drawn.
Ruth. Then she fell on her face,  bowed herself to the ground,  said to him, Why have I found favor in thy sight that thou should take knowledge of me, seeing I am a foreigner?
Ruth. And Boaz answered and said to her, It has been fully shown me all that thou have done to thy mother-in-law since the death of thy husband,  how thou have left thy father and thy mother,  the land of thy nativity,  have come to a people that thou knew not formerly.
Ruth. Jehovah recompense thy work,  a full reward be given thee of Jehovah, the God of Israel, under whose wings thou have come to take refuge.
Ruth. Then she said, Let me find favor in thy sight, my lord, because thou have comforted me,  because thou have spoken kindly to thy handmaid, though I be not as one of thy handmaidens.
Ruth. And at mealtime Boaz said to her, Come here,  eat of the bread,  dip thy morsel in the vinegar. And she sat beside the reapers,  they passed her parched grain,  she ate,  was satisfied,  left of it.
Ruth. And when she arose up to glean, Boaz commanded his young men, saying, Let her glean even among the sheaves,  do not reproach her.
Ruth. And also pull out some for her from the bundles,  leave it,  let her glean,  do not rebuke her.
Ruth. So she gleaned in the field until evening. And she beat out that which she had gleaned,  it was about an ephah of barley.
Ruth. And she took it up,  went into the city,  her mother-in-law saw what she had gleaned. And she brought forth and gave to her that which she had left after she was satisfied.
Ruth. And her mother-in-law said to her, Where have thou gleaned today? And where have thou worked? Blessed be he who took knowledge of thee. And she showed her mother-in-law with whom she had worked,  said, The man's name with whom I worked today is Boaz.
Ruth. And Naomi said to her daughter-in-law, Blessed be he of Jehovah who has not left off his kindness to the living and to the dead. And Naomi said to her, The man is near of kin to us, one of our near kinsmen.
Ruth. And Ruth the Moabitess said, Yes, he said to me, Thou shall keep close by my young men until they have ended all my harvest.
Ruth. And Naomi said to Ruth her daughter-in-law, It is good, my daughter, that thou go out with his maidens,  that they not meet thee in any other field.
Ruth. So she kept close by the maidens of Boaz, to glean to the end of barley harvest and of wheat harvest. And she dwelt with her mother-in-law.
Ruth. And Naomi her mother-in-law said to her, My daughter, shall I not seek rest for thee, that it may be well with thee?
Ruth. And now is not Boaz our kinsman, with whose maidens thou were? Behold, he winnows barley tonight in the threshing-floor.
Ruth. Wash thyself therefore,  anoint thee,  put thy raiment upon thee,  get thee down to the threshing-floor. But do not make thyself known to the man until he shall have done eating and drinking.
Ruth. And it shall be, when he lies down, that thou shall notice the place where he shall lie. And thou shall go in,  uncover his feet,  lie thee down. And he will tell thee what thou shall do.
Ruth. And she said to her, All that thou say I will do.
Ruth. And she went down to the threshing-floor,  did according to all that her mother-in-law bade her.
Ruth. And when Boaz had eaten and drunk,  his heart was merry, he went to lie down at the end of the heap of grain. And she came softly,  uncovered his feet,  laid down.
Ruth. And it came to pass at midnight, that the man was startled,  turned himself, , behold, a woman lay at his feet.
Ruth. And he said, Who are thou? And she answered, I am Ruth thy handmaid. Spread therefore thy skirt over thy handmaid, for thou are a near kinsman.
Ruth. And he said, Blessed be thou of Jehovah, my daughter. Thou have shown more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning, inasmuch as thou did not follow young men, whether poor or rich.
Ruth. And now, my daughter, fear not. I will do to thee all that thou say, for all the city of my people know that thou are a worthy woman.
Ruth. And now it is true that I am a near kinsman. However there is a kinsman nearer than I.
Ruth. Remain this night,  it shall be in the morning that if he will perform to thee the part of a kinsman, well; let him do the kinsman's part. But if he will not do the part of a kinsman to thee, then I will do the part of a kinsman to thee, as Jehovah lives. Lie down until the morning.
Ruth. And she lay at his feet until the morning. And she rose up before one could discern another. For he said, Let it not be known that the woman came to the threshing-floor.
Ruth. And he said, Bring the mantle that is upon thee,  hold it. And she held it,  he measured six measures of barley,  laid it on her,  he went into the city.
Ruth. And when she came to her mother-in-law, she said, Who are thou, my daughter? And she told her all that the man had done to her.
Ruth. And she said, He gave me these six measures of barley, for he said, Go not empty to thy mother-in-law.
Ruth. Then she said, Sit still, my daughter, until thou know how the matter will fall, for the man will not rest until he has finished the thing this day.
Ruth. Now Boaz went up to the gate,  sat down there. And, behold, the near kinsman of whom Boaz spoke came by, to whom he said, Such man, stay, turn aside. Sit down here. And he turned aside,  sat down.
Ruth. And he took ten men of the elders of the city,  said, Sit ye down here. And they sat down.
Ruth. And he said to the near kinsman, Naomi, who has come again out of the country of Moab, sells the parcel of land, which was our brother Elimelech's.
Ruth. And I thought to disclose it to thee, saying, Buy it before those who sit here,  before the elders of my people. If thou will redeem it, redeem it,  if thou will not redeem it, then tell me that I may know, for there is none to redeem it besides thee,  I am after thee. And he said, I will redeem it.
Ruth. Then Boaz said, That day thou buy the field of the hand of Naomi, thou must buy it also of Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of the dead, to raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance.
Ruth. And the near kinsman said, I cannot redeem it for myself lest I mar my own inheritance. Take thou my right of redemption on thee, for I cannot redeem it.
Ruth. Now this was the custom in former time in Israel concerning redeeming and concerning exchanging, to confirm all things: A man drew off his shoe,  gave it to his neighbor. And this was the manner of attestation in Israel.
Ruth. So the near kinsman said to Boaz, Buy it for thyself. And he drew off his shoe.
Ruth. And Boaz said to the elders,  to all the people, Ye are witnesses this day, that I have bought all that was Elimelech's,  all that was Chilion's and Mahlon's, from the hand of Naomi.
Ruth. Moreover Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of Mahlon, I have purchased to be my wife, to raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance, that the name of the dead not be cut off from among his brothers,  from the gate of his place. Ye are witnesses this day.
Ruth. And all the people who were in the gate,  the elders, said, We are witnesses. Jehovah make the woman that has come into thy house like Rachel and like Leah, which two built the house of Israel,  do thou worthily in Ephrathah,  be famous in Bethlehem.
Ruth. And let thy house be like the house of Perez whom Tamar bore to Judah, of the seed which Jehovah shall give thee by this young woman.
Ruth. So Boaz took Ruth,  she became his wife. And he went in to her,  Jehovah gave her conception,  she bore a son.
Ruth. And the women said to Naomi, Blessed be Jehovah, who has not left thee this day without a near kinsman. And let his name be famous in Israel.
Ruth. And he shall be to thee a restorer of life,  a nourisher of thine old age, for thy daughter-in-law, who loves thee, who is better to thee than seven sons, has borne him.
Ruth. And Naomi took the child,  laid it in her bosom,  became nurse to it.
Ruth. And the women, her neighbors, gave it a name, saying, There is a son born to Naomi. And they called his name Obed. He is the father of Jesse, the father of David.
Ruth. Now these are the generations of Perez: Perez begot Hezron,
Ruth. and Hezron begot Ram,  Ram begot Amminadab,
Ruth. and Amminadab begot Nahshon,  Nahshon begot Salmon,
Ruth. and Salmon begot Boaz,  Boaz begot Obed,
Ruth. and Obed begot Jesse,  Jesse begot David.
I Samuel
Now there was a certain man of Ramathaim-zophim of the hill-country of Ephraim. And his name was Elkanah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
And he had two wives: the name of the one was Hannah,  the name of the other Peninnah. And Peninnah had children,  Hannah had no children.
And this man went up out of his city from year to year to worship and to sacrifice to Jehovah of hosts in Shiloh. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, priests to Jehovah, were there.
And when the day came that Elkanah sacrificed, he gave to Peninnah his wife,  to all her sons and her daughters, portions,
but to Hannah he gave a double portion, for he loved Hannah,  Jehovah had shut up her womb.
And her rival provoked her greatly, to make her fret, because Jehovah had shut up her womb.
And as he did so year by year when she went up to the house of Jehovah, so she provoked her. Therefore she wept,  did not eat.
And Elkanah her husband said to her, Hannah, why do thou weep? And why do thou not eat? And why is thy heart grieved? Am not I better to thee than ten sons?
So Hannah rose up after they had eaten in Shiloh,  after they had drunk. Now Eli the priest was sitting upon his seat by the door-post of the temple of Jehovah.
And she was in bitterness of soul,  prayed to Jehovah,  wept much.
And she vowed a vow,  said, O Jehovah of hosts, if thou will indeed look on the affliction of thy handmaid,  remember me,  not forget thy handmaid,  will give to thy handmaid a man-child, then I will give him to Jehovah all the days of his life,  there shall no razor come upon his head.
And it came to pass, as she continued praying before Jehovah, that Eli noticed her mouth.
Now Hannah, she spoke in her heart; only her lips moved,  her voice was not heard. Therefore Eli thought she was drunk.
And Eli said to her, How long will thou be drunken? Put away thy wine from thee.
And Hannah answered and said, No, my lord, I am a woman of a sorrowful spirit. I have drunk neither wine nor strong drink,  I poured out my soul before Jehovah.
Count not thy handmaid for an iniquitous woman, for out of the abundance of my complaint and my provocation have I spoken until now.
Then Eli answered and said, Go in peace,  the God of Israel grant thy petition that thou have asked of him.
And she said, Let thy handmaid find favor in thy sight. So the woman went her way,  ate,  her countenance was no more sad.
And they rose up in the morning early,  worshiped before Jehovah,  returned,  came to their house to Ramah. And Elkanah knew Hannah his wife,  Jehovah remembered her.
And it came to pass, when the time came about, that Hannah conceived,  bore a son. And she called his name Samuel, saying, Because I have asked him of Jehovah.
And the man Elkanah,  all his house, went up to offer to Jehovah the yearly sacrifice,  his vow.
But Hannah did not go up, for she said to her husband, Not until the child be weaned,  then I will bring him, that he may appear before Jehovah,  abide there forever.
And Elkanah her husband said to her, Do what seems good to thee. Remain until thou have weaned him, only Jehovah establish his word. So the woman remained and gave her son suck, until she weaned him.
And when she had weaned him, she took him up with her, with three bullocks,  one ephah of meal,  a bottle of wine,  brought him to the house of Jehovah in Shiloh,  the child was young.
And they killed the bullock,  brought the child to Eli.
And she said, Oh, my lord, as thy soul lives, my lord, I am the woman who stood by thee here, praying to Jehovah.
I prayed for this child,  Jehovah has given me my petition which I asked of him.
Therefore also I have granted him to Jehovah; as long as he lives he is granted to Jehovah. And he worshiped Jehovah there.
And Hannah prayed,  said, My heart exults in Jehovah. My horn is exalted in Jehovah. My mouth is enlarged over my enemies because I rejoice in thy salvation.
There is none holy as Jehovah, for there is none besides thee, neither is there any rock like our God.
Talk no more so very proudly. Let not arrogancy come out of your mouth, for Jehovah is a God of knowledge,  by him actions are weighed.
The bows of the mighty men are broken,  those who stumbled are girded with strength.
Those who were full have hired out themselves for bread,  those who were hungry have ceased to hunger. Yea, the barren has borne seven,  she who has many sons languishes.
Jehovah kills,  makes alive. He brings down to Sheol,  brings up.
Jehovah makes poor,  makes rich. He brings low, he also lifts up.
He raises up the poor out of the dust, he lifts up the needy from the dunghill, to make them sit with rulers,  inherit the throne of glory. For the pillars of the earth are Jehovah's,  he has set the world upon them.
He will keep the feet of his holy ones,  the wicked shall be put to silence in darkness, for by strength no man shall prevail.
Those who strive with Jehovah shall be broken to pieces. He will thunder against them in heaven. Jehovah will judge the ends of the earth,  he will give strength to his king,  exalt the horn of his anointed.
And Elkanah went to Ramah to his house,  the child ministered to Jehovah before Eli the priest.
Now the sons of Eli were base men; they knew not Jehovah.
And the custom of the priests with the people was, that, when any man offered sacrifice, the priest's servant came, while the flesh was boiling, with a flesh-hook of three teeth in his hand,
and he struck it into the pan, or kettle, or caldron, or pot. All that the flesh-hook brought up the priest took with it. So they did in Shiloh to all the Israelites who came there.
And before they burned the fat, the priest's servant came,  said to the man who sacrificed, Give flesh to roast for the priest, for he will not have boiled flesh from thee,  raw.
And if the man said to him, They will surely burn the fat first,  then take as much as thy soul desires, then he would say, No,  thou shall give it to me now,  if not, I will take it by force.
And the sin of the young men was very great before Jehovah, for the men despised the offering of Jehovah.
But Samuel ministered before Jehovah, being a child, girded with a linen ephod.
Moreover his mother made him a little robe,  brought it to him from year to year when she came up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.
And Eli blessed Elkanah and his wife,  said, Jehovah give thee seed by this woman for the petition which was asked of Jehovah. And they went to their own home.
And Jehovah visited Hannah,  she conceived,  bore three sons and two daughters. And the child Samuel grew before Jehovah.
Now Eli was very old. And he heard all that his sons did to all Israel,  how that they lay with the women who assembled at the door of the tent of meeting.
And he said to them, Why do ye such things? For I hear of your evil dealings from all this people.
No, my sons, for it is no good report that I hear. Ye make Jehovah's people to transgress.
If one man sins against another, God shall judge him,  if a man sins against Jehovah, who shall entreat for him? Notwithstanding, they did not hearken to the voice of their father, because Jehovah intended to kill them.
And the child Samuel grew on,  increased in favor both with Jehovah,  also with men.
And there came a man of God to Eli,  said to him, Thus says Jehovah, Did I reveal myself to the house of thy father when they were in Egypt in bondage to Pharaoh's house?
And did I choose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, to wear an ephod before me? And did I give to the house of thy father all the offerings of the sons of Israel made by fire?
Why do ye kick at my sacrifice and at my offering, which I have commanded in my habitation,  honor thy sons above me, to make yourselves fat with the chief of all the offerings of Israel my people?
Therefore Jehovah, the God of Israel, says, I said indeed that thy house,  the house of thy father, should walk before me forever,  now Jehovah says, Be it far from me, for those who honor me I will honor,  those who despise me shall be lightly esteemed.
Behold, the days come, that I will cut off thine arm,  the arm of thy father's house, that there shall not be an old man in thy house.
And thou shall see an enemy in my habitation, in all that I shall give Israel,  there shall not be an old man in thy house forever.
And the man of thine, whom I shall not cut off from my altar, shall be to consume thine eyes,  to grieve thy heart. And all the increase of thy house shall die in the flower of their age.
And this shall be the sign to thee, that shall come upon thy two sons, on Hophni and Phinehas: In one day they shall die, both of them.
And I will raise up for me a faithful priest who shall do according to that which is in my heart and in my mind. And I will build for him a sure house,  he shall walk before my anointed forever.
And it shall come to pass, that everyone who is left in thy house shall come and bow down to him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread,  shall say, Put me, I pray thee, into one of the priests' offices that I may eat a morsel of bread.
And the child Samuel served Jehovah before Eli. And the word of Jehovah was precious in those days; there was no frequent vision.
And it came to pass at that time, when Eli was laid down in his place (now his eyes had begun to grow dim so that he could not see),
and the lamp of God was not yet gone out,  Samuel was laid down in the temple of Jehovah where the ark of God was,
that Jehovah called Samuel. And he said, Here I am.
And he ran to Eli,  said, Here I am, for thou called me. And he said, I did not call. Lie down again. And he went and lay down.
And Jehovah called yet again, Samuel. And Samuel arose and went to Eli,  said, Here I am, for thou called me. And he answered, I did not call, my son. Lie down again.
Now Samuel did not yet know Jehovah, neither was the word of Jehovah yet revealed to him.
And Jehovah called Samuel again the third time. And he arose and went to Eli,  said, Here I am, for thou called me. And Eli perceived that Jehovah had called the child.
Therefore Eli said to Samuel, Go, lie down,  it shall be, if he calls thee, that thou shall say, Speak, Jehovah, for thy servant hears. So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
And Jehovah came,  stood,  called as at other times, Samuel, Samuel. Then Samuel said, Speak, for thy servant hears.
And Jehovah said to Samuel, Behold, I will do a thing in Israel at which both the ears of everyone who hears it shall tingle.
In that day I will perform against Eli all that I have spoken concerning his house, from the beginning even to the end.
For I have told him that I will judge his house forever, for the iniquity which he knew, because his sons brought a curse upon themselves,  he did not restrain them.
And therefore I have sworn to the house of Eli that the iniquity of Eli's house shall not be expiated with sacrifice nor offering forever.
And Samuel lay until the morning,  opened the doors of the house of Jehovah. And Samuel was afraid to show Eli the vision.
Then Eli called Samuel,  said, Samuel, my son. And he said, Here I am.
And he said, What is the thing that Jehovah has spoken to thee? I pray thee, hide it not from me. God do so to thee,  more also, if thou hide anything from me of all the things that he spoke to thee.
And Samuel told him every whit,  hid nothing from him. And he said, It is Jehovah. Let him do what seems him good.
And Samuel grew,  Jehovah was with him,  let none of his words fall to the ground.
And all Israel from Dan even to Beersheba knew that Samuel was established to be a prophet of Jehovah.
And Jehovah appeared again in Shiloh, for Jehovah revealed himself to Samuel in Shiloh by the word of Jehovah.
And the word of Samuel came to all Israel. Now Israel went out against the Philistines to battle,  encamped beside Ebenezer,  the Philistines encamped in Aphek.
And the Philistines put themselves in array against Israel. And when they joined battle, Israel was smitten before the Philistines; and they killed of the army in the field about four thousand men.
And when the people came into the camp, the elders of Israel said, Why has Jehovah smitten us today before the Philistines? Let us fetch the ark of the covenant of Jehovah out of Shiloh to us, that it may come among us,  save us out of the hand of our enemies.
So the people sent to Shiloh,  they brought from there the ark of the covenant of Jehovah of hosts, who sits above the cherubim. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
And when the ark of the covenant of Jehovah came into the camp, all Israel shouted with a great shout, so that the earth rang again.
And when the Philistines heard the noise of the shout, they said, What is the meaning of the noise of this great shout in the camp of the Hebrews? And they understood that the ark of Jehovah came into the camp.
And the Philistines were afraid, for they said, God has come into the camp. And they said, Woe to us! For there has not been such a thing heretofore.
Woe to us! Who shall deliver us out of the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods that smote the Egyptians with all manner of plagues in the wilderness.
Be strong,  strengthen yourselves like men, O ye Philistines, that ye be not servants to the Hebrews, as they have been to you. Conduct yourselves like men,  fight.
And the Philistines fought,  Israel was smitten,  they fled every man to his tent. And there was a very great slaughter, for there fell of Israel thirty thousand footmen.
And the ark of God was taken,  the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were killed.
And there ran a man of Benjamin out of the army,  came to Shiloh the same day, with his clothes torn,  with dirt upon his head.
And when he came, lo, Eli was sitting upon his seat by the wayside watching, for his heart trembled for the ark of God. And when the man came into the city,  told it, all the city cried out.
And when Eli heard the noise of the crying, he said, What does the noise of this tumult mean? And the man hastened,  came and told Eli.
Now Eli was ninety-eight years old,  his eyes were dim so that he could not see.
And the man said to Eli, I am he who came out of the army,  I fled today out of the army. And he said, How did the matter go, my son?
And he who brought the news answered and said, Israel has fled before the Philistines,  there has been also a great slaughter among the people. And thy two sons also, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead,  the ark of God is taken.
And it came to pass, when he made mention of the ark of God, that Eli fell from off his seat backward by the side of the gate. And his neck broke,  he died, for he was an old man,  heavy. And he had judged Israel forty years.
And his daughter-in-law, Phinehas' wife, was with child, near to be delivered. And when she heard the news that the ark of God was taken,  that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she bowed herself and brought forth, for her pains came upon her.
And about the time of her death the women who stood by her said to her, Fear not, for thou have brought forth a son. But she did not answer, neither did she regard it.
And she named the child Ichabod, saying, The glory has departed from Israel, because the ark of God was taken,  because of her father-in-law and her husband.
And she said, The glory has departed from Israel, for the ark of God is taken.
Now the Philistines had taken the ark of God,  they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
And the Philistines took the ark of God,  brought it into the house of Dagon,  set it by Dagon.
And when those of Ashdod arose early on the morrow, behold, Dagon was fallen upon his face to the ground before the ark of Jehovah. And they took Dagon,  set him in his place again.
And when they arose early on the morning of the morrow, behold, Dagon was fallen upon his face to the ground before the ark of Jehovah,  the head of Dagon and both the palms of his hands lay cut off upon the threshold. Only the stump of Dagon was left to him.
Therefore neither the priests of Dagon, nor any who come into Dagon's house, tread on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod, to this day.
But the hand of Jehovah was heavy upon them of Ashdod,  he destroyed them,  smote them with tumors, even Ashdod and the borders of it.
And when the men of Ashdod saw that it was so, they said, The ark of the God of Israel shall not abide with us, for his hand is hard upon us,  upon Dagon our god.
They sent therefore and gathered all the lords of the Philistines to them,  said, What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel? And they answered, Let the ark of the God of Israel be carried about to Gath. And they carried the ark of the God of Israel there.
And it was so, that, after they had carried it about, the hand of Jehovah was against the city with a very great discomfiture. And he smote the men of the city, both small and great,  tumors broke out upon them.
So they sent the ark of God to Ekron. And it came to pass, as the ark of God came to Ekron, that the Ekronites cried out, saying, They have brought about the ark of the God of Israel to us, to kill us and our people.
They sent therefore and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines,  they said, Send away the ark of the God of Israel,  let it go again to its own place, that it not kill us and our people. For there was a deadly discomfiture throughout all the city; the hand of God was very heavy there.
And the men who did not die were smitten with the tumors,  the cry of the city went up to heaven.
And the ark of Jehovah was in the country of the Philistines seven months.
And the Philistines called for the priests and the psychics, saying, What shall we do with the ark of Jehovah? Show us with what we shall sent it to its place.
And they said, If ye send away the ark of the God of Israel, do not send it empty,  by all means return for him a trespass offering. Then ye shall be healed,  it shall be known to you why his hand is not removed from you.
Then they said, What shall be the trespass offering which we shall return to him? And they said, Five golden tumors,  five golden mice, according to the number of the lords of the Philistines, for one plague was on you all,  on your lords.
Therefore ye shall make images of your tumors,  images of your mice that mar the land. And ye shall give glory to the God of Israel. Perhaps he will lighten his hand from off you,  from off your gods,  from off your land.
Why then do ye harden your hearts as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? When he had wrought wonderfully among them, did they not let the people go,  they departed?
Now therefore take and prepare for you a new cart,  two milk cows on which there has come no yoke. And tie the cows to the cart,  bring their calves home from them.
And take the ark of Jehovah,  lay it upon the cart. And put the jewels of gold, which ye return to him for a trespass offering, in a coffer by the side of it,  send it away, that it may go.
And watch. If it goes up by the way of its own border to Beth-shemesh, then he has done to us this great evil,  if not, then we shall know that it is not his hand that smote us; it was a chance that happened to us.
And the men did so,  took two milk cows,  tied them to the cart,  shut up their calves at home.
And they put the ark of Jehovah upon the cart,  the coffer with the mice of gold and the images of their tumors.
And the cows took the straight way by the way to Beth-shemesh. They went along the highway, lowing as they went,  turned not aside to the right hand or to the left. And the lords of the Philistines went behind them to the border of Beth-shemesh.
And those of Beth-shemesh were reaping their wheat harvest in the valley. And they lifted up their eyes,  saw the ark,  rejoiced to see it.
And the cart came into the field of Joshua the Beth-shemite,  stood there where there was a great stone. And they split the wood of the cart,  offered up the cows for a burnt offering to Jehovah.
And the Levites took down the ark of Jehovah,  the coffer that was with it, in which the jewels of gold were,  put them on the great stone. And the men of Beth-shemesh offered burnt offerings and sacrificed sacrifices the same day to Jehovah.
And when the five lords of the Philistines had seen it, they returned to Ekron the same day.
And these are the golden tumors which the Philistines returned for a trespass offering to Jehovah: for Ashdod one, for Gaza one, for Ashkelon one, for Gath one, for Ekron one.
And the golden mice, according to the number of all the cities of the Philistines belonging to the five lords, both of fortified cities and of country villages, even to the great stone on which they set down the ark of Jehovah, which stone remains to this day in the field of Joshua the Beth-shemite.
And he smote of the men of Beth-shemesh, because they had looked into the ark of Jehovah. He smote of the people fifty thousand and seventy men. And the people mourned, because Jehovah had smitten the people with a great slaughter.
And the men of Beth-shemesh said, Who is able to stand before Jehovah, this holy God? And to whom shall he go up from us?
And they sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kiriath-jearim, saying, The Philistines have brought back the ark of Jehovah. Come ye down,  fetch it up to you.
And the men of Kiriath-jearim came,  fetched up the ark of Jehovah,  brought it into the house of Abinadab in the hill,  sanctified Eleazar his son to keep the ark of Jehovah.
And it came to pass, from the day that the ark abode in Kiriath-jearim, that the time was long, for it was twenty years,  all the house of Israel lamented after Jehovah.
And Samuel spoke to all the house of Israel, saying, If ye do return to Jehovah with all your heart, then put away the foreign gods and the Ashtaroth from among you,  direct your hearts to Jehovah,  serve him only. And he will deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines.
Then the sons of Israel did put away the Baalim and the Ashtaroth,  served Jehovah only.
And Samuel said, Gather all Israel to Mizpah,  I will pray for you to Jehovah.
And they gathered together to Mizpah,  drew water,  poured it out before Jehovah,  fasted on that day,  said there, We have sinned against Jehovah. And Samuel judged the sons of Israel in Mizpah.
And when the Philistines heard that the sons of Israel were gathered together to Mizpah, the lords of the Philistines went up against Israel. And when the sons of Israel heard it, they were afraid of the Philistines.
And the sons of Israel said to Samuel, Do not cease to cry to Jehovah our God for us, that he will save us out of the hand of the Philistines.
And Samuel took a sucking lamb,  offered it for a whole burnt offering to Jehovah. And Samuel cried to Jehovah for Israel,  Jehovah answered him.
And as Samuel was offering up the burnt offering, the Philistines drew near to battle against Israel,  Jehovah thundered with a great thunder on that day upon the Philistines,  discomfited them,  they were smitten down before Israel.
And the men of Israel went out of Mizpah,  pursued the Philistines,  smote them until they came under Beth-car.
Then Samuel took a stone,  set it between Mizpah and Shen,  called the name of it Ebenezer, saying, Jehovah has helped us to now.
So the Philistines were subdued,  they came no more within the border of Israel,  the hand of Jehovah was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel.
And the cities which the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to Israel, from Ekron even to Gath. And Israel delivered the border of it out of the hand of the Philistines. And there was peace between Israel and the Amorites.
And Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life.
And he went from year to year in circuit to Bethel,  Gilgal,  Mizpah. And he judged Israel in all those places.
And his return was to Ramah, for his house was there. And there he judged Israel,  there he built an altar to Jehovah.
And it came to pass, when Samuel was old, that he made his sons judges over Israel.
Now the name of his firstborn was Joel,  the name of his second, Abijah. They were judges in Beersheba.
And his sons did not walk in his ways,  turned aside after dishonest gain,  took bribes,  perverted justice.
Then all the elders of Israel gathered themselves together,  came to Samuel to Ramah.
And they said to him, Behold, thou are old,  thy sons do not walk in thy ways. Now make for us a king to judge us like all the nations.
But the thing displeased Samuel when they said, Give us a king to judge us. And Samuel prayed to Jehovah.
And Jehovah said to Samuel, Hearken to the voice of the people in all that they say to thee, for they have not rejected thee,  they have rejected me, that I should not be king over them.
According to all the works which they have done since the day that I brought them up out of Egypt even to this day, in that they have forsaken me,  served other gods, so do they also to thee.
Now therefore hearken to their voice. However thou shall protest solemnly to them,  shall show them the manner of the king who shall reign over them.
And Samuel told all the words of Jehovah to the people who asked of him a king.
And he said, This will be the manner of the king who shall reign over you: He will take your sons,  appoint them to him for his chariots,  to be his horsemen,  they shall run before his chariots.
And he will appoint them to him for captains of thousands,  captains of fifties. And he will set some to plow his ground,  to reap his harvest,  to make his instruments of war,  the instruments of his chariots.
And he will take your daughters to be perfumers,  to be cooks,  to be bakers.
And he will take your fields,  your vineyards,  your oliveyards, even the best of them,  give them to his servants.
And he will take the tenth of your seed,  of your vineyards,  give to his officers,  to his servants.
And he will take your men-servants,  your maid-servants,  your finest young men,  your donkeys,  put them to his work.
He will take the tenth of your flocks. And ye shall be his servants.
And ye shall cry out in that day because of your king whom ye shall have chosen you,  Jehovah will not answer you in that day.
But the people refused to hearken to the voice of Samuel. And they said, No,  we will have a king over us
that we also may be like all the nations,  that our king may judge us,  go out before us,  fight our battles.
And Samuel heard all the words of the people,  he repeated them in the ears of Jehovah.
And Jehovah said to Samuel, Hearken to their voice,  make for them a king. And Samuel said to the men of Israel, Go ye every man to his city.
Now there was a man of Benjamin whose name was Kish, the son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Becorath, the son of Aphiah, the son of a Benjamite, a mighty man of valor.
And he had a son whose name was Saul, a young man and fine looking. And there was not among the sons of Israel a man better looking than he. From his shoulders and upward he was taller than any of the people.
And the donkeys of Kish, Saul's father, were lost. And Kish said to Saul his son, Take now one of the servants with thee,  arise, go seek the donkeys.
And he passed through the hill-country of Ephraim,  passed through the land of Shalishah,  they did not find them. Then they passed through the land of Shaalim,  they were not there. And he passed through the land of the Benjamites,  they did not find them.
When they came to the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant who was with him, Come,  let us return, lest my father leave off caring for the donkeys,  be anxious for us.
And he said to him, Behold now, there is in this city a man of God,  he is a man who is held in honor. All that he says comes surely to pass. Now let us go there, perhaps he can tell us concerning our journey on which we go.
Then Saul said to his servant, But behold, if we go, what shall we bring the man? For the bread is spent in our vessels,  there is not a present to bring to the man of God. What have we?
And the servant answered Saul again,  said, Behold, I have in my hand the fourth part of a shekel of silver. I will give that to the man of God, to tell us our way.
(Formerly in Israel, when a man went to inquire of God, thus he said, Come,  let us go to the seer, for he who is now called a Prophet was formerly called a Seer.)
Then Saul said to his servant, Well said. Come, let us go. So they went to the city where the man of God was.
As they went up the ascent to the city, they found young maidens going out to draw water,  said to them, Is the seer here?
And they answered them,  said, He is. Behold, he is before thee. Make haste now, for he has come today into the city, for the people have a sacrifice today in the high place.
As soon as ye have come into the city, ye shall straightaway find him before he goes up to the high place to eat. For the people will not eat until he comes, because he blesses the sacrifice,  afterwards those who are bidden eat. Now therefore get you up, for at this time ye shall find him.
And they went up to the city. And as they came within the city, behold, Samuel came out toward them, to go up to the high place.
Now Jehovah had revealed to Samuel a day before Saul came, saying,
Tomorrow about this time I will send thee a man out of the land of Benjamin,  thou shall anoint him to be prince over my people Israel. And he shall save my people out of the hand of the Philistines, for I have looked upon my people, because their cry has come to me.
And when Samuel saw Saul, Jehovah said to him, Behold, the man of whom I spoke to thee! This man shall have authority over my people.
Then Saul drew near to Samuel in the gate,  said, Tell me, I pray thee, where the seer's house is.
And Samuel answered Saul,  said, I am the seer. Go up before me to the high place, for ye shall eat with me today. And in the morning I will let thee go,  will tell thee all that is in thy heart.
And as for thy donkeys that were lost three days ago, set not thy mind on them, for they are found. And for whom is all that is desirable in Israel? Is it not for thee,  for all thy father's house?
And Saul answered and said, Am I not a Benjamite, of the smallest of the tribes of Israel? And my family the least of all the families of the tribe of Benjamin? Why then speak thou to me according to this manner?
And Samuel took Saul and his servant,  brought them into the guest-chamber,  made them sit in the chief place among those who were bidden, who were about thirty men.
And Samuel said to the cook, Bring the portion which I gave thee, of which I said to thee, Set it by thee.
And the cook took up the thigh,  that which was upon it,  set it before Saul. And Samuel said, Behold, that which has been reserved! Set it before thee and eat, because it has been kept for thee to the appointed time, for I said, I have invited the people. So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
And when they came down from the high place into the city, he conversed with Saul upon the housetop.
And they arose early. And it came to pass about the dawning of the day, that Samuel called to Saul on the housetop, saying, Up, that I may send thee away. And Saul arose,  they went out both of them, he and Samuel, abroad.
As they were going down at the end of the city, Samuel said to Saul, Bid the servant pass on before us (and he passed on),  stand thou still first, that I may cause thee to hear the word of God.
Then Samuel took the vial of oil,  poured it upon his head,  kissed him,  said, Is it not that Jehovah has anointed thee to be prince over his inheritance?
When thou are departed from me today, then thou shall find two men by Rachel's sepulcher in the border of Benjamin at Zelzah. And they will say to thee, The donkeys which thou went to seek are found, , lo, thy father has left off caring for the donkeys,  is anxious for you, saying, What shall I do for my son?
Then thou shall go on forward from there,  thou shall come to the oak of Tabor. And there shall meet thee there three men going up to God to Bethel, one carrying three kids,  another carrying three loaves of bread,  another carrying a bottle of wine.
And they will salute thee,  give thee two loaves of bread, which thou shall receive from their hand.
After that thou shall come to the hill of God where is the garrison of the Philistines. And it shall come to pass, when thou have come there to the city, that thou shall meet a band of prophets coming down from the high place with a psaltery,  a timbrel,  a pipe,  a harp, before them,  they will be prophesying.
And the Spirit of Jehovah will come mightily upon thee,  thou shall prophesy with them,  shall be turned into another man.
And let it be, when these signs have come to thee, that thou do as occasion shall serve thee, for God is with thee.
And thou shall go down before me to Gilgal. And, behold, I will come down to thee, to offer burnt offerings,  to sacrifice sacrifices of peace offerings. Thou shall tarry seven days till I come to thee,  show thee what thou shall do.
And it was so, that, when he had turned his back to go from Samuel, God gave him another heart. And all those signs came to pass that day.
And when they came there to the hill, behold, a band of prophets met him. And the Spirit of God came mightily upon him,  he prophesied among them.
And it came to pass, when all who knew him formerly saw, that, behold, he prophesied with the prophets, then the people said one to another, What is this that has come to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?
And a man from the same place answered and said, And who is their father? Therefore it became a proverb, Is Saul also among the prophets?
And when he had made an end of prophesying, he came to the high place.
And Saul's uncle said to him and to his servant, Where did ye go? And he said, To seek the donkeys,  when we saw that they were not found, we came to Samuel.
And Saul's uncle said, Tell me, I pray thee, what Samuel said to you.
And Saul said to his uncle, He told us plainly that the donkeys were found. But concerning the matter of the kingdom, of which Samuel spoke, he did not tell him.
And Samuel called the people together to Jehovah to Mizpah.
And he said to the sons of Israel, Thus says Jehovah, the God of Israel, I brought up Israel out of Egypt,  I delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians,  out of the hand of all the kingdoms that oppressed you,
but ye have this day rejected your God who himself saves you out of all your calamities and your distresses,  ye have said to him, No,  set a king over us. Now therefore present yourselves before Jehovah by your tribes,  by your thousands.
So Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel near,  the tribe of Benjamin was taken.
And he brought the tribe of Benjamin near by their families,  the family of the Matrites was taken,  Saul the son of Kish was taken. But when they sought him, he could not be found.
Therefore they asked of Jehovah further, Is there yet a man to come here? And Jehovah answered, Behold, he has hid himself among the baggage.
And they ran and fetched him from there. And when he stood among the people, he was higher than any of the people from his shoulders and upward.
And Samuel said to all the people, See ye him whom Jehovah has chosen, that there is none like him among all the people? And all the people shouted,  said, Live, O king!
Then Samuel told the people the manner of the kingdom,  wrote it in a book,  laid it up before Jehovah. And Samuel sent all the people away, every man to his house.
And Saul also went to his house to Gibeah,  mighty men went with him, whose hearts God had touched.
But certain worthless fellows said, How shall this man save us? And they despised him,  brought him no present. But he held his peace.
Then Nahash the Ammonite came up,  encamped against Jabesh-gilead. And all the men of Jabesh said to Nahash, Make a covenant with us,  we will serve thee.
And Nahash the Ammonite said to them, On this condition will I make it with you, that all your right eyes be put out,  I will lay it for a reproach upon all Israel.
And the elders of Jabesh said to him, Give us seven days' respite that we may send messengers to all the borders of Israel,  then, if there be none to save us, we will come out to thee.
Then the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul,  spoke these words in the ears of the people. And all the people lifted up their voice,  wept.
And, behold, Saul came following the oxen out of the field,  Saul said, What troubles the people that they weep? And they told him the words of the men of Jabesh.
And the Spirit of God came mightily upon Saul when he heard those words,  his anger was greatly kindled.
And he took a yoke of oxen,  cut them in pieces,  sent them throughout all the borders of Israel by the hand of messengers, saying, Whoever does not come forth behind Saul and behind Samuel, so shall it be done to his oxen. And the dread of Jehovah fell on the people,  they came out as one man.
And he numbered them in Bezek,  the sons of Israel were three hundred thousand,  the men of Judah thirty thousand.
And they said to the messengers who came, Thus ye shall say to the men of Jabesh-gilead, Tomorrow, by the time the sun is hot, ye shall have deliverance. And the messengers came and told the men of Jabesh,  they were glad.
Therefore the men of Jabesh said, Tomorrow we will come out to you,  ye shall do with us all that seems good to you.
And it was so on the morrow, that Saul put the people in three companies. And they came into the midst of the camp in the morning watch,  smote the Ammonites until the heat of the day. And it came to pass, that those who remained were scattered so that not two of them were left together.
And the people said to Samuel, Who is he who said, Shall Saul reign over us? Bring the men that we may put them to death.
And Saul said, There shall not a man be put to death this day, for today Jehovah has wrought deliverance in Israel.
Then Samuel said to the people, Come,  let us go to Gilgal,  renew the kingdom there.
And all the people went to Gilgal. And there they made Saul king before Jehovah in Gilgal,  there they offered sacrifices of peace offerings before Jehovah,  there Saul and all the men of Israel rejoiced greatly.
And Samuel said to all Israel, Behold, I have hearkened to your voice in all that ye said to me,  have made a king over you.
And now, behold, the king walks before you. And I am old and gray headed, , behold, my sons are with you. And I have walked before you from my youth to this day.
Here I am. Witness against me before Jehovah,  before his anointed: Whose ox have I taken? Or whose donkey have I taken? Or whom have I defrauded? Whom have I oppressed? Or of whose hand have I taken a bribe to blind my eyes with it? And I will restore it to you.
And they said, Thou have not defrauded us, nor oppressed us, neither have thou taken anything of any man's hand.
And he said to them, Jehovah is witness against you,  his anointed is witness this day, that ye have not found anything in my hand. And they said, He is witness.
And Samuel said to the people, It is Jehovah who appointed Moses and Aaron,  who brought your fathers up out of the land of Egypt.
Now therefore stand still that I may plead with you before Jehovah concerning all the righteous acts of Jehovah, which he did to you and to your fathers.
When Jacob had come into Egypt,  your fathers cried to Jehovah, then Jehovah sent Moses and Aaron who brought forth your fathers out of Egypt,  made them to dwell in this place.
But they forgot Jehovah their God,  he sold them into the hand of Sisera, captain of the army of Hazor,  into the hand of the Philistines,  into the hand of the king of Moab,  they fought against them.
And they cried to Jehovah,  said, We have sinned because we have forsaken Jehovah,  have served the Baalim and the Ashtaroth,  now deliver us out of the hand of our enemies,  we will serve thee.
And Jehovah sent Jerubbaal,  Bedan,  Jephthah,  Samuel,  delivered you out of the hand of your enemies on every side,  ye dwelt in safety.
And when ye saw that Nahash the king of the sons of Ammon came against you, ye said to me, No,  a king shall reign over us, when Jehovah your God was your king.
Now therefore behold the king whom ye have chosen,  whom ye have asked for. And, behold, Jehovah has set a king over you.
If ye will fear Jehovah,  serve him,  hearken to his voice,  not rebel against the commandment of Jehovah, then both ye and also the king who reigns over you shall be followers of Jehovah your God.
But if ye will not hearken to the voice of Jehovah,  rebel against the commandment of Jehovah, then the hand of Jehovah will be against you as it was against your fathers.
Now therefore stand still and see this great thing, which Jehovah will do before your eyes.
Is it not wheat harvest today? I will call to Jehovah that he may send thunder and rain,  ye shall know and see that your wickedness is great, which ye have done in the sight of Jehovah in asking a king for you.
So Samuel called to Jehovah,  Jehovah sent thunder and rain that day. And all the people greatly feared Jehovah and Samuel.
And all the people said to Samuel, Pray for thy servants to Jehovah thy God that we not die, for we have added to all our sins this evil, to ask a king for us.
And Samuel said to the people, Fear not. Ye have indeed done all this evil, yet turn not aside from following Jehovah,  serve Jehovah with all your heart.
And turn ye not aside after vain things which cannot profit nor deliver, for they are vain.
For Jehovah will not forsake his people for his great name's sake, because it has pleased Jehovah to make you a people to himself.
Moreover as for me, far be it from me that I should sin against Jehovah in ceasing to pray for you. But I will instruct you in the good and the right way.
Only fear Jehovah,  serve him in truth with all your heart, for consider what great things he has done for you.
But if ye shall still do wickedly, ye shall be consumed, both ye and your king.
Saul was â€¦ years old when he began to reign. And when he had reigned two years over Israel,
Saul chose for him three thousand men of Israel, of which two thousand were with Saul in Michmash,  on the mount of Bethel,  a thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin,  the rest of the people he sent every man to his tent.
And Jonathan smote the garrison of the Philistines that was in Geba,  the Philistines heard of it. And Saul blew the trumpet throughout all the land, saying, Let the Hebrews hear.
And all Israel heard say that Saul had smitten the garrison of the Philistines,  also that Israel was had in abomination with the Philistines. And the people were gathered together after Saul to Gilgal.
And the Philistines assembled themselves together to fight with Israel: thirty thousand chariots,  six thousand horsemen,  people as the sand which is on the sea-shore in multitude. And they came up,  encamped in Michmash, eastward of Beth-aven.
When the men of Israel saw that they were in a strait (for the people were distressed), then the people hid themselves in caves,  in thickets,  in rocks,  in coverts,  in pits.
Now some of the Hebrews had gone over the Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead,  as for Saul, he was yet in Gilgal,  all the people followed him trembling.
And he tarried seven days, according to the set time that Samuel had appointed,  Samuel did not come to Gilgal,  the people were scattered from him.
And Saul said, Bring here the burnt offering to me,  the peace offerings. And he offered the burnt offering.
And it came to pass that, as soon as he had made an end of offering the burnt offering, behold, Samuel came,  Saul went out to meet him, that he might salute him.
And Samuel said, What have thou done? And Saul said, Because I saw that the people were scattered from me,  that thou did not come within the days appointed,  that the Philistines assembled themselves together at Michmash,
therefore I said, Now the Philistines will come down upon me to Gilgal,  I have not entreated the favor of Jehovah. I forced myself therefore,  offered the burnt offering.
And Samuel said to Saul, Thou have done foolishly. Thou have not kept the commandment of Jehovah thy God, which he commanded thee. For now Jehovah would have established thy kingdom upon Israel forever,
but now thy kingdom shall not continue. Jehovah has sought for him a man after his own heart,  Jehovah has appointed him to be prince over his people, because thou have not kept that which Jehovah commanded thee.
And Samuel arose,  got up from Gilgal to Gibeah of Benjamin. And Saul numbered the people who were present with him, about six hundred men.
And Saul,  Jonathan his son,  the people that were present with them, abode in Geba of Benjamin,  the Philistines encamped in Michmash.
And the spoilers came out of the camp of the Philistines in three companies. One company turned to the way that leads to Ophrah, to the land of Shual,
and another company turned the way to Beth-horon,  another company turned the way of the border that looks down upon the valley of Zeboim toward the wilderness.
Now there was no blacksmith found throughout all the land of Israel, for the Philistines said, Lest the Hebrews make for them swords or spears,
but all the Israelites went down to the Philistines to sharpen every man his share,  his coulter,  his axe,  his mattock.
Yet they had a file for the mattocks,  for the coulters,  for the forks,  for the axes,  to set the goads.
So it came to pass in the day of battle, that there was neither sword nor spear found in the hand of any of the people who were with Saul and Jonathan. But with Saul and with Jonathan his son there was found.
And the garrison of the Philistines went out to the pass of Michmash.
Now it fell upon a day that Jonathan the son of Saul said to the young man who bore his armor, Come,  let us go over to the Philistines' garrison that is on yonder side. But he did not tell his father.
And Saul abode in the outermost part of Gibeah under the pomegranate tree which is in Migron. And the people who were with him were about six hundred men,
and Ahijah, the son of Ahitub, Ichabod's brother, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eli, the priest of Jehovah in Shiloh, wearing an ephod. And the people did not know that Jonathan was gone.
And between the passes by which Jonathan sought to go over to the Philistines' garrison, there was a rocky crag on the one side,  a rocky crag on the other side. And the name of the one was Bozez,  the name of the other Seneh.
The one crag rose up on the north in front of Michmash,  the other on the south in front of Geba.
And Jonathan said to the young man who bore his armor, Come,  let us go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised. It may be that Jehovah will work for us, for there is no limitation to Jehovah to save by many or by few.
And his armor bearer said to him, Do all that is in thy heart. Turn thee, behold, I am with thee according to thy heart.
Then Jonathan said, Behold, we will pass over to the men,  we will disclose ourselves to them.
If they say thus to us, Tarry until we come to you, then we will stand still in our place,  will not go up to them.
But if they say thus, Come up to us, then we will go up, for Jehovah has delivered them into our hand,  this shall be the sign to us.
And both of them disclosed themselves to the garrison of the Philistines. And the Philistines said, Behold, the Hebrews come forth out of the holes where they had hid themselves.
And the men of the garrison answered Jonathan and his armor bearer,  said, Come up to us,  we will show you a thing. And Jonathan said to his armor bearer, Come up after me, for Jehovah has delivered them into the hand of Israel.
And Jonathan climbed up upon his hands and upon his feet,  his armor bearer after him. And they fell before Jonathan,  his armor bearer killed them after him.
And that first slaughter, which Jonathan and his armor bearer made, was about twenty men, within as it were half a furrow's length in an acre of land.
And there was a trembling in the camp, in the field,  among all the people. The garrison,  the spoilers, they also trembled. And the earth quaked, so there was an exceedingly great trembling.
And the watchmen of Saul in Gibeah of Benjamin looked, , behold, the multitude melted away,  they went here and there.
Then Saul said to the people who were with him, Number now,  see who has gone from us. And when they had numbered, behold, Jonathan and his armor bearer were not there.
And Saul said to Ahijah, Bring here the ark of God. For the ark of God was there at that time with the sons of Israel.
And it came to pass, while Saul talked to the priest, that the tumult that was in the camp of the Philistines went on and increased. And Saul said to the priest, Withdraw thy hand.
And Saul and all the people who were with him were gathered together,  came to the battle. And, behold, every man's sword was against his fellow,  there was a very great discomfiture.
Now the Hebrews who were with the Philistines as formerly,  who went up with them into the camp, from the country round about, even they also turned to be with the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
Likewise all the men of Israel who had hid themselves in the hill-country of Ephraim, when they heard that the Philistines fled, even they also followed close after them in the battle.
So Jehovah saved Israel that day,  the battle passed over by Beth-aven.
And the men of Israel were distressed that day, for Saul had adjured the people, saying, Cursed be the man who eats any food until it be evening,  I be avenged on my enemies. So none of the people tasted food.
And all the people came into the forest,  there was honey upon the ground.
And when the people came to the forest, behold, the honey dropped,  no man put his hand to his mouth, for the people feared the oath.
But Jonathan heard not when his father charged the people with the oath, therefore he put forth the end of the rod that was in his hand,  dipped it in the honeycomb,  put his hand to his mouth,  his eyes were enlightened.
Then one of the people answered,  said, Thy father strictly charged the people with an oath, saying, Cursed be the man who eats food this day,  the people were faint.
