Prov. She has killed her beasts. She has mingled her wine. She has also furnished her table.
Prov. She has sent forth her maidens. She cries out upon the highest places of the city:
Prov. He who is simple, let him turn in here. As for him who is void of understanding, she says to him,
Prov. Come, eat ye of my bread,  drink of the wine which I have mingled.
Prov. Forsake ye simpleness,  live,  walk in the way of understanding.
Prov. He who corrects a scoffer gets himself reviling. And he who reproves a wicked man gets himself a bruise.
Prov. Reprove not a scoffer, lest he hate thee. Reprove a wise man,  he will love thee.
Prov. Give opportunity to a wise man,  he will be yet wiser. Teach a righteous man,  he will increase in learning.
Prov. The fear of Jehovah is the beginning of wisdom,  the knowledge of the Holy is understanding.
Prov. For by me thy days shall be multiplied,  the years of thy life shall be increased.
Prov. If thou are wise, thou are wise for thyself. And if thou scoff, thou alone shall bear it.
Prov. The foolish woman is clamorous, simple,  knows nothing.
Prov. And she sits at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city,
Prov. to call to those who pass by, who go right on their ways:
Prov. He who is simple, let him turn in here. And as for him who is void of understanding, she says to him,
Prov. Stolen waters are sweet,  bread in secret is pleasant.
Prov. But he knows not that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
Prov. The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son makes a glad father,  a foolish son is the heaviness of his mother.
Prov. Treasures of wickedness profit nothing,  righteousness delivers from death.
Prov. Jehovah will not allow the soul of a righteous man to famish,  he thrusts away the desire of the wicked.
Prov. He who works with a slack hand becomes poor,  the hand of the diligent makes rich.
Prov. He who gathers in summer is a wise son. He who sleeps in harvest is a son who causes shame.
Prov. Blessings are upon the head of a righteous man,  violence covers the mouth of the wicked.
Prov. The memory of a righteous man is blessed,  the name of the wicked shall rot.
Prov. The wise in heart will receive commandments,  a prating fool shall fall.
Prov. He who walks uprightly walks securely,  he who perverts his ways shall be known.
Prov. He who winks with the eye causes sorrow. And a prating fool shall fall.
Prov. The mouth of a righteous man is a fountain of life,  violence covers the mouth of the wicked.
Prov. Hatred stirs up strife,  love covers all transgressions.
Prov. In the lips of him who has discernment wisdom is found,  a rod is for the back of him who is void of understanding.
Prov. Wise men lay up knowledge,  the mouth of a foolish man is a present destruction.
Prov. The rich man's wealth is his strong city. The destruction of the poor is their poverty.
Prov. The labor of a righteous man produces life. The fruit of a wicked man is to sin.
Prov. He is in the way of life who heeds correction,  he who forsakes reproof errs.
Prov. He who hides hatred is of lying lips. And he who utters a slander is a fool.
Prov. Transgression is not lacking in the multitude of words,  he who refrains his lips does wisely.
Prov. The tongue of a righteous man is choice silver. The heart of the wicked is little worth.
Prov. The lips of a righteous man feeds many,  the foolish die for lack of understanding.
Prov. The blessing of Jehovah, it makes rich,  he adds no sorrow with it.
Prov. It is as sport to a fool to do mischief,  so is wisdom to a man of understanding.
Prov. The fear of a wicked man shall come upon him. And the desire of the righteous shall be granted.
Prov. When the whirlwind passes, the wicked man is no more,  the righteous man is an everlasting foundation.
Prov. As vinegar to the teeth,  as smoke to the eyes, so is the sluggard to those who send him.
Prov. The fear of Jehovah prolongs days,  the years of the wicked shall be shortened.
Prov. The hope of the righteous is gladness,  the expectation of the wicked shall perish.
Prov. The way of Jehovah is a stronghold to the upright,  it is a destruction to the workers of iniquity.
Prov. A righteous man shall never be removed,  the wicked shall not dwell in the land.
Prov. The mouth of a righteous man brings forth wisdom,  the perverse tongue shall be cut off.
Prov. The lips of a righteous man knows what is acceptable,  the mouth of the wicked is perverseness.
Prov. A false balance is an abomination to Jehovah,  a just weight is his delight.
Prov. When pride comes, then comes shame,  with the lowly is wisdom.
Prov. The integrity of the upright shall guide them,  the perverseness of the treacherous shall destroy them.
Prov. Riches do not profit in the day of wrath,  righteousness delivers from death.
Prov. The righteousness of the perfect shall direct his way,  the wicked man shall fall by his own wickedness.
Prov. The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them,  the treacherous shall be taken in their own iniquity.
Prov. When a wicked man dies, his expectation shall perish,  the hope of iniquity perishes.
Prov. A righteous man is delivered out of trouble,  a wicked man comes in his stead.
Prov. The hypocrite destroys his neighbor with his mouth,  the righteous shall be delivered through knowledge.
Prov. When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices. And when the wicked perish, there is shouting.
Prov. By the blessing of the upright the city is exalted,  it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.
Prov. He who despises his neighbor is void of wisdom,  a man of understanding holds his peace.
Prov. He who goes around as a tale-bearer reveals secrets,  he who is of a faithful spirit conceals a matter.
Prov. Where no wise guidance is, the people fall,  in the multitude of counselors there is safety.
Prov. He who is surety for a stranger shall smart for it,  he who hates suretyship is secure.
Prov. A gracious woman obtains honor,  aggressive men obtain riches.
Prov. The merciful man does good to his own soul,  he who is cruel troubles his own flesh.
Prov. A wicked man earns deceitful wages,  he who sows righteousness has a sure reward.
Prov. He who is steadfast in righteousness comes to life,  he who pursues evil comes to his own death.
Prov. Those who are perverse in heart are an abomination to Jehovah,  such as are perfect in their way are his delight.
Prov. Hand in hand, the evil man shall not be unpunished,  the seed of the righteous shall be delivered.
Prov. A ring of gold in a swine's snout, is a beautiful woman who is without discretion.
Prov. The desire of the righteous is only good. The expectation of the wicked is wrath.
Prov. There is he who scatters,  increases yet more,  there he is who withholds more than is proper,  only to want.
Prov. The generous soul shall be made prosperous,  he who waters shall also be watered himself.
Prov. The people shall curse him who withholds grain,  a blessing shall be upon the head of him who sells it.
Prov. He who diligently seeks good seeks favor,  he who searches after evil, it shall come to him.
Prov. He who trusts in his riches shall fall,  the righteous shall flourish as the green leaf.
Prov. He who troubles his own house shall inherit the wind. And a foolish man shall be servant to a wise man of heart.
Prov. The fruit of a righteous man is a tree of life,  he who is wise wins souls.
Prov. Behold, a righteous man shall be recompensed in the earth, how much more the wicked man and the sinner!
Prov. He who loves correction loves knowledge,  he who hates reproof is brutish.
Prov. A good man shall obtain favor of Jehovah,  he will condemn a man of wicked devices.
Prov. A man shall not be established by wickedness,  the root of the righteous shall not be moved.
Prov. A worthy woman is the crown of her husband,  she who makes ashamed is as rottenness in his bones.
Prov. The thoughts of the righteous are just. The counsels of the wicked are deceit.
Prov. The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood,  the mouth of the upright shall deliver them.
Prov. The wicked are overthrown,  are not,  the house of the righteous shall stand.
Prov. A man shall be commended according to his wisdom,  he who is of a perverse heart shall be despised.
Prov. Better is he who is lightly esteemed,  has a servant, than he who honors himself,  lacks bread.
Prov. A righteous man regards the life of his beast,  the tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
Prov. He who tills his land shall have plenty of bread,  he who pursues vanities is void of understanding.
Prov. A wicked man desires the net of evil men,  the root of the righteous gives.
Prov. A wicked man is snared by the transgression of his lips,  the righteous shall come out of trouble.
Prov. A man shall be satisfied with good by the fruit of his mouth,  the actions of a man's hands shall be rendered to him.
Prov. The way of a fool is right in his own eyes,  he who is wise hearkens to counsel.
Prov. A fool's vexation is instantly known,  a prudent man conceals shame.
Prov. He who utters truth shows forth righteousness,  a false witness, deceit.
Prov. There is he who speaks rashly like the piercings of a sword,  the tongue of the wise is health.
Prov. The lips of truth shall be established forever,  a lying tongue is but for a moment.
Prov. Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil,  joy is to the counselors of peace.
Prov. There shall no mischief happen to a righteous man,  the wicked shall be filled with evil.
Prov. Lying lips are an abomination to Jehovah,  those who deal truly are his delight.
Prov. A prudent man conceals knowledge,  the heart of fools proclaims foolishness.
Prov. The hand of the diligent shall bear rule,  the slothful shall be put under task work.
Prov. Heaviness in the heart of a man makes it droop,  a good word makes it glad.
Prov. A righteous man is a guide to his neighbor,  the way of the wicked causes them to err.
Prov. The slothful man roasts not that which he took in hunting,  the substance of a diligent man is precious.
Prov. Life is in the way of righteousness,  in the pathway thereof there is no death.
Prov. A wise son hears his father's instruction,  a scoffer listens not to rebuke.
Prov. A man shall eat good by the fruit of his mouth,  the soul of the treacherous, violence.
Prov. He who guards his mouth keeps his life. He who opens wide his lips shall have destruction.
Prov. The soul of the sluggard desires,  has nothing,  the soul of the diligent shall be made fat.
Prov. A righteous man hates lying,  a wicked man is loathsome,  comes to shame.
Prov. Righteousness guards him who is upright in the way,  wickedness overthrows the sinner.
Prov. There is he who makes himself rich, yet has nothing,  he who makes himself poor, yet has great wealth.
Prov. The ransom of a man's life is his riches,  the poor hears no threatening.
Prov. The light of the righteous rejoices,  the lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
Prov. Through pride a vain man causes contention,  wisdom is with the well-advised.
Prov. Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished,  he who gathers by labor shall have increase.
Prov. Hope deferred makes the heart sick,  when the desire comes, it is a tree of life.
Prov. He who despises the word brings destruction on himself,  he who fears the commandment shall be rewarded.
Prov. The law of a wise man is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death.
Prov. Good understanding gives favor,  the way of the transgressor is hard.
Prov. Every prudent man works with knowledge,  a fool flaunts folly.
Prov. A wicked messenger falls into evil,  a faithful ambassador is health.
Prov. Poverty and shame are to him who refuses correction,  he who regards reproof shall be honored.
Prov. The desire accomplished is sweet to the soul,  it is an abomination to fools to depart from evil.
Prov. Walk with wise men,  thou shall be wise. But the companion of fools shall smart for it.
Prov. Evil pursues sinners,  the righteous shall be recompensed with good.
Prov. A good man leaves an inheritance to his son's sons,  the wealth of the sinner is laid up for the righteous.
Prov. Much food is in the tillage of the poor,  there is that is consumed because of injustice.
Prov. He who spares his rod hates his son,  he who loves him chastens him promptly.
Prov. A righteous man eats to the satisfying of his soul,  the belly of the wicked shall want.
Prov. Every wise woman builds her house,  a foolish woman plucks it down with her own hands.
Prov. He who walks in his uprightness fears Jehovah,  he who is perverse in his ways despises him.
Prov. In the mouth of a fool is a rod of pride,  the lips of the wise shall preserve them.
Prov. Where no oxen are, the crib is clean,  by the strength of the ox is much increase.
Prov. A faithful witness will not lie,  a false witness utters lies.
Prov. A scoffer seeks wisdom,  finds it not,  knowledge is easy to him who has understanding.
Prov. Go into the presence of a foolish man,  thou shall not perceive the lips of knowledge.
Prov. The wisdom of a prudent man is to understand his way,  the folly of fools is deceit.
Prov. Fools mock at sin,  among the upright there is good will.
Prov. The heart knows its own bitterness,  a stranger does not intermeddle with its joy.
Prov. The house of the wicked shall be overthrown,  the tent of the upright shall flourish.
Prov. There is a way which seems right to a man,  the end thereof are the ways of death.
Prov. Even in laughter the heart is sorrowful,  the end of mirth is heaviness.
Prov. The backslider in heart shall be filled with his own ways,  a good man from his own fruits.
Prov. A simple man believes every word,  the prudent man looks well to his going.
Prov. A wise man fears,  departs from evil,  the fool bears himself insolently,  is confident.
Prov. He who is soon angry will deal foolishly. And a man of wicked devices is hated.
Prov. The simple inherit folly,  the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
Prov. The evil bow down before the good,  the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
Prov. The poor man is regarded inferior even by his own neighbor,  the rich man has many friends.
Prov. He who despises his neighbor sins,  he who has pity on the poor, happy is he.
Prov. Do they not err who devise evil? But mercy and truth are to those who devise good.
Prov. In all labor there is profit,  the talk of the lips tends only to poverty.
Prov. The crown of the wise is their riches. The foolishness of fools is folly.
Prov. A true witness delivers souls,  he who utters lies causes deceit.
Prov. In the fear of Jehovah is strong confidence,  his sons shall have a place of refuge.
Prov. The fear of Jehovah is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death.
Prov. In the multitude of people is the king's glory,  in the want of people is the destruction of the prince.
Prov. He who is slow to anger is of great understanding,  he who is hasty of spirit exalts folly.
Prov. A tranquil heart is the life of the flesh,  envy is the rottenness of the bones.
Prov. He who oppresses a poor man reproaches his maker,  he who has mercy on a needy man honors him.
Prov. An evil man is thrust down in his evil-doing,  a righteous man has hope in his death.
Prov. Wisdom rests in the heart of him who has understanding,  what is in the inward part of fools is made known.
Prov. Righteousness exalts a nation,  sin is a reproach to any people.
Prov. The king's favor is toward a servant who deals wisely,  his wrath will be to him who causes shame.
Prov. A soft answer turns away wrath,  a grievous word stirs up anger.
Prov. The tongue of the wise utters knowledge rightly,  the mouth of fools pours out folly.
Prov. The eyes of Jehovah are in every place, keeping watch upon the evil and the good.
Prov. A gentle tongue is a tree of life,  perverseness in it is a breaking of the spirit.
Prov. A fool despises his father's correction,  he who regards reproof gets prudence.
Prov. In the house of a righteous man is much treasure,  in the revenues of a wicked man is trouble.
Prov. The lips of the wise disperse knowledge,  the heart of the foolish, not so.
Prov. The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to Jehovah,  the prayer of the upright is his delight.
Prov. The way of a wicked man is an abomination to Jehovah,  he loves him who follows after righteousness.
Prov. There is grievous correction for him who forsakes the way. He who hates reproof shall die.
Prov. Sheol and Abaddon are before Jehovah. How much more then the hearts of the sons of men!
Prov. A scoffer does not like to be reproved. He will not go to the wise.
Prov. A glad heart makes a cheerful countenance,  by sorrow of heart the spirit is broken.
Prov. The heart of him who has understanding seeks knowledge,  the mouth of fools feeds on folly.
Prov. All the days of the afflicted are evil,  he who is of a cheerful heart has a continual feast.
Prov. Better is little with the fear of Jehovah, than great treasure and trouble with it.
Prov. Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a fatted ox and hatred with it.
Prov. A wrathful man stirs up contention,  he who is slow to anger appeases strife.
Prov. The way of the sluggard is as a hedge of thorns,  the path of the upright is made a highway.
Prov. A wise son makes a glad father,  a foolish man despises his mother.
Prov. Folly is joy to him who is void of wisdom,  a man of understanding makes his going straight.
Prov. Where there is no counsel, plans are disappointed,  in the multitude of counselors they are established.
Prov. A man has joy in the answer of his mouth,  a word in due season, how good it is!
Prov. To the wise man the way of life is upward, that he may depart from Sheol beneath.
Prov. Jehovah will root up the house of the proud,  he will establish the border of the widow.
Prov. Evil devices are an abomination to Jehovah,  pleasant words are pure.
Prov. He who is greedy of gain troubles his own house,  he who hates bribes shall live.
Prov. The heart of a righteous man meditates to answer,  the mouth of the wicked pours out evil things.
Prov. Jehovah is far from the wicked,  he hears the prayer of the righteous.
Prov. The light of the eyes rejoices the heart. Good news make the bones fat.
Prov. The ear that hearkens to the reproof of life shall abide among the wise.
Prov. He who refuses correction despises his own soul,  he who hearkens to reproof gets understanding.
Prov. The fear of Jehovah is the instruction of wisdom,  before honor is humility.
Prov. The plans of the heart belong to man,  the answer of the tongue is from Jehovah.
Prov. All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes,  Jehovah weighs the spirits.
Prov. Commit thy works to Jehovah,  thy purposes shall be established.
Prov. Jehovah has made everything for its own end, yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
Prov. Everyone who is proud in heart is an abomination to Jehovah. Hand in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
Prov. By mercy and truth iniquity is atoned for,  by the fear of Jehovah men depart from evil.
Prov. When a man's ways please Jehovah, he makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Prov. Better is a little, with righteousness, than great revenues with injustice.
Prov. A man's heart devises his way,  Jehovah directs his steps.
Prov. A divine sentence is in the lips of the king. His mouth shall not transgress in judgment.
Prov. A just balance and scales are Jehovah's. All the weights of the bag are his work.
Prov. It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness, for the throne is established by righteousness.
Prov. Righteous lips are the delight of kings,  they love him who speaks right.
Prov. The wrath of a king is messengers of death,  a wise man will pacify it.
Prov. In the light of the king's countenance is life,  his favor is as a cloud of the latter rain.
Prov. How much better it is to get wisdom than gold! Yea, to get understanding is rather to be chosen than silver.
Prov. The highway of the upright is to depart from evil. He who keeps his way preserves his soul.
Prov. Pride is before destruction,  a haughty spirit before a fall.
Prov. Better it is to be of a lowly spirit with the poor, than to divide the spoil with the proud.
Prov. He who gives heed to the word shall find good,  whoever trusts in Jehovah, happy is he.
Prov. The wise in heart shall be called prudent,  the sweetness of the lips increases learning.
Prov. Understanding is a well-spring of life to him who has it,  the correction of fools is folly.
Prov. The heart of the wise instructs his mouth,  adds learning to his lips.
Prov. Pleasant words are a honeycomb: Sweet to the soul,  health to the bones.
Prov. There is a way which seems right to a man,  the end thereof are the ways of death.
Prov. The appetite of the laboring man labors for him, for his mouth urges him.
Prov. A worthless man devises mischief,  in his lips there is as a scorching fire.
Prov. A perverse man scatters abroad strife,  a whisperer separates chief friends.
Prov. A man of violence entices his neighbor,  leads him in a way that is not good.
Prov. He who shuts his eyes devises perverse things. He who moves his lips brings evil to pass.
Prov. The hoary head is a crown of glory. It shall be found in the way of righteousness.
Prov. He who is slow to anger is better than the mighty,  he who rules his spirit, than he who takes a city.
Prov. The lot is cast into the lap,  the whole disposing thereof is of Jehovah.
Prov. Better is a dry morsel,  quietness with it, than a house full of feasting with strife.
Prov. A servant who deals wisely shall have rule over a son who causes shame,  shall have part in the inheritance among the brothers.
Prov. The refining pot is for silver,  the furnace for gold,  Jehovah tries the hearts.
Prov. An evildoer gives heed to wicked lips. A liar gives ear to a mischievous tongue.
Prov. He who mocks a poor man reproaches his maker. He who is glad at calamity shall not be unpunished.
Prov. Son's sons are the crown of old men,  the glory of sons are their fathers.
Prov. Excellent speech is not appropriate to a fool, much less lying lips to a prince.
Prov. A bribe is a precious stone in the eyes of him who has it; wherever it turns, it prospers.
Prov. He who covers a transgression seeks love,  he who repeats a matter separates chief friends.
Prov. A rebuke enters deeper into him who has understanding than a hundred stripes into a fool.
Prov. An evil man seeks only rebellion. Therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.
Prov. Let a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, rather than a fool in his folly.
Prov. He who rewards evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
Prov. The beginning of strife is like letting out water. Therefore leave off contention, before there is quarrelling.
Prov. He who justifies a wicked man,  he who condemns a righteous man, both of them alike are an abomination to Jehovah.
Prov. Why is there a price in the hand of a fool to buy wisdom, since he has no understanding?
Prov. A friend loves at all times,  a brother is born for adversity.
Prov. A man void of understanding strikes hands,  becomes surety in the presence of his neighbor.
Prov. He loves transgression who loves strife. He who raises high his gate seeks destruction.
Prov. He who has a wayward heart finds no good,  he who has a perverse tongue falls into mischief.
Prov. He who begets a fool it is to his sorrow,  the father of a fool has no joy.
Prov. A cheerful heart is a good medicine,  a broken spirit dries up the bones.
Prov. A wicked man receives a bribe out of the bosom, to pervert the ways of justice.
Prov. Wisdom is before the face of him who has understanding,  the eyes of a fool are in the ends of the earth.
Prov. A foolish son is a grief to his father,  bitterness to her who bore him.
Prov. Also to punish a righteous man is not good, nor to smite nobles for uprightness.
Prov. He who spares his words has knowledge,  he who is of a cool spirit is a man of understanding.
Prov. Even a fool, when he holds his peace, is considered wise. When he shuts his lips, he is prudent.
Prov. He who desires to separate himself seeks excuses,  rages against all sound wisdom.
Prov. A fool has no delight in understanding,  only that his heart may reveal itself.
Prov. When a wicked man comes, contempt also comes,  with disgrace, reproach.
Prov. The words of a man's mouth are deep waters. The wellspring of wisdom is a flowing brook.
Prov. To respect the person of a wicked man is not good, nor to turn aside a righteous man in judgment.
Prov. A fool's lips enter into contention,  his mouth calls for stripes.
Prov. A fool's mouth is his destruction,  his lips are the snare of his soul.
Prov. The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels,  they go down into the innermost parts.
Prov. He also that is slack in his work is brother to him that is a destroyer.
Prov. The name of Jehovah is a strong tower. A righteous man runs into it,  is safe.
Prov. The rich man's wealth is his strong city,  as a high wall in his own imagination.
Prov. Before destruction the heart of man is haughty,  before honor is humility.
Prov. He who gives answer before he hears, it is folly and shame to him.
Prov. The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity,  a broken spirit who can bear?
Prov. The heart of a prudent man gets knowledge,  the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
Prov. A man's gift makes room for him,  brings him before great men.
Prov. He who pleads his case first seems just,  his neighbor comes and searches him out.
Prov. The lot causes contentions to cease,  decides between the mighty.
Prov. A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city,  such contentions are like the bars of a castle.
Prov. A man's belly shall be filled with the fruit of his mouth. With the increase of his lips he shall be satisfied.
Prov. Death and life are in the power of the tongue,  those who love it shall eat the fruit of it.
Prov. He who finds a wife finds a good thing,  obtains favor from Jehovah.
Prov. A poor man uses entreaties,  a rich man answers roughly.
Prov. He who makes many friends does it to his own destruction,  there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
Prov. Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity than he who is perverse in his lips and is a fool.
Prov. Also, that the soul be without knowledge is not good. And he who hastens with his feet sins.
Prov. The foolishness of a man subverts his way,  his heart rages against Jehovah.
Prov. Wealth adds many friends,  a poor man is separated from his friend.
Prov. A false witness shall not be unpunished,  he who utters lies shall not escape.
Prov. Many will entreat the favor of a generous man,  every man is a friend to him who gives gifts.
Prov. All the brothers of a poor man regard him inferior, how much more do his friends go far from him! He pursues with words,  they are gone.
Prov. He who gets wisdom loves his own soul. He who keeps understanding shall find good.
Prov. A false witness shall not be unpunished,  he who utters lies shall perish.
Prov. Luxurious living is not fitting for a fool, much less for a servant to have rule over rulers.
Prov. The discretion of a man makes him slow to anger,  it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
Prov. The king's wrath is as the roaring of a lion,  his favor is as dew upon the grass.
Prov. A foolish son is the calamity of his father,  the contentions of a wife are a continual dropping.
Prov. House and riches are an inheritance from fathers,  a prudent wife is from Jehovah.
Prov. Slothfulness casts into a deep sleep,  the idle soul shall suffer hunger.
Prov. He who keeps the commandment keeps his soul. He who is careless of his ways shall die.
Prov. He who has pity upon a poor man lends to Jehovah,  he will repay him his good deed.
Prov. Chasten thy son while there is hope,  let not thy soul spare for his crying.
Prov. A man of great wrath shall bear the penalty, for if thou deliver him, thou must do it yet again.
Prov. Hear counsel,  receive instruction, that thou may be wise in thy latter end.
Prov. There are many devices in a man's heart,  the counsel of Jehovah, that shall stand.
Prov. That which makes a man to be desired is his kindness,  a poor man is better than a liar.
Prov. The fear of Jehovah is life to a man,  he shall abide satisfied. He shall not be visited with evil.
Prov. The sluggard buries his hand in the dish,  will not so much as bring it to his mouth again.
Prov. Smite a scoffer,  a simple man will learn prudence. And reprove him who has understanding,  he will understand knowledge.
Prov. He who does violence to his father,  chases away his mother, is a son that causes shame and brings reproach.
Prov. To err from the words of knowledge, cease, my son, to hear instruction.
Prov. A worthless witness mocks at justice,  the mouth of the wicked swallows iniquity.
Prov. Judgments are prepared for scoffers,  stripes for the back of fools.
Prov. Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler,  whoever errs thereby is not wise.
Prov. The terror of a king is as the roaring of a lion. He who provokes him to anger sins against his own life.
Prov. It is an honor for a man to keep aloof from strife,  every fool will be quarrelling.
Prov. The sluggard will not plow because of the winter. Therefore he shall beg in harvest,  have nothing.
Prov. Purpose in the heart of man is deep water,  a man of understanding will draw it out.
Prov. Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness,  a faithful man who can find?
Prov. A righteous man who walks in his integrity, blessed are his sons after him.
Prov. A king who sits on the throne of judgment scatters away all evil with his eyes.
Prov. Who can say, I have made my heart clean. I am pure from my sin?
Prov. Diverse weights,  diverse measures, both of them alike are an abomination to Jehovah.
Prov. Even a child makes himself known by his doings, whether his work be pure,  whether it be right.
Prov. The hearing ear,  the seeing eye, Jehovah has made even both of them.
Prov. Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty. Open thine eyes,  thou shall be satisfied with bread.
Prov. It is bad, it is bad, says the buyer,  when he is gone his way, then he boasts.
Prov. There is gold,  abundance of rubies,  the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
Prov. Take his garment who is surety for a stranger,  hold him in pledge for foreigners.
Prov. Bread of falsehood is sweet to a man,  afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
Prov. Every purpose is established by counsel,  by wise guidance make thou war.
Prov. He who goes about as a tale-bearer reveals secrets. Therefore do not associate with him who opens wide his lips.
Prov. He who curses his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in blackness of darkness.
Prov. An inheritance gotten hastily at the beginning shall not be blessed in the end.
Prov. Say thou not, I will recompense evil. Wait for Jehovah,  he will save thee.
Prov. Diverse weights are an abomination to Jehovah,  a false balance is not good.
Prov. A man's goings are of Jehovah, how then can man understand his way?
Prov. It is a snare to a man to say rashly, It is holy. And to make inquiry after vows.
Prov. A wise king winnows the wicked,  brings the wheel over them.
Prov. The spirit of man is the lamp of Jehovah, searching all his innermost parts.
Prov. Kindness and truth preserve the king,  his throne is upheld by kindness.
Prov. The glory of young men is their strength,  the beauty of old men is the hoary head.
Prov. Stripes that wound cleanse away evil,  strokes, the innermost parts.
Prov. The king's heart is in the hand of Jehovah as streams of water. He turns it wherever he will.
Prov. Every way of a man is right in his own eyes,  Jehovah weighs the hearts.
Prov. To do righteousness and justice is more acceptable to Jehovah than sacrifice.
Prov. A high look,  a proud heart, even the lamp of the wicked, is sin.
Prov. The thoughts of a diligent man lead only to abundance,  everyone who is hasty, only to want.
Prov. The getting of treasures by a lying tongue is a vapor driven to and fro by those who seek death.
Prov. The violence of the wicked shall sweep them away, because they refuse to do justice.
Prov. The way of him who is laden with guilt is exceedingly crooked,  as for a pure man, his work is right.
Prov. It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a contentious woman in a wide house.
Prov. The soul of a wicked man desires evil. His neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
Prov. When a scoffer is punished, a simple man is made wise,  when a wise man is instructed, he receives knowledge.
Prov. A righteous man considers the house of the wicked: the wicked are overthrown to ruin.
Prov. He who stops his ears at the cry of a poor man, he also shall cry,  shall not be heard.
Prov. A gift in secret pacifies anger,  a present in the bosom, strong wrath.
Prov. It is joy to the righteous to do justice,  it is a destruction to the workers of iniquity.
Prov. The man who wanders out of the way of understanding shall rest in the assembly of the dead.
Prov. He who loves pleasure shall be a poor man. He who loves wine and oil shall not be rich.
Prov. A wicked man is a ransom for a righteous man,  the treacherous dealer for the upright.
Prov. It is better to dwell in a desert land, than with a contentious and fretful woman.
Prov. There is precious treasure and oil in the dwelling of a wise man,  a foolish man swallows it up.
Prov. He who follows after righteousness and kindness finds life, righteousness,  honor.
Prov. A wise man scales the city of the mighty,  brings down the strength of the confidence of it.
Prov. He who keeps his mouth and his tongue keeps his soul from troubles.
Prov. The proud and haughty man, scoffer is his name. He works in the arrogance of pride.
Prov. The desire of the sluggard kills him, for his hands refuse to labor.
Prov. There is he who covets greedily all the day long,  the righteous gives and does not withhold.
Prov. The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination. How much more when he brings it with a wicked mind!
Prov. A false witness shall perish,  the man who hears shall speak so as to endure.
Prov. A wicked man hardens his face,  as for an upright man, he establishes his ways.
Prov. There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against Jehovah.
Prov. The horse is prepared against the day of battle,  victory is from Jehovah.
Prov. A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, loving favor rather than silver and gold.
Prov. The rich and the poor meet together. Jehovah is the maker of them all.
Prov. A prudent man sees the evil,  hides himself,  the simple pass on,  suffer for it.
Prov. The reward of humility and the fear of Jehovah is riches and honor and life.
Prov. Thorns and snares are in the way of a perverse man. He who keeps his soul shall be far from them.
Prov. Train up a child in the way he should go,  even when he is old he will not depart from it.
Prov. The rich rule over the poor,  the borrower is servant to the lender.
Prov. He who sows iniquity shall reap calamity,  the rod of his wrath shall fail.
Prov. He who has a bountiful eye shall be blessed, for he gives of his bread to the poor.
Prov. Cast out the scoffer,  contention will go out, yea, strife and reproach will cease.
Prov. He who loves pureness of heart, for the grace of his lips, the king will be his friend.
Prov. The eyes of Jehovah preserve knowledge,  he overthrows the words of the treacherous man.
Prov. The sluggard says, There is a lion outside. I shall be slain in the streets.
Prov. The mouth of interloping women is a deep pit. He who is abhorred of Jehovah shall fall in it.
Prov. Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child,  the rod of correction shall drive it far from him.
Prov. He who oppresses a poor man to his increase,  he who gives to a rich man, comes only to want.
Prov. Incline thine ear,  hear the words of the wise,  apply thy heart to my knowledge.
Prov. For it is a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee, if they be established together upon thy lips.
Prov. That thy trust may be in Jehovah, I have made them known to thee this day, even to thee.
Prov. Have I not written to thee excellent things of counsels and knowledge,
Prov. to make thee know the certainty of the words of truth, that thou may carry back words of truth to those who send thee?
Prov. Do not rob a poor man, because he is poor, nor oppress an afflicted man in the gate.
Prov. For Jehovah will plead their cause,  despoil of life those who despoil them.
Prov. Make no friendship with a man who is given to anger,  thou shall not go with a wrathful man,
Prov. lest thou learn this ways,  get a snare to thy soul.
Prov. Be thou not one of those who strike hands, or of those who are sureties for debts.
Prov. If thou have not wherewith to pay, why should he take away thy bed from under thee?
Prov. Remove not the ancient landmark, which thy fathers have set.
Prov. See thou a man diligent in his business? He shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before obscure men.
Prov. When thou sit to eat with a ruler, consider diligently him who is before thee,
Prov. and put a knife to thy throat if thou be a man given to appetite.
Prov. Be not desirous of his dainties, since they are deceitful food.
Prov. Weary not thyself to be rich. Out of thine own wisdom, cease.
Prov. Will thou set thine eyes upon that which is not? For it certainly makes itself wings, like an eagle that flies toward heaven.
Prov. Eat thou not the bread of an evil eye, nor desire thou his dainties.
Prov. For as he thinks within himself, so is he. Eat and drink, he says to thee,  his heart is not with thee.
Prov. The morsel which thou have eaten thou shall vomit up,  lose thy sweet words.
Prov. Speak not in the hearing of a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of thy words.
Prov. Remove not the ancient landmark. And enter not into the fields of the fatherless,
Prov. for their Redeemer is strong. He will plead their cause against thee.
Prov. Apply thy heart to instruction,  thine ears to the words of knowledge.
Prov. Withhold not correction from the child, for if thou beat him with the rod, he will not die.
Prov. Thou shall beat him with the rod,  shall deliver his soul from Sheol.
Prov. My son, if thy heart be wise, my heart will be glad, even mine.
Prov. Yea, my heart will rejoice when thy lips speak right things.
Prov. Let not thy heart envy sinners,  be thou in the fear of Jehovah all the day long.
Prov. For surely there is a reward,  thy hope shall not be cut off.
Prov. Hear thou, my son,  be wise,  guide thy heart in the way.
Prov. Be not among winebibbers, among gluttonous eaters of flesh.
Prov. For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty,  drowsiness will clothe a man with rags.
Prov. Hearken to thy father who begot thee,  despise not thy mother when she is old.
Prov. Buy the truth,  do not sell it, yea, wisdom,  instruction,  understanding.
Prov. The father of a righteous man will greatly rejoice,  he who begets a wise son will have joy of him.
Prov. Let thy father and thy mother be glad,  let her who bore thee rejoice.
Prov. My son, give me thy heart,  let thine eyes delight in my ways.
Prov. For a harlot is a deep ditch,  an interloping woman is a narrow pit.
Prov. Yea, she lies in wait as a robber,  increases the treacherous among men.
Prov. Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? Who has complaining? Who has wounds without cause? Who has redness of eyes?
Prov. Those who tarry long at the wine. Those who go to seek out mixed wine.
Prov. Look not thou upon the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it goes down smoothly.
Prov. At the end it bites like a serpent,  stings like an adder.
Prov. Thine eyes shall behold strange things,  thy heart shall utter perverse things.
Prov. Yea, thou shall be as he who lies down in the midst of the sea, or as he who lies upon the top of a mast.
Prov. They have stricken me, thou shall say,  I was not hurt. They have beaten me,  I did not feel it. When shall I awake? I will seek it yet again.
Prov. Be not thou envious against evil men, nor desire to be with them.
Prov. For their heart meditates oppression,  their lips talk of mischief.
Prov. Through wisdom a house is built,  by understanding it is established,
Prov. and by knowledge the chambers are filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
Prov. A wise man is strong, yea, a man of knowledge increases might.
Prov. For by wise guidance thou shall make thy war,  in the multitude of counselors there is safety.
Prov. Wisdom is too high for a fool. He opens not his mouth in the gate.
Prov. He who devises to do evil, men shall call him a mischief-maker.
Prov. The thought of folly is sin. And the scoffer is an abomination to men.
Prov. If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small.
Prov. Deliver those who are carried away to death,  hold thou back those who are ready to be slain.
Prov. If thou say, Behold, we did not know this, Does not he who weighs the hearts consider it? And he who keeps thy soul, does he not know it? And shall not he render to every man according to his work?
Prov. My son, eat thou honey, for it is good,  the droppings of the honeycomb, which are sweet to thy taste,
Prov. so the knowledge of wisdom is to thy soul. If thou have found it, then there shall be a reward,  thy hope shall not be cut off.
Prov. Lay not in wait, O wicked man, against the habitation of the righteous. Do not destroy his resting place.
Prov. For a righteous man falls seven times,  rises up again,  the wicked are overthrown by calamity.
Prov. Rejoice not when thine enemy falls,  let not thy heart be glad when he is overthrown,
Prov. lest Jehovah see it,  it displease him,  he turn away his wrath from him.
Prov. Fret not thyself because of evildoers, nor be thou envious at the wicked.
Prov. For there shall be no reward to the evil man. The lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
Prov. My son, fear thou Jehovah and the king,  do not associate with those who are given to change.
Prov. For their calamity shall rise suddenly,  the destruction from them both, who knows it?
Prov. These also are from the wise: To have respect of persons in judgment is not good.
Prov. He who says to a wicked man, Thou are righteous, peoples shall curse him, nations shall abhor him.
Prov. But to those who rebuke him shall be delight,  a good blessing shall come upon them.
Prov. He who gives a right answer kisses the lips.
Prov. Prepare thy work outside,  make it ready for thee in the field,  afterwards build thy house.
Prov. Be not a witness against thy neighbor without cause,  deceive not with thy lips.
Prov. Say not, I will do so to him as he has done to me; I will render to the man according to his work.
Prov. I went by the field of the sluggard,  by the vineyard of the man void of understanding.
Prov. And, lo, it was all grown over with thorns. The face of it was covered with nettles,  the stone wall of it was broken down.
Prov. Then I beheld,  considered well. I saw,  received instruction:
Prov. Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep,
Prov. so thy poverty shall come as a robber,  thy want as an armed man.
Prov. These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.
Prov. It is the glory of God to conceal a thing,  the glory of kings is to search out a matter.
Prov. As the heavens for height,  the earth for depth, so the heart of kings is unsearchable.
Prov. Take away the dross from the silver,  there comes forth a vessel for the refiner.
Prov. Take away the wicked from before the king,  his throne shall be established in righteousness.
Prov. Put not thyself forward in the presence of the king,  stand not in the place of great men.
Prov. For it is better that it be said to thee, Come up here, than that thou should be put lower in the presence of the prince, whom thine eyes have seen.
Prov. Go not forth hastily to strive. What will thou do in the end of it when thy neighbor has put thee to shame?
Prov. Debate thy case with thy neighbor himself,  disclose not the secret of another,
Prov. lest he who hears it revile thee,  thine infamy turn not away.
Prov. A word fitly spoken is apples of gold in a network of silver.
Prov. An earring of gold,  an ornament of fine gold, is a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.
Prov. As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, is a faithful messenger to those who send him, for he refreshes the soul of his masters.
Prov. Clouds and wind without rain, is he who boasts himself of his gifts falsely.
Prov. By long-suffering a ruler is persuaded,  a soft tongue breaks the bone.
Prov. Have thou found honey? Eat as much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled with it,  vomit it.
Prov. Let thy foot be seldom in thy neighbor's house, lest he be weary of thee,  hate thee.
Prov. A man who bears false witness against his neighbor is a maul,  a sword,  a sharp arrow.
Prov. Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is a broken tooth,  a foot out of joint.
Prov. As he who takes off a garment in cold weather,  vinegar upon soda, so is he who sings songs to a heavy heart.
Prov. If thine enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat,  if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
Prov. For thou will heap coals of fire upon his head,  Jehovah will reward thee.
Prov. The north wind brings forth rain. So does a backbiting tongue, an angry countenance.
Prov. It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a contentious woman in a wide house.
Prov. As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.
Prov. A troubled fountain,  a corrupted spring, is a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
Prov. It is not good to eat much honey, so for men to search out their own glory is grievous.
Prov. He whose spirit is without restraint is a city that is broken down and without walls.
Prov. As snow in summer,  as rain in harvest, so honor is not seemly for a fool.
Prov. As the sparrow in her wandering, as the swallow in her flying, so the curse that is causeless does not alight.
Prov. A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,  a rod for the back of fools.
Prov. Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like to him.
Prov. Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.
Prov. He who sends a message by the hand of a fool cuts off the feet,  drinks injury.
Prov. The legs of a lame man hang loose. So is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Prov. As he who binds a stone in a sling, so is he who gives honor to a fool.
Prov. As a thorn that goes up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Prov. As an archer who wounds all, so is he who hires a fool,  he who hires those who pass by.
Prov. As a dog who returns to his vomit, is a fool who repeats his folly.
Prov. See thou a man wise in his own conceit? There is more hope for a fool than of him.
Prov. The sluggard says, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.
Prov. The door turns upon its hinges, so does the sluggard upon his bed.
Prov. The sluggard buries his hand in the dish. It wearies him to bring it again to his mouth.
Prov. The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men who can render a reason.
Prov. He who passes by,  meddles with strife not his, is like he who takes a dog by the ears.
Prov. As a madman who casts firebrands, arrows,  death,
Prov. so is the man who deceives his neighbor,  says, Am I not in sport?
Prov. For lack of wood the fire goes out,  where there is no whisperer, contention ceases.
Prov. As coals are to hot embers,  wood to fire, so is a contentious man to inflame strife.
Prov. The words of a whisperer are as dainty morsels,  they go down into the innermost parts.
Prov. Fervent lips and a wicked heart are an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross.
Prov. He who hates masquerades with his lips,  he lays up deceit within him.
Prov. When he speaks graciously, believe him not, for there are seven abominations in his heart.
Prov. Though his hatred cover itself with guile, his wickedness shall be openly shown before the assembly.
Prov. He who digs a pit shall fall in it,  he who rolls a stone, it shall return upon him.
Prov. A lying tongue hates those whom it has wounded,  a flattering mouth works ruin.
Prov. Boast not thyself of tomorrow, for thou know not what a day may bring forth.
Prov. Let another man praise thee,  not thine own mouth, a stranger,  not thine own lips.
Prov. A stone is heavy,  the sand weighty,  a fool's vexation is heavier than both.
Prov. Wrath is cruel,  anger is overwhelming,  who is able to stand before jealousy?
Prov. Better is open rebuke than love that is hidden.
Prov. Faithful are the wounds of a friend,  the kisses of an enemy are profuse.
Prov. The full soul loathes a honeycomb,  to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
Prov. As a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man who wanders from his place.
Prov. Oil and perfume rejoice the heart, so too the sweetness of a man's friend by hearty counsel.
Prov. Forsake not thine own friend,  thy father's friend. And go not to thy brother's house in the day of thy calamity. Better is a neighbor nearby than a brother far off.
Prov. My son, be wise,  make my heart glad, that I may answer him who reproaches me.
Prov. A prudent man sees the evil,  hides himself. The simple pass on,  suffer for it.
Prov. Take his garment who is surety for a stranger,  hold him in pledge who is surety for a strange woman.
Prov. He who blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be considered a curse to him.
Prov. A continual dropping in a very rainy day,  a contentious woman are alike.
Prov. He who would restrain her restrains the wind,  his right hand encounters oil.
Prov. Iron sharpens iron, so a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
Prov. He who keeps the fig tree shall eat the fruit of it,  he who regards his master shall be honored.
Prov. As in water face is to face, so the heart of a man is to a man.
Prov. Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,  the eyes of man are never satisfied.
Prov. The refining pot is for silver,  the furnace for gold,  a man is tried by his praise.
Prov. Though thou should pound a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain, yet his foolishness will not depart from him.
Prov. Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks,  look well to thy herds.
Prov. For riches are not forever. And does the crown endure to all generations?
Prov. The hay is carried,  the tender grass shows itself,  the herbs of the mountains are gathered in.
Prov. The lambs are for thy clothing,  the goats are the cost of the field.
Prov. And then will be goats' milk enough for thy food; for the food of thy household,  maintenance for thy maidens.
Prov. A wicked man flees when no man pursues,  the righteous are bold as a lion.
Prov. For the transgression of a land many are the rulers of it. But by men of understanding and knowledge the state shall be prolonged.
Prov. A needy man who oppresses the poor is a sweeping rain which leaves no food.
Prov. Those who forsake the law praise the wicked,  such as keep the law contend with them.
Prov. Evil men do not understand justice,  those who seek Jehovah understand all things.
Prov. Better is the poor man who walks in his integrity, than he who is perverse in his ways, though he be rich.
Prov. He who keeps the law is a wise son,  he who is a companion of gluttons shames his father.
Prov. He who augments his substance by interest and increase, gathers it for him who has pity on the poor.
Prov. He who turns away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer is an abomination.
Prov. He who causes the upright to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit. But the perfect shall inherit good.
Prov. The rich man is wise in his own conceit,  a poor man who has understanding searches him out.
Prov. When the righteous triumph, there is great glory,  when the wicked rise, men hide themselves.
Prov. He who covers his transgressions shall not prosper,  he who confesses and forsakes them shall obtain mercy.
Prov. Happy is the man who fears always,  he who hardens his heart shall fall into mischief.
Prov. A roaring lion,  a ranging bear, is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
Prov. The ruler who lacks understanding is also a great oppressor,  he who hates covetousness shall prolong his days.
Prov. A man who is laden with the blood of any person shall flee to the pit. Let no man stay him.
Prov. He who walks uprightly shall be delivered,  he who is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.
Prov. He who tills his land shall have plenty of bread,  he who follows after vanity shall have poverty enough.
Prov. A faithful man shall abound with blessings,  he who makes haste to be rich shall not be unpunished.
Prov. To have respect of persons is not good, nor that a man should transgress for a piece of bread.
Prov. He who has an evil eye hastens after riches,  does not know that want shall come upon him.
Prov. He who rebukes a man shall afterward find more favor than he who flatters with the tongue.
Prov. He who robs his father or his mother,  says, It is no transgression, the same is the companion of a destroyer.
Prov. He who is of a greedy spirit stirs up strife,  he who puts his trust in Jehovah shall be made fat.
Prov. He who trusts in his own heart is a fool,  he who walks wisely, he shall be delivered.
Prov. He who gives to the poor shall not lack,  he who hides his eyes shall have many a curse.
Prov. When the wicked rise, men hide themselves,  when they perish, the righteous increase.
Prov. He who, being often reproved, hardens his neck shall suddenly be destroyed,  that without remedy.
Prov. When the righteous are increased, the people rejoice,  when a wicked man bears rule, the people sigh.
Prov. He who loves wisdom delights his father,  he who keeps company with harlots wastes his substance.
Prov. By justice the king establishes the land,  he who exacts gifts overthrows it.
Prov. A man who flatters his neighbor spreads a net for his steps.
Prov. In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare,  a righteous man sings and rejoices.
Prov. A righteous man takes knowledge of the cause of the poor. A wicked man has no such understanding to know.
Prov. Scoffers set a city in a flame,  wise men turn away wrath.
Prov. If a wise man has a controversy with a foolish man, whether he be angry or laugh, there will be no rest.
Prov. Bloodthirsty men hate him who is perfect,  the upright seek his soul.
Prov. A fool utters all his anger,  a wise man keeps it back and calms it.
Prov. If a ruler hearkens to falsehood, all his servants are wicked.
Prov. The poor man and the oppressor meet together. Jehovah enlightens the eyes of them both.
Prov. The king who faithfully judges the poor, his throne shall be established forever.
Prov. The rod and reproof give wisdom,  a child left to himself causes shame to his mother.
Prov. When the wicked are increased, transgression increases,  the righteous shall look upon their fall.
Prov. Correct thy son,  he will give thee rest, yea, he will give delight to thy soul.
Prov. Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint,  he who keeps the law, happy is he.
Prov. A servant will not be corrected by words, for though he understands, he will not give heed.
Prov. See thou a man who is hasty in his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
Prov. He who brings up his servant gently from childhood shall have him become a son at the last.
Prov. An angry man stirs up strife,  a wrathful man abounds in transgression.
Prov. A man's pride shall bring him low,  he who is of a lowly spirit shall obtain honor.
Prov. He who is partner with a thief hates his own soul; he hears the adjuration and utters nothing.
Prov. The fear of man brings a snare,  he who puts his trust in Jehovah shall be safe.
Prov. Many seek the ruler's favor,  a man's justice is from Jehovah.
Prov. An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous,  he who is upright in the way is an abomination to a wicked man.
Prov. The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, the oracle. The man says to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:
Prov. Surely I am more brutish than any man,  have not the understanding of a man,
Prov. and I have not learned wisdom, nor have I the knowledge of the Holy.
Prov. Who has ascended up into heaven,  descended? Who has gathered the wind in his fists? Who has bound the waters in his garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is his name,  what is his son's name, if thou know?
Prov. Every word of God is tried. He is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
Prov. Add thou not to his words, lest he reprove thee,  thou be found a liar.
Prov. Two things I have asked of thee, deny me not before I die:
Prov. Remove far from me falsehood and lies. Give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the food that is needful for me,
Prov. lest I be full,  deny thee,  say, Who is Jehovah? or lest I be poor,  steal,  use the name of my God profanely.
Prov. Slander not a servant to his master, lest he curse thee,  thou be held guilty.
Prov. There is a generation who curses their father,  does not bless their mother.
Prov. There is a generation who are pure in their own eyes,  yet are not washed from their filthiness.
Prov. There is a generation, O how lofty are their eyes,  their eyelids are lifted up.
Prov. There is a generation whose teeth are swords,  their jaw teeth, knives, to devour the poor from off the earth,  the needy from among men.
Prov. The leach has two daughters, crying, Give, give. There are three things that are never satisfied, yea, four that do not say, Enough:
Prov. Sheol,  the barren womb, the earth that is not satisfied with water,  the fire that does not say, Enough.
Prov. The eye that mocks at his father,  despises to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out,  the young eagles shall eat it.
Prov. There are three things which are too wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not:
Prov. The way of an eagle in the air, the way of a serpent upon a rock, the way of a ship in the midst of the sea,  the way of a man with a maiden.
Prov. So is the way of an adulterous woman: She eats,  wipes her mouth,  says, I have done no iniquity.
Prov. For three things the earth trembles,  for four, which it cannot bear:
Prov. For a servant when he is king,  a fool when he is filled with food,
Prov. for a hateful woman when she is married,  a handmaid that is heir to her mistress.
Prov. There are four things which are little upon the earth,  they are exceedingly wise:
Prov. The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer,
Prov. the conies are but a feeble folk, yet they make their houses in the rocks,
Prov. the locusts have no king, yet they go forth all of them by bands,
Prov. the lizard takes hold with her hands, yet she is in kings' palaces.
Prov. There are three things which are stately in their march, yea, four which are stately in going:
Prov. The lion, which is mightiest among beasts,  turns not away from any,
Prov. the greyhound, also the he-goat,  the king against whom there is no rising up.
Prov. If thou have done foolishly in lifting up thyself, or if thou have thought evil, lay thy hand upon thy mouth.
Prov. For the churning of milk brings forth butter,  the wringing of the nose brings forth blood, so the forcing of wrath brings forth strife.
Prov. The words of king Lemuel, the oracle which his mother taught him.
Prov. What, my son? And what, O son of my womb? And what, O son of my vows?
Prov. Give not thy strength to women, nor thy ways to that which destroys kings.
Prov. It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, nor for rulers to say, Where is strong drink?
Prov. Lest they drink,  forget the law,  pervert the justice due to any who is afflicted.
Prov. Give strong drink to him who is ready to perish,  wine to the bitter in soul.
Prov. Let him drink,  forget his need,  remember his misery no more.
Prov. Open thy mouth for the mute, in the cause of all such as are left desolate.
Prov. Open thy mouth, judge righteously,  minister justice to the poor and needy.
Prov. A worthy woman who can find? For her price is far above rubies.
Prov. The heart of her husband trusts in her,  he shall have no lack of gain.
Prov. She does him good and not evil all the days of her life.
Prov. She seeks wool and flax,  works willingly with her hands.
Prov. She is like the merchant ships: she brings her bread from afar.
Prov. She also rises while it is yet night,  gives food to her household,  their task to her maidens.
Prov. She considers a field,  buys it. With the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
Prov. She girds her loins with strength,  makes strong her arms.
Prov. She perceives that her merchandise is profitable. Her lamp does not go out by night.
Prov. She lays her hands to the distaff,  her hands hold the spindle.
Prov. She stretches out her hand to the poor, yea, she reaches forth her hands to the needy.
Prov. She is not afraid of the snow for her household, for all her household are clothed with scarlet.
Prov. She makes for herself carpets of tapestry. Her clothing is fine linen and purple.
Prov. Her husband is known in the gates when he sits among the elders of the land.
Prov. She makes linen garments and sells them,  delivers girdles to the merchant.
Prov. Strength and dignity are her clothing,  she laughs at the time to come.
Prov. She opens her mouth with wisdom,  the law of kindness is on her tongue.
Prov. She looks well to the ways of her household,  does not eat the bread of idleness.
Prov. Her sons rise up,  call her blessed. Her husband also,  he praises her.
Prov. Many daughters have done worthily,  thou excel them all.
Prov. Charm is deceitful,  beauty is vain,  a woman who fears Jehovah, she shall be praised.
Prov. Give her of the fruit of her hands,  let her works praise her in the gates.
Ecclesiastes
Eccl. The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
Eccl. Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher, vanity of vanities, all is vanity.
Eccl. What profit has man from all his labor in which he labors under the sun?
Eccl. One generation goes,  another generation comes,  the earth abides forever.
Eccl. The sun also arises,  the sun goes down and hastens to its place where it arises.
Eccl. The wind goes toward the south,  turns around to the north. It turns around continually in its course,  the wind returns again to its circuits.
Eccl. All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full. To the place from where the rivers come, there they go again.
Eccl. All things are full of weariness, man cannot utter it. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
Eccl. That which has been is that which shall be,  that which has been done is that which shall be done. And there is no new thing under the sun.
Eccl. Is there a thing of which it may be said, See, this is new? It has been long ago, in the ages which were before us.
Eccl. There is no remembrance of the former things, nor shall there be any remembrance of the latter that are to come, among those who shall come after.
Eccl. I the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
Eccl. And I applied my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom concerning all that is done under heaven. It is a great tribulation that God has given to the sons of men to be exercised therewith.
Eccl. I have seen all the works that are done under the sun, , behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. That which is crooked cannot be made straight,  that which is wanting cannot be numbered.
Eccl. I communed with my own heart, saying, Lo, I have gotten for me great wisdom above all who were before me in Jerusalem. Yea, my heart has had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.
Eccl. And I applied my heart to know wisdom,  to know madness and folly. I perceived that this also was a striving after wind.
Eccl. For in much wisdom is much grief,  he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
Eccl. I said in my heart, Come now, I will prove thee with mirth, therefore enjoy pleasure. And, behold, this also was vanity.
Eccl. I said of laughter, It is mad,  of mirth, What does it do?
Eccl. I searched in my heart how to cheer my flesh with wine (my heart yet guiding me with wisdom),  how to lay hold on folly, till I might see what it was good for the sons of men that they should do under heaven all the days of their life.
Eccl. I made for me great works. I built for me houses. I planted for me vineyards.
Eccl. I made for me gardens and parks,  I planted trees in them of all kinds of fruit.
Eccl. I made for me pools of water, to water from there the forest where trees were reared.
Eccl. I bought men-servants and maid-servants,  had servants born in my house. I also had great possessions of herds and flocks, above all who were before me in Jerusalem.
Eccl. I also gathered for me silver and gold,  the treasure of kings and of the provinces. I got for me men-singers and women-singers,  the luxuries of the sons of men,  a wife and wives.
Eccl. So I was great,  increased more than all who were before me in Jerusalem. Also my wisdom remained with me.
Eccl. And whatever my eyes desired I kept not from them. I did not withhold my heart from any joy. For my heart rejoiced because of all my labor,  this was my portion from all my labor.
Eccl. Then I looked on all the works that my hands had wrought,  on the labor that I had labored to do, , behold, all was vanity and a striving after wind,  there was no profit under the sun.
Eccl. And I turned myself to behold wisdom and madness and folly. For what can the man do who comes after the king? Even that which has been done long ago.
Eccl. Then I saw that wisdom excels folly as far as light excels darkness.
Eccl. The wise man's eyes are in his head,  the fool walks in darkness. And yet I perceived that one event happens to them all.
Eccl. Then I said in my heart, As it happens to the fool, so it will happen even to me,  why then was I more wise? Then I said in my heart that this also is vanity.
Eccl. For of the wise man, even as of the fool, there is no remembrance forever, seeing that in the days to come all will have been long forgotten. And how the wise man dies even as the fool!
Eccl. So I hated life, because the work that is wrought under the sun was grievous to me. For all is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. And I hated all my labor in which I labored under the sun, seeing that I must leave it to the man who shall be after me.
Eccl. And who knows whether he will be a wise man or a fool? Yet he will have rule over all my labor in which I have labored,  in which I have shown myself wise under the sun. This also is vanity.
Eccl. Therefore I turned about to cause my heart to despair concerning all the labor in which I had labored under the sun.
Eccl. For there is a man whose labor is with wisdom,  with knowledge,  with skillfulness, yet he shall leave it to a man who has not labored in it for his portion. This also is vanity and a great evil.
Eccl. For what has a man of all his labor,  of the striving of his heart in which he labors under the sun?
Eccl. For all his days are but sorrows,  his travail is grief, yea, even in the night his heart takes no rest. This also is vanity.
Eccl. There is nothing better for a man than that he should eat and drink,  make his soul enjoy good in his labor. This also I saw, that it is from the hand of God.
Eccl. For who can eat, or who can have enjoyment, without him?
Eccl. For to the man who pleases him God gives wisdom and knowledge and joy,  to the sinner he gives travail, to gather and to heap up, that he may give to him who pleases God. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. For everything there is a season,  a time for every purpose under heaven:
Eccl. a time to be born,  a time to die, a time to plant,  a time to pluck up that which is planted,
Eccl. a time to kill,  a time to heal, a time to break down,  a time to build up,
Eccl. a time to weep,  a time to laugh, a time to mourn,  a time to dance,
Eccl. a time to cast away stones,  a time to gather stones together, a time to embrace,  a time to refrain from embracing,
Eccl. a time to seek,  a time to lose, a time to keep,  a time to cast away,
Eccl. a time to tear,  a time to sew, a time to keep silence,  a time to speak,
Eccl. a time to love,  a time to hate, a time for war,  a time for peace.
Eccl. What profit has he who works in that in which he labors?
Eccl. I have seen the travail which God has given to the sons of men to be employed therewith.
Eccl. He has made everything beautiful in its time. Also he has set eternity in their heart, yet so that man cannot find out the work that God has done from the beginning even to the end.
Eccl. I know that there is nothing better for them, than to rejoice,  to do good as long as they live.
Eccl. And also that every man should eat and drink,  enjoy good in all his labor. It is the gift of God.
Eccl. I know that, whatever God does, it shall be forever. Nothing can be put to it, nor anything taken from it. And God has done it that men should fear before him.
Eccl. That which is, has been long ago,  that which is to be, has long ago been. And God seeks again that which has passed away.
Eccl. And moreover I saw under the sun, in the place of justice, that wickedness was there,  in the place of righteousness, that wickedness was there.
Eccl. I said in my heart, God will judge the righteous man and the wicked man, for there is a time there for every purpose and for every work.
Eccl. I said in my heart, It is because of the sons of men, that God may prove them,  that they may see that they themselves are beasts.
Eccl. For that which befalls the sons of men befalls beasts, even one thing befalls them; as the one dies, so dies the other. Yea, they all have one breath,  man has no preeminence above the beasts; for all is vanity.
Eccl. All go to one place. All are of the dust,  all turn to dust again.
Eccl. Who knows the spirit of man, whether it goes upward,  the spirit of the beast, whether it goes downward to the earth?
Eccl. Therefore I saw that there is nothing better, than that a man should rejoice in his works, for that is his portion. For who shall bring him back to see what shall be after him?
Eccl. Then I returned and saw all the oppressions that are done under the sun. And, behold, the tears of such as were oppressed,  they had no comforter. And on the side of their oppressors there was power,  they had no comforter.
Eccl. Therefore I praised the dead who have long been dead more than the living who are yet alive.
Eccl. Yea, better than them both is him who has not yet been, who has not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
Eccl. Then I saw all labor and every skilful work, that for this a man is envied by his neighbor. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. The fool folds his hands together,  eats his own flesh.
Eccl. Better is a handful, with quietness, than two handfuls with labor and striving after wind.
Eccl. Then I returned and saw vanity under the sun.
Eccl. There is one man who is alone,  he has not a second, yea, he has neither son nor brother. Yet there is no end of all his labor, nor are his eyes satisfied with riches. For whom then, he says, do I labor,  deprive my soul of good? This also is vanity, yea, it is a great travail.
Eccl. Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their labor.
Eccl. For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow,  woe to him who is alone when he falls,  has not another to lift him up.
Eccl. Again, if two lie together, then they have warmth,  how can one be warm alone?
Eccl. And if a man prevails against him who is alone, two shall withstand him. And a threefold cord is not quickly broken.
Eccl. Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king who does not know how to receive admonition any more.
Eccl. For he came forth out of prison to be king, yea, even in his kingdom he was born poor.
Eccl. I saw all the living who walk under the sun, that they were with the youth, the second, who stood up in his stead.
Eccl. There was no end of all the people, even of all those over whom he was. Yet those who come after shall not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. Keep thy foot when thou go to the house of God, for to draw near to hear is better than to give the sacrifice of fools. For they know not that they do evil.
Eccl. Be not rash with thy mouth,  let not thy heart be hasty to utter anything before God. For God is in heaven,  thou upon earth. Therefore let thy words be few.
Eccl. For a dream comes with a multitude of business,  a fool's voice with a multitude of words.
Eccl. When thou vow a vow to God, defer not to pay it, for he has no pleasure in fools. Pay that which thou vow.
Eccl. Better is it that thou should not vow, than that thou should vow and not pay.
Eccl. Do not allow thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin, nor say thou before the agent, that is was an error. Why should God be angry at thy voice,  destroy the work of thy hands?
Eccl. For in the multitude of dreams there are vanities,  in many words. But fear thou God.
Eccl. If thou see the oppression of a poor man,  the violent wresting of justice and righteousness in a province, marvel not at the matter. For a man higher than the high is observing,  there are higher men than they.
Eccl. Moreover the abundance of the land is for all. The king himself is served by the field.
Eccl. He who loves silver shall not be satisfied with silver, nor he who loves abundance, with increase. This also is vanity.
Eccl. When goods increase, they are increased who eat them. And what advantage is there to the owner of it, except the beholding of them with his eyes?
Eccl. The sleep of a laboring man is sweet, whether he eats little or much,  the fullness of the rich will not allow him to sleep.
Eccl. There is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun: Riches were kept by the owner of it to his hurt.
Eccl. And those riches perish in a bad venture. And if he has begotten a son, there is nothing in his hand.
Eccl. As he came forth from his mother's womb, naked shall he go again as he came,  shall take nothing for his labor, which he may carry away in his hand.
Eccl. And this also is a grievous evil, that in all points as he came, so shall he go. And what profit has he that he labored for the wind?
Eccl. All his days also he eats in gloom,  he is greatly troubled,  has depression and anger.
Eccl. Behold, that which I have seen to be good and to be fitting is for a man to eat and to drink,  to enjoy good in all his labor in which he labors under the sun all the days of his life which God has given him, for this is his portion.
Eccl. Every man also to whom God has given riches and wealth,  has given him power to eat of it,  to take his portion,  to rejoice in his labor-this is the gift of God.
Eccl. For he shall not much remember the days of his life, because God answers him in the joy of his heart.
Eccl. There is an evil which I have seen under the sun,  it is heavy upon men:
Eccl. A man to whom God gives riches, wealth,  honor, so that he lacks nothing for his soul of all that he desires, yet God does not give him power to eat of it,  an alien eats it. This is vanity,  it is an evil disease.
Eccl. If a man begets a hundred sons,  lives many years so that the days of his years are many,  his soul is not filled with good,  moreover he has no burial, I say, that an untimely birth is better than he.
Eccl. For it comes in vanity,  departs in darkness,  the name of it is covered with darkness.
Eccl. Moreover it has not seen the sun nor known it, this one has rest rather than the other.
Eccl. Yea, though he lives a thousand years twice told,  yet enjoys no good, do not all go to one place?
Eccl. All the labor of man is for his mouth,  yet the appetite is not filled.
Eccl. For what advantage has the wise man more than the fool? What has the poor man, who knows how to walk before the living?
Eccl. Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
Eccl. Whatever has been, the name of it was given long ago,  it is know what man is. Neither can he contend with him who is mightier than he.
Eccl. Since there are many things that increase vanity, what is man the better?
Eccl. For who knows what is good for man in life, all the days of his vain life which he spends as a shadow? For who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?
Eccl. A good name is better than precious oil,  the day of death, than the day of birth.
Eccl. It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting. For that is the end of all men,  the living will lay it to his heart.
Eccl. Sorrow is better than laughter, for by the sadness of the countenance the heart is made glad.
Eccl. The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning,  the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
Eccl. It is better to hear the rebuke of a wise man, than for a man to hear the song of fools.
Eccl. For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool. This also is vanity.
Eccl. Surely oppression makes the wise man foolish,  a bribe destroys the understanding.
Eccl. Better is the end of a thing than the beginning of it. The patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.
Eccl. Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry, for anger rests in the bosom of fools.
Eccl. Say thou not, What is the cause that the former days were better than these? For thou do not inquire wisely concerning this.
Eccl. Wisdom is as good as an inheritance, yea, it is more excellent for those who see the sun.
Eccl. For wisdom is a defense, even as money is a defense. But the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom preserves the life of him who has it.
Eccl. Consider the work of God. For who can make that straight, which he has made crooked?
Eccl. In the day of prosperity be joyful,  in the day of adversity consider. Yea, God has made the one side by side with the other, to the end that man should not find out anything after him.
Eccl. All this I have seen in my days of vanity. There is a righteous man who perishes in his righteousness,  there is a wicked man who prolongs his life in his evil-doing.
Eccl. Be not over-righteous, nor show thyself too wise. Why should thou destroy thyself?
Eccl. Do not much wrong, nor be thou a fool. Why should thou die before thy time?
Eccl. It is good that thou should take hold of this, yea, also from that withdraw not thy hand. For he who fears God shall come forth from them all.
Eccl. Wisdom is a strength to the wise man more than ten rulers that are in a city.
Eccl. Surely there is not a righteous man upon earth that does good,  sins not.
Eccl. Also do not take heed to all words that are spoken, lest thou hear thy servant curse thee.
Eccl. For many times also thine own heart knows that thou thyself likewise have cursed others.
Eccl. All this I have proved in wisdom. I said, I will be wise,  it was far from me.
Eccl. That which is, is far off and exceedingly deep. Who can find it out?
Eccl. I turned about,  my heart was set to know and to search out,  to seek wisdom and the reason of things,  to know that wickedness is folly,  that foolishness is madness.
Eccl. And I find more bitter than death the woman whose heart is snares and nets,  whose hands are chains. He who pleases God shall escape from her,  the sinner shall be taken by her.
Eccl. Behold, I have found this, says the Preacher, laying one thing to another, to find out the account,
Eccl. which my soul still seeks,  I have not found: among a thousand I have found one man,  among all those I have not found a woman.
