Eccl. Behold, this only I have found: That God made man upright,  they have sought out many contrivances.
Eccl. Who is as the wise man? And who knows the interpretation of a thing? A man's wisdom makes his face to shine,  the hardness of his face is changed.
Eccl. I say, Keep the king's command,  that because of the oath of God.
Eccl. Be not hasty to go out of his presence. Persist not in an evil matter, for he does whatever pleases him.
Eccl. For the king's word has power,  who may say to him, What are thou doing?
Eccl. He who keeps a commandment shall know no evil thing. And a wise man's heart discerns the time and decision.
Eccl. For to every purpose there is a time and decision, although the distress of man is great upon him.
Eccl. For he knows not that which shall be, for who can tell him how it shall be?
Eccl. There is no man who has power over the spirit to retain the spirit, nor has he power over the day of death. And there is no discharge in war. Neither shall wickedness deliver him who is given to it.
Eccl. All this I have seen,  applied my heart to every work that is done under the sun. There is a time in which one man has power over another to his hurt.
Eccl. So I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy,  they were praised in the city where they had so done. This also is vanity.
Eccl. Because sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.
Eccl. Though a sinner does evil a hundred times,  prolongs his days, yet surely I know that it shall be well with those who fear God, who fear before him.
Eccl. But it shall not be well with a wicked man, neither shall he prolong his days, which are as a shadow, because he did not fear before God.
Eccl. There is a vanity which is done upon the earth, that there are righteous men to whom it happens according to the work of the wicked, again, there are wicked men to whom it happens according to the work of the righteous. I said that this also is vanity.
Eccl. Then I commended joy, because a man has no better thing under the sun, than to eat,  to drink,  to be cheerful. For that shall abide with him in his labor all the days of his life which God has given him under the sun.
Eccl. When I applied my heart to know wisdom,  to see the business that is done upon the earth (for also there is he who sees sleep with his eyes neither day nor night),
Eccl. then I beheld all the work of God, that man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun. Because however much a man labors to seek it out, yet he shall not find it. Yea moreover, though a wise man thinks to know it, yet he shall not be able to find it.
Eccl. For all this I laid to my heart, even to explore all this, that the righteous,  the wise,  their works, are in the hand of God. No man understands, either love or hatred. All is before them.
Eccl. All things come alike to all. There is one event to the righteous man and to the wicked man, to the good man,  to the clean man,  to the unclean man, to him who sacrifices and to him who does not sacrifice, as is the good man, so is the sinner,  he who swears, as he who fears an oath.
Eccl. This is an evil in all that is done under the sun, that there is one event to all. Yea also, the heart of the sons of men is full of evil,  madness is in their heart while they live,  after that they go to the dead.
Eccl. Because to him who is joined with all the living there is hope, for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
Eccl. For the living know that they shall die,  the dead know not anything, nor have they any more a reward, for the memory of them is forgotten.
Eccl. As well their love, as their hatred and their envy, has perished long ago, nor have they any more a portion forever in anything that is done under the sun.
Eccl. Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy,  drink thy wine with a merry heart, for God has already accepted thy works.
Eccl. Let thy garments be always white,  let not thy head lack oil.
Eccl. Live joyfully with the wife whom thou love all the days of thy life of vanity, which he has given thee under the sun, all thy days of vanity. For that is thy portion in life,  in thy labor in which thou labor under the sun.
Eccl. Whatever thy hand finds to do, do with thy might, for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in Sheol, where thou go.
Eccl. I returned,  saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill,  time and chance happens to them all.
Eccl. For man also does not know his time. As the fishes that are taken in an evil net,  as the birds that are caught in the snare, even so are the sons of men snared in an evil time when it falls suddenly upon them.
Eccl. I have also seen wisdom under the sun this way,  it seemed great to me:
Eccl. There was a little city,  few men within it. And there came a great king against it,  besieged it,  built great bulwarks against it.
Eccl. Now there was found in it a poor wise man. And he by his wisdom delivered the city, yet no man remembered that same poor man.
Eccl. Then I said, Wisdom is better than strength. Nevertheless the poor man's wisdom is despised,  his words are not heard.
Eccl. The words of the wise heard in quiet are better than the cry of him who rules among fools.
Eccl. Wisdom is better than weapons of war,  one sinner destroys much good.
Eccl. Dead flies cause the oil of the perfumer to send forth an evil odor, so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.
Eccl. A wise man's heart is at his right hand,  a fool's heart at his left.
Eccl. Yea also, when the fool walks by the way, his understanding fails him,  he says to everyone that he is a fool.
Eccl. If the spirit of the ruler rises up against thee, leave not thy place, for deference allays great offenses.
Eccl. There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as it were an error which proceeds from the ruler:
Eccl. Folly is set in great dignity,  the rich sit in a low place.
Eccl. I have seen servants upon horses,  rulers walking like servants upon the earth.
Eccl. He who digs a pit shall fall into it,  he who breaks through a wall, a serpent shall bite him.
Eccl. He who hews out stones shall be hurt therewith,  he who splits wood is endangered thereby.
Eccl. If the iron be blunt,  he does not whet the edge, then he must increase strength. But wisdom is advantageous to make right.
Eccl. If the serpent bites before it is charmed, then is there no advantage in the charmer.
Eccl. The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious,  the lips of a fool will swallow himself up.
Eccl. The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness,  the end of his talk is mischievous madness.
Eccl. A fool also multiplies words; yet man knows not what shall be,  that which shall be after him, who can tell him?
Eccl. The labor of fools wearies every one of them, for he knows not how to go to the city.
Eccl. Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child,  thy rulers feast in the morning!
Eccl. Happy are thou, O land, when thy king is the son of noble men,  thy rulers feast in due season, for strength,  not for drunkenness!
Eccl. By slothfulness the roof sinks in,  through idleness of the hands the house leaks.
Eccl. A feast is made for laughter,  wine makes glad the life,  money answers all things.
Eccl. Revile not the king, no, not in thy thought,  revile not the rich in thy bedchamber. For a bird of the heavens shall carry the voice,  that which has wings shall tell the matter.
Eccl. Cast thy bread upon the waters, for thou shall find it after many days.
Eccl. Give a portion to seven, yea, even to eight, for thou know not what evil shall be upon the earth.
Eccl. If the clouds are full of rain, they empty themselves upon the earth,  if a tree falls toward the south, or toward the north, in the place where the tree falls, there shall it be.
Eccl. He who observes the wind shall not sow,  he who regards the clouds shall not reap.
Eccl. As thou know not what is the way of the wind, nor how the bones grow in the womb of her who is with child, even so thou know not the work of God who does all.
Eccl. In the morning sow thy seed,  in the evening withhold not thy hand, for thou know not which shall prosper, whether this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good.
Eccl. Truly the light is sweet,  a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to behold the sun.
Eccl. Yea, if a man lives many years, let him rejoice in them all. But let him remember the days of darkness, for they shall be many. All that comes is vanity.
Eccl. Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth,  let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth,  walk in the ways of thy heart,  in the sight of thine eyes. But know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.
Eccl. Therefore remove sorrow from thy heart,  put away evil from thy flesh, for youth and the dawn of life are vanity.
Eccl. Remember also thy Creator in the days of thy youth, before the evil days come,  the years draw nigh, when thou shall say, I have no pleasure in them,
Eccl. before the sun,  the light,  the moon,  the stars, are darkened,  the clouds return after the rain,
Eccl. in the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble,  the strong men shall bow themselves,  the grinders cease because they are few,  those who look out of the windows shall be darkened,
Eccl. and the doors shall be shut in the street, when the sound of the grinding is low,  he shall rise up at the voice of a bird,  all the daughters of music shall be brought low,
Eccl. yea, they shall be afraid of height,  terrors shall be in the way,  the almond tree shall blossom,  the grasshopper shall be a burden,  desire shall fail, because man goes to his everlasting home,  the mourners go about the streets,
Eccl. before the silver cord is loosed, or the golden bowl is broken, or the pitcher is broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the cistern,
Eccl. and the dust returns to the earth as it was,  the spirit returns to God who gave it.
Eccl. Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher, all is vanity.
Eccl. And further, because the Preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge. Yea, he pondered,  sought out,  set in order many proverbs.
Eccl. The Preacher sought to find out acceptable words,  that which was written uprightly-words of truth.
Eccl. The words of the wise are as goads,  as nails fastened by the masters of assemblies. They have been given from one shepherd.
Eccl. And furthermore, my son, be admonished: of making many books there is no end,  much study is a weariness of the flesh.
Eccl. This is the end of the matter, all has been heard: Fear God,  keep his commandments, for this is the whole of man.
Eccl. For God will bring every work into judgment, with every hidden thing, whether good or evil.
Song of Solomon
Song. The Song of songs, which is Solomon's.
Song. Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, for thy love is better than wine.
Song. Thine oils have a good fragrance. Thy name is oil poured forth. Therefore the virgins love thee.
Song. Draw me, we will run after thee. The king has brought me into his chambers. We will be glad and rejoice in thee. We will make mention of thy love more than of wine. Rightly do they love thee.
Song. I am black,  comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.
Song. Look not upon me, because I am swarthy, because the sun has scorched me. My mother's sons were incensed against me. They made me keeper of the vineyards,  my own vineyard I have not kept.
Song. Tell me, O thou whom my soul loves, where thou feed thy flock, where thou make it to rest at noon. For why should I be as she who is veiled beside the flocks of thy companions?
Song. If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock,  feed thy kids beside the shepherds' tents.
Song. I have compared thee, O my love, to a steed in Pharaoh's chariots.
Song. Thy cheeks are comely with plaits of hair, thy neck with strings of jewels.
Song. We will make thee plaits of gold with studs of silver.
Song. While the king sat at his table, my spikenard sent forth its fragrance.
Song. My beloved is to me a bundle of myrrh that lies between my breasts.
Song. My beloved is to me a cluster of henna-flowers in the vineyards of En-gedi.
Song. Behold, thou are fair, my love, behold thou are fair. Thine eyes are doves.
Song. Behold, thou are fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant. Also our couch is green.
Song. The beams of our house are cedars, our rafters are firs.
Song. I am a rose of Sharon. A lily of the valleys.
Song. As a lily among thorns, So is my love among the daughters.
Song. As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight,  his fruit was sweet to my taste.
Song. He brought me to the banquet house,  his banner over me was love.
Song. Sustain ye me with raisins, refresh me with apples, for I am sick from love.
Song. His left hand is under my head,  his right hand embraces me.
Song. I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, or by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake love, until it please.
Song. The voice of my beloved! Behold, he comes, leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
Song. My beloved is like a roe or a young hart. Behold, he stands behind our wall. He looks in at the windows. He glances through the lattice.
Song. My beloved spoke,  said to me, Rise up, my love, my fair one,  come away.
Song. For, lo, the winter is past. The rain is over and gone.
Song. The flowers appear on the earth. The time of the singing has come,  the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.
Song. The fig tree ripens her green figs,  the vines are in blossom. They give forth their fragrance. Arise, my love, my fair one,  come away.
Song. O my dove, who are in the clefts of the rock, in the covert of the steep place, let me see thy countenance; let me hear thy voice. For sweet is thy voice,  thy countenance is comely.
Song. Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vineyards. For our vineyards are in blossom.
Song. My beloved is mine,  I am his. He feeds among the lilies.
Song. Until the day be cool,  the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved,  be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
Song. By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loves. I sought him,  I did not find him.
Song. I said, I will rise now,  go around the city. In the streets and in the broad ways I will seek him whom my soul loves. I sought him,  I did not find him.
Song. The watchmen who go about the city found me. I said, Did ye see him whom my soul loves?
Song. It was but a little that I passed from them when I found him whom my soul loves. I held him,  would not let him go until I had brought him into my mother's house,  into the chamber of her who conceived me.
Song. I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, or by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake love, until it please.
Song. Who is this who comes up from the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant?
Song. Behold, it is the litter of Solomon. Sixty mighty men are around it, of the mighty men of Israel.
Song. They all handle the sword,  are expert in war. Every man has his sword upon his thigh, because of fear in the night.
Song. King Solomon made himself a palanquin of the wood of Lebanon.
Song. He made the pillars thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of gold, the seat thereof of purple, the midst thereof being paved with love, from the daughters of Jerusalem.
Song. Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion,  behold king Solomon with the crown with which his mother has crowned him in the day of his espousals,  in the day of the gladness of his heart.
Song. Behold, thou are fair, my love, behold, thou are fair. Thine eyes are doves behind thy veil. Thy hair is as a flock of goats that lie along the side of mount Gilead.
Song. Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes that are newly shorn, which have come up from the washing, of which every one has twins,  none is bereaved among them.
Song. Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet,  thy mouth is comely. Thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate behind thy veil.
Song. Thy neck is like the tower of David built for an armory, on which there hang a thousand bucklers, all the shields of the mighty men.
Song. Thy two breasts are like two fawns that are twins of a roe, which feed among the lilies.
Song. Until the day is cool,  the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh,  to the hill of frankincense.
Song. Thou are all fair, my love,  there is no spot in thee.
Song. Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, with me from Lebanon. Look from the top of Amana, from the top of Senir and Hermon, from the lions' dens, from the mountains of the leopards.
Song. Thou have ravished my heart, my sister, my bride. Thou have ravished my heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck.
Song. How fair is thy love, my sister, my bride! How much better is thy love than wine,  the fragrance of thine oils than all manner of spices!
Song. Thy lips, O my bride, drop the honeycomb. Honey and milk are under thy tongue,  the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.
Song. A garden shut up is my sister, my bride, a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
Song. Thy shoots are an orchard of pomegranates, with precious fruits, henna with spikenard plants,
Song. spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense, myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices.
Song. Thou are a fountain of gardens, a well of living waters,  flowing streams from Lebanon.
Song. Awake, O north wind,  come, thou south, blow upon my garden, that the spices of it may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden,  eat his precious fruits.
Song. I have come into my garden, my sister, my bride. I have gathered my myrrh with my spice. I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey. I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends. Drink, yea. Drink abundantly, O beloved.
Song. I was asleep,  my heart awoke. It is the voice of my beloved who knocks, saying, Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled. For my head is filled with dew, my locks with the drops of the night.
Song. I have put off my garment, how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them?
Song. My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door,  my heart was moved for him.
Song. I rose up to open to my beloved,  my hands drops with myrrh,  my fingers with liquid myrrh, upon the handles of the bolt.
Song. I opened to my beloved,  my beloved had withdrawn himself,  was gone. My soul had failed me when he spoke. I sought him,  I could not find him. I called him,  he gave me no answer.
Song. The watchmen who go about the city found me. They smote me, they wounded me. The keepers of the walls took away my mantle from me.
Song. I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved, that ye tell him that I am sick from love.
Song. What is thy beloved more than another beloved, O thou fairest among women? What is thy beloved more than another beloved, that thou do so adjure us?
Song. My beloved is white and ruddy, the chief among ten thousand.
Song. His head is the most fine gold. His locks are bushy, black as a raven.
Song. His eyes are like doves beside the water-brooks, washed with milk, fitly set.
Song. His cheeks are as a bed of spices, banks of sweet herbs. His lips are lilies, dropping liquid myrrh.
Song. His hands are rings of gold set with beryl. His body is ivory work overlaid with sapphires.
Song. His legs are pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold. His aspect is like Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
Song. His mouth is most sweet. Yea, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved,  this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.
Song. Where has thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? Where has thy beloved turned, that we may seek him with thee?
Song. My beloved has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens,  to gather lilies.
Song. I am my beloved's,  my beloved is mine. He feeds among the lilies.
Song. Thou are fair, O my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jerusalem, sublime as an army with banners.
Song. Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me. Thy hair is as a flock of goats that lie along the side of Gilead.
Song. Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes, which have come up from the washing, of which every one has twins,  none is bereaved among them.
Song. Thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate behind thy veil.
Song. There are sixty queens,  eighty concubines,  virgins without number.
Song. My dove, my undefiled, is but one. She is the only one of her mother. She is the choice one of her who bore her. The daughters saw her,  called her blessed, yea, the queens and the concubines,  they praised her.
Song. Who is she who looks forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun, sublime as an army with banners?
Song. I went down into the garden of nuts, to see the green plants of the valley, to see whether the vine budded,  the pomegranates were in flower.
Song. Before I was aware, my soul set me among the chariots of my princely people.
Song. Return, return, O Shulammite, return, return, that we may look upon thee. Why will ye look upon the Shulammite, as upon the dance of two armies?
Song. How beautiful are thy feet in sandals, O prince's daughter! Thy rounded thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a skilful workman.
Song. Thy body is a round goblet, no mingled wine is wanting. Thy waist is a heap of wheat set about with lilies.
Song. Thy two breasts are like two fawns that are twins of a roe.
Song. Thy neck is like the tower of ivory. Thine eyes, the pools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim. Thy nose is like the tower of Lebanon which looks toward Damascus.
Song. Thy head upon thee is like Carmel,  the hair of thy head like purple. The king is held captive in the tresses.
Song. How fair and how pleasant thou are, O love, for delights!
Song. This thy stature is like to a palm tree,  thy breasts to its clusters.
Song. I said, I will climb up into the palm tree. I will take hold of the branches of it. Let thy breasts be as clusters of the vine,  the smell of thy breath like apples,
Song. and thy mouth like the best wine, that goes down smoothly for my beloved, gliding through the lips and teeth.
Song. I am my beloved's,  his desire is toward me.
Song. Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field. Let us lodge in the villages.
Song. Let us get up early to the vineyards. Let us see whether the vine has budded, its blossom is open, the pomegranates are in flower. There I will give thee my love.
Song. The mandrakes give forth fragrance. And at our doors are all manner of precious fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
Song. Oh that thou were as my brother, who sucked the breasts of my mother! When I should find thee outside, I would kiss thee. Yes,  none would despise me.
Song. I would lead thee,  bring thee into my mother's house, who would instruct me. I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine, of the juice of my pomegranate.
Song. His left hand under my head,  his right hand should embrace me.
Song. I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that ye stir not up, nor awake love, until it please.
Song. Who is this who comes up from the wilderness, leaning upon her beloved? Under the apple tree I awoke thee. There thy mother was in travail with thee. There she who brought thee forth was in travail.
Song. Set me as a seal upon thy heart, as a seal upon thine arm. For love is strong as death, jealousy is cruel as Sheol. The flashes of it are flashes of fire, a most vehement flame.
Song. Many waters cannot quench love, nor can floods drown it. If a man would give all the substance of his house for love, he would be utterly scorned.
Song. We have a little sister,  she has no breasts. What shall we do for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?
Song. If she is a wall, we will build upon her a turret of silver. And if she is a door, we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
Song. I am a wall,  my breasts like the towers. Then I was in his eyes as one who found peace.
Song. Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon. He let out the vineyard to keepers. Every one for the fruit of it was to bring a thousand pieces of silver.
Song. My vineyard, which is mine, is before me. Thou, O Solomon, shall have the thousand,  those who keep the fruit of it, two hundred.
Song. Thou who dwell in the gardens, the companions hearken for thy voice. Cause me to hear it.
Song. Make haste, my beloved,  be thou like to a roe or to a young hart upon the mountains of spices.
Isaiah
The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem, in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz,  Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Hear, O heavens,  give ear, O earth, for Jehovah has spoken. I have nourished and brought up sons,  they have rebelled against me.
The ox knows his owner,  the donkey his master's crib,  Israel does not know; my people does not consider.
Ah sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a seed of evildoers, sons who deal corruptly! They have forsaken Jehovah. They have despised the Holy One of Israel. They have gone away backward.
Why will ye still be stricken, that ye revolt more and more? The whole head is sick,  the whole heart faint.
From the sole of the foot even to the head there is no soundness in it,  wounds,  bruises,  fresh stripes. They have not been closed nor bound up nor soothed with oil.
Your country is desolate. Your cities are burned with fire. Your land-strangers devour it in your presence,  it is desolate, as overthrown by strangers.
the daughter of Zion is left as a booth in a vineyard, as a shed in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city.
Unless Jehovah of hosts had left to us a seed, we should have been as Sodom, we should have been like Gomorrah.
Hear the word of Jehovah, ye rulers of Sodom, give ear to the law of our God, ye people of Gomorrah.
What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices? says Jehovah. I have had enough of the burnt offerings of rams,  the fat of fed beasts. And I do not delight in the blood of bullocks or of lambs or of he-goats.
When ye come to appear before me, who has required this at your hand-to trample my courts?
Bring no more vain oblations. Incense is an abomination to me. New moon and sabbath, the calling of assemblies-I cannot bear iniquity and the solemn meeting.
Your new moons and your appointed feasts my soul hates. They are a trouble to me. I am weary of bearing them.
when ye spread forth your hands, I will hide my eyes from you. Yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear; your hands are full of blood.
Wash you, make you clean, put away the evil of your doings from before my eyes. Cease to do evil.
Learn to do good. Seek justice, relieve the oppressed, judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.
Come now,  let us reason together, says Jehovah, though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow. Though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
If ye are willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the land.
But if ye refuse and rebel, ye shall be devoured with the sword, for the mouth of Jehovah has spoken it.
How the faithful city has become a harlot! She who was full of justice! Righteousness lodged in her,  now murderers.
Thy silver has become dross, thy wine mixed with water.
Thy rulers are rebellious,  companions of thieves. Everyone loves bribes,  follows after rewards. They judge not the fatherless, nor does the cause of the widow come to them.
Therefore says the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel, Ah, I will ease me of my adversaries,  avenge me of my enemies.
I will turn my hand upon thee,  thoroughly purge away thy dross,  will take away all thy tin.
I will restore thy judges as at the first,  thy counselors as at the beginning. Afterward thou shall be called the city of righteousness, a faithful town.
Zion shall be redeemed with justice,  her converts with righteousness.
But the destruction of transgressors and sinners shall be together,  those who forsake Jehovah shall be consumed.
For they shall be ashamed of the oaks which ye have desired,  ye shall be confounded for the gardens that ye have chosen.
For ye shall be as an oak whose leaf fades,  as a garden that has no water.
the strong man shall be as flax,  his work as a spark. And they shall both burn together,  none shall quench them.
The word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.
it shall come to pass in the latter days, that the mountain of Jehovah's house shall be established on the top of the mountains,  shall be exalted above the hills,  all nations shall flow to it.
many peoples shall go and say, Come ye,  let us go up to the mountain of Jehovah, to the house of the God of Jacob,  he will teach us of his ways,  we will walk in his paths. For out of Zion shall go forth the law,  the word of Jehovah from Jerusalem.
he will judge between the nations,  will decide concerning many peoples,  they shall beat their swords into plowshares,  their spears into pruning-hooks. Nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.
O house of Jacob, come ye,  let us walk in the light of Jehovah.
For thou have forsaken thy people the house of Jacob, because they are filled with things from the east,  are soothsayers like the Philistines. And they strike hands with the children of foreigners.
their land is full of silver and gold, neither is there any end of their treasures. Their land is also full of horses, neither is there any end of their chariots.
Their land is also full of idols. They worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made,
so the common man bows down,  the great man degrades himself. Therefore do not forgive them.
Enter into the rock,  hide thee in the dust, from before the terror of Jehovah,  from the glory of his majesty.
The lofty looks of man shall be brought low,  the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down,  Jehovah alone shall be exalted in that day.
For there shall be a day of Jehovah of hosts upon all that is proud and haughty,  upon all that is lifted up,  it shall be brought low,
upon all the cedars of Lebanon that are high and lifted up,  upon all the oaks of Bashan,
upon all the high mountains,  upon all the hills that are lifted up,
upon every lofty tower,  upon every fortified wall,
upon all the ships of Tarshish,  upon all pleasant imagery.
the loftiness of man shall be bowed down,  the haughtiness of men shall be brought low,  Jehovah alone shall be exalted in that day.
the idols shall utterly pass away.
men shall go into the caves of the rocks,  into the holes of the earth, from before the terror of Jehovah,  from the glory of his majesty, when he arises to shake the earth mightily.
In that day men shall cast away their idols of silver,  their idols of gold, which have been made for them to worship, to the moles and to the bats,
to go into the caverns of the rocks,  into the clefts of the ragged rocks, from before the terror of Jehovah,  from the glory of his majesty, when he arises to shake the earth mightily.
Cease ye from man, whose breath is in his nostrils, for how is he to be accounted of?
For, behold, the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, takes away from Jerusalem and from Judah support and staff, the whole support of bread,  the whole support of water,
the mighty man,  the man of war, the judge,  the prophet,  the diviner,  the elder,
the captain of fifty,  the honorable man,  the counselor,  the expert craftsman,  the skilful enchanter.
I will give sons to be their rulers,  babes shall rule over them.
the people shall be oppressed, every one by another,  every one by his neighbor. The child shall behave himself proudly against the old man,  the base against the honorable.
When a man shall take hold of his brother in the house of his father, saying, Thou have clothing, be thou our ruler,  let this ruin be under thy hand,
in that day he shall lift up his voice, saying, I will not be a healer, for in my house is neither bread nor clothing. Ye shall not make me ruler of the people.
For Jerusalem is ruined,  Judah is fallen, because their tongue and their doings are against Jehovah, to provoke the eyes of his glory.
The show of their countenance witnesses against them,  they declare their sin as Sodom; they do not hide it. Woe to their soul! For they have done evil to themselves.
Say ye of the righteous, that it is well, for they shall eat the fruit of their doings.
Woe to the wicked! It is ill with him, for what his hands have done shall be done to him.
As for my people, children are their oppressors,  women rule over them. O my people, those who lead thee cause thee to err,  destroy the way of thy paths.
Jehovah stands up to contend,  stands to judge the peoples.
Jehovah will enter into judgment with the elders of his people,  the rulers of it. It is ye who have eaten up the vineyard; the spoil of a poor man is in your houses.
What do ye mean that ye crush my people,  grind the face of the poor? says the Lord, Jehovah of hosts.
Moreover Jehovah said, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,  walk with outstretched necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go,  making a tinkling with their feet,
therefore the Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion,  Jehovah will lay bare their secret parts.
In that day the Lord will take away the beauty of their anklets,  the hair nets,  the crescents,
the pendants,  the bracelets,  the mufflers,
the bonnets,  the ankle chains,  the sashes,  the perfume-boxes,  the amulets,
the rings,  the nose-jewels,
the festival robes,  the mantles,  the shawls,  the satchels,
the hand-mirrors,  the fine linen,  the turbans,  the veils.
it shall come to pass, that instead of sweet spices there shall be rottenness,  instead of a girdle, a rope,  instead of well set hair, baldness,  instead of a robe, a girding of sackcloth, branding instead of beauty.
Thy men shall fall by the sword,  thy mighty in the war.
her gates shall lament and mourn,  she shall be desolate and sit upon the ground.
seven women shall take hold of one man in that day, saying, We will eat our own bread,  wear our own apparel. Only let us be called by thy name; take thou away our reproach.
In that day the branch of Jehovah shall be beautiful and glorious,  the fruit of the land shall be excellent and comely for those who have escaped from Israel.
it shall come to pass, that he who is left in Zion,  he who remains in Jerusalem, shall be called holy, even everyone who is written among the living in Jerusalem,
when the Lord shall have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion,  shall have purged the blood of Jerusalem from the midst of it, by the spirit of justice,  by the spirit of burning.
Jehovah will create over the whole habitation of mount Zion,  over her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day,  the shining of a flaming fire by night, for over all the glory, a covering.
there shall be a pavilion for a shade in the daytime from the heat,  for a refuge,  for a covert from storm and from rain.
Let me sing for my well-beloved a song of my beloved concerning his vineyard. My well-beloved had a vineyard in a very fruitful hill.
he dug it,  gathered out the stones of it,  planted it with the choicest vine,  built a tower in the midst of it,  also hewed out a winepress in it. And he looked that it should bring forth grapes,  it brought forth wild grapes.
now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, judge, I pray you, between me and my vineyard.
What could have been done more to my vineyard that I have not done in it? Why, when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, it brought forth wild grapes?
now I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard. I will take away the hedge of it,  it shall be eaten up. I will break down the wall of it,  it shall be trodden down.
I will lay it waste. It shall not be pruned nor hoed,  there shall come up briers and thorns. I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.
For the vineyard of Jehovah of hosts is the house of Israel,  the men of Judah his pleasant plant. And he looked for justice,  behold, oppression, for righteousness,  behold, a cry.
Woe to those who join house to house, who lay field to field, till there is no room,  ye be made to dwell alone in the midst of the land!
In my ears says Jehovah of hosts, of a truth many houses shall be desolate, even great and fair, without inhabitant.
For ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath,  a homer of seed shall yield but an ephah.
Woe to those who rise up early in the morning, that they may follow strong drink, who tarry late into the night, till wine inflame them!
the harp and the lute, the tambourine and the pipe,  wine, are in their feasts,  they do not regard the work of Jehovah, nor have they considered the operation of his hands.
Therefore my people have gone into captivity for lack of knowledge,  their honorable men are famished,  their multitude are parched with thirst.
Therefore Sheol has enlarged its desire,  opened its mouth without measure. And their glory,  their multitude,  their pomp,  he who rejoices among them, descend into it.
the common man is bowed down,  the great man is debased,  the eyes of the lofty are humbled,
but Jehovah of hosts is exalted in justice,  God the Holy One is sanctified in righteousness.
Then the lambs shall feed as in their pasture,  wanderers shall eat the waste places of the fat ones.
Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of falsehood,  sin as it were with a cart rope,
who say, Let him make speed, let him hasten his work, that we may see it. And let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near and come, that we may know it!
Woe to those who call evil good,  good evil, who put darkness for light,  light for darkness, who put bitter for sweet,  sweet for bitter!
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes,  prudent in their own sight!
Woe to those who are mighty to drink wine,  men of strength to mingle strong drink,
who justify the wicked for rewards,  take away the justice of the righteous man from him!
Therefore as the tongue of fire devours the stubble,  as the dry grass sinks down in the flame, so their root shall be as rottenness,  their blossom shall go up as dust, because they have rejected the law of Jehovah of hosts,  despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.
Therefore the anger of Jehovah is kindled against his people,  he has stretched forth his hand against them,  has smitten them. And the mountains tremble,  their dead bodies are as refuse in the midst of the streets. For all this his anger is not turned away,  his hand is stretched out still.
he will lift up an ensign to the nations from far,  will whistle for them from the end of the earth, , behold, they shall come with speed swiftly.
None shall be weary nor stumble among them. None shall slumber nor sleep, nor shall the belt of their loins be loosed, nor the latchet of their shoes be broken,
whose arrows are sharp,  all their bows bent. Their horses' hoofs shall be accounted as flint,  their wheels as a whirlwind.
Their roaring shall be like a lioness. They shall roar like young lions. Yea, they shall roar,  lay hold of the prey,  carry it away safe,  there shall be none to deliver.
they shall roar against them in that day like the roaring of the sea. And if a man looks to the land, behold, darkness and distress,  the light is darkened in the clouds of it.
In the year that king Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up,  his train filled the temple.
Above him stood the seraphim. Each one had six wings, with two he covered his face,  with two he covered his feet,  with two he flew.
one cried to another,  said, Holy, holy, holy, is Jehovah of hosts. The whole earth is full of his glory.
the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of him who cried,  the house was filled with vapor.
Then I said, Woe is me! For I am undone, because I am a man of unclean lips,  I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips. For my eyes have seen the King, Jehovah of hosts.
Then one of the seraphim flew to me, having a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with the tongs from off the altar.
he touched my mouth with it,  said, Lo, this has touched thy lips,  thine iniquity is taken away,  thy sin forgiven.
I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, Whom shall I send,  who will go for us? Then I said, Lo, send me.
he said, Go,  tell this people, Hear ye indeed,  do not understand,  see ye indeed,  do not perceive.
Make the heart of this people fat,  make their ears heavy,  shut their eyes, lest they see with their eyes,  hear with their ears,  understand with their heart,  turn,  be healed.
Then I said, Lord, how long? And he answered, Until cities be waste without inhabitant,  houses without man,  the land become utterly waste,
Jehovah has removed men far away,  the forsaken places be many in the midst of the land.
if there be yet a tenth in it, it also shall in turn be eaten up. As a terebinth,  as an oak, whose stock remains when they are felled, so the holy seed is the stock of it.
it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin the king of Syria,  Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to war against it,  could not prevail against it.
it was told the house of David, saying, Syria is allied with Ephraim. And his heart trembled,  the heart of his people, as the trees of the forest tremble with the wind.
Then Jehovah said to Isaiah, Go forth now to meet Ahaz, thou,  Shear-jashub thy son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool, in the highway of the fuller's field.
say to him, Take heed,  be quiet. Fear not, nor let thy heart be faint, because of these two tails of smoking firebrands, for the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria,  of the son of Remaliah.
Because Syria, Ephraim,  the son of Remaliah, have purposed evil against thee, saying,
Let us go up against Judah,  vex it,  let us make a breach in it for us,  set up a king in the midst of it, even the son of Tabeel,
thus says the lord Jehovah: It shall not stand, nor shall it come to pass.
For the head of Syria is Damascus,  the head of Damascus is Rezin. And within sixty-five years Ephraim shall be broken in pieces, so that is shall not be a people.
the head of Ephraim is Samaria,  the head of Samaria is Remaliah's son. If ye will not believe, surely ye shall not be established.
Jehovah spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
Ask thee a sign of Jehovah thy God, ask it either in the depth, or in the height above.
But Ahaz said, I will not ask, nor will I test Jehovah.
he said, Hear ye now, O house of David. Is it a small thing for you to weary men, that ye will weary my God also?
Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign: Behold, a virgin shall conceive,  bear a son,  shall call his name Immanuel.
Butter and honey shall he eat, when he knows to refuse the evil,  choose the good.
For before the child shall know to refuse the evil,  choose the good, the land whose two kings thou abhor shall be forsaken.
Jehovah will bring upon thee,  upon thy people,  upon thy father's house, days that have not come, from the day that Ephraim departed from Judah-even the king of Assyria.
it shall come to pass in that day, that Jehovah will whistle for the fly that is in the outermost part of the rivers of Egypt,  for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
they shall come,  shall rest all of them in the desolate valleys,  in the clefts of the rocks,  upon all thorn-hedges,  upon all pastures.
In that day the Lord will shave with a razor what is hired in the parts beyond the River, even with the king of Assyria, the head and the hair of the feet,  it shall also consume the beard.
it shall come to pass in that day, that a man shall keep alive a young cow and two sheep.
it shall come to pass, that because of the abundance of milk which they shall give he shall eat butter. For everyone who is left in the midst of the land shall eat butter and honey.
it shall come to pass in that day, that every place where there were a thousand vines at a thousand silver coins, shall be for briers and thorns.
Men shall come there with arrows and with bow, because all the land shall be briers and thorns.
all the hills that were dug with the mattock, thou shall not come there for fear of briers and thorns,  it shall be for the sending forth of oxen,  for the treading of sheep.
Jehovah said to me, Take thee a great tablet,  write upon it with the pen of a man, For Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
I will take to me faithful witnesses to record, Uriah the priest,  Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.
I went to the prophetess,  she conceived,  bore a son. Then Jehovah said to me, Call his name Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
For before the child shall have knowledge to cry, My father, , My mother, the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be carried away before the king of Assyria.
Jehovah spoke to me yet again, saying,
Inasmuch as this people have refused the waters of Shiloah that go softly,  rejoice in Rezin and Remaliah's son,
now therefore, behold, the Lord brings up upon them the waters of the River, strong and many, even the king of Assyria and all his glory. And it shall come up over all its channels,  go over all its banks,
it shall sweep onward into Judah. It shall overflow and pass through; it shall reach even to the neck. And the stretching out of its wings shall fill the breadth of thy land, O Immanuel.
Make an uproar, O ye peoples,  be broken in pieces. And give ear, all ye of far countries. Gird yourselves,  be broken in pieces. Gird yourselves,  be broken in pieces.
Take counsel together,  it shall be brought to nothing. Speak the word,  it shall not stand, for God is with us.
For Jehovah spoke thus to me with a strong hand,  instructed me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,
Say ye not, A conspiracy, concerning all of which this people shall say, A conspiracy, nor fear ye their fear, nor be in dread of it.
Jehovah of hosts, him ye shall sanctify,  let him be your fear,  let him be your dread.
he shall be for a sanctuary,  for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offense to both the houses of Israel, for a net and for a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
many shall stumble on it,  fall,  be broken,  be snared,  be taken.
Bind thou up the testimony. Seal the law among my disciples.
I will wait for Jehovah, who hides his face from the house of Jacob,  I will be a man who has trusted in him.
Behold, I and the children whom Jehovah has given me are for signs and for wonders in Israel from Jehovah of hosts, who dwells in mount Zion.
when they shall say to you, Seek for those who have familiar spirits and for the wizards, who chirp and who mutter, should not a people seek for their God? On behalf of the living seek to the dead?
Seek to the law and to the testimony! If they speak not according to this word, surely there is no morning for them.
they shall pass through it, greatly distressed and hungry. And it shall come to pass that, when they shall be hungry, they shall fret themselves,  curse by their king and by their God,  turn their faces upward.
they shall look to the earth, , behold, distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish,  into thick darkness to be driven away.
But there shall be no gloom to her who was in anguish. In the former time he brought into contempt the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali,  in the latter time he has made it glorious, by the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles.
The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light. Those who dwelt in the land of the shadow of death, upon them the light has shone.
Thou have multiplied the nation. Thou have increased their joy. They joy before thee according to the joy in harvest, as men rejoice when they divide the spoil.
For the yoke of his burden,  the staff of his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, thou have broken as in the day of Midian.
For all the armor of the armed man in the tumult,  the garments rolled in blood, shall be for burning, for fuel of fire.
For to us a child is born, to us a son is given. And the government shall be upon his shoulder. And his name shall be called Wonderful, Counselor, Mighty God, Father of Eternity, Prince of Peace.
Of the increase of his government and of peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David,  upon his kingdom, to establish it,  to uphold it with justice and with righteousness from henceforth even forever. The zeal of Jehovah of hosts will perform this.
The Lord sent a word into Jacob,  it has lighted upon Israel.
all the people shall know, even Ephraim and the inhabitant of Samaria, who say in pride and in arrogance of heart,
The bricks are fallen,  we will build with hewn stone, the sycamores are cut down,  we will put cedars in their place.
Therefore Jehovah will set up on high against him the adversaries of Rezin,  will stir up his enemies,
the Syrians in front,  the Philistines behind,  they shall devour Israel with open mouth. For all this his anger is not turned away,  his hand is stretched out still.
Yet the people have not turned to him who smote them, nor have they sought Jehovah of hosts.
Therefore Jehovah will cut off from Israel head and tail, palm-branch and rush, in one day.
The elder and the honorable man, he is the head. And the prophet who teaches lies, he is the tail.
For those who lead this people cause them to err,  those who are led by them are destroyed.
Therefore the Lord will not rejoice over their young men, nor will he have compassion on their fatherless and widows. For everyone is profane and an evildoer,  every mouth speaks folly. For all this his anger is not turned away,  his hand is stretched out still.
For wickedness burns as the fire. It devours the briers and thorns. Yea, it kindles in the thickets of the forest,  they roll upward in a column of smoke.
Through the wrath of Jehovah of hosts is the land burnt up,  the people are as the fuel of fire; no man spares his brother.
he shall snatch on the right hand,  be hungry. And he shall eat on the left hand,  they shall not be satisfied. They shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm-
Manasseh, Ephraim,  Ephraim, Manasseh,  together they shall be against Judah. For all this his anger is not turned away,  his hand is stretched out still.
Woe to those who decree unrighteous decrees,  to the writers who write perverseness,
to turn aside the needy from justice,  to rob the poor of my people of their right, that widows may be their spoil,  that they may make the fatherless their prey!
what will ye do in the day of visitation,  in the desolation which shall come from far? To whom will ye flee for help? And where will ye leave your glory?
They shall only bow down under the prisoners,  shall fall under the slain. For all this his anger is not turned away,  his hand is stretched out still.
Ho, Assyrian, the rod of my anger, the staff in whose hand is my indignation!
I will send him against a profane nation,  against the people of my wrath. I will give him a charge, to take the spoil,  to take the prey,  to tread them down like the mire of the streets.
However he does not so reason, nor does his heart so think,  it is in his heart to destroy,  to cut off nations not a few.
For he says, Are not my rulers all of them kings?
Is not Calno as Carchemish? Is not Hamath as Arpad? Is not Samaria as Damascus?
As my hand has found the kingdoms of the idols, whose graven images excelled those of Jerusalem and of Samaria,
shall I not, as I have done to Samaria and her idols, so do to Jerusalem and her idols?
Therefore it shall come to pass, that, when the Lord has performed his whole work upon mount Zion and on Jerusalem, I will punish the fruit of the arrogant heart of the king of Assyria,  the glory of his high looks.
For he has said, By the strength of my hand I have done it,  by my wisdom, for I have understanding. And I have removed the bounds of the peoples,  have robbed their treasures. And like a valiant man I have brought down those who sit on thrones.
my hand has found as a nest the riches of the peoples. And like a gathering of eggs that are forsaken, I have gathered all the earth. And there was none that moved the wing, or that opened the mouth, or chirped.
Shall the axe boast itself against him who hews with it? Shall the saw magnify itself against him who wields it? As if a rod should wield those who lift it up, or as if a staff should lift up him who is not wood.
Therefore will the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, send among his fat ones, leanness,  under his glory there shall be kindled a burning like the burning of fire.
the light of Israel will be for a fire,  his Holy One for a flame,  it will burn and devour his thorns and his briers in one day.
he will consume the glory of his forest,  of his fruitful field, both soul and body. And it shall be as when a standard-bearer faints.
the remnant of the trees of his forest shall be few, so that a child may write them.
it shall come to pass in that day, that the remnant of Israel,  those who are escaped of the house of Jacob, shall no more again lean upon him who smote them,  shall lean upon Jehovah, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
A remnant shall return, even the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.
For though thy people, Israel, be as the sand of the sea, a remnant of them shall return. A destruction is determined, overflowing with righteousness.
For a full end,  that determined, the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, will make in the midst of all the earth.
Therefore thus says the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, O my people who dwell in Zion, be not afraid of the Assyrian, though he smites thee with the rod,  lifts up his staff against thee, according to the manner of Egypt.
For yet a very little while,  the indignation shall be accomplished,  my anger is to his destruction.
Jehovah of hosts will stir up against him a scourge as in the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb. And his rod will be over the sea,  he will lift it up according to the manner of Egypt.
it shall come to pass in that day, that his burden shall depart from off thy shoulder,  his yoke from off thy neck,  the yoke shall be destroyed because of fatness.
He has come to Aiath. He has passed through Migron. At Michmash he lays up his baggage.
They have gone over the pass. They have taken up their lodging at Geba. Ramah trembles. Gibeah of Saul has fled.
Cry aloud with thy voice, O daughter of Gallim! Hearken, O Laishah! O thou poor Anathoth!
Madmenah is a fugitive. The inhabitants of Gebim flee for safety.
This very day he shall halt at Nob. He shakes his hand at the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
Behold, the Lord, Jehovah of hosts, will lop off the boughs with terror. And the high of stature shall be hewn down,  the lofty shall be brought low.
he will cut down the thickets of the forest with iron,  Lebanon shall fall by a mighty one.
there shall come forth a shoot out of the stock of Jesse. And a branch out of his roots shall bear fruit.
the Spirit of Jehovah shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of Jehovah.
his delight shall be in the fear of Jehovah. And he shall not judge according to the sight of his eyes, nor decide according to the hearing of his ears,
but with righteousness he shall judge the poor,  decide with equity for the meek of the earth. And he shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth,  with the breath of his lips he shall kill the wicked.
righteousness shall be the belt of his waist,  faithfulness the belt of his loins.
the wolf shall dwell with the lamb,  the leopard shall lie down with the kid,  the calf and the young lion and the fatling together,  a little child shall lead them.
the cow and the bear shall feed; their young ones shall lie down together. And the lion shall eat straw like the ox.
the sucking child shall play on the hole of the asp,  the weaned child shall put his hand on the adder's den.
They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain, for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of Jehovah as the waters cover the sea.
in that day there shall be a root of Jesse,  he who arises to rule over the Gentiles. In him shall the Gentiles hope,  his resting-place shall be glorious.
it shall come to pass in that day, that the Lord will set his hand again the second time to recover the remnant of his people, who shall remain, from Assyria,  from Egypt,  from Pathros,  from Cush,  from Elam,  from Shinar,  from Hamath,  from the islands of the sea.
he will set up an ensign for the nations,  will assemble the outcasts of Israel,  gather together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth.
Also the envy of Ephraim shall depart,  those who vex Judah shall be cut off. Ephraim shall not envy Judah,  Judah shall not vex Ephraim.
they shall fly down upon the shoulder of the Philistines on the west. Together they shall despoil the sons of the east. They shall put forth their hand upon Edom and Moab,  the sons of Ammon shall obey them.
Jehovah will utterly destroy the tongue of the Egyptian sea. And with his scorching wind he will wave his hand over the River,  will smite it into seven streams,  cause men to march over dry shod.
there shall be a highway for the remnant of his people, who shall remain, from Assyria, like as there was for Israel in the day that he came up out of the land of Egypt.
in that day thou shall say, I will give thanks to thee, O Jehovah, for though thou were angry with me. Thine anger is turned away and thou comfort me.
Behold, God is my salvation. I will trust,  will not be afraid, for Jehovah, even Jehovah, is my strength and song,  he has become my salvation.
Therefore with joy ye shall draw water out of the wells of salvation.
in that day ye shall say, Give thanks to Jehovah. Call upon his name. Declare his doings among the peoples. Make mention that his name is exalted.
Sing to Jehovah, for he has done excellent things. Let this be known in all the earth.
Cry aloud and shout, thou inhabitant of Zion, for great in the midst of thee is the Holy One of Israel.
The burden of Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw.
Set ye up an ensign upon the bare mountain. Lift up the voice to them. Wave the hand, that they may go into the gates of the nobles.
I have commanded my consecrated ones, yea, I have called my mighty men for my anger, even my proudly exulting ones.
The noise of a multitude in the mountains, as of a great people! The noise of a tumult of the kingdoms of the nations gathered together! Jehovah of hosts is mustering the army for the battle.
They come from a far country, from the outermost part of heaven, even Jehovah,  the weapons of his indignation, to destroy the whole land.
Wail ye, for the day of Jehovah is at hand. It shall come as destruction from the Almighty.
Therefore all hands shall be feeble,  every heart of man shall melt.
they shall be dismayed. Pangs and sorrows shall take hold. They shall be in pain as a woman in travail. They shall look in amazement one at another, their faces, faces of flame.
Behold, the day of Jehovah comes, cruel, with wrath and fierce anger, to make the land a desolation,  to destroy the sinners thereof out of it.
For the stars of heaven and the constellations of it shall not give their light. The sun shall be darkened in its going forth,  the moon shall not cause its light to shine.
I will punish the world for the evil,  the wicked for their iniquity. And I will cause the arrogance of the proud to cease,  will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.
I will make a man more rare than fine gold, even a man than the pure gold of Ophir.
Therefore I will make the heavens to tremble,  the earth shall be shaken out of its place, in the wrath of Jehovah of hosts,  in the day of his fierce anger.
it shall come to pass, that as the chased roe,  as sheep that no man gathers, they shall turn every man to his own people,  shall flee every man to his own land.
Everyone who is found shall be thrust through,  everyone who is taken shall fall by the sword.
Their infants also shall be dashed in pieces before their eyes. Their houses shall be rifled,  their wives ravished.
Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them, who shall not regard silver,  as for gold, they shall not delight in it.
their bows shall dash the young men in pieces. And they shall have no pity on the fruit of the womb; their eye shall not spare children.
Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldeans' pride, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
It shall never be inhabited, nor shall it be dwelt in from generation to generation. Neither shall the Arabian pitch tent there, nor shall shepherds make their flocks to lie down there.
But wild beasts of the desert shall lie there,  their houses shall be full of doleful creatures. And ostriches shall dwell there,  wild goats shall dance there.
wolves shall cry in their castles,  jackals in the pleasant palaces. And her time is near to come,  her days shall not be prolonged.
For Jehovah will have compassion on Jacob,  will yet choose Israel,  set them in their own land. And the sojourner shall join himself with them,  they shall cling to the house of Jacob.
the peoples shall take them,  bring them to their place. And the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of Jehovah for servants and for handmaids. And they shall take them captive whose captives they were,  they shall rule over their oppressors.
it shall come to pass in the day that Jehovah shall give thee rest from thy sorrow,  from thy trouble,  from the hard service in which thou were made to serve,
that thou shall take up this taunt against the king of Babylon,  say, How has the oppressor ceased, the golden city ceased!
Jehovah has broken the staff of the wicked, the scepter of the rulers,
who smote the peoples in wrath with a continual stroke, who ruled the nations in anger, with a persecution that none restrained.
The whole earth is at rest,  is quiet. They break forth into singing.
Yea, the fir trees rejoice at thee,  the cedars of Lebanon, saying, Since thou are laid low, no hewer has come up against us.
Sheol from beneath is moved for thee, to meet thee at thy coming. It stirs up the dead for thee, even all the chief ones of the earth. It has raised up from their thrones all the kings of the nations.
They shall all answer and say to thee, Have thou also become weak as we? Have thou become like us?
Thy pomp is brought down to Sheol,  the noise of thy viols. The worm is spread under thee,  worms cover thee.
How thou are fallen from heaven, O day-star, son of the morning! How thou are cut down to the ground, who laid the nations low!
thou said in thy heart, I will ascend into heaven. I will exalt my throne above the stars of God,  I will sit upon the mount of congregation, in the outermost parts of the north.
I will ascend above the heights of the clouds. I will make myself like the Most High.
Yet thou shall be brought down to Sheol, to the utmost parts of the pit.
Those who see thee shall gaze at thee. They shall consider thee, saying, Is this the man who made the earth to tremble, who shook kingdoms,
who made the world as a wilderness,  overthrew the cities of it, who did not let loose his prisoners to their home?
All the kings of the nations, all of them, sleep in glory, each one in his own house.
But thou are cast forth away from thy sepulcher like an abominable branch, clothed with the slain, who are thrust through with the sword, who go down to the stones of the pit, as a dead body trodden under foot.
Thou shall not be joined with them in burial, because thou have destroyed thy land. Thou have slain thy people. The seed of evildoers shall not be named forever.
Prepare ye slaughter for his sons for the iniquity of their fathers, that they not rise up,  possess the earth,  fill the face of the world with cities.
I will rise up against them, says Jehovah of hosts,  cut off from Babylon name and remnant,  son and son's son, says Jehovah.
I will also make it a possession for the porcupine,  pools of water. And I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says Jehovah of hosts.
Jehovah of hosts has sworn, saying, Surely, as I have thought, so shall it come to pass,  as I have purposed, so shall it stand,
that I will break the Assyrian in my land,  tread him under foot upon my mountains. Then shall his yoke depart from off them,  his burden depart from off their shoulder.
This is the purpose that is purposed upon the whole earth,  this is the hand that is stretched out upon all the nations.
For Jehovah of hosts has purposed,  who shall annul it? And his hand is stretched out,  who shall turn it back?
In the year that king Ahaz died was this burden.
Rejoice not, O Philistia, all of thee, because the rod that smote thee is broken. For out of the serpent's root shall come forth an adder,  his fruit shall be a fiery flying serpent.
the firstborn of the poor shall feed,  the needy shall lie down in safety. And I will kill thy root with famine,  thy remnant shall be slain.
Howl, O gate, cry, O city. Thou are melted away, O Philistia, all of thee. For there comes a smoke out of the north,  there is no straggler in his ranks.
What then shall a man answer the messengers of the nation? That Jehovah has founded Zion,  in her shall the afflicted of his people take refuge.
The burden of Moab. For in a night Ar of Moab is laid waste,  brought to nothing. For in a night Kir of Moab is laid waste,  brought to nothing.
They have gone up to Bayith,  to Dibon, to the high places, to weep. Moab wails over Nebo,  over Medeba. On all their heads is baldness. Every beard is cut off.
In their streets they gird themselves with sackcloth. On their housetops,  in their broad places, everyone wails, weeping abundantly.
Heshbon cries out,  Elealeh. Their voice is heard even to Jahaz. Therefore the armed men of Moab cry aloud. His soul trembles within him.
My heart cries out for Moab. Her nobles flee to Zoar, to Eglath-shelishi-yah. For they go up with weeping by the ascent of Luhith. For they raise up a cry of destruction in the way of Horonaim.
For the waters of Nimrim shall be desolate, for the grass is withered away. The tender grass fails. There is no green thing.
Therefore the abundance they have gotten,  that which they have laid up, they shall carry away over the brook of the willows.
For the cry has gone round about the borders of Moab, the wailing of it to Eglaim,  the wailing of it to Beer-elim.
For the waters of Dimon are full of blood. For I will bring yet more upon Dimon, a lion upon those of Moab who escape,  upon the remnant of the land.
Send ye the lambs for the ruler of the land from Selah to the wilderness, to the mount of the daughter of Zion.
For it shall be that, as wandering birds, as a scattered nest, so shall the daughters of Moab be at the fords of the Arnon.
Give counsel, execute justice, make thy shade as the night in the midst of the noonday. Hide the outcasts. Do not betray the fugitive.
Let my outcasts dwell with thee. As for Moab, be thou a covert to him from the face of the destroyer. For the extortioner is brought to nothing. Destruction ceases. The oppressors are consumed out of the land.
a throne shall be established in loving kindness,  he shall sit on it in truth, in the tent of David, judging,  seeking justice,  swift to do righteousness.
We have heard of the pride of Moab, that he is very proud, even of his arrogance,  his pride,  his wrath. His boastings are nothing.
Therefore Moab shall wail for Moab, everyone shall wail. Ye shall mourn for the raisin-cakes of Kir-hareseth, utterly stricken.
For the fields of Heshbon languish,  the vine of Sibmah. The lords of the nations have broken down the choice branches of it, which reached even to Jazer, which wandered into the wilderness. Its shoots were spread abroad. They passed over the sea.
Therefore I will weep with the weeping of Jazer for the vine of Sibmah. I will water thee with my tears, O Heshbon,  Elealeh. for upon thy summer fruits and upon thy harvest the battle shout has fallen.
gladness is taken away,  joy out of the fruitful field. And in the vineyards there shall be no singing nor joyful noise. No treader shall tread out wine in the presses. I have made the vintage shout to cease.
Therefore my heart sounds like a harp for Moab,  my inward parts for Kir-heres.
it shall come to pass, when Moab presents himself, when he wearies himself upon the high place,  shall come to his sanctuary to pray, that he shall not prevail.
This is the word that Jehovah spoke concerning Moab in time past.
But now Jehovah has spoken, saying, Within three years, as the years of a hireling, the glory of Moab shall be brought into contempt, with all his great multitude. And the remnant shall be very small and of no account.
The burden of Damascus. Behold, Damascus is taken away from being a city,  it shall be a ruinous heap.
The cities of Aroer are forsaken. They shall be for flocks, which shall lie down,  none shall make them afraid.
the fortress shall cease from Ephraim,  the kingdom from Damascus. And the remnant of Syria, they shall be as the glory of the sons of Israel, says Jehovah of hosts.
it shall come to pass in that day, that the glory of Jacob shall be made thin,  the fatness of his flesh shall grow lean.
it shall be as when the harvestman gathers the standing grain,  his arm reaps the ears. Yea, it shall be as when he gleans ears in the valley of Rephaim.
Yet there shall be gleanings left in it, as the shaking of an olive tree-two or three berries in the top of the uppermost bough, four or five in the outmost branches of a fruitful tree, says Jehovah, the God of Israel.
In that day men shall look to their maker,  their eyes shall have respect for the Holy One of Israel.
they shall not look to the altars, the work of their hands, nor shall they have respect for that which their fingers have made, either the Asherim, or the sun-images.
In that day their strong cities shall be as the forsaken places in the woodland and on the mountain top, which were forsaken from before the sons of Israel,  it shall be a desolation.
For thou have forgotten the God of thy salvation,  have not been mindful of the rock of thy strength. Therefore thou plant pleasant plants,  set it with foreign slips.
In the day of thy planting thou hedge it in,  in the morning thou make thy seed to blossom. But the harvest flees away in the day of grief and of desperate sorrow.
Ah, the uproar of many peoples, who roar like the roaring of the seas,  the rushing of nations, that rush like the rushing of mighty waters!
The nations shall rush like the rushing of many waters,  he shall rebuke them. And they shall flee far off,  shall be chased as the chaff of the mountains before the wind,  like the whirling dust before the storm.
At eventide, behold, terror,  before the morning they are not. This is the portion of those who despoil us,  the lot of those who rob us.
Ah, the land of the rustling of wings, which is beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,
that sends ambassadors by the sea, even in vessels of papyrus upon the waters, saying, Go, ye swift messengers, to a nation tall and smooth, to a people fearful from their beginning onward, a nation that metes out and treads down, whose land the rivers divide!
All ye inhabitants of the world,  ye dwellers on the earth, when an ensign is lifted up on the mountains, see ye,  when the trumpet is blown, hear ye.
For thus Jehovah has said to me, I will be still,  I will behold in my dwelling-place, like clear heat in sunshine, like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.
For before the harvest, when the blossom is over,  the flower becomes a ripening grape, he will cut off the sprigs with pruning-hooks,  he will take away and cut down the spreading branches.
They shall be left together to the ravenous birds of the mountains,  to the beasts of the earth. And the ravenous birds shall summer upon them,  all the beasts of the earth shall winter upon them.
In that time a present shall be brought to Jehovah of hosts from a people tall and smooth, even from a people fearful from their beginning onward, a nation that metes out and treads down, whose land the rivers divide, to the place of the name of Jehovah of hosts, the mount Zion.
The burden of Egypt. Behold, Jehovah rides upon a swift cloud,  comes to Egypt. And the idols of Egypt shall tremble at his presence,  the heart of Egypt shall melt in the midst of it.
I will stir up the Egyptians against the Egyptians,  they shall fight each one against his brother,  each one against his neighbor, city against city, kingdom against kingdom.
the spirit of Egypt shall fail in the midst of it,  I will destroy the counsel of it. And they shall seek for the idols,  for the charmers,  for those who have familiar spirits,  for the wizards.
I will give over the Egyptians into the hand of a cruel lord. And a fierce king shall rule over them, says the Lord, Jehovah of hosts.
the waters shall fail from the sea,  the river shall be wasted and become dry.
the rivers shall become foul. The streams of Egypt shall be diminished and dried up. The reeds and flags shall wither away.
The meadows by the Nile, by the brink of the Nile,  all the sown fields of the Nile, shall become dry, be driven away,  be no more.
the fishermen shall lament,  all those who cast a hook into the Nile shall mourn,  those who spread nets upon the waters shall languish.
Moreover those who work in combed flax,  those who weave white cloth, shall be confounded.
the pillars of Egypt shall be broken in pieces. All those who work for hire shall be grieved in soul.
The rulers of Zoan are utterly foolish. The counsel of the wisest counselors of Pharaoh has become brutish. How will ye say to Pharaoh, I am the son of wise men, the son of ancient kings?
Where then are thy wise men? And let them tell thee now,  let them know what Jehovah of hosts has purposed concerning Egypt.
The rulers of Zoan have become fools. The rulers of Memphis are deceived. They have caused Egypt to go astray, the chief of her tribes.
Jehovah has mingled a spirit of perverseness in the midst of her,  they have caused Egypt to go astray in every work of it, as a drunken man staggers in his vomit.
Neither shall there be for Egypt any work, which head or tail, palm-branch or rush, may do.
In that day the Egyptians shall be like women,  they shall tremble and fear because of the shaking of the hand of Jehovah of hosts, which he shakes over them.
the land of Judah shall become a terror to Egypt. Everyone to whom mention is made of it shall be afraid because of the purpose of Jehovah of hosts, which he purposes against it.
In that day there shall be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak the language of Canaan,  swear to Jehovah of hosts. One shall be called The city of destruction.
In that day shall there be an altar to Jehovah in the midst of the land of Egypt,  a pillar to Jehovah at the border of it.
it shall be for a sign and for a witness to Jehovah of hosts in the land of Egypt. For they shall cry to Jehovah because of oppressors,  he will send them a savior,  a defender,  he will deliver them.
Jehovah shall be known to Egypt,  the Egyptians shall know Jehovah in that day. Yea, they shall worship with sacrifice and oblation,  shall vow a vow to Jehovah,  shall perform it.
Jehovah will smite Egypt, smiting and healing,  they shall return to Jehovah. And he will be entreated by them,  will heal them.
In that day there shall be a highway out of Egypt to Assyria. And the Assyrian shall come into Egypt,  the Egyptian into Assyria,  the Egyptians shall worship with the Assyrians.
In that day Israel shall be the third with Egypt and with Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth,
in that Jehovah of hosts has blessed them, saying, Blessed be Egypt my people,  Assyria the work of my hands,  Israel my inheritance.
In the year that Tartan came to Ashdod, when Sargon the king of Assyria sent him,  he fought against Ashdod and took it,
at that time Jehovah spoke by Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, Go,  loose the sackcloth from off thy loins,  put thy shoe from off thy foot. And he did so, walking naked and barefoot.
Jehovah said, Just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot three years for a sign and a wonder concerning Egypt and concerning Ethiopia,
so shall the king of Assyria lead away the captives of Egypt,  the exiles of Ethiopia, young and old, naked and barefoot,  with buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
they shall be dismayed and confounded because of Ethiopia their confidence,  of Egypt their glory.
the inhabitant of this coastland shall say in that day, Behold, such is our trust, where we fled for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria. And we, how shall we escape?
The burden of the wilderness of the sea. As whirlwinds in the South sweep through, it comes from the wilderness, from a terrible land.
A grievous vision is declared to me. The treacherous man deals treacherously,  the destroyer destroys. Go up, O Elam. Besiege, O Media, all the sighing of it I have made to cease.
Therefore my loins are filled with anguish. Pangs have taken hold upon me, as the pangs of a woman in travail. I am pained so that I cannot hear. I am dismayed so that I cannot see.
My heart flutters. Horror has frightened me. The twilight that I desired has been turned into trembling to me.
They prepare the table, they set the watch, they eat, they drink. Rise up, ye rulers, anoint the shield.
For thus has the Lord said to me, Go, set a watchman. Let him declare what he sees.
when he sees a troop, horsemen in pairs, a troop of donkeys, a troop of camels, he shall hearken diligently with much heed.
he cried out as a lion, O Lord, I stand continually upon the watchtower in the daytime,  am set in my ward whole nights,
and, behold, here comes a troop of men, horsemen in pairs. And he answered and said, Fallen, fallen is Babylon. And all the graven images of her gods are broken to the ground.
O my threshing,  the grain of my floor! That which I have heard from Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, I have declared to you.
The burden of Dumah. He calls to me out of Seir, Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night?
The watchman said, The morning comes,  also the night. If ye will inquire, inquire ye; turn ye back, come.
The burden upon Arabia. In the forest in Arabia ye shall lodge, O ye caravans of Dedanites.
To him who was thirsty they brought water. The inhabitants of the land of Tema met the fugitives with their bread.
For they fled away from the swords, from the drawn sword,  from the bent bow,  from the grievousness of war.
For thus the Lord has said to me, Within a year, according to the years of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar shall fail.
the residue of the number of the archers, the mighty men of the sons of Kedar, shall be few. For Jehovah, the God of Israel, has spoken it.
The burden of the valley of vision. What troubles thee now, that thou have wholly gone up to the housetops?
O thou that are full of shoutings, a tumultuous city, a joyous town. Thy slain are not slain with the sword, nor are they dead in battle.
All thy rulers fled away together. They were bound by the archers. All who were found of thee were bound together; they fled afar off.
