Matt. Then the Pharisees having departed, they took counsel how they might trap him in his talk.
Matt. And they send out their disciples to him, with the Herodians, saying, Teacher, we know that thou are true,  teach the way of God in truth,  it is not a concern to thee about a man, for thou look not to the personage of men.
Matt. Tell us therefore, what does it seem to thee? Is it permitted to give tribute to Caesar or not?
Matt. But Jesus having known their wickedness, said, Why do ye tempt me, ye hypocrites?
Matt. Exhibit to me the tribute money. And they brought to him a denarius.
Matt. And he says to them, Whose is this image and inscription?
Matt. They say to him, Caesar's. Then he says to them, Therefore, render the things of Caesar to Caesar,  the things of God to God.
Matt. And when they heard it, they marveled. And having left him, they departed.
Matt. On that day Sadducees came to him, those who claim to be no resurrection. And they questioned him, saying,
Matt. Teacher, Moses said, If some man dies, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife,  raise up seed to his brother.
Matt. Now there were with us seven brothers. And the first having married perished. And having no seed left his wife to his brother.
Matt. Likewise also the second,  the third, until the seventh.
Matt. And last of all, the woman also died.
Matt. In the resurrection therefore, which of the seven will she be wife? For they all had her.
Matt. But having answered, Jesus said to them, Ye are led astray, not knowing the scriptures, nor the power of God.
Matt. For in the resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage,  are as agents of God in heaven.
Matt. But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken to you by God, saying,
Matt. I am the God of Abraham,  the God of Isaac,  the God of Jacob? God is not God of the dead,  of the living.
Matt. And when the multitudes heard it, they were astonished at his doctrine.
Matt. But the Pharisees, having heard that he silenced the Sadducees, they came together in the same place.
Matt. And one of them, a lawyer, questioned, trying him,  saying,
Matt. Teacher, which is the great commandment in the law?
Matt. And Jesus said to him, Thou shall love the Lord thy God with thy whole heart,  with thy whole soul,  with thy whole mind.
Matt. This is the first and great commandment.
Matt. And the second is like it, Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself.
Matt. On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.
Matt. Now the Pharisees having been gathered together, Jesus interrogated them, saying,
Matt. What does it seem to you about the Christ? Whose son is he? They say to him, Of David.
Matt. He says to them, How then does David in Spirit call him Lord, saying,
Matt. The Lord said to my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand until I place thine enemies a footstool of thy feet?
Matt. If David therefore calls him Lord, how is he his son?
Matt. And no man was able to answer him a word, nor did any man from that day dare to question him any more.
Matt. Then Jesus spoke to the multitudes and to his disciples, saying,
Matt. The scholars and the Pharisees sit on Moses' seat.
Matt. All things therefore, however many they may tell you to observe, observe and do,  do not ye according to their works, for they say,  do not.
Matt. For they bind heavy burdens and difficult to bear,  lay them on men's shoulders,  they do not want to move them with their finger.
Matt. But all their works they do in order to be seen by men. And they make broad their phylacteries,  enlarge the hems of their garments.
Matt. And they love the chief place at feasts,  the chief seats in the synagogues,
Matt. and the greetings in the marketplaces,  to be designated by men, Rabbi, Rabbi.
Matt. But be ye not designated Rabbi, for one is your leader, the Christ,  ye are all brothers.
Matt. And do not designate a father of you upon the earth, for one is your Father, he in the heavens.
Matt. And be ye not designated leaders, for one is your leader, the Christ.
Matt. But the greater of you will be your helper.
Matt. And he who will exalt himself will be made low,  he who will make himself low will be exalted.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye close up the kingdom of the heavens ahead of men. For ye enter not in, nor do ye allow those who are entering to enter in.
Matt. But woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye devour widows' houses,  praying long in pretence. Because of this ye will receive greater condemnation.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye encompass the sea and the land to make one proselyte,  when it happens, ye make him twice more a son of hell than yourselves.
Matt. Woe to you, ye blind guides, who say, Whoever may swear by the temple, it is nothing,  whoever may swear by the gold of the temple, he is obligated.
Matt. Ye foolish and blind men, for which is greater, the gold, or the temple that makes the gold sacred?
Matt. And, Whoever may swear by the altar, it is nothing,  whoever may swear by the gift upon it, he is obligated.
Matt. Ye foolish and blind men, for which is greater, the gift, or the altar that makes the gift sacred?
Matt. He therefore who swears by the altar, swears by it,  by all things on it.
Matt. And he who swears by the temple, swears by it,  by him who dwells in it.
Matt. And he who swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God,  by him who sits upon it.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye tithe the mint and the anise and the cummin,  have omitted the weightier matters of the law-justice and mercy and faith. These things must be done,  not neglecting those things.
Matt. Ye blind guides, who strain out the gnat,  swallow the camel.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye cleanse the outside of the cup and of the platter,  inside they are full of plunder and unrighteousness.
Matt. Thou blind Pharisee, cleanse first the inside of the cup and of the platter, so that the outside of them may also become clean.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye are like whitewashed tombs, which indeed appear beautiful outwardly,  inside are full of dead men's bones,  of all uncleanness.
Matt. In this way also, ye indeed outwardly appear righteous to men,  inside ye are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.
Matt. Woe to you, scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye build the tombs of the prophets,  adorn the sepulchers of the righteous,
Matt. and say, If we had been in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.
Matt. So then ye testify to yourselves that ye are sons of those who murdered the prophets.
Matt. Then fill ye up the measure of your fathers.
Matt. Ye serpents, ye offspring of vipers, how will ye escape from the damnation of hell?
Matt. Because of this, behold, I send to you prophets,  wise men,  scholars. And some of them ye will kill and crucify,  some of them ye will scourge in your synagogues,  will persecute from city to city,
Matt. so that upon you may come all the righteous blood shed on the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zachariah son of Barachiah, whom ye murdered between the sanctuary and the altar.
Matt. Truly I say to you, that all these things will come upon this generation.
Matt. O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets,  stones those who have been sent to her. How often I wanted to gathered thy children together the way a hen gathers her chicks under her wings,  ye would not.
Matt. Behold, your house is left to you desolate.
Matt. For I say to you, ye will, no, not see me henceforth, until ye say, Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.
Matt. And when Jesus departed he was going from the temple. And his disciples came near to exhibit to him the buildings of the temple.
Matt. But Jesus said to them, Do ye not see all these things? Truly I say to you, there will be left here, no, not a stone upon a stone, that will not be thrown down.
Matt. And as he sat on the mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately, saying, Tell us, when will these things be? And what is the sign of thy coming,  of the termination of the age?
Matt. And having answered, Jesus said to them, See that not any man may lead you astray.
Matt. For many will come in my name, saying, I am the Christ,  will lead many astray.
Matt. And ye are going to hear of wars and rumors of wars. See that ye not be alarmed, for all the things must happen,  the end is not yet.
Matt. For nation will rise against nation,  kingdom against kingdom,  there will be famines and plagues and earthquakes in places.
Matt. But all these things are the beginning of travail.
Matt. Then they will deliver you up for tribulation,  will kill you,  ye will be hated by all the nations because of my name.
Matt. And then many will be caused to stumble,  they will betray each other and will hate each other.
Matt. And many false prophets will arise,  will lead many astray.
Matt. And because of the increased lawlessness, the love of the many will become cold.
Matt. But he who endures to the end, this man will be saved.
Matt. And this good news of the kingdom will be proclaimed in the whole world for a testimony to all the nations,  then the end will come.
Matt. When therefore ye see the abomination of desolation that was spoken of through Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place (let him who reads understand),
Matt. then let those in Judea flee to the mountains.
Matt. Let the man on the housetop not go down to take things from his house.
Matt. And let the man in the field not return back to take his clothes.
Matt. And woe to those who have in the womb and to those who suckle in those days.
Matt. And pray ye that your flight may not happen in winter, nor on a sabbath,
Matt. for then there will be great tribulation, such as not has happened from the beginning of the world until now, nor, no, it will not happen.
Matt. And if those days were not shortened, no flesh would be saved. But because of the chosen those days will be shortened.
Matt. Then if any man should say to you, Lo, here is the Christ, or, Here, believe ye not.
Matt. For there will arise false Christs and false prophets,  they will give great signs and wonders, so as to lead astray, if possible, even the chosen.
Matt. Behold, I have foretold it to you.
Matt. If therefore they should say to you, Behold, he is in the wilderness, do not go forth. Behold, he is in the inner chambers, do not believe.
Matt. For as the lightning comes out from the east,  shines as far as the west, so also will be the coming of the Son of man.
Matt. For wherever the carcass may be, there the vultures will be gathered together.
Matt. But straightaway after the tribulation of those days the sun will be darkened,  the moon will not give its light. And the stars will fall from the sky,  the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
Matt. And then the sign of the Son of man will appear in the sky. And then all the tribes of the earth will beat the breast,  they will see the Son of man coming in the clouds of the sky with power and much glory.
Matt. And he will send forth his agents with a great trumpet sound,  they will gather together his chosen from the four winds, from the boundaries of the heavens-as far as their boundaries.
Matt. Now learn a parable from the fig tree. When its branch now becomes tender,  sprouts leaves, ye know that the summer is near.
Matt. So ye also, when ye see all these things, know that it is near, at the doors.
Matt. Truly I say to you, this generation will, no, not pass away, until all these things happen.
Matt. The sky and the earth will pass away,  my words may, no, not pass away.
Matt. But about that day and hour no man knows, not even the agents of the heavens, except my Father only.
Matt. And as the days of Noah, so also will be the coming of the Son of man.
Matt. For as in the days before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage until that day Noah entered into the ark.
Matt. And they knew not until the flood came,  took them all away. So also will be the coming of the Son of man.
Matt. Then two men will be in the field, one is taken,  one is left.
Matt. Two women grinding at the mill, one is taken,  one is left.
Matt. Watch therefore, because ye know not at what hour your Lord comes.
Matt. But know this, that if the house-ruler had known in what watch the thief was coming, he would have watched,  would not have allowed his house to be broken into.
Matt. Because of this ye also be ready, because in that hour ye think not the Son of man comes.
Matt. Who then is the faithful and wise bondman, whom his lord appointed over his service, to give them the provision on time?
Matt. Blessed is that bondman, whom his lord when he comes will find so doing.
Matt. Truly I say to you, that he will appoint him over all things being possessed by him.
Matt. But if that evil bondman should say in his heart, My lord is late coming,
Matt. and should begin to beat the fellow bondmen,  to eat and drink with the drunken,
Matt. the lord of that bondman will come in a day that he does not expect,  in an hour that he is not aware,
Matt. and he will cut him in two,  place his share with the hypocrites. There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
Matt. Then the kingdom of heaven will be like ten virgins, who, having taken their lamps, went forth to the bridegroom's gathering.
Matt. And five of them were wise,  five were foolish,
Matt. foolish women, who, having taken their lamps, took no olive oil with them.
Matt. But the wise took olive oil in their vessels with their lamps.
Matt. Now while the bridegroom delayed, they all slumbered and slept.
Matt. But at midnight a shout occurred, Behold, the bridegroom comes! Go ye forth for his gathering.
Matt. Then all those virgins were roused,  put their lamps in order.
Matt. And the foolish said to the wise, Give us from your olive oil, because our lamps are going out.
Matt. But the wise answered, saying, Perhaps there may not be enough for us and you. But go ye rather to those who sell,  buy for yourselves.
Matt. And while they went to buy, the bridegroom came. And the prepared entered in with him for the wedding festivities,  the door was shut.
Matt. But afterward the other virgins also came, saying, Lord, Lord, open to us.
Matt. But having answered, he said, Truly I say to you, I know you not.
Matt. Watch therefore, because ye know not the day nor the hour in which the Son of man comes.
Matt. For, like a man going on a journey, he called his own bondmen,  delivered to them the things possessed by him.
Matt. And to one he gave five talents, to another two, to another one, to each according to his personal ability,  straightaway he journeyed.
Matt. And having departed, the man who received the five talents worked with them,  made five other talents.
Matt. And likewise also the man of the two gained two others.
Matt. But having departed, the man who received the one dug in the ground,  hid his lord's silver.
Matt. Now after a long time the lord of those bondmen comes,  takes up accounting with them.
Matt. And having come, the man who received the five talents brought five other talents, saying, Lord, thou delivered five talents to me, lo, I have gained five other talents besides them.
Matt. And his lord said to him, Well, good and faithful bondman. Thou were faithful over a few things, I will appoint thee over many things. Enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Matt. And also having come, the man who received the two talents said, Lord, thou delivered two talents to me, lo, I have gained two other talents besides them.
Matt. His lord said to him, Well, good and faithful bondman. Thou were faithful over a few things, I will appoint thee over many things. Enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Matt. And the man who received the one talent also having come, said, Lord, I knew thee that thou are a hard man, reaping where thou did not sow,  gathering from where thou did not scatter.
Matt. And after being afraid, having gone, I hid thy talent in the ground. Lo, thou have thine own.
Matt. But having answered, his lord said to him, Thou evil and lazy bondman, thou knew that I reap where I sowed not,  gather from where I did not scatter.
Matt. Thou ought therefore to have placed my silver with the bankers,  having come I would have received back my own with interest.
Matt. Take ye therefore the talent from him,  give it to him who has the ten talents.
Matt. For to every man who has will be given,  he will have abundance,  from him who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him.
Matt. And cast ye the unprofitable bondman into the outer darkness. There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth.
Matt. But when the Son of man comes in his glory,  all the holy agents with him, then he will sit on the throne of his glory.
Matt. And all the nations will be gathered before him,  he will separate them from each other, as the shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
Matt. And he will truly place the sheep at his right hand,  the goats at the left.
Matt. Then the King will say to those at his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
Matt. For I was hungry,  ye gave me to eat. I was thirsty,  ye gave me to drink. I was a stranger,  ye took me in,
Matt. naked,  ye clothed me. I was feeble,  ye came to help me. I was in prison,  ye came to me.
Matt. Then the righteous will answer him, saying, Lord, when did we see thee hungering,  fed thee, or thirsting,  gave thee drink?
Matt. And when did we see thee a stranger,  took thee in, or naked,  clothed thee?
Matt. And when did we see thee weak, or in prison,  came to thee?
Matt. And having answered, the King will say to them, Truly I say to you, inasmuch as ye did it to one of these my brothers, the least, ye did it to me.
Matt. Then he will also say to those at the left hand, Depart from me, ye accursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his agents.
Matt. For I was hungry,  ye did not give me to eat, I was thirsty,  ye gave me no drink,
Matt. I was a stranger,  ye did not take me in, naked,  ye did not clothe me, weak,  in prison,  ye did not come to help me.
Matt. Then they will also answer, saying, Lord, when did we see thee hungering, or thirsting, or a stranger, or naked, or weak, or in prison,  did not serve thee?
Matt. Then he will answer them, saying, Truly I say to you, inasmuch as ye did it not to one of these least, ye did it not to me.
Matt. And these will go away into eternal punishment,  the righteous into eternal life.
Matt. And it came to pass, when Jesus had finished all these saying, he said to his disciples,
Matt. Ye know that after two days the Passover comes,  the Son of man is betrayed to be crucified.
Matt. Then the chief priests,  the scholars,  the elders of the people, assembled together to the courtyard of the high priest, who was called Caiaphas,
Matt. and they deliberated so that they might take Jesus by trickery,  kill him.
Matt. But they said, Not during the feast, lest an uproar develop among people.
Matt. Now when Jesus happened to be in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
Matt. a woman came to him having an alabaster cruse of precious ointment,  she poured it upon his head as he sat relaxing.
Matt. But when his disciples saw it, they were indignant, saying, Why this waste?
Matt. For this ointment could have been sold for much,  given to the poor.
Matt. But Jesus knowing it, he said to them, Why do ye cause troubles to the woman? For she has wrought a good work upon me.
Matt. For ye always have the poor with you,  ye do not always have me.
Matt. For by pouring this ointment upon my body, she did it for my burial.
Matt. Truly I say to you, wherever this good news may be proclaimed in the whole world, what this woman did will also be told for a memorial of her.
Matt. Then one of the twelve, who was called Judas Iscariot, having gone to the chief priests,
Matt. he said, What are ye willing to give me,  I will deliver him to you? And they weighed out to him thirty silver pieces.
Matt. And from that time he sought a favorable opportunity so that he might betray him.
Matt. Now on the first day of unleavened bread the disciples came to Jesus, saying, Where do thou want that we should prepare for thee to eat the Passover?
Matt. And he said, Go into the city to a certain man,  say to him, The teacher says, My time is near. I keep the Passover with my disciples with thee.
Matt. And the disciples did as Jesus arranged for them,  they prepared the Passover.
Matt. Now having become evening, he was sitting with the twelve.
Matt. And as they were eating, he said, Truly I say to you, that one of you will betray me.
Matt. And being exceedingly sorrowful, they began, each of them, to say to him, Is it I, Lord?
Matt. And having answered, he said, He who dipped his hand with me in the dish, this man will betray me.
Matt. The Son of man indeed goes as it is written about him,  woe to that man through whom the Son of man is betrayed! It were good for him if that man had not been born.
Matt. And Judas (the man who betrayed him) having answered, he said, Is it I, Rabbi? He says to him, Thou have said.
Matt. And as they were eating, Jesus, having taken bread, having expressed thanks, broke in pieces,  he gave to the disciples,  said, Take, eat, this is my body.
Matt. And having taken the cup, having expressed thanks, he gave to them, saying, All ye drink of it,
Matt. for this is my blood of the new covenant, which is shed on behalf of many for remission of sins.
Matt. But I say to you, that I will, no, not drink of this fruit of the grapevine henceforth until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom.
Matt. And having sung a hymn, they went out to the mount of Olives.
Matt. Then Jesus says to them, All ye will be caused to stumble by me in this night, for it is written, I will strike the shepherd,  the sheep of the flock will be scattered.
Matt. But after I am raised up, I will go before you into Galilee.
Matt. But having answered, Peter said to him, If all men will be caused to stumble by thee, I will never be caused to stumble.
Matt. Jesus said to him, Truly I say to thee, that in this night, before a cock sounds, thou will deny me thrice.
Matt. Peter says to him, Even if I must die with thee, I will, no, not deny thee. And likewise also, said all the disciples.
Matt. Then Jesus comes with them to a place called Gethsemane,  he says to his disciples, Sit ye here until, after going, I may pray there.
Matt. And having taken Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, he began to be sorrowful and distressed.
Matt. Then Jesus says to them, My soul is deeply grieved, as far as of death. Remain ye here and watch with me.
Matt. And having gone forward a little, he fell on his face praying,  saying, My Father, if it be possible, may this cup pass from me. Nevertheless, not as I want,  as thou.
Matt. And he comes to the disciples,  finds them sleeping. And he says to Peter, So ye could not watch with me one hour.
Matt. Watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation. Truly, the spirit is willing,  the flesh is weak.
Matt. Having gone again a second time, he prayed, saying, My Father, if it is not possible for this cup to pass from me, except I drink it, may thy will happen.
Matt. And having come again, he finds them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
Matt. And when he left them, having gone away again, he prayed a third time, saying again the same statement.
Matt. Then he comes to his disciples,  says to them, Sleep what remains,  take rest. Behold, the hour has come near,  the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Matt. Awake, we go. Behold, he who betrays me has come near.
Matt. And while he was still speaking, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came,  with him a great multitude with swords and clubs from the chief priest and elders of the people.
Matt. Now the man who betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomever I may kiss is he. Seize him.
Matt. And straightaway having come to Jesus, he said, Hail, Rabbi,  kissed him much.
Matt. And Jesus said to him, Friend, why are thou here? Then having come, they threw their hands on Jesus,  seized him.
Matt. And behold, one of those with Jesus, having stretched out a hand, drew his sword,  when he struck the bondman of the high priest, he cut off his ear.
Matt. Then Jesus says to him, Return thy sword into its place, for all those who take a sword will die by a sword.
Matt. Or do thou think that I cannot now call my Father,  he will provide to me more than twelve legions of agents?
Matt. How then would the scriptures be fulfilled that it is necessary to happen this way?
Matt. In that hour Jesus said to the multitudes, Did ye come out as against a robber with swords and clubs to seize me? I sat daily with you teaching in the temple,  ye did not seize me.
Matt. But all this has come to pass, so that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples fled, having forsook him.
Matt. And those who seized Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest where the scholars and the elders were assembled together.
Matt. But Peter followed him from afar, as far as the courtyard of the high priest. And having entered inside, he sat with the subordinates to see the outcome.
Matt. Now the chief priests and the elders and the whole council sought false testimony against Jesus, so that they might put him to death,
Matt. and they did not find it. And although many false witnesses came, they did not find it.
Matt. But finally two false witnesses having come, they said, This man said, I am able to destroy the temple of God,  to build it by three days.
Matt. And the high priest having stood up, he said to him, Answer thou nothing? What do these testify against thee?
Matt. But Jesus was silent. And having responded, the high priest said to him, I adjure thee by the living God, that thou tell us if thou are the Christ, the Son of God.
Matt. Jesus says to him, Thou have said. Nevertheless I say to you, Henceforth ye will see the Son of man sitting at the right hand of Power,  coming in the clouds of the sky.
Matt. Then the high priest tore his garments, saying, He has blasphemed. What further need have we of witnesses? Behold, now ye heard his blasphemy.
Matt. What does it seem to you? Having answered, they said, He is deserving of death.
Matt. Then they spat in his face and struck him with a fist. And some slapped him,
Matt. saying, Prophesy to us, thou Christ. Who is he who struck thee?
Matt. Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard,  one servant girl came to him, saying, Thou also were with Jesus the Galilean.
Matt. But he denied before them all, saying, I do not know what thou say.
Matt. And when he was gone out into the porch, another woman saw him,  says to them there, This man was also with Jesus the Nazarene.
Matt. And again he denied with an oath, I do not know the man.
Matt. And after a little while those who stood, having approached, said to Peter, Surely thou also are of them, for thy accent even makes thee apparent.
Matt. Then he began to curse vehemently and to swear, I do not know the man. And straightaway a cock sounded.
Matt. And Peter remembered the saying that Jesus said to him, Before a cock sounds, thou will deny me thrice. And having gone outside, he wept bitterly.
Matt. But having become morning, all the chief priests and the elders of the people held consultation against Jesus in order to condemn him to death.
Matt. And having bound him, they led him away and delivered him to Pontius Pilate the governor.
Matt. Then Judas, who betrayed him, after seeing that he was condemned, having repented, he brought back the thirty silver pieces to the chief priests and elders,
Matt. saying, I sinned, having betrayed innocent blood. But they said, What is it to us? See thou to it.
Matt. And having cast down the silver pieces in the temple, he departed,  after going away, he hanged himself.
Matt. And after taking the silver pieces, the chief priests said, It is not permitted to put them into the treasury, since it is a price of blood.
Matt. And having held consultation, they bought the potter's field with them for burial for foreigners.
Matt. Therefore that field was called the field of blood, to this day.
Matt. Then that which was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled, which says, And they took the thirty silver pieces, the price of him who was valued, whom they valued from the sons of Israel,
Matt. and they gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed me.
Matt. Now Jesus stood before the governor,  the governor questioned him, saying, Are thou the king of the Jews? And Jesus said to him, Thou say.
Matt. And when he was accused by the chief priests and elders, he answered nothing.
Matt. Then Pilate says to him, Do thou not hear how many things they testify against thee?
Matt. And he did not answer him, not even one word, so as for the governor to marvel greatly.
Matt. Now during a feast the governor had been accustomed to release to the crowd one prisoner whom they wanted.
Matt. And they had then a notorious prisoner called Barabbas.
Matt. When therefore they were gathered together, Pilate said to them, Whom do ye want I should release to you? Barabbas, or Jesus who is called Christ?
Matt. For he knew that they delivered him up because of envy.
Matt. And while he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him, saying, There is nothing for thee and that righteous man. For I suffered many things this day in a dream because of him.
Matt. But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the multitudes that they should ask for Barabbas,  destroy Jesus.
Matt. Now the governor having answered, he said to them, Which of the two do ye want I would release to you? And they said, Barabbas.
Matt. Pilate says to them, What then shall I do to Jesus who is called Christ? They all say to him, He should be crucified.
Matt. And the governor said, For what evil has he done? But they cried out even more, saying, He should be crucified.
Matt. And when Pilate saw that he was accomplishing nothing,  rather an uproar was developing, after taking water, he washed his hands in front of the multitude, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this righteous man. See ye to it.
Matt. And having answered, all the people said, His blood be on us,  on our children.
Matt. Then he released Barabbas to them,  having scourged Jesus he delivered him so that he would be crucified.
Matt. Then the soldiers of the governor, having taken Jesus into the Praetorium, gathered the whole band to him.
Matt. And having stripped him, they put a scarlet robe on him.
Matt. And having woven a crown of thorns, they put it upon his head,  a reed in his right hand. And having knelt down before him, they ridiculed him, saying, Hail, king of the Jews!
Matt. And having spat upon him, they took the reed and were striking him on his head.
Matt. And after they ridiculed him, they took the robe off of him,  put his clothes on him,  led him away in order to crucify.
Matt. And while coming out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name. They drafted this man, so that he might take his cross.
Matt. And having come to a place called Golgotha, that is called, the place of a skull,
Matt. they gave him vinegar to drink mingled with gall. And having tasted it, he would not drink.
Matt. And when they crucified him, they divided his garments, casting a lot.
Matt. And as they sat, they keep watch over him there.
Matt. And they set up over his head his accusation written, THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Matt. Then two robbers are crucified with him, one at the right hand and one at the left.
Matt. And those who passed by reviled him, shaking their heads,
Matt. and saying, Thou who destroy the temple,  build it in three days, save thyself. If thou are the Son of God, come down from the cross.
Matt. And likewise also the chief priests, ridiculing with the scholars,  elders,  Pharisees, said,
Matt. He saved others, he cannot save himself. If he is the king of Israel, let him now come down from the cross,  we will believe in him.
Matt. He trusted in God, let him rescue him now, if he wants him, for he said, I am the Son of God.
Matt. And also the robbers who were crucified with him reviled him the same way.
Matt. Now from the sixth hour darkness developed over all the land until the ninth hour.
Matt. And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out in a great voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani? That is, My God, my God, why have thou forsaken me?
Matt. And some of those who stood there, when they heard it, said, This man calls Elijah.
Matt. And straightaway one of them, after running,  having taken a sponge,  having filled it with vinegar, put it on a reed,  gave him to drink.
Matt. But the others said, Leave thou be. We might see if Elijah comes he will save him.
Matt. And Jesus, having cried out again in a great voice, yielded up his spirit.
Matt. And behold, the curtain of the temple was torn in two from the top to the bottom,  the earth quaked,  the rocks split,
Matt. and the sepulchers were opened,  many bodies of the sanctified who have been asleep arose.
Matt. And having come forth out of the sepulchers after his resurrection they entered into the holy city and appeared to many.
Matt. Now the centurion,  those with him watching over Jesus, when they saw the earthquake,  the things that happened, they feared greatly, saying, Truly this was the Son of God.
Matt. And many women were there watching from afar, who followed Jesus from Galilee, serving him,
Matt. among whom was Mary Magdalene,  Mary the mother of James and Joses,  the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
Matt. And having become evening, there came a rich man from Arimathaea, named Joseph, who also himself was discipled by Jesus.
Matt. This man having come to Pilate, requested the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded the body to be given.
Matt. And Joseph having taken the body, wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,
Matt. and laid it in his own new sepulcher, which he hewed out in the rock. And having rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulcher, he departed.
Matt. And Mary Magdalene,  the other Mary were there, sitting opposite the tomb.
Matt. Now on the morrow, which is after the Preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees came together to Pilate,
Matt. saying, Sir, we remember that that deceiver said while he was still alive, After three days I am raised.
Matt. Command therefore to secure the tomb until the third day, lest his disciples having come by night steal him away,  say to the people, He was raised from the dead. And the last error will be worse than the first.
Matt. Pilate said to them, Ye have security. Go, make it as secure as ye know how.
Matt. And having gone, they made the tomb secure, with the security having sealed the stone.
Matt. Now late on the sabbath day, being dawn toward the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the tomb.
Matt. And behold, a great earthquake occurred, for an agent of the Lord, having descended from heaven, having come, he rolled the stone away from the door and sat upon it.
Matt. And his appearance was as lightning and his clothing white as snow.
Matt. And those watching over shook from fear of him,  became as dead men.
Matt. And having responded, the agent said to the women, Fear ye not, for I know that ye seek Jesus, who was crucified.
Matt. He is not here, for he was raised as he said. Come, see the place where the Lord lay.
Matt. And after going quickly, tell his disciples, He was raised from the dead,  lo, he goes before you into Galilee. There ye will see him. Behold, I have told you.
Matt. And after coming out quickly from the sepulcher with fear and great joy, they ran to notify his disciples.
Matt. And as they were going to tell his disciples, behold, Jesus also met them, saying, Hail. And having come, they held his feet and worshiped him.
Matt. Then Jesus says to them, Fear not. Go notify my brothers that they should depart into Galilee,  there they will see me.
Matt. Now while they were going, behold, some of the security having come into the city, reported to the chief priests all the things that happened.
Matt. And after assembling with the elders,  having taken consultation, they gave many silver pieces to the soldiers, saying,
Matt. Say ye, His disciples, having come by night, stole him from us while we slept.
Matt. And if this should be heard by the governor, we will persuade him,  will make you worry free.
Matt. And having taken the silver pieces, they did as they were instructed. And this saying was spread abroad among the Jews until this day.
Matt. But the eleven disciples went for Galilee to the mountain where Jesus arranged for them.
Matt. And when they saw him, they worshiped him,  men doubted.
Matt. And Jesus having come, he spoke to them, saying, All authority in heaven and on earth was given to me.
Matt. After going, make ye disciples of all the nations, immersing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,
Matt. teaching them to observe all things, as many as I commanded you. And lo, I am with you all the days, until the end of the age. Truly.
Mark
Mark. The beginning of the good news of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
Mark. As it is written in the prophets, Behold, I send my agent before thy face, who will prepare thy way before thee.
Mark. The voice of a man crying out in the wilderness: Prepare ye the way of the Lord. Make his paths straight.
Mark. It came to pass, that John was immersing in the wilderness and preaching an immersion of repentance for remission of sins.
Mark. And all the land of Judea and the Jerusalemites went out to him,  they were all immersed by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins.
Mark. And John was clothed with camel's hair and a leather belt around his waist,  eating locusts and wild honey.
Mark. And he preached, saying, A man mightier than I comes after me of whom I am not worthy, having stooped down, to loosen the strap of his shoes.
Mark. I indeed immersed you in water,  he will immerse you in the Holy Spirit.
Mark. And it came to pass in those days, that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee,  was immersed by John in the Jordan.
Mark. And straightaway coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens divided,  the Spirit descending upon him as a dove.
Mark. And a voice occurred out of the heavens, Thou are my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.
Mark. And straightaway the Spirit drives him forth into the wilderness.
Mark. And he was there in the wilderness forty days tempted by Satan. And he was with the wild beasts. And the agents served him.
Mark. Now after John was delivered up, Jesus came into Galilee proclaiming the good news of God,
Mark. and saying, The time is fulfilled,  the kingdom of God has come near. Repent ye,  believe in the good news.
Mark. And walking beside the sea of Galilee he saw Simon and Andrew his brother, the son of Simon, casting a net in the sea, for they were fishermen.
Mark. And Jesus said to them, Come ye behind me,  I will make you to become fishermen of men.
Mark. And straightaway they left the nets,  followed him.
Mark. And having advanced a little from there he saw James the son of Zebedee,  John his brother, who were also in the boat mending the nets.
Mark. And straightaway he called them. And having left their father Zebedee in the boat with the workmen, they went behind him.
Mark. And they entered into Capernaum,  straightaway on the sabbath day, having entered into the synagogue, he taught.
Mark. And they were astonished at his teaching, for he was teaching them as having authority,  not as the scholars.
Mark. And a man was in their synagogue with an unclean spirit. And he cried out,
Mark. saying, Oh no! What is with us and with thee, Jesus of Nazareth? Did thou come to destroy us? I know thee who thou are, the Holy man of God.
Mark. And Jesus rebuked him, saying, Be thou muzzled,  come out of him.
Mark. And the unclean spirit, having convulsed him and having cried in a great voice, came out of him.
Mark. And they were all amazed, so as to question among themselves, saying, What is this? What is this new doctrine, that he commands with authority,  the unclean spirits also obey him?
Mark. And his fame went forth straightaway into the entire region around Galilee.
Mark. And straightaway, when they came forth out of the synagogue they came into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
Mark. But Simon's mother-in-law lay feverish,  straightaway they tell him about her.
Mark. And upon coming, having taken hold of her hand, he raised her up and the fever left her. And straightaway she served them.
Mark. And having become evening when the sun set they brought to him all who were faring badly,  those who were demon-possessed.
Mark. And the whole city was gathered together near the door.
Mark. And he healed many who were faring badly with various diseases,  cast out many demons. And he did not allow the demons to speak, because they had recognized him.
Mark. And having risen early, very much in the night, he came out and departed into a desolate place,  prayed there.
Mark. And Simon and those with him searched for him.
Mark. And having found him, they say to him, All are seeking thee.
Mark. And he says to them, Let us go into the nearby towns, so that I may preach there also. For I came forth for this.
Mark. And he was preaching in their synagogues in all Galilee,  casting out the demons.
Mark. And a leper comes to him beseeching him,  kneeling down to him,  saying to him, If thou will thou can make me clean.
Mark. And Jesus, having felt compassion, having reached out his hand, he touched him,  says to him, I will, be thou clean.
Mark. And after he spoke, straightaway the leprosy departed from him,  he was cleansed.
Mark. And having strictly warned him, straightaway he sent him out.
Mark. And he says to him, See thou say nothing to any man,  go, show thyself to the priest,  bring for thy cleansing the things that Moses commanded for a testimony to them.
Mark. But having gone out, he began to proclaim it much,  to spread abroad the matter, so as for him to no longer be able to enter openly into a city,  was outside in desolate places. And they came to him from all directions.
Mark. And having again entered into Capernaum, after some days it was heard that he was in a house.
Mark. And straightaway many were gathered together, so as to accommodate no more, not even near the door. And he spoke the word to them.
Mark. And they come bringing to him a paralyzed man, being taken by four men.
Mark. And not being able to come near to him because of the crowd, they uncovered the roof where he was. And when they had broken through, they let down the bed on which the paralyzed man lay.
Mark. And having seen their faith, Jesus says to the paralyzed man, Child, thy sins are forgiven thee.
Mark. But some of the scholars were sitting there,  deliberating in their hearts,
Mark. Why does this man speak blasphemies this way. Who can forgive sins but one, God?
Mark. And straightaway Jesus, having perceived in his spirit that they so deliberated within themselves, said to them, Why do ye deliberate these things in your hearts?
Mark. Which is easier, to say to the paralyzed man, Thy sins are forgiven thee, or to say, Arise,  take up thy bed and walk?
Mark. But that ye may know that the Son of man has authority on earth to forgive sins (he says to the paralyzed man),
Mark. I say to thee, Arise,  take up thy bed,  go to thy house.
Mark. And straightaway he arose,  having taken up the bed, he went forth before them all, so as for all to be amazed,  to glorify God, saying, We never saw it like this.
Mark. And he went forth again by the sea,  all the multitude resorted to him,  he taught them.
Mark. And as he passed by he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the tax office. And he says to him, Follow thou me. And having risen, he followed him.
Mark. And it came to pass, while he was dining in his house, that many tax collectors and sinners were dining with Jesus and his disciples, for there were many,  they followed him.
Mark. And the scholars of the Pharisees, when they saw him eating with the tax collectors and sinners, they said to his disciples, Why is it that he eats and drinks with tax collectors and sinners?
Mark. And when Jesus heard it he says to them, Those who are strong have no need of a physician,  those faring badly. I came not to call the righteous,  sinners for repentance.
Mark. And John's disciples and those of the Pharisees were fasting. And they come and say to him, Why do John's disciples and those of the Pharisees fast,  the disciples with you do not fast?
Mark. And Jesus said to them, The sons of the wedding hall cannot fast while the bridegroom is with them. As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.
Mark. But the days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them,  then they will they fast in those day.
Mark. And no man sews a new patch of cloth on an old garment, otherwise the patch of it pulls away, the new from the old,  a tear becomes worse.
Mark. And no man puts new wine into old wineskins, otherwise the new wine bursts the wineskins,  the wine is spilled,  the wineskins will be destroyed. But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins.
Mark. And it came to pass, that he was passing through the grain fields on the sabbath day,  his disciples began to make a path while plucking the ears.
Mark. And the Pharisees said to him, Look, why are they doing what is not permitted on the sabbath day?
Mark. And he said to them, Did ye never read what David did when he had need,  was hungry, he and those with him?
Mark. How he entered into the house of God under Abiathar the high priest,  ate the loaves of the presentation, which is not permitted to eat except for the priests. And he also gave to those who were with him?
Mark. And he said to them, The sabbath came into being for sake of man,  not man for sake of the sabbath.
Mark. So then the Son of man is lord even of the sabbath.
Mark. And he entered again into the synagogue,  a man was there who had a withered hand.
Mark. And they watched him whether he would heal him on the sabbath day, so that they might accuse him.
Mark. And he says to the man who had a withered hand, Stand up in the midst.
Mark. And he says to them, Is it permitted to do good on the sabbath day or to do harm, to save life or to kill? But they were silent.
Mark. And having looked around on them with anger, being grieved at the callousness of their heart, he says to the man, Stretch forth thy hand. And he stretched it out,  his hand was restored as the other.
Mark. And the Pharisees having gone out, they straightaway were making a plot with the Herodians against him, how they might destroy him.
Mark. And Jesus withdrew with his disciples to the sea,  a great multitude from Galilee followed him.
Mark. And from Judea,  from Jerusalem,  from Idumaea,  beyond the Jordan,  around Tyre and Sidon, a great multitude, having heard how many things he did, came to him.
Mark. And he spoke to his disciples that a small boat would stay by him because of the crowd, lest they should throng him.
Mark. For he healed many, so as to press upon him, so that as many as had afflictions might touch him.
Mark. And the unclean spirits, whenever they saw him, fell down before him,  cried out, saying, Thou are the Son of God.
Mark. And he chided them much that they should not make him known.
Mark. And he goes up onto the mountain,  calls in those whom he himself wanted,  they went to him.
Mark. And he appointed twelve men, so that they might be with him,  that he might send them forth to preach,
Mark. and to have authority to heal diseases and to cast out demons.
Mark. And he added to Simon the name Peter;
Mark. and James the son of Zebedee,  John the brother of James,  he added to them the name Boanerges, which is, Sons of thunder;
Mark. and Andrew,  Philip,  Bartholomew,  Matthew,  Thomas,  James the son of Alphaeus,  Thaddaeus,  Simon the Canaanite,
Mark. and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him. And they come to a house.
Mark. And the multitude comes together again, so as for them, no, not even to be able to eat bread.
Mark. And when those with him heard it, they went out to grasp him, for they said, He is beside himself.
Mark. And the scholars who came down from Jerusalem said, He has Beelzebub, , By the ruler of the demons he casts out the demons.
Mark. And having summoned them, he said to them in parables, How can Satan cast out Satan?
Mark. And if a kingdom be divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.
Mark. And if a house be divided against itself, that house cannot stand.
Mark. And if Satan has rise up against himself,  is divided, he cannot stand,  has an end.
Mark. But no man, having enter into the house of the strong man, can plunder his goods unless he first binds the strong man,  then he may plunder his house.
Mark. Truly I say to you, that all the sins will be forgiven the sons of men,  the blasphemies, as many as they may blaspheme.
Mark. But whoever may blaspheme against the Holy Spirit has no forgiveness, into the age,  is deserving of eternal damnation,
Mark. because they said, He has an unclean spirit.
Mark. Then his brothers and mother come,  standing outside, they sent to him, calling him.
Mark. And a multitude was sitting around him,  they said to him, Behold, thy mother,  thy brothers,  thy sisters, outside seek for thee.
Mark. And he answered them, saying, Who is my mother and my brothers?
Mark. And having looked around at those who sat about him, he says, Behold, my mother and my brothers.
Mark. For whoever may do the will of God, the same is my brother and sister and mother.
Mark. And again he began to teach by the sea. And a great multitude was gathered to him, so as for him, after entering into the boat, to sit on the sea,  all the multitude was by the sea on the land.
Mark. And he taught them many things in parables,  said to them in his teaching,
Mark. Listen. Behold, the man who sows went forth to sow.
Mark. And it came to pass during the sowing, some fell by the path,  the birds came and devoured it.
Mark. And others fell on the rocky ground where it had not much soil. And straightaway it sprang up, because it had no depth of soil.
Mark. And when the sun was risen it was scorched,  because it had no root it dried out.
Mark. And others fell among the thorns,  the thorns grew up and choked it,  it gave no fruit.
Mark. And others fell into the good ground and gave fruit, coming up and increasing,  brought forth, one thirty,  one sixty,  one a hundred.
Mark. And he said, He who has ears to hear, let him hear.
Mark. And when he became alone, those around him, with the twelve, asked him the parable.
Mark. And he said to them, To you is given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God,  to those outside, all things occur in parables.
Mark. So that seeing they may see,  not perceive,  hearing they may hear,  not understand, lest they should turn,  the sins would be forgiven them.
Mark. And he says to them, Do ye not know this parable? And how will ye understand all the parables?
Mark. The man who sows sows the word.
Mark. And these are those by the path where the word is sown. And whenever they may hear, straightaway Satan comes,  takes away the word that has been sown in their hearts.
Mark. And these in like manner are those being sown upon the rocky places, who, whenever they may hear the word, straightaway receive it with joy.
Mark. And they have no root in themselves,  are temporary. Afterward, when tribulation or persecution develops because of the word, straightaway they are caused to stumble.
Mark. And these are those being sown in the thorns, who hear the word,
Mark. and the cares of this age,  the deceitfulness of wealth,  the cravings about other things entering in, choke the word,  it becomes unfruitful.
Mark. And these are those that were sown upon the good ground, who hear the word and receive it,  bear fruit, one thirty,  one sixty,  one a hundred.
Mark. And he said to them, Does the lamp come so that it might be put under the bushel or under the bed? Is it not so that it might be put on the lampstand?
Mark. For there is not anything hid, except that it may be revealed, nor become secret,  that it may come to be visible.
Mark. If any man has ears to hear, let him hear.
Mark. And he said to them, Watch what ye hear. By what measure ye measure, it will be measured to you,  to those who hear, it will be added to you.
Mark. For whoever has, to him it will be given. And he who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him.
Mark. And he said, Thus is the kingdom of God, as if a man should cast seed into the ground,
Mark. and should sleep and rise night and day,  the seed should sprout and lengthen, he knows not how.
Mark. For the earth bears fruit spontaneously, first the blade, then the ear, then the full grain in the ear.
Mark. But when the fruit yields, straightaway he sends forth the sickle, because the harvest has come.
Mark. And he said, To what shall we liken the kingdom of God? Or by what parable shall we compare it?
Mark. It is like a grain of the mustard plant, which, when it is sown in the ground, is smaller than all the seeds upon the ground.
Mark. Yet when it is sown, it goes up and becomes greater than all the plants,  it makes great branches, so that the birds of the sky can lodge under the shade of it.
Mark. And with many such parables he spoke the word to them, as they were able to hear it.
Mark. And he did not speak to them apart from a parable,  privately he explained all things to his disciples.
Mark. And on that day, having become evening, he says to them, Let us pass through to the other side.
Mark. And having sent the multitude away, they bring him along as he was in the boat. And other small boats were also with him.
Mark. And a great storm of wind develops,  the waves were thrown into the boat, so as for it now to be filling.
Mark. And he himself was in the stern sleeping on the cushion. And they awake him,  say to him, Teacher, does it not concern thee that we perish?
Mark. And having awaken, he rebuked the wind,  said to the sea, Be quiet! Silence! And the wind ceased,  it became a great calm.
Mark. And he said to them, Why are ye cowardly this way? How have ye no faith?
Mark. And they feared a great fear,  said to each other, Who then is this, that even the wind and the sea also obey him?
Mark. And they came to the other side of the sea into the country of the Gadarenes.
Mark. And when he came out of the boat, straightaway there met him out of the sepulchers a man with an unclean spirit who had his habitation among the sepulchers.
Mark. And no man was able to bind him, not even with chains.
Mark. Because he was often bound with shackles and chains,  the chains were pulled apart by him,  the shackles broken in pieces. And no man had strength to subdue him.
Mark. And always, night and day, in the mountains and in the sepulchers, he was crying out,  cutting himself with stones.
Mark. And when he saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and worshiped him.
Mark. And having cried out in a great voice, he said, What is with me and with thee, Jesus, thou Son of the Most High God? I adjure thee by God, do not torment me.
Mark. For he said to him, Come out from the man, thou unclean spirit.
Mark. And he demanded him, What is thy name? And he answered, saying, My name is Legion, because we are many.
Mark. And he besought him much that he would not send them outside of the territory.
Mark. Now there was near the mountain a great herd of swine feeding.
Mark. And all the demons besought him, saying, Send us into the swine, so that we may enter into them.
Mark. And straightaway, Jesus allowed them. And the unclean spirits having come out, entered into the swine. And the herd stampeded down the slope into the sea,  were drowned in the sea. And there were about two thousand.
Mark. And those who fed the swine fled,  reported in the city and in the fields. And they came to see what it was that happened.
Mark. And they come to Jesus,  see the man who was demon-possessed, sitting,  clothed,  in his right mind (the man who had the legion),  they were afraid.
Mark. And those who saw it related to them how it happened to the man who was demon-possessed,  about the swine.
Mark. And they began to beg him to depart from their borders.
Mark. And as he entered into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed besought him that he might be with him.
Mark. But Jesus did not allow him,  says to him, Go to thy house to thy men,  report to them how much the Lord has done for thee,  was merciful to thee.
Mark. And he departed,  began to proclaim in Decapolis how much Jesus did for him. And all men marveled.
Mark. And when Jesus crossed over again in the boat to the other side, a great multitude gathered to him,  he was near the sea.
Mark. And behold, one of the synagogue rulers comes, Jairus by name. And having seen him, he falls at his feet,
Mark. and besought him much, saying, My little daughter has a terminal condition, so that having come, thou may lay thy hands on her, that she may be saved and will live.
Mark. And he went with him,  a great multitude followed him,  they thronged him.
Mark. And a certain woman, being with an issue of blood twelve years,
Mark. and having suffered many things by many physicians,  having spent all of her things,  was helped nothing,  who became worse instead,
Mark. when she heard about Jesus, having come in the crowd from behind, she touched his garment.
Mark. For she said, If I but touch his garments, I will be healed.
Mark. And straightaway the flow of her blood was dried up,  she knew in the body that she was healed of her scourge.
Mark. And straightaway, Jesus, when he recognized in himself that power went forth from him, having turned around in the crowd, he said, Who touched my garments?
Mark. And his disciples said to him, Thou see the multitude crowding thee,  thou say, Who touched me?
Mark. And he looked around to see the woman who did this thing.
Mark. But the woman fearing and trembling, knowing what has happened to her, came and fell down before him,  told him all the truth.
Mark. And he said to her, Daughter, thy faith has healed thee. Go in peace,  be healthy from thy scourge.
Mark. While he still spoke, they come from the synagogue ruler saying, Thy daughter died, why still trouble the teacher?
Mark. But straightaway, Jesus, having heard the word spoken, says to the ruler of the synagogue, Fear not, only believe.
Mark. And he allowed no man to accompany him except Peter,  James,  John the brother of James.
Mark. And he comes to the house of the synagogue ruler,  sees a commotion, much weeping and wailing.
Mark. And when he entered in, he says to them, Why do ye make a commotion,  weep? The child did not die,  sleeps.
Mark. And they ridiculed him. But he, having put them all out, takes the father of the child and the mother and those with him,  enters in where the child was lying.
Mark. And having taken the child's hand, he says to her, Talitha cumi. Which is, being interpreted, Little girl, I say to thee, awake.
Mark. And straightaway the little girl rose up and walked, for she was twelve years old. And they were amazed with a great amazement.
Mark. And he commanded them much that no man should know this. And he said to give her to eat.
Mark. And he went out from there,  came into his fatherland,  his disciples follow him.
Mark. And having become sabbath, he began to teach in the synagogue. And many who heard him were astonished, saying, How are these things in this man? and, What is the wisdom that was given to him,  such mighty works happen by his hands?
Mark. Is this not the carpenter, the son of Mary,  brother of James and Joses and Judah and Simon? And are not his sisters here with us? And they were offended by him.
Mark. But Jesus said to them, A prophet is not without honor, except in his fatherland,  among his kin,  in his house.
Mark. And he could do no mighty work there, none, except having laid his hands upon a few feeble men he healed them.
Mark. And he marveled because of their unbelief. And he went around the villages teaching.
Mark. And he summons the twelve,  began to send them forth in pairs. And he gave them authority over the unclean spirits.
Mark. And he commanded them that they should take up nothing for the way, except only a staff-no scrip, no bread, no copper in the belt-
Mark. but shod with sandals, , Do not wear two coats.
Mark. And he said to them, Wherever ye enter into a house, lodge there until ye depart from there.
Mark. And as many as might not receive you nor hear you, as ye depart from there, shake off the dust under your feet for a testimony to them. Truly I say to you, it will be more tolerable for Sodom or Gomorrah in the day of judgment than for that city.
Mark. And having departed, they preached that men should repent.
Mark. And they cast out many demons,  anointed many feeble men with olive oil,  healed them.
Mark. And king Herod heard, for his name had become well known. And he said, John, the man who immerses, was raised from the dead,  because of this the powers work in him.
Mark. Others said, He is Elijah,  others said, He is a prophet, like one of the prophets.
Mark. But Herod, when he heard, said, This is John whom I beheaded. He was raised from the dead.
Mark. For Herod himself having sent forth, he arrested John,  bound him in prison because of Herodias, his brother Philip's wife, because he married her.
Mark. For John said to Herod, It is not permitted for thee to have thy brother's wife.
Mark. And Herodias was resentful toward him,  wanted to kill him. And she could not,
Mark. for Herod feared John, knowing him to be a righteous and holy man,  he protected him. And having heard of him-the many things he was doing-he even heard of him gladly.
Mark. And having become an opportune day, when Herod on his birthday made a dinner for his chiefs,  the high captains,  the leading men of Galilee,
Mark. and the daughter of her (of Herodias) having come in and danced,  having pleased Herod and those who sat with the king, he said to the maiden, Ask of me whatever thou may want,  I will give to thee.
Mark. And he swore to her, Whatever thou may ask of me, I will give to thee, as much as half of my kingdom.
Mark. And having gone out, she said to her mother, What shall I ask? And she said, The head of John the immerser.
Mark. And having come in straightaway with haste to the king, she asked, saying, I want that thou may give me, of it on a platter, the head of John the immerser.
Mark. And the king, who became exceeding sorry, did not want to refuse her because of the oaths,  of those dining together.
Mark. And straightaway having sent an executioner, the king commanded his head to be brought. And having departed, he beheaded him in the prison,
Mark. and brought his head on a platter,  gave it to the maiden. And the maiden gave it to her mother.
Mark. And when his disciples heard, they came and took up his corpse,  laid it in a sepulcher.
Mark. And the apostles gather together to Jesus,  reported all to him,  how many things they did,  how many things they taught.
Mark. And he said to them, Come ye yourselves in private into a desolate place,  rest a while. For there were many coming and going,  they had no opportunity even to eat.
Mark. And they departed in the boat to a desolate place in private.
Mark. And they saw them going. And many recognized him,  ran together on foot there from all the cities. And they went before them,  came together to him.
Mark. And Jesus having come out, he saw a great multitude. And he felt compassion toward them, because they were as sheep not having a shepherd. And he began to teach them many things.
Mark. And now many an hour having come to pass, his disciples having come to him, they say, The place is desolate,  it is now many an hour.
Mark. Send them away, so that after going into the fields and villages around, they may buy loaves for themselves, for they do not have what they may eat.
Mark. But having answered, he said to them, Give ye them to eat. And they say to him, After departing, shall we buy loaves of two hundred denarii,  give them to eat?
Mark. And he says to them, How many loaves have ye? Go and see. And when they knew, they say, Five,  two fishes.
Mark. And he commanded them to sit down, all by companies upon the green grass.
Mark. And they sat down in groups, by hundreds and by fifties.
Mark. And after taking the five loaves and the two fishes, having looked up to heaven, he blessed,  broke the loaves in pieces,  he gave to the disciples so that they might set before them. And he distributed the two fishes to them all.
Mark. And they all ate,  were filled.
Mark. And they took up fragments, twelve baskets full,  from the fishes.
Mark. And those who ate the loaves were five thousand men.
Mark. And straightaway he compelled his disciples to enter into the boat,  to go ahead to the other side, to Bethsaida, while he himself would send the crowd away.
Mark. And after sending them away, he departed onto the mountain to pray.
Mark. And having become evening, the boat was in the midst of the sea,  he alone on the land.
Mark. And he saw them toiling in rowing, for the wind was against them. And about the fourth watch of the night he comes to them, walking on the sea,  wanted to passed by them.
Mark. But they, when they saw him walking on the sea, supposed it to be a ghost,  cried out.
Mark. For they all saw him,  were troubled. And straightaway he spoke with them,  says to them, Cheer up. It is I, fear not.
Mark. And he went up to them into the boat,  the wind ceased. And they were exceedingly amazed in themselves, extraordinarily so. And they wondered,
Mark. for they did not understand about the loaves, for their heart was hardened.
Mark. And having crossed over, they came to the land of Gennesaret,  moored to the shore.
Mark. And when they came out of the boat, straightaway, having recognized him,
Mark. after running around that whole region around, they began to carry about on beds those who were faring badly, where they heard he was there.
Mark. And wherever he entered, into villages or cities or fields, they laid those who were feeble in the marketplaces,  besought him that if they might but touch the hem of his garment. And as many as touched him were being healed.
Mark. And the Pharisees,  some of the scholars, having come from Jerusalem, gathered in to him.
Mark. And having seen some of his disciples eating their loaves with profane hands, that is, unwashed, they accused them.
Mark. (For the Pharisees,  all the Jews, unless they wash their hands carefully, do not eat, holding the tradition of the elders.
Mark. And coming from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they bathe. And there are many other things that they have taken in to retain: washings of cups,  pots,  brazen vessels,  beds.)
Mark. Then the Pharisees and the scholars demand of him, Why do thy disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders,  eat their bread with unwashed hands?
Mark. And having answered, he said to them, Well did Isaiah prophesy about you hypocrites, as it is written, This people honors me with their lips,  their heart is far distant from me.
Mark. But in vain they worship me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men.
Mark. For having set aside the commandment of God, ye hold the tradition of men: washings of pots and cups and many other such like things ye do.
Mark. And he said to them, Well do ye reject the commandment of God, so that ye may keep your tradition.
Mark. For Moses said, Honor thy father and thy mother, , He who speaks evil of father or mother, let him perish in death.
Mark. But ye say, If a man should say to his father or mother, Whatever ye might be benefited from me is Corban, that is, an offering,
Mark. then ye no longer allow him to do anything for his father or his mother,
Mark. annulling the word of God by your tradition that ye have delivered. And many such like things ye do.
Mark. And having summoned all the people, he said to them, Hear me all of you,  understand.
Mark. There is nothing outside the man, entering into him that can defile him,  the things coming out of him those are the things that defile the man.
Mark. If any man has ears to hear, let him hear.
Mark. And when he entered into a house from the crowd, his disciples questioned him about the parable.
Mark. And he says to them, Are also ye so without understanding? Do ye not perceive that everything outside that enters into the man cannot defile him,
Mark. because it does not enter into his heart,  into the belly,  goes out into the toilet (making all foods clean)?
Mark. And he said, That which comes out of the man, that defiles the man.
Mark. For from inside the heart of men proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders, thefts,
Mark. covetings, wickednesses, deceit, licentiousness, an evil eye, reviling, pride, foolishness.
Mark. All these evil things come from inside,  defile the man.
Mark. And having risen from there, he went away into the borders of Tyre and Sidon. And having entered into a house, he wanted no man to know it,  yet he could not be hid.
Mark. For a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit, after hearing about him, having come, she fell down at his feet.
Mark. Now the woman was a Greek, a Syrophoenician by race. And she besought him that he would cast out the demon from her daughter.
Mark. And Jesus said to her, Allow the children first be filled, for it is not right to take the children's bread and cast it to the house dogs.
Mark. But she answered and says to him, Yes, Lord, for even the house dogs under the table eat of the children's crumbs.
Mark. And he said to her, Because of this saying, go thou. The demon has gone out of thy daughter.
Mark. And having departed to her house, she found the demon having gone out,  her daughter laid upon the bed.
Mark. And again having departed from the borders of Tyre and Sidon, he came to the sea of Galilee in the midst of the regions of Decapolis.
Mark. And they bring a deaf, tongue-tied man to him,  they beseech him to lay his hand upon him.
Mark. And having taken him from the multitude in private, he put his fingers into his ears,  having spat, he touched his tongue.
Mark. And having looked up to heaven, he sighed,  says to him, Ephphatha, that is, Be opened.
Mark. And straightaway his ears were opened,  the bond of his tongue was loosened,  he spoke plainly.
Mark. And he commanded them that they should tell no man,  as much as he commanded them, so much the more abundantly they proclaimed it.
Mark. And they were exceedingly astonished, saying, He has done all things well. He even makes the deaf to hear,  the mute to speak.
Mark. In those days, the multitude being very great,  not having what they might eat, Jesus having summoned his disciples, he says to them,
Mark. I feel compassion toward the multitude, because they continue with me now three days,  do not have what they might eat.
Mark. And if I send them away without food to their house, they will faint on the way, for some of them come from afar.
Mark. And his disciples answered him, From where will anyone be able to fill these men of loaves here in a desolate place?
Mark. And he questioned them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven.
Mark. And he commanded the crowd to sit down on the ground. And after taking the seven loaves, having given thanks, he broke in pieces,  gave to his disciples so that they might place before them. And they place before the crowd.
Mark. And they had a few small fishes. And having blessed them, he said to also place before them.
Mark. And they ate and were filled. And they took up seven hampers of surplus fragments.
Mark. And those who ate were about four thousand,  he sent them away.
Mark. And straightaway having entered into the boat with his disciples, he came into the parts of Dalmanutha.
Mark. And the Pharisees came forth,  began to dispute with him, seeking from him a sign from the sky, testing him.
Mark. And having sighed deeply in his spirit, he says, Why does this generation seek a sign? Truly I am telling you if a sign will be given to this generation.
Mark. And having left them, having entered again into a boat, he departed to the other side.
Mark. And they forgot to take loaves,  they did not have with them in the boat except one loaf.
Mark. And he commanded them, saying, Take heed, watch for the leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of Herod.
Mark. And they deliberated among each other, saying, We have no loaves.
Mark. And knowing it Jesus says to them, Why do ye deliberate because ye have no loaves? Do ye not yet perceive nor understand? Have ye your heart still hardened?
Mark. Having eyes, ye see not,  having ears, ye hear not? And do ye not remember?
Mark. When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did ye take up? They say to him, Twelve.
Mark. And when the seven for the four thousand, how many hampers full of fragments did ye take up? And they said, Seven.
Mark. And he said to them, How do ye not understand?
Mark. And he comes to Bethsaida,  they bring a blind man to him,  call for him so that he might touch him.
Mark. And having taken the hand of the blind man, he led him outside of the village. And having spat on his eyes, having laid his hands upon him, he questioned him if he sees anything?
Mark. And having looked up, he said, The men that I see, I see as trees walking.
Mark. Then again he put his hands upon his eyes,  made him look up. And he was restored,  saw all men clearly.
Mark. And he sent him away to his house, saying, Thou may neither go into the village, nor may tell any man in the village.
Mark. And Jesus went forth,  his disciples, into the villages of Caesarea Philippi. And on the way he questioned his disciples, saying to them, Who do men say that I am?
Mark. And they answered, saying, John the immerser,  others, Elijah,  others, one of the prophets.
Mark. And he says to them, But who do ye say that I am? And having answered, Peter says to him, Thou are the Christ.
Mark. And he chided them that they should tell no man about him.
Mark. And he began to teach them that it was necessary for the Son of man to suffer many things,  be rejected by the elders,  the chief priests,  the scholars,  be killed,  after three days to rise.
Mark. And he spoke the matter openly. And having taken him aside, Peter began to rebuke him.
Mark. But he, having turned around,  having looked on his disciples, he rebuked Peter, saying, Go thee behind me, Satan, because thou think not the things of God,  the things of men.
Mark. And having called in the multitude with his disciples, he said to them, Whoever wants to follow behind me, let him deny himself,  take up his cross,  follow me.
Mark. For whoever wants to save his life will lose it,  whoever will lose his life because of me and the good news, this man will save it.
Mark. For what will it profit a man if he should gain the whole world,  forfeit his soul?
Mark. Or what will a man give in exchange for his soul?
Mark. For whoever may be ashamed of me and of my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of man will also be ashamed of him when he comes in the glory of his Father with the holy agents.
Mark. And he said to them, Truly I say to you, there are some of those who have stood here, who will, no, not taste of death until they see the kingdom of God come in power.
Mark. And after six days Jesus takes Peter and James and John,  leads them up onto a high mountain alone, in private. And he was transfigured before them,
Mark. and his garments became glistening, exceedingly white, as snow, such as no fuller on earth is able to whiten.
Mark. And Elijah with Moses appeared to them,  they were talking with Jesus.
Mark. And having responded, Peter says to Jesus, Rabbi, it is good for us to be here. And we could make three tabernacles: one for thee,  one for Moses,  one for Elijah.
Mark. For he knew not what he would say, for they were frightened.
Mark. And a cloud developed overshadowing them. And a voice came out of the cloud, This is my beloved Son. Hear ye him.
Mark. And suddenly having looked around, they saw no man anymore,  only Jesus with themselves.
Mark. And as they were coming down from the mountain, he commanded them that they should tell no man what they saw, except when the Son of man will rise from the dead.
Mark. And they kept the saying to themselves, discussing what is the rising from the dead.
Mark. And they questioned him, saying, The scholars say that Elijah must first come.
Mark. And having answered, he said to them, Elijah indeed comes first and restores all. And how it is written for the Son of man, that he would suffer many things and be rejected.
Mark. But I say to you, that Elijah has also come,  they did to him as much as they wanted, just as it is written for him.
Mark. And when they came to the disciples he saw a great multitude around them,  scholars disputing with them.
Mark. And straightaway all the multitude, having noticed him, were startled. And running near they greeted him.
Mark. And he questioned the scholars, What are ye disputing with them?
Mark. And having answered, one from the multitude said, Teacher, I brought my son to thee, who has a mute spirit.
Mark. And wherever it seizes him, it tears him,  he foams,  gnashes his teeth,  becomes limp. And I spoke to thy disciples that they might cast it out,  they were not able.
Mark. And having answered him, he says, O faithless generation, how long will I be with you? How long will I endure you? Bring him to me.
Mark. And they brought him to him. And when he saw him, straightaway the spirit convulsed him. And having fallen on the ground, he wallowed, foaming.
Mark. And he questioned his father, How much time is it since this has happened to him? And he said, From childhood.
Mark. And it often casts him both into the fire and into the waters so that it might destroy him. But if thou can do anything, help us, having compassion toward us.
Mark. And Jesus said to him, If thou are able to believe, all things are possible to him who believes.
Mark. And straightaway the father of the child having cried out, he said with tears, I believe. Lord, help thou my unbelief.
Mark. And when Jesus saw that a crowd was running together, he rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to it, Thou mute and deaf spirit, I command thee to come out of him,  enter into him no more.
Mark. And having cried out,  having convulsed him much, it came out. And he became as if dead, so as for many to say that he was dead.
Mark. But having taken him by the hand, Jesus lifted him up,  he arose.
Mark. And when he came into the house, his disciples questioned him privately, We were not able to cast it out.
Mark. And he said to them, This kind can come out by nothing, except by prayer and fasting.
Mark. And having departed from there, they passed through Galilee,  he did not want that any man would know it.
Mark. For he taught his disciples,  said to them, The Son of man is delivered up into the hands of men,  they will kill him. And after being killed, he will rise the third day.
Mark. But they did not understand the saying,  were afraid to question him.
Mark. And he came to Capernaum. And having become in the house he questioned them, What were ye deliberating among yourselves on the way?
