Mark. But they were silent, for on the way they discussed among each other, who is greater.
Mark. And having sat down, he called the twelve,  he says to them, If any man wants to be first, he will be last of all,  helper of all.
Mark. And having taken a child, he set it in the midst of them. And after embracing it, he said to them,
Mark. Whoever may receive one of such children in my name, receives me,  whoever may receive me, does not receive me,  him who sent me.
Mark. And John answered him, saying, Teacher, we saw a certain man, who does not follow us, casting out demons in thy name,  we forbade him, because he does not follow us.
Mark. But Jesus said, Forbid him not, for there is no man who will do a mighty work in my name,  will be able quickly to speak evil of me.
Mark. For he who is not against you is for you.
Mark. For whoever may give you a cup of water to drink in my name, because ye are of Christ, truly I say to you, he will, no, not lose his reward.
Mark. And whoever may cause one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it is good for him instead, if a millstone were hanged about his neck,  he were cast into the sea.
Mark. And if thy hand may cause thee to stumble, cut it off. It is good for thee to enter into life maimed, than having thy two hands to go into hell, into the unquenchable fire,
Mark. where their worm does not perish,  the fire is not quenched.
Mark. And if thy foot may cause thee to stumble, cut it off. It is good for thee to enter into life crippled, than having thy two feet to be cast into hell, into the unquenchable fire
Mark. where their worm does not perish,  the fire is not quenched.
Mark. And if thine eye may cause thee to stumble, pluck it out. It is good for thee to enter into the kingdom of God one-eyed, rather than having two eyes to be cast into the hell of fire,
Mark. where their worm does not perish,  the fire is not quenched.
Mark. For every man will be salted with fire,  every sacrifice will be salted with salt material.
Mark. The salt material is good,  if the salt material becomes saltless, by what will ye season it? Have salt in yourselves,  be at peace among each other.
Mark. And having risen from there, he comes into the borders of Judea through the other side of the Jordan. And multitudes come together to him again, , as he has practiced, he taught them again.
Mark. And the Pharisees having approached, they demanded of him if it is permitted for a man to divorce a wife, testing him.
Mark. And having answered, he said to them, What did Moses command you?
Mark. And they said, Moses permitted to write a document of divorce,  to divorce her.
Mark. But having answered, Jesus said to them, For your hard heart he wrote for you this commandment.
Mark. But from the beginning of creation God made them male and female.
Mark. Because of this a man will leave his father and mother behind,  will be bonded with his wife,
Mark. and the two will be in one flesh. So then they are no more two,  one flesh.
Mark. What therefore God has joined together, no man shall separate.
Mark. And in the house the disciples questioned him again about the same thing.
Mark. And he says to them, Whoever may divorce his wife,  will marry another, commits adultery against her.
Mark. And if a woman should divorce her husband,  will be married to another, she commits adultery.
Mark. And they brought children to him, so that he would touch them. And the disciples rebuked those who were bringing them.
Mark. But when Jesus saw it, he was displeased,  said to them, Allow the children to come to me. Forbid them not, for of such is the kingdom of God.
Mark. Truly I say to you, whoever will not receive the kingdom of God as a child, he will, no, not enter it.
Mark. And having embraced them, while laying his hands upon them, he blessed them.
Mark. And as he was going forth on the way, one man having ran to him,  having knelt to him, questioned him, Good teacher, what should I do that I may inherit eternal life?
Mark. And Jesus said to him, Why do thou call me good? None is good except one, God.
Mark. Thou know the commandments. Thou shall not commit adultery. Thou shall not murder. Thou shall not steal. Thou shall not testify falsely. Thou shall not defraud. Thou shall honor thy father and mother.
Mark. And having answered, he said to him, Teacher, all these things I have observed from my youth.
Mark. And having looked at him, Jesus loved him,  said to him, One thing thou lack. Go thou, sell as many things as thou have,  give to the poor,  thou will have treasure in heaven. And after taking up the cross, come, follow me.
Mark. But having become somber at the saying, he went away sorrowing, for he was a man who has many possessions.
Mark. And Jesus having looked around, he says to his disciples, How difficultly those who have riches will enter into the kingdom of God.
Mark. And the disciples were astonished at his words. But again having answered, Jesus says to them, Children, how difficult it is for those who trust in riches to enter into the kingdom of God.
Mark. It is easier for a camel to go through the hole of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
Mark. And they were exceedingly astonished, saying among themselves, Then who can be saved?
Mark. And having looked at them, Jesus says, With men, impossible,  not with God. For with God all things are possible.
Mark. Peter began to say to him, Lo, we have left all,  have followed thee.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus said, Truly I say to you, there is no man who has left house, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, because of me,  because of the good news,
Mark. but he will receive a hundredfold now in this time, houses,  brothers,  sisters,  mothers,  children,  lands-with persecutions-and in the coming age, eternal life.
Mark. But many first will be last,  the last first.
Mark. And they were on the road going up to Jerusalem,  Jesus was going ahead of them. And they were amazed,  those who followed were afraid. And again having summoned the twelve, he began to tell them the things that were going to happen to him.
Mark. Behold, we go up to Jerusalem. And the Son of man will be delivered to the chief priests and the scholars. And they will condemn him to death,  will deliver him to the Gentiles.
Mark. And they will mock him,  will scourge,  will spit upon him,  will kill him. And the third day he will rise.
Mark. And James and John, the sons of Zebedee, come to him, saying, Teacher, we wish that thou would do for us whatever we ask.
Mark. And he said to them, What do ye want me to do for you?
Mark. And they said to him, Grant to us that we may sit, one at thy right hand,  one at thy left hand, in thy glory.
Mark. But Jesus said to them, Ye know not what ye are asking. Are ye able to drink the cup that I drink? And to be immersed the immersion that I am immersed?
Mark. And they said to him, We are able. And Jesus said to them, Ye will indeed drink the cup that I drink,  the immersion that I am immersed ye will be immersed.
Mark. But to sit at my right hand or at my left hand is not mine to give,  for whom it has been prepared.
Mark. And when the ten heard it they began to indignant about James and John.
Mark. And having summoned them, Jesus says to them, Ye know that those who presume to rule over the Gentiles, lord over them,  their great men have power over them.
Mark. But it is not so among you. Instead, whoever may want to become great among you, will be your helper,
Mark. and whoever of you may want to become first, will be a bondman of all.
Mark. For the Son of man also came not to be served,  to serve,  to give his life a ransom for many.
Mark. And they come to Jericho. And as he went out from Jericho,  his disciples and a considerable crowd, Bartimaeus, the blind son of Timaeus, was sitting by the road begging.
Mark. And when he heard that it was Jesus the Nazarene, he began to cry out and say, Jesus, thou son of David, be merciful to me.
Mark. And many rebuked him, that he would be quiet,  he cried out much more, Thou son of David, be merciful to me.
Mark. And having stood still, Jesus said for him to be called. And they call the blind man, saying to him, Cheer up. Arise, he calls thee.
Mark. And he, having thrown off his garment, having risen, came to Jesus.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus says to him, What do thou want I would do to thee? And the blind man said to him, Rabboni, that I may receive my sight.
Mark. And Jesus said to him, Go thou, thy faith has healed thee. And straightaway he received his sight,  followed him on the way.
Mark. And when they came near to Jerusalem, to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount of Olives, he sends forth two of his disciples,
Mark. and says to them, Go ye into the village opposite you,  straightaway as ye enter into it, ye will find a colt tied, on which none of men have ever sat. After untying it, bring it.
Mark. And if any man should say to you, Why are ye doing this? say ye, The Lord has need of it,  straightaway he sends it here.
Mark. And they departed,  found the colt tied by the door outside in the street,  they untied it.
Mark. And some of those who stood there said to them, What are ye doing, untying the colt?
Mark. And they said to them just as Jesus commanded,  they allowed them.
Mark. And they brought the colt to Jesus,  threw their garments on it,  he sat upon it.
Mark. And many spread their garments upon the road,  others were cutting branches from the fields,  were spreading on the road.
Mark. And those who went in front,  those who came behind, cried out saying, Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!
Mark. Blessed is the kingdom of our father David that comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!
Mark. And Jesus entered into Jerusalem,  into the temple. And when he looked around on all things, the hour now being evening, he went out to Bethany with the twelve.
Mark. And on the morrow when they came out from Bethany he was hungry.
Mark. And having seen a fig tree afar off having leaves, he came, if perhaps he will find anything on it. And when he came to it he found nothing except leaves, for it was not the time of figs.
Mark. And having responded, Jesus said to it, No man may eat fruit from thee, no more into the age. And his disciples heard it.
Mark. And they come to Jerusalem. And having entered into the temple, Jesus began to drive out those who sold and bought in the temple. And he overturned the tables of the moneychangers,  the seats of those who sold the doves.
Mark. And he did not permit that any man might carry a container through the temple.
Mark. And he taught, saying to them, Is it not written, My house will be called a house of prayer for all the nations? But ye made it a den of robbers.
Mark. And the scholars and the chief priests heard it,  sought how they might destroy him, for they feared him, because all the people were awed at his doctrine.
Mark. And when it became evening he went forth outside of the city.
Mark. And passing by in the morning, they saw the fig tree dried out from the roots.
Mark. And having remembered, Peter says to him, Rabbi, behold, the fig tree that thou cursed has been dried out.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus says to them, Have faith in God.
Mark. For truly I say to you, that whoever may say to this mountain, Be thou taken up and cast into the sea,  will not doubt in his heart,  will believe that what he says comes to pass, whatever he may say will be for him.
Mark. Because of this I say to you, all things, as many as ye may ask, praying, believe that ye receive,  it will be for you.
Mark. And whenever ye may stand praying, forgive, if ye have anything against any man, so that also your Father in the heavens will forgive you your trespasses.
Mark. But if ye do not forgive, neither will your Father in the heavens forgive your trespasses.
Mark. And they come again to Jerusalem. And as he was walking in the temple, the chief priests,  the scholars,  the elders come to him.
Mark. And they say to him, By what authority are thou doing these things? Or who gave thee this authority so that thou may do these things?
Mark. And having answering, Jesus said to them, I also will question you one word,  answer me,  I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Mark. The immersion of John, was it from heaven, or from men? Answer me.
Mark. And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we should say, From heaven, he will say, Why then did ye not believe him?
Mark. But should we say, From men? (They feared the people, for all held John that he was indeed a prophet.)
Mark. And having answered, they say to Jesus, We do not know. And having answering, Jesus says to them, Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
Mark. And he began to speak to them in parables. A man planted a vineyard,  set up a hedge,  dug a wine vat,  built a tower,  leased it to farmers,  went on a journey.
Mark. And at the season he sent forth a bondman to the farmers, so that he might receive by the farmers from the fruit of the vineyard.
Mark. And having seized him, they beat him,  sent him away empty.
Mark. And again he sent another bondman to them. And that man, having stoned, they wounded in the head,  sent him away shamefully treated.
Mark. And again he sent another,  that man they killed,  many others, beating some,  killing some.
Mark. Therefore, still having his one beloved son, he also sent him to them, last, saying, They will be made ashamed by my son.
Mark. But those farmers said among themselves, This is the heir. Come, let us kill him,  the inheritance will be ours.
Mark. And having taken him, they killed him,  cast him outside of the vineyard.
Mark. What therefore will the lord of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the farmers,  will give the vineyard to others.
Mark. And have ye not read this scripture: The stone that those who build rejected, this came to be into the head of the corner.
Mark. This happened from the Lord,  it is marvelous in our eyes?
Mark. And they sought to seize him. And they feared the multitude, for they knew that he spoke the parable against them. And having left him, they went away.
Mark. And they send some of the Pharisees and of the Herodians to him, so that they might catch him in talk.
Mark. And when they came, they say to him, Teacher, we have seen that thou are true,  it is not a care to thee about any man, for thou look not to a personage of men,  teach the way of God in truth. Is it permitted to give tribute to Caesar or not?
Mark. Should we give, or should we not give? But Jesus, knowing their hypocrisy, said to them, Why do ye test me? Bring me a denarius, so that I may see it.
Mark. And they brought it. And he says to them, Whose is this image and inscription? And they said to him, Caesar's.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus said to them, Render the things of Caesar to Caesar,  the things of God to God. And they marveled at him.
Mark. And Sadducees come to him, who say there is no resurrection. And they questioned him, saying,
Mark. Teacher, Moses wrote to us, If a man's brother dies,  leaves behind a wife,  leaves no child, that his brother should take his wife,  raise up seed for his brother.
Mark. There were seven brothers. And the first took a wife,  dying left no seed.
Mark. And the second took her,  died, neither did he leave seed behind,  the third likewise.
Mark. And the seven took her,  left no seed. Last of all the woman also died.
Mark. In the resurrection when they rise, whose wife will she be of them? For the seven had her as wife.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus said to them, Are ye not led astray because of this: not knowing the scriptures nor the power of God?
Mark. For when they rise from the dead, they neither marry, nor are given in marriage,  are as agents in the heavens.
Mark. But about the dead, that they rise, have ye not read in the book of Moses, how God spoke to him at the bush, saying, I am the God of Abraham,  the God of Isaac,  the God of Jacob?
Mark. He is not the God of the dead,  God of the living. Ye therefore are much misled.
Mark. And one of the scholars having come, having heard them disputing, knowing that he had answered them well, he questioned him, Which is the first commandment of all?
Mark. And Jesus answered him, The first of all the commandments is, Hear, thou Israel, the Lord our God is one Lord,
Mark. and thou shall love the Lord thy God from thy whole heart,  from thy whole soul,  from thy whole mind,  from thy whole strength. This is the first commandment.
Mark. And this second is similar, Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself. There is no other commandment greater than these.
Mark. And the scholar said to him, Well, teacher. Thou spoke in truth that he is one,  there is no other but he.
Mark. And to love him from the whole heart,  from the whole understanding,  from the whole soul,  from the whole strength,  to love his neighbor as himself, is more than all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.
Mark. And when Jesus saw him, that he answered wisely, he said to him, Thou are not far from the kingdom of God. And no man dared to question him any more.
Mark. And having responded as he taught in the temple, Jesus said, How do the scholars say that the Christ is the son of David?
Mark. For David himself said by the Holy Spirit, The Lord says to my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand until I may place thine enemies a footstool of thy feet.
Mark. David himself therefore calls him Lord,  in what way is he his son? And the great multitude heard him gladly.
Mark. And in his teaching he said to them, Look away from the scholars, those who desire to go about in long robes,  salutations in the marketplaces,
Mark. and chief seats in the synagogues,  places of honor at the feasts,
Mark. those who devour widows' houses,  praying long in pretence. These will receive greater condemnation.
Mark. And having sat down opposite the treasury, Jesus watched how the multitude cast money into the treasury,  many rich men cast in much.
Mark. And one poor widow having come, she cast in two mites, which are a quadrans.
Mark. And having summoned his disciples, he says to them, Truly I say to you, that this poor widow cast in more than all those who are casting into the treasury.
Mark. For they all cast in from that which is abundant to them,  she from her need cast in all, as many things she had, her whole living.
Mark. And as he went forth out of the temple, one of his disciples says to him, Teacher, see what kind of stones and what kind of buildings.
Mark. And Jesus having answered, he said to him, See thou these great buildings? There will be left, no, not a stone upon a stone, that will, no, not be brought down.
Mark. And as he sat upon the mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew questioned him privately,
Mark. Tell us, when will these things be? And what is the sign when all these things are going to be fulfilled?
Mark. And having answered them, Jesus began to say to them, Watch that not any man lead you astray.
Mark. For many will come in my name, saying, I am,  they will lead many astray.
Mark. And when ye may hear of wars and rumors of wars, be not alarmed, for it must happen,  the end is not yet.
Mark. For nation will rise against nation,  kingdom against kingdom,  there will be earthquakes in various places,  there will be famines and troubles. These things are the beginnings of travails.
Mark. But watch ye yourselves, for they will deliver you up to councils,  ye will be beaten in synagogues. And ye will be stood before rulers and kings because of me, for a testimony to them.
Mark. And the good news must first be preached to all the nations.
Mark. But when they lead you, delivering you up, be not anxious before what ye might speak, nor meditate. But whatever may be given you in that hour, speak ye this, for ye are not who speak,  the Holy Spirit.
Mark. And brother will betray brother to death,  a father a child. And children will rise up against parents,  will condemn them to death.
Mark. And ye will be hated by all men because of my name,  he who endures to the end, this man will be saved.
Mark. But when ye see the abomination of desolation, which was spoken by Daniel the prophet, standing where it ought not (let him who reads understand), then let those in Judea flee to the mountains,
Mark. and let the man on the housetop not go down into the house, nor enter in to take anything out of his house,
Mark. and let the man who is in the field not turn back for the things behind, to take his cloak.
Mark. But woe to those who have in the womb,  to those who suckle in those days.
Mark. And pray ye that your flight may not be in winter.
Mark. For those days will be tribulation, such as has not happened from the beginning of the creation that God created until now,  no, will not happen.
Mark. And unless the Lord cut short the days, no flesh would have been saved,  because of the chosen, whom he chose, he cut short the days.
Mark. And then if any man should say to you, Lo, here is the Christ, or, Lo, there, do not believe.
Mark. For false Christs and false prophets will arise,  will give signs and wonders, in order to lead astray, if possible, even the chosen.
Mark. But watch ye. Behold, I have foretold all to you.
Mark. But in those days, after that tribulation, the sun will be darkened,  the moon will not give its light,
Mark. and the stars of the sky will be falling,  the powers that are in the heavens will be shaken.
Mark. And then they will see the Son of man coming in clouds with much power and glory.
Mark. And then he will send forth his agents,  will gather together his chosen from the four winds, from the outermost part of the earth as far as the outermost part of heaven.
Mark. But learn a parable from the fig tree. When its branch now becomes tender,  sprouts the leaves, ye know that summer is near.
Mark. So ye also, when ye may see these things happening, know ye that it is near, at the doors.
Mark. Truly I say to you, that this generation will, no, not pass away, until all these things happen.
Mark. The sky and the earth will pass away,  my words may, no, not pass away.
Mark. But about that day or that hour no man knows, not even the agents in heaven, nor the Son,  the Father.
Mark. Watch ye! Be alert and pray, for ye know not when the time is,
Mark. like a man abroad, having left his house,  having given authority to his bondmen,  to each man his work,  commanded the doorkeeper that he should watch.
Mark. Watch therefore, for ye know not when the lord of the house comes, at evening, or at midnight, or at cock crowing, or in the morning,
Mark. lest having come suddenly, he may find you sleeping.
Mark. And what I say to you I say to all, watch!
Mark. Now after two days was the Passover and the unleavened bread. And the chief priests and the scholars sought how, having take him with trickery, they might kill him,
Mark. but they said, Not during the feast, lest there will be an uproar of the people.
Mark. And while he was in Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, as he sat relaxing, a woman came having an alabaster cruse of ointment of pure spikenard, very valuable. And having broken the alabaster cruse, she poured it on his head.
Mark. And some were indignant within themselves, saying, Why has this waste of the ointment happened?
Mark. For this could have been sold for over three hundred denarii,  given to the poor. And they grumbled at her.
Mark. But Jesus said, Leave her be. Why do ye cause troubles for her? She performed a good work on me.
Mark. For ye always have the poor with you,  whenever ye may desire ye can do them well,  ye do not always have me.
Mark. She applied what she had to anoint my body. She did it beforehand for the burial.
Mark. And truly I say to you, wherever this good news may be preached in the whole world, also what she did will be told for a memorial of her.
Mark. And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went away to the chief priests, so that he might betray him to them.
Mark. And when they heard it, they were glad,  promised to give him silver. And he sought how he might betray him conveniently.
Mark. And on the first day of unleavened bread, when they killed the Passover, his disciples say to him, Where do thou want, after going, we should prepare that thou may eat the Passover?
Mark. And he sends forth two of his disciples,  says to them, Go into the city,  a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you. Follow him.
Mark. And wherever he may enter, say ye to the house-ruler, The teacher says, Where is the guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?
Mark. And he himself will show you a large upper room spread out ready. Prepare ye for us there.
Mark. And his disciples went forth,  came into the city,  found just as he had said to them. And they prepared the Passover.
Mark. And having become evening he comes with the twelve.
Mark. And as they were relaxing and eating, Jesus said, Truly I say to you, that one of you eating with me will betray me.
Mark. They began to be sorrowful,  to say to him one by one, Not I? and another, Not I?
Mark. And having answered, he said to them, It is one of the twelve dipping with me in the dish.
Mark. The Son of man indeed goes as it is written about him,  woe to that man through whom the Son of man is betrayed! It was good for him if that man was not born.
Mark. And as they were eating, Jesus having taken bread, having blessed, he broke in pieces,  gave to them,  said, Take, eat, this is my body.
Mark. And after taking the cup, having expressed thanks, he gave to them,  they all drank from it.
Mark. And he said to them, This is my blood of the new covenant, which is poured out for many.
Mark. Truly I say to you, that I will no more drink of the fruit of the grapevine, until that day when I drink it anew in the kingdom of God.
Mark. And when they sang a hymn, they went out onto the mount of Olives.
Mark. And Jesus says to them, All ye will be caused to stumble by me this night, because it is written, I will strike the shepherd,  the sheep will be scattered.
Mark. But after I am raised up, I will go before you into Galilee.
Mark. But Peter said to him, Even if all will be caused to stumble, yet not I.
Mark. And Jesus says to him, Truly I say to thee, that thou today, in this night, before a cock sounds twice, will deny me thrice.
Mark. But he spoke more extreme, If I must die with thee, I will, no, not deny thee. And they all spoke the same way also.
Mark. And they come to a place the name of which was Gethsemane. And he says to his disciples, Sit ye here until I pray.
Mark. And he takes Peter and James and John with him,  began to be greatly disturbed,  very distressed.
Mark. And he says to them, My soul is deeply grieved, to the point of death. Remain ye here,  watch.
Mark. And having gone forward a little, he fell on the ground,  prayed that, if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
Mark. And he said, Abba, Father, all things are possible to thee. Remove this cup from me,  not what I want,  what thou want.
Mark. And he comes and finds them sleeping. And he says to Peter, Simon, Do thou sleep? Could thou not watch one hour?
Mark. Watch ye and pray that ye may not enter into temptation. Truly, the spirit is willing,  the flesh is weak.
Mark. And again having departed, he prayed, having said the same statement.
Mark. And having returned, he found them again sleeping, for their eyes were weighed down,  they knew not what they should reply to him.
Mark. And he comes the third time,  says to them, Sleep the remaining,  take your rest. It is enough. The hour has come. Behold, the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Mark. Arise, let us be going. Behold, he who betrays me has come near.
Mark. And straightaway, while he still spoke, Judas, being one of the twelve, comes,  with him a great multitude with swords and clubs from the chief priests,  the scholars,  the elders.
Mark. Now he who betrayed him had given them a sign, saying, Whomever I may kiss is he. Seize him,  lead away securely.
Mark. And when he came, straightaway having approached him, he says, Rabbi, Rabbi,  kissed him much.
Mark. And they threw their hands on him,  seized him.
Mark. And a certain one of those who stood by, having drawn his sword, struck the bondman of the high priest,  cut off his ear.
Mark. And having answered, Jesus said to them, Have ye come out as against a robber with swords and clubs to arrest me?
Mark. I was daily near you, teaching in the temple,  ye did not seize me-but that the scriptures might be fulfilled.
Mark. And having forsook him, they all fled.
Mark. And a certain one young man followed with him, having been wrapped naked in a linen cloth. And the young men seized him,
Mark. but having left behind the linen cloth, he fled from them naked.
Mark. And they led Jesus away to the high priest. And all the chief priests and the elders and the scholars assemble with him.
Mark. And Peter followed him from a distance, as far as inside the courtyard of the high priest,  was sitting with the subordinates,  warming himself near the light.
Mark. Now the chief priests and the whole council sought testimony against Jesus in order to put him to death,  did not find it.
Mark. For many testified falsely against him,  their testimonies were not consistent.
Mark. And some men having stood up, testified falsely against him, saying,
Mark. We heard him saying, I will destroy this temple made with hands,  by three days I will build another not made with hands.
Mark. And not even this way was their testimony consistent.
Mark. And the high priest having stood up in the midst, he demanded Jesus, saying, Thou answer nothing? What is it these men testify against thee?
Mark. But he remained silent,  answered nothing. Again the high priest demanded him,  says to him, Are thou the Christ, the Son of the Blessed?
Mark. And Jesus said, I am. And ye will see the Son of man sitting at the right hand of Power,  coming with the clouds of the sky.
Mark. And the high priest having torn his clothes, he says, What further need have we of witnesses?
Mark. Ye have heard the blasphemy. What does it seem to you? And they all condemned him to be deserving of death.
Mark. And some began to spit on him,  to cover his face,  to strike him with a fist,  to say to him, Prophesy. And the subordinates were throwing him with slaps.
Mark. And as Peter was below in the courtyard, one of the servant girls of the high priest comes.
Mark. And having seen Peter warming himself, having looked at him, she says, Thou also were with Jesus of Nazareth.
Mark. But he denied, saying, I know not, nor understand what thou say. And he went outside onto the porch,  a cock sounded.
Mark. And the servant girl having seen him, she began again to say to those who stood by, This man is from them.
Mark. But he again denied it. And after a little while again those who stood by said to Peter, Surely thou are from them, for thou are a Galilean,  thy accent is similar.
Mark. But he began to curse and to swear, I do not know this man of whom ye speak.
Mark. And the second time a cock sounded. And Peter remembered the saying that Jesus said to him, Before a cock sounds twice, thou will deny me thrice. And having broke down, he wept.
Mark. And straightaway in the morning the chief priests with the elders and scholars and the whole council, having made a plan, after binding Jesus, they took him away,  delivered him up to Pilate.
Mark. And Pilate questioned him, Are thou the king of the Jews? And having answered, he said to him, Thou say.
Mark. And the chief priests accused him of many things.
Mark. And Pilate again questioned him, saying, Thou answer nothing? Behold how many things they testify against thee.
Mark. But Jesus answered nothing any more, so as for Pilate to wonder.
Mark. Now during a feast he released to them one prisoner, whomever they requested.
Mark. And a man who was called Barabbas was with the rebels who were bound, men who had committed murder during the insurrection.
Mark. And having cried aloud, the multitude began to ask as he was always doing for them.
Mark. And Pilate answered them, saying, Do ye wish that I would release to you the king of the Jews?
Mark. For he knew that the chief priests had delivered him up because of envy.
Mark. But the chief priests incited the crowd, so that he would release Barabbas to them instead.
Mark. And again having answered, Pilate said to them, What then do ye wish I would do to the man whom ye call the king of the Jews?
Mark. And they cried out again, Crucify him.
Mark. And Pilate said to them, For what evil has he done? But they cried out even more, Crucify him.
Mark. And Pilate, wanting to do what was sufficient for the crowd, released Barabbas to them. And he delivered Jesus, after scourging, so that he might be crucified.
Mark. And the soldiers led him away inside the courtyard, which is the Praetorium,  they call together the whole band.
Mark. And they put purple clothing on him,  clothe him with a woven crown of thorns,
Mark. and began to salute him, Hail, king of the Jews!
Mark. And they struck his head with a reed,  spat upon him,  bowing their knees worshiped him.
Mark. And when they had mocked him, they took the purple garment off of him,  dressed him with his own garments. And they lead him out so that they might crucify him.
Mark. And they draft a certain Simon, a Cyrenian passing by coming from the countryside, the father of Alexander and Rufus, so that he would take his cross.
Mark. And they bring him to the place Golgotha, which is, being interpreted, the place of a skull.
Mark. And they gave him wine mingled with myrrh to drink,  he did not take it.
Mark. And having crucified him, they divided his garments, casting a lot for them, who would take what.
Mark. And it was the third hour,  they crucified him.
Mark. And the inscription of his accusation was inscribed, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Mark. And they crucify two robbers with him, one at his right hand,  one at his left.
Mark. And the scripture was fulfilled, which says, And he was reckoned with lawless men.
Mark. And those who passed by railed at him, wagging their heads,  saying, Ha! Thou who destroy the temple,  build it in three days,
Mark. save thyself,  come down from the cross.
Mark. Likewise also the chief priests mocking among each other with the scholars said, He saved others, he cannot save himself.
Mark. Let the Christ, the king of Israel, come down now from the cross, that we may see and believe in him. And those who were crucified with him reviled him.
Mark. And having become the sixth hour, darkness occurred over the whole land until the ninth hour.
Mark. And at the ninth hour Jesus cried out in a great voice, saying, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? which is, being interpreted, My God, my God, why have thou forsaken me?
Mark. And some of those who stood by, when they heard it, said, Behold, he calls Elijah.
Mark. And one having ran,  having filled a sponge of vinegar,  having placed it on a reed, gave him to drink, saying, Leave be. We might see if Elijah comes to take him down.
Mark. And having given out a great voice, Jesus expired.
Mark. And the curtain of the temple was torn in two from the top to the bottom.
Mark. And when the centurion, who stood from opposite him, saw that he expired, having cried out this way, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God.
Mark. And there were also women looking on from a distance, among whom were also Mary Magdalene,  Mary the mother of James the small man,  of Joses,  Salome;
Mark. women who also followed him and served him when he was in Galilee, also many other women who came up with him to Jerusalem.
Mark. And now having become evening, since it was the Preparation, that is, pre-sabbath,
Mark. Joseph of Arimathaea came, an honorable councilman who also himself was awaiting the kingdom of God, emboldened, he went in near Pilate,  requested the body of Jesus.
Mark. And Pilate wondered if he died already. And having summoned the centurion, he questioned him if he was already dead.
Mark. And having ascertained from the centurion, he granted the body to Joseph.
Mark. And having bought fine linen,  having taken him down, he wrapped him in the linen,  laid him in a sepulcher, being that which had been hewn out of rock. And he rolled a stone to the door of the sepulcher.
Mark. And Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was laid.
Mark. And when the sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene,  Mary the mother of James,  Salome, bought spices, so that having come, they might anoint him.
Mark. And very much early morning on the first day of the week, they come near to the sepulcher when the sun was risen.
Mark. And they said to themselves, Who will roll away the stone for us from the door of the sepulcher?
Mark. And having looked, they see that the stone has been rolled back, for it was very large.
Mark. And having entered into the sepulcher, they saw a young man sitting on the right side, clothed in a white robe,  they were alarmed.
Mark. And he says to them, Be not alarmed. Ye seek Jesus, the man of Nazareth who was crucified. He was raised. He is not here. Behold, the place where they laid him.
Mark. But go, tell his disciples and Peter, that he goes before you into Galilee. Ye will see him there, just as he said to you.
Mark. And having come out, they fled from the sepulcher,  trembling and astonishment seized them. And they said nothing to any man, for they were afraid.
Mark. Now having risen early morning on the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons.
Mark. That woman, having gone, informed those who became with him, as they mourned and wept.
Mark. And those men, when they heard that he is alive,  was seen by her, did not believe.
Mark. And after these things he appeared in a different form to two of them as they walked going into the countryside.
Mark. And those men having departed, they reported to the others. Neither did they believe those men.
Mark. Afterward he became visible to them, to the eleven, who were relaxing. And he upbraided their unbelief and hard heart, because they did not believe those who saw him after he was raised.
Mark. And he said to them, Having gone into all the world, preach ye the good news to the whole creation.
Mark. He who believes and is immersed will be saved,  he who does not believe will be damned.
Mark. And these signs will accompany those who believe: In my name they will cast out demons. They will speak in new tongues.
Mark. They will take up serpents,  if they drink anything deadly, it will, no, not harm them. They will lay hands on the feeble,  they will fare well.
Mark. Therefore indeed, the Lord, after he spoke to them, was taken up into heaven,  sat down at the right hand of God.
Mark. And those men, having gone forth, they preached everywhere, the Lord working jointly,  confirming the word by the signs that followed. Truly.
Luke
Luke. Inasmuch as many have taken in hand to arrange in order a narration about the deeds that have been brought to fullness among us,
Luke. just as they delivered them to us, who became from the beginning eyewitnesses and servants of the word,
Luke. it occurred to me also, having followed closely from the beginning all things accurately, to write to thee in order, eminent Theophilus,
Luke. so that thou might know the certainty of the declarations about which thou were instructed.
Luke. It came to pass in the days of Herod, king of Judea, there was a certain priest, named Zacharias, from the division of Abijah,  his wife was from the daughters of Aaron,  her name was Elizabeth.
Luke. And they were both righteous before God, going in all the commandments and righteous things of the Lord blameless.
Luke. And there was no child to them because Elizabeth was barren,  they were both advanced in their days.
Luke. But it came to pass during his service as a priest in the course of his division in the presence of God,
Luke. that, according to the custom of the priesthood, he was chosen by lot to burn incense after entering into the temple of the Lord.
Luke. And the whole multitude of the people were praying outside at the hour of incense.
Luke. And an agent of the Lord became visible to him, standing on the right side of the altar of incense.
Luke. And Zacharias having seen, was shaken,  fear fell upon him.
Luke. But the agent said to him, Fear not, Zacharias, because thy plea was heard,  thy wife Elizabeth will bear a son for thee. And thou shall call his name John.
Luke. And there will be joy and exultation for thee,  many will rejoice at his birth.
Luke. For he will be great in the sight of the Lord,  he should, no, not drink wine and strong drink. And he will be filled of the Holy Spirit, even from his mother's belly.
Luke. And he will turn back many of the sons of Israel to the Lord their God.
Luke. And he will go ahead, in front of him, in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn back the hearts of fathers toward children,  the disobedient in a mentality of the righteous, to make ready for the Lord a people prepared.
Luke. And Zacharias said to the agent, How will I know this? For I am aged,  my wife is advanced in her days.
Luke. And having answered, the agent said to him, I am Gabriel who stand in the presence of God. And I was sent to speak to thee,  to announce these good news to thee.
Luke. And behold, thou will be mute,  not able to speak until that day these things will come to pass, because thou did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time.
Luke. And the people were waiting for Zacharias,  they wondered during his delay in the temple.
Luke. And when he came out, he could not speak to them,  they recognized that he had seen a vision in the temple. And he was beckoning to them,  remained speechless.
Luke. And it came to pass, when the days of his service were fulfilled, he departed to his house.
Luke. And after these days his wife Elizabeth conceived,  she concealed herself five months, saying,
Luke. Thus the Lord has done to me during the days in which he looked, to take away my shame among men.
Luke. Now in the sixth month the agent Gabriel was sent by God to a city of Galilee, named Nazareth,
Luke. to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David. And the virgin's name was Mary.
Luke. And the agent having come in near her, he said, Hail, thou who are highly favored. The Lord is with thee, thou who are blessed among women.
Luke. But having seen, she was perplexed at his saying,  was pondering what kind of greeting this might be.
Luke. And the agent said to her, Fear not, Mary, for thou have found favor with God.
Luke. And behold, thou will conceive in thy womb,  bring forth a son. And thou shall call his name JESUS.
Luke. This man will be great,  will be called the Son of the Most High. And the Lord God will give to him the throne of his father David.
Luke. And he will reign over the house of Jacob into the ages. And of his kingdom there will be no end.
Luke. And Mary said to the agent, How will this be, since I know not a man?
Luke. And having answered, the agent said to her, The Holy Spirit will come upon thee,  the power of the Most High will overshadow thee. Therefore also the holy thing that is begotten will be called the Son of God.
Luke. And behold, Elizabeth thy kinswoman, she also has conceived a son in her old age,  this is the sixth month with her who was called barren.
Luke. For no word from God will be impossible.
Luke. And Mary said, Behold the maid-servant of the Lord. May it happen to me according to thy word. And the agent departed from her.
Luke. And having risen in these days, Mary went with haste into the hill country, into a city of Judah,
Luke. and entered into the house of Zacharias and greeted Elizabeth.
Luke. And it came to pass, when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, the babe leaped in her belly. And Elizabeth was filled of the Holy Spirit,
Luke. and she exclaimed in a great voice,  said, Blessed are thou among women,  blessed is the fruit of thy belly.
Luke. And why is this to me, that the mother of my Lord would come to me?
Luke. For lo, when the voice of thy greeting happened in my ears, the babe leaped with joy in my belly.
Luke. And blessed is she who believed, because there will be a fulfillment of the things that were spoken to her from the Lord.
Luke. And Mary said, My soul magnifies the Lord,
Luke. and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
Luke. because he has looked upon the lowliness of his bondmaid. For behold, from henceforth all generations will regard me blessed,
Luke. because the Mighty has done great things to me. And his name is holy.
Luke. And his mercy is for generations of generations to those who fear him.
Luke. He did a mighty work by his arm. He scattered the proud in the mentality of their heart.
Luke. He brought down potentates from thrones,  raised up lowly men.
Luke. He filled those who are hungry with good things,  those who are rich he sent away empty.
Luke. He helped his boy Israel to be reminded of mercy,
Luke. just as he spoke to our fathers: to Abraham and his seed into the age.
Luke. And Mary dwelt with her about three months,  returned to her house.
Luke. Now the time for Elizabeth was fulfilled for her to give birth,  she brought forth a son.
Luke. And her neighbors and her kinfolk heard that the Lord magnified his mercy toward her,  they rejoiced with her.
Luke. And it came to pass on the eighth day, that they came to circumcise the child,  they were calling it by the name of his father Zacharias.
Luke. And his mother having answered, said, No,  he will be called John.
Luke. And they said to her, There is no man among thy relatives who is called by this name.
Luke. And they made signs to his father, whatever he wanted to call him.
Luke. And having asked for a writing tablet, he wrote, saying, His name is John. And they all marveled.
Luke. And immediately his mouth was opened,  his tongue,  he spoke, praising God.
Luke. And fear developed in all who dwell around them. And all these sayings were talked about in the entire hill country of Judea.
Luke. And all who heard stored up in their heart, saying, What then will this child be? For the hand of the Lord was with him.
Luke. And his father Zacharias was filled of the Holy Spirit,  prophesied, saying,
Luke. Blessed is the Lord, the God of Israel, because he came to help,  made ransom for his people.
Luke. And he raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of his boy David,
Luke. just as he spoke by the mouth of his holy prophets from of old,
Luke. salvation from our enemies,  from the hand of all who hate us,
Luke. to do mercy with our fathers,  his holy covenant to be remembered,
Luke. the oath that he swore to Abraham our father, to give to us,
Luke. without fear from the hand of our enemies, having been saved to serve him
Luke. in piety and righteousness before him all the days of our life.
Luke. And thou, child, will be called a prophet of the Most High. For thou will go ahead, before the face of the Lord, to prepare his ways,
Luke. to give knowledge of salvation to his people in the remission of their sins,
Luke. because of the bowels of mercy of our God, by which the dayspring from on high came to help us,
Luke. to give light to those who dwell in darkness and the shadow of death, to guide our feet into a way of peace.
Luke. And the child grew,  became strong in spirit. And he was in the desolate regions until the day of his manifestation to Israel.
Luke. Now it came to pass in those days, a decree went out from Caesar Augustus to enroll all the world.
Luke. This enrollment first occurred when Quirinius was governor of Syria.
Luke. And all went to be enrolled, each into his personal city.
Luke. And Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judea to the city of David, which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and patriarchy of David,
Luke. to enroll himself with Mary, the woman who was betrothed to him, being pregnant.
Luke. And it came to pass while they were there, the days were fulfilled for her to bring forth.
Luke. And she brought forth her son, the firstborn,  wrapped him in swaddling clothes,  laid him in the feed trough, because there was no place for them in the inn.
Luke. And there were shepherds in the same region living in the fields,  keeping watch by night over their flock.
Luke. And behold, an agent of the Lord stood near them,  the glory of the Lord shone around them. And they feared a great fear.
Luke. And the agent said to them, Fear not, for behold, I bring you good news of great joy that will be to all the people,
Luke. because to you was born today in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ Lord.
Luke. And this is the sign to you: Ye will find a babe wrapped in swaddling clothes,  lying in a feed trough.
Luke. And suddenly there came to be with the agent a multitude of the heavenly host praising God,  saying,
Luke. Glory to God in the highest,  on earth peace, goodwill among men.
Luke. And it came to pass, as the agents went away from them into heaven, that the men (the shepherds) said to each other, Let us indeed go through as far as Bethlehem,  see this declaration that has come to pass, which the Lord made known to us.
Luke. And having hastened, they came and found both Mary and Joseph,  the babe lying in the feed trough.
Luke. And when they saw it, they informed about the declaration that was told them about this child.
Luke. And all who heard it wondered about the things that were spoken to them by the shepherds.
Luke. But Mary kept all these proclamations, pondering in her heart.
Luke. And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all that they heard and saw, as it was told to them.
Luke. And when eight days were fulfilled to circumcise him, that his name was called JESUS, the one called by the agent before he was conceived in the belly.
Luke. And when the days of their purification according to the law of Moses were fulfilled, they brought him up to Jerusalem, to present him to the Lord,
Luke. (just as it is written in a law of the Lord that every male that opens a womb will be called holy to the Lord),
Luke. and to offer a sacrifice according to that which is said in a law of the Lord, a pair of turtledoves, or two young pigeons.
Luke. And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon. And this man was righteous and devout, waiting for the encouragement of Israel,  the Holy Spirit was upon him.
Luke. And it was divinely revealed to him by the Holy Spirit, that he would not see death before he would see the Christ of the Lord.
Luke. And he came by the Spirit into the temple. And when the parents brought in the child Jesus, for them to do according to the custom of the law about him,
Luke. he also received it into his arms,  praised God,  said,
Luke. Now dismiss thy bondman in peace, Master, according to thy word,
Luke. because my eyes have seen thy salvation,
Luke. which thou prepared toward the face of all the peoples:
Luke. a light for enlightenment of Gentiles,  glory of thy people Israel.
Luke. And Joseph and his mother were marveling at the things being spoken about him.
Luke. And Simeon blessed them,  said to Mary his mother, Behold, this man is set for the falling and the rising of many in Israel,  for a sign being repudiated
Luke. (and also of thee, a sword will pierce through thine own soul), so that thoughts out of many hearts may be revealed.
Luke. And there was Anna, a prophetess, a daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher (being advanced in many days, having lived with a husband seven years from her virginity,
Luke. and this woman was a widow to eighty-four years), who did not depart from the temple, serving with fastings and supplications night and day.
Luke. And having stood near at that same hour, she acknowledged the Lord,  spoke about him to all those who were awaiting redemption in Jerusalem.
Luke. And when they completed all things according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee to their own city Nazareth.
Luke. And the child grew,  became strong in spirit, filled with wisdom. And the grace of God was upon it.
Luke. And his parents went to Jerusalem every year at the feast of the Passover.
Luke. And when he became twelve years old, them having gone up according to the custom of the feast,
Luke. and having fulfilled the days, during their return the boy Jesus remained behind in Jerusalem. And Joseph and his mother did not know it,
Luke. but, having supposed him to be in the caravan, they went a day's journey. And they sought him among their kinfolk and acquaintances.
Luke. And not having found him, they turned back to Jerusalem, seeking him.
Luke. And it came to pass after three days they found him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the teachers, both hearing them,  questioning them.
Luke. And all who heard him were astonished at his understanding and answers.
Luke. And when they saw him they were amazed. And his mother said to him, Child, why did thou this way to us? Behold, thy father and I were seeking thee sorrowing.
Luke. And he said to them, Why is it that ye were seeking me? Had ye not known that I must be among the things of my Father?
Luke. And they did not understand the saying that he spoke to them.
Luke. And he went down with them,  came to Nazareth,  was being subordinate to them. And his mother kept all these sayings in her heart.
Luke. And Jesus increased in wisdom and in stature,  in favor with God and men.
Luke. Now in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judea,  Herod being tetrarch of Galilee,  his brother Philip being tetrarch of the region belonging to Ituraea,  of the region of Trachonitis,  Lysanias being tetrarch of Abilene,
Luke. in the high priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came to be in John the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.
Luke. And he came into all the region around the Jordan, preaching an immersion of repentance for remission of sins,
Luke. as it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet, which says, The voice of a man crying out in the wilderness: Prepare ye the way of the Lord. Make his paths straight.
Luke. Every valley will be filled,  every mountain and hill will be brought low. And the crooked things will be into straight and the rough into smooth ways.
Luke. And all flesh will see the salvation of God.
Luke. He said therefore to the multitudes who went out to be immersed by him, Ye offspring of vipers, who showed you to flee from the coming wrath?
Luke. Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance,  do not begin to say within yourselves, We have a father, Abraham. For I say to you, that God is able from these stones to raise up children to Abraham.
Luke. And even now the axe is laid at the root of the trees. Every tree therefore not making good fruit is cut down,  cast into fire.
Luke. And the crowds questioned him, saying, What then shall we do?
Luke. And having answered, he says to them, He who has two coats, let him share with him not having,  he who has food, let him do likewise.
Luke. And tax collectors also came to be immersed,  they said to him, Teacher, what should we do?
Luke. And he said to them, Collect not one thing more than from what has been appointed for you.
Luke. And men who were soldiers also questioned him, saying, And we, what should we do? And he said to them, Do violence to no man, nor accuse falsely,  be content with your wages.
Luke. And as the people were expectant,  all pondering in their hearts about John, if perhaps he was the Christ,
Luke. John responded, saying to them all, I indeed immerse you in water,  a man mightier than I comes, of whom I am not worthy to unloose the strap of his shoes. He will immerse you in the Holy Spirit and fire,
Luke. whose winnowing fork is in his hand,  he will thoroughly cleanse his threshing floor,  will gather the wheat into his storehouse,  the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire.
Luke. Indeed therefore, also exhorting the people with many other things, he preached the good news.
Luke. But Herod the tetrarch, being reproved by him about Herodias his brother's wife,  about all of which evil things Herod had done,
Luke. also added this to them all, he even locked up John in prison.
Luke. Now it came to pass, during the immersion of all the people, Jesus also having been immersed and praying, for the heaven to be opened,
Luke. and the Holy Spirit to descend in a bodily form as a dove upon him,  a voice to occur out of heaven, saying, Thou are my beloved Son. In thee I am well pleased.
Luke. And Jesus himself was beginning to be about thirty years old, being the son (as was supposed) of Joseph, the son of Heli,
Luke. the son of Matthat, the son of Levi, the son of Melchi, the son of Janna, the son of Joseph,
Luke. the son of Mattathias, the son of Amos, the son of Nahum, the son of Esli, the son of Naggai,
Luke. the son of Maath, the son of Mattathias, the son of Semein, the son of Joseph, the son of Joda,
Luke. the son of Joannan, the son of Rhesa, the son of Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, the son of Neri,
Luke. the son of Melchi, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam, the son of Elmadam, the son of Er,
Luke. the son of Jose, the son of Eliezer, the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat, the son of Levi,
Luke. the son of Simeon, the son of Judah, the son of Joseph, the son of Jonam, the son of Eliakim,
Luke. the son of Melea, the son of Menna, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David,
Luke. the son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Boaz, the son of Salmon, the son of Nahshon,
Luke. the son of Amminadab, the son of Ram, the son of Hezron, the son of Perez, the son of Judah,
Luke. the son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Terah, the son of Nahor,
Luke. the son of Serug, the son of Reu, the son of Peleg, the son of Heber, the son of Shelah
Luke. the son of Cainan, the son of Arphaxad, the son of Shem, the son of Noah, the son of Lamech,
Luke. the son of Methuselah, the son of Enoch, the son of Jared, the son of Mahalaleel, the son of Cainan,
Luke. the son of Enos, the son of Seth, the son of Adam, the son of God.
Luke. And Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan,  was led by the Spirit into the wilderness,
Luke. being tempted forty days by the devil. And he ate nothing in those days,  when they were ended, afterward he was hungry.
Luke. And the devil said to him, If thou are the Son of God, speak to this stone that it may become bread.
Luke. And Jesus answered, saying to him, It is written, Man will not live on bread alone,  on every saying of God.
Luke. And having brought him onto a high mountain, the devil showed him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
Luke. And the devil said to him, I will give to thee all this authority,  the glory of them, because it has been delivered to me,  to whomever I want I give it.
Luke. If therefore thou will worship before me, it will all be thine.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to him, Go thee behind me, Satan. It is written, Thou shall worship the Lord thy God,  him only shall thou serve.
Luke. And he brought him to Jerusalem,  set him on the pinnacle of the temple,  he said to him, If thou are the Son of God, cast thyself down from here,
Luke. for it is written, He will give his agents orders about thee, to protect thee,
Luke. and, They will take thee up on their hands, lest thou dash thy foot against a stone.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to him, It is said, Thou shall not challenge the Lord thy God.
Luke. And when the devil ended every temptation, he withdrew from him until a time.
Luke. And Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit into Galilee. And a report went out about him through the entire region around.
Luke. And he taught in their synagogues, being glorified by all.
Luke. And he came to Nazareth, where he was brought up. And according to that which was customary to him, he entered into the synagogue on the sabbath day,  stood up to read.
Luke. And the book of the prophet Isaiah was given to him. And having opened the book, he found the place where it was written,
Luke. The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he anointed me to preach good news to the poor. He has sent me to heal the broken hearted, to proclaim deliverance to the captives,  recovering of sight to the blind, to sent forth in deliverance those who have been broken,
Luke. to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord.
Luke. And having closed the book, having given it back to the attendant, he sat down. And the eyes of all in the synagogue were focused on him.
Luke. And he began to say to them, Today this scripture has been fulfilled in your ears.
Luke. And all witnessed to him,  wondered at the words of grace that proceeded out of his mouth. And they said, Is this not the son of Joseph?
Luke. And he said to them, Ye will doubtless say to me this proverb: Physician, heal thyself. How many things we heard that happened at Capernaum, do also here in thy fatherland.
Luke. And he said, Truly I say to you, that not one prophet is acceptable in his fatherland.
Luke. But in truth I say to you, many widows were in Israel in the days of Elijah, when the sky was shut up for three years and six months, when a great famine occurred on all the land.
Luke. And Elijah was sent to none of them, except to Zarephath, to a widow woman of Sidon.
Luke. And many lepers were in Israel near Elisha the prophet,  none of them was cleansed, except Naaman the Syrian.
Luke. And all in the synagogue were filled with rage, having heard these things.
Luke. And having risen up, they thrust him outside of the city,  brought him as far as the brow of the hill on which their city had been built, in order to throw him down headlong.
Luke. But he, having passed through the midst of them, departed.
Luke. And he came down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee. And he was teaching them on the sabbath day,
Luke. and they were astonished at his teaching, for his word was with authority.
Luke. And in the synagogue there was a man who had a spirit of an unclean deity. And it cried out in a great voice, saying,
Luke. Oh no! What is with us and with thee, Jesus of Nazareth? Did thou come to destroy us? I know thee who thou are, the Holy man of God.
Luke. And Jesus rebuked it, saying, Be thou muzzled,  come out of him. And the demon having thrown him down in the midst, it came out of him, not having harm him.
Luke. And amazement developed in all,  they spoke among each other, saying, What is this word? Because with authority and power he commands the unclean spirits,  they come out.
Luke. And a report about him went forth into every place of the region around.
Luke. And having arisen from the synagogue, he entered into the house of Simon. And Simon's mother-in-law was gripped by a great fever,  they besought him about her.
Luke. And having stood over her, he rebuked the fever. And it left her,  immediately after rising up, she served them.
Luke. And when the sun was setting, all, as many as had those who were incapacitated with various diseases, brought them to him. And having laid his hands on each one of them, he healed them.
Luke. And also demons came out from many, crying out,  saying, Thou are the Christ, the Son of God. And rebuking them, he did not allow them to speak, because they knew him to be the Christ.
Luke. And when it became day, having departed, he went to a desolate place. And the multitudes sought him,  they came to him,  were restraining him not depart from them.
Luke. But he said to them, I must preach the good news of the kingdom of God to the other cities also, because I was sent for this.
Luke. And he was preaching in the synagogues of Galilee.
Luke. Now it came to pass, while the multitude pressed upon him to hear the word of God,  having stood still, he was beside the lake of Gennesaret.
Luke. And he saw two boats standing by the lake,  the fishermen having gone out of them, were washing their nets.
Luke. And having entered into one of the boats, which was Simon's, he asked him to put out a little from the land. And having sat down, he taught the crowds from the boat.
Luke. And when he stopped speaking, he said to Simon, Put out into the depth,  let down your nets for a catch.
Luke. And having answered, Simon said to him, Master, having toiled through the whole night, we took nothing,  at thy saying, I will let down the net.
Luke. And having done this, they enclosed a great multitude of fishes,  their net was tearing.
Luke. And they beckoned to their partners in the other boat, after coming, to assist them. And they came and filled both the boats, so as for them to be sunk down.
Luke. But Simon Peter having seen, he fell down at Jesus' knees, saying, Depart from me, because I am a sinful man, Lord.
Luke. For astonishment surrounded him,  all those with him, at the catch of the fishes that they caught,
Luke. and likewise also James and John, sons of Zebedee, who were partners with Simon. And Jesus said to Simon, Fear not, from henceforth thou will be catching men.
Luke. And when they brought their boats to land, after forsaking all, they followed him.
Luke. And it came to pass while he was in one of the cities, behold, a man full of leprosy. And having seen Jesus, having fallen on his face, he besought him, saying, Lord, if thou will, thou can make me clean.
Luke. And having stretched forth his hand, he touched him, having said, I will, be thou clean. And straightaway the leprosy departed from him.
Luke. And he commanded him to tell no man, , After going, show thyself to the priest,  bring concerning thy cleansing, just as Moses commanded for a testimony to them.
Luke. But the report about him went through more,  many multitudes came together to hear,  to be healed by him from their infirmities.
Luke. But he himself was withdrawing into the desolate regions,  praying.
Luke. And it came to pass during one of those days, he was also teaching. And there were seated Pharisees and law teachers, who were men having come out of every town of Galilee and Judea and Jerusalem. And the power of the Lord was to heal them.
Luke. And behold, men bringing a man on a bed who was paralyzed. And they sought to bring him in,  to lay him before him.
Luke. And not having found how they might bring him in because of the multitude, after going up upon the housetop, they let him down through the tiles with the small bed into the midst in front of Jesus.
Luke. And having seen their faith, he said to him, Man, thy sins are forgiven thee.
Luke. And the scholars and the Pharisees began to deliberate, saying, Who is this who speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins, except God alone?
Luke. But when Jesus perceived their thoughts, having responded, he said to them, Why do ye deliberate in your hearts?
Luke. Which is easier, to say, Thy sins are forgiven thee, or to say, Arise and walk?
Luke. But that ye may know that the Son of man has authority upon earth to forgive sins (he said to the paralyzed man), I say to thee, Arise,  after taking up thy small bed, go to thy house.
Luke. And immediately having risen up before them, after taking up that on which he lay, he departed to his house glorifying God.
Luke. And amazement gripped all,  they glorified God. And they were filled with fear, saying, We have seen strange things today.
Luke. And after these things he went forth and saw a tax collector, named Levi, sitting at the tax office. And he said to him, Follow me.
Luke. And after leaving behind all, having risen up, he followed him.
Luke. And Levi made a great feast for him in his house,  there was a large crowd of tax collectors and others who were relaxing with them.
Luke. And their scholars and Pharisees murmured against his disciples, saying, Why do ye eat and drink with the tax collectors and sinners?
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to them, Those who are well have no need of a physician,  those faring badly.
Luke. I have not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance.
Luke. And they said to him, Why do the disciples of John fast often,  make supplications,  likewise those of the Pharisees,  thine eat and drink.
Luke. And he said to them, Ye cannot make the sons of the wedding hall fast while the bridegroom is with them.
Luke. But the days will also come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, then they will fast in those days.
Luke. And he also spoke a parable to them. No man puts a patch of a new garment on an old garment, otherwise both the new tears,  that from the new will not blend with the old.
Luke. And no man puts new wine into old wineskins, otherwise the new wine will burst the wineskins,  will itself be spilled,  the wineskins will be ruined.
Luke. But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins,  both are preserved together.
Luke. And no man having drunk old straightaway desires new, for he says, The old is better.
Luke. Now it came to pass for him to be going through the grain fields on a particular sabbath,  his disciples were plucking the ears and were eating, rubbing them in their hands.
Luke. But some of the Pharisees said to them, Why do ye what is not permitted to do on the sabbath day?
Luke. And having answered them, Jesus said, Have ye not read even this, what David did when he was hungry,  those who were with him,
Luke. how he entered into the house of God,  took and ate the loaves of the presentation,  also gave to those who were with him, which is not permitted to eat, except the priests alone?
Luke. And he said to them, The Son of man is lord also of the sabbath.
Luke. And it also came to pass on another sabbath for him to enter into the synagogue and teach. And a man was there,  his right hand was withered.
Luke. And the scholars and the Pharisees watched if he would heal on the sabbath, so that they might find an accusation against him.
Luke. But he knew their thoughts,  he said to the man who had the withered hand, Rise up,  stand forth in the midst. And having risen, he stood up.
Luke. Then Jesus said to them, I will question you. What? Is it permitted on the sabbath to do good, or to do harm, to save life, or to kill?
Luke. And having looked around on them all, he said to him, Stretch forth thy hand. And he did,  his hand was restored whole as the other.
Luke. But they were filled with fury,  deliberated with each other what they might do to Jesus.
Luke. And he happened in these days to go out onto the mountain to pray,  he was continuing all night in prayer to God.
Luke. And when it became day, he called his disciples,  chose twelve from them, whom he also named apostles:
Luke. Simon, whom he also named Peter,  Andrew his brother, James and John, Philip and Bartholomew,
Luke. Matthew and Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus,  Simon who was called the Zealot,
Luke. Judas the son of James,  Judas Iscariot who also became a traitor.
Luke. And having come down with them, he stood on a level place. And a company of his disciples,  a large number of the people from all Judea and Jerusalem,  the maritime Tyre and Sidon, were those who came to hear him,  to be healed from their diseases,
Luke. also those who were afflicted with unclean spirits. And they were healed.
Luke. And all the multitude sought to touch him, because power came forth from him,  healed them all.
Luke. And having lifted up his eyes on his disciples, he said, Blessed are the poor, because the kingdom of God is what belongs to you.
Luke. Blessed are those who hunger now, because ye will be filled. Blessed are those who weep now, because ye will laugh.
Luke. Blessed are ye, when men will hate you,  when they will exclude you,  revile you,  cast out your name as evil, because of the Son of man.
Luke. Rejoice ye in that day,  leap, for behold, your reward is great in heaven, for their fathers did in the same way to the prophets.
Luke. However, woe to you the rich, because ye have received your consolation.
Luke. Woe to you who are filled now, because ye will hunger. Woe to you who laugh now, because ye will mourn and weep.
Luke. Woe when men will speak well of you, for their fathers did in the same way to the false prophets.
Luke. But I say to you, to those who hear, love your enemies. Do good to those who hate you.
Luke. Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who mistreat you.
Luke. To him who strikes thee on the cheek offer the other also,  from him who takes away thy cloak, also do not withhold thy coat.
Luke. Give to every man who asks thee,  from him who takes away thy personal things do not demand them back.
Luke. And as ye desire that men would do to you, do ye also to them likewise.
Luke. And if ye love those who love you, what credit is for you? For even sinners love those who love them.
Luke. And if ye do good to those who do good to you, what credit is for you? For even sinners do the same.
Luke. And if ye lend to whom ye hope to receive, what credit is for you? For even sinners lend to sinners, to receive as much again.
Luke. But love your enemies,  do good,  lend, despairing nothing,  your reward will be great. And ye will be sons of the Most High, because he is good toward the ungrateful and bad.
Luke. Become ye therefore merciful, even as your Father is merciful.
Luke. And do not criticize,  ye will, no, not be criticized. And do not condemn,  ye will, no, not be condemned. Forgive,  ye will be forgiven.
Luke. Give,  it will be given to you, good measure, pressed down, shaken together,  running over, they will give into your bosom. For with the same measure with which ye measure, it will be measured again to you.
Luke. And he spoke a parable to them. Can a blind man lead a blind man? Will they not both fall into a ditch?
Luke. A disciple is not above his teacher,  every disciple who is fully developed will be as his teacher.
Luke. And why do thou see the speck in thy brother's eye,  do not perceive the beam in thine own eye?
Luke. Or how can thou say to thy brother, Brother, allow me to take out the speck that is in thine eye, when thou thyself do not see the beam in thine own eye? Thou hypocrite, first take out the beam from thine own eye,  then thou will see clearly to take out the speck in thy brother's eye.
Luke. For a good tree is not producing corrupt fruit, nor a corrupt tree producing good fruit.
Luke. For each tree is known from its own fruit. For they do not gather figs from thorns, nor do they harvest grapes from a bramble bush.
Luke. The good man out of the good treasure of his heart brings forth the good,  the bad man out of the bad treasure of his heart brings forth the bad, for out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks.
Luke. And why do ye call me, Lord, Lord,  not do the things that I say?
Luke. Every man who comes to me,  hears my sayings,  does them, I will show you to whom he is like.
Luke. He is like a man who builds a house, who dug and excavated,  laid a foundation upon the rock. And when a flood developed, the stream beat upon that house,  could not shake it, for it had been founded upon the rock.
Luke. But he who heard,  not having done, is like a man who built a house upon the soil without a foundation, on which the stream beat,  straightaway it fell. And the ruin of that house became great.
Luke. And when he completed all his sayings in the ears of the people, he entered into Capernaum.
Luke. And a certain centurion's bondman faring badly was going to perish, who was esteemed by him.
Luke. And having heard about Jesus, he sent elders of the Jews to him who asked him that, having come, he would save his bondman.
Luke. And when they came to Jesus they urged him earnestly, saying, He is worthy for whom thou may offer this,
Luke. for he loves our nation,  he himself built the synagogue for us.
Luke. And Jesus went with them. And when he was now not far distant from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying to him, Lord, be not troubled, for I am not worthy that thou should come under my roof.
Luke. Therefore neither did I consider myself worthy to come to thee,  speak by word,  my boy will be healed.
Luke. For I also am a man set under authority, having soldiers under myself. And I say to this man, Go,  he goes,  to another, Come,  he comes,  to my bondman, Do this,  he does.
Luke. And when Jesus heard these things, he marveled him,  having turned around to the multitude who followed him, he said, I say to you, not even in Israel have I found such great faith.
Luke. And those who were sent, having returned to the house, found the bondman who was feeble, being well.
Luke. And it came to pass on the next day that he went to a city called Nain,  a considerable number of his disciples went with him, also a large multitude.
Luke. Now when he came near to the gate of the city, behold, an only begotten son who died was being carried out for his mother. And she was a widow,  a considerable crowd of the city was with her.
Luke. And when the Lord saw her, he felt compassion toward her,  said to her, Weep not.
Luke. And having come, he touched the coffin,  the men carrying it stood still. And he said, Young man, I say to thee, arise.
Luke. And the dead man sat up,  began to speak. And he gave him to his mother.
Luke. And fear seized all. And they glorified God, saying, A great prophet has been raised among us, , God came to help his people.
Luke. And this report about him went forth in the whole of Judea,  in all the region around.
Luke. And the disciples of John informed him about all these things.
Luke. And having summoned a certain two of his disciples, John sent them to Jesus, saying, Are thou he who comes, or do we look for another man?
Luke. And when they came to him, they said, John the immerser has sent us to thee, saying, Are thou he who comes, or do we look for another man?
Luke. And in the same hour he healed many from diseases and plagues and evil spirits. And he granted sight to many blind men.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to them, After going, report to John the things that ye saw and heard: the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed,  the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, the poor are preached good news.
Luke. And blessed is he, whoever will not be offended by me.
Luke. And after John's messengers departed, he began to say to the multitudes about John, What did ye go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken with the wind?
Luke. But what did ye go out to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? Behold, those in elegant clothing,  existing in luxury, are in kingly places.
Luke. But what did ye go out to see? A prophet? Yea, I say to you,  much more than a prophet.
Luke. This is he about whom it is written, Behold, I send my agent before thy face, who will prepare thy way before thee.
Luke. For I say to you, among men born of women there is not one prophet greater than John the immerser, yet the smaller in the kingdom of God is greater than he.
Luke. And all the people having heard,  the tax collectors who were immersed the immersion of John, justified God.
Luke. But the Pharisees and the lawyers who were not immersed by him, rejected the purpose of God for themselves.
Luke. To what, then will I compare the men of this generation,  to what are they like?
Luke. They are like children sitting in the marketplace,  calling to each other,  saying, We piped to you,  ye did not dance. We mourned to you,  ye did not weep.
Luke. For John the immerser has come neither eating bread nor drinking wine,  ye say, He has a demon.
Luke. The Son of man has come eating and drinking,  ye say, Behold the man, a glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!
Luke. And wisdom is justified from all her children.
