Luke. And a certain man of the Pharisees asked him that he would eat with him. And having entered into the Pharisee's house, he sat down.
Luke. And behold, a woman in the city who was sinful. And when she knew that he sat in the Pharisee's house, having brought an alabaster cruse of ointment,
Luke. and having stood behind near his feet, weeping, she began to wet his feet with the tears,  wiped them with the hair of her head. And she kissed his feet much,  anointed them with the ointment.
Luke. But when the Pharisee who invited him saw it, he spoke within himself, saying, This man, if he were a prophet, would know who and what kind the woman is who touches him, that she is sinful.
Luke. And having responded, Jesus said to him, Simon, I have something to say to thee. And he says, speak Teacher.
Luke. There were two debtors to a certain creditor, the one owed five hundred denarii,  the other fifty.
Luke. And of them not having to repay, he forgave them both. Which of them therefore, do thou say, will love him more?
Luke. And having answered, Simon said, I suppose that it was to whom he forgave more. And he said to him, Thou have judged correctly.
Luke. And having turned to the woman, he said to Simon, See thou this woman? I entered into thy house; thou gave no water for my feet. But this woman has wet my feet with tears,  wiped them with the hairs of her head.
Luke. Thou gave me no kiss,  this woman, since I came in, has not ceased kissing my feet much.
Luke. Thou did not anoint my head with olive oil,  this woman has anointed my feet with ointment.
Luke. For this reason I say to thee, her many sins are forgiven, because she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, loves little.
Luke. And he said to her, Thy sins are forgiven.
Luke. And those who sat together began to say within themselves, Who is this who even forgives sins?
Luke. And he said to the woman, Thy faith has saved thee. Go in peace.
Luke. And it came to pass that he traveled through, by city and village in succession, announcing and preaching the good news of the kingdom of God,  the twelve men with him,
Luke. and certain women who were healed from evil spirits and infirmities: Mary who was called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out,
Luke. and Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herod's steward,  Susanna,  many other women who served them from the things they possessed.
Luke. And when a large multitude gathered together,  those coming to him from each city, he spoke by a parable.
Luke. The man who sows went forth to sow his seed. And during his sowing, some fell by the way,  it was trampled,  the birds of the sky devoured it.
Luke. And another fell on the rock,  having grown, it withered away because of not having moisture.
Luke. And another fell amidst the thorns,  having grown together, the thorns choked it.
Luke. And another fell on the good ground,  having grown it produced fruit a hundredfold. As he said these things, he called out, He who has ears to hear, let him hear.
Luke. And his disciples questioned him, saying, What is this parable?
Luke. And he said, To you it is given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God,  to the others in parables, so that seeing they would not see,  hearing they would not understand.
Luke. Now the parable is this. The seed is the word of God.
Luke. And those by the way are those who hear, then the devil comes,  takes away the word from their heart, lest having believed, they would be saved.
Luke. And those on the rock are those who, when they hear, receive the word with joy. And these have no root, who believe for a time,  withdraw in time of trial.
Luke. And that which fell in the thorns, these are those who heard,  as they go they are choked by cares and wealth and pleasures of life,  do not bring to maturity.
Luke. But those in the good ground, these are those who in an good and right heart, having heard the word, hold it firm,  bring forth fruit in perseverance.
Luke. And no man, having lit a lamp, covers it with a container, or places it under a bed,  places it on a lampstand, so that those who enter in may see the light.
Luke. For there is no secret that will not become visible, nor hid, that will not be known and come to be visible.
Luke. Notice therefore how ye hear. For whoever has, to him will be given,  whoever has not, even what he seems to have will be taken from him.
Luke. And his mother and brothers came to him,  they could not come near him because of the crowd.
Luke. And it was reported to him, saying, Thy mother and thy brothers stand outside, desiring to see thee.
Luke. But having answered, he said to them, My mother and my brothers are these who hear the word of God and do it.
Luke. Now it came to pass on one of those days, that he entered into a boat, also his disciples. And he said to them, Let us pass through to the other side of the lake. And they launched forth,
Luke. but as they sailed he began to asleep. And a storm of wind came down on the lake,  they were filling up,  were in peril.
Luke. And having approached, they awoke him, saying, Master, master, we are perishing. And having risen, he rebuked the wind and the raging of the water,  they ceased,  it became calm.
Luke. And he said to them, Where is your faith? And having feared, they wondered, saying to each other, Who then is this man, that he commands even the winds and the water,  they obey him?
Luke. And they sailed toward the country of the Gadarenes, which is opposite Galilee.
Luke. And when he came forth upon the land, a certain man met him out of the city, who had demons of a considerable time. And he wore no clothing,  did not dwell in a house,  in the sepulchers.
Luke. And when he saw Jesus, having cried out, he fell down before him. And in a great voice he said, What is with me and with thee, Jesus, thou Son of the Most High God? I beseech thee, do not torment me.
Luke. For he commanded the unclean spirit to come out from the man, for many times it had seized him. And he was bound with chains and shackles,  guarded. And breaking the bonds apart, he was driven by the demon into the desolate regions.
Luke. And Jesus demanded him, saying, What is thy name? And he said, Legion, because many demons were entered into him.
Luke. And they entreated him that he would not command them to go out into the abyss.
Luke. Now a herd of considerable swine was there feeding on the mountain,  they implored him that he would allow them to enter into those. And he allowed them.
Luke. And the demons having come out from the man, they entered into the swine. And the herd stampeded down the slope into the lake,  were drowned.
Luke. And when those who tended them saw what happened, they fled and reported it in the city and in the fields.
Luke. And they came out to see what happened. And they came to Jesus,  found the man, from whom the demons had gone out, sitting near the feet of Jesus, clothed and in his right mind. And they were afraid.
Luke. And also those who saw it informed them how the man who was demon-possessed was saved.
Luke. And the whole multitude of the region around the Gadarenes besought him to depart from them, because they were gripped by great fear. And he, having embarked into the boat, returned.
Luke. But the man from whom the demons had gone out begged him to be with him. But Jesus sent him away, saying,
Luke. Return to thy house,  relate everything God did for thee. And he departed, proclaiming throughout the whole city how many things Jesus did for him.
Luke. And it came to pass during Jesus returning, the multitude welcomed him, for they were all waiting for him.
Luke. And behold, there came a man whose name was Jairus,  he was a ruler of the synagogue. And having fallen down near Jesus' feet, he besought him to come into his house,
Luke. because there was with him an only begotten daughter, about twelve years old,  she was dying. But during his going the multitudes thronged him.
Luke. And a woman being with an issue of blood for twelve years, who, although she spent her entire living on physicians, was unable to be healed by any,
Luke. having come from behind, she touched the border of his garment. And immediately the issue of her blood stayed.
Luke. And Jesus said, Who is he who touched me? But when they all denied, Peter and those with him, said, Master, the multitudes come together and crowd thee,  thou say, Who is he who touched me?
Luke. But Jesus said, Who touched me? For I perceived power having gone forth from me.
Luke. And when the woman saw that she was not hid, she came trembling. And having fallen down before him, she declared to him in the presence of all the people for what reason she touched him,  how she was healed immediately.
Luke. And he said to her, Cheer up, Daughter. Thy faith has healed thee. Go in peace.
Luke. While he still spoke, some man comes from the synagogue ruler, saying to him, Thy daughter has died. Do not trouble the teacher.
Luke. But having heard it, Jesus answered him, saying, Fear not, only believe and she will be saved.
Luke. And when he came to the house, he did not allow any man to enter in except Peter and John and James,  the father of the girl and the mother.
Luke. And all were weeping and bewailing her. But he said, Weep not. She did not die,  sleeps.
Luke. And they ridiculed him, knowing that she died.
Luke. But having sent them all away outside, having taken her by the hand, he called out, saying, Girl, awake.
Luke. And her spirit returned,  she rose up immediately. And he commanded to give her to eat.
Luke. And her parents were amazed,  he ordered them to tell no man that which happened.
Luke. And having summoned the twelve, he gave them power and authority over all demons,  to heal diseases.
Luke. And he sent them to preach the kingdom of God,  to heal those who were incapacitated.
Luke. And he said to them, Take nothing for the way, neither staffs, nor bag, nor bread, nor silver, nor have two coats each.
Luke. And into whatever house ye may enter, remain there,  from there depart.
Luke. And as many as will not receive you, when departing from that city, also shake off the dust from your feet for a testimony against them.
Luke. And having departed, they passed through the villages, preaching the good news,  healing everywhere.
Luke. But Herod the tetrarch heard of all that was done by him. And he was perplexed, because it was said by some that John was risen from the dead,
Luke. and by some that Elijah appeared,  by others that a prophet, one of the ancient men arose.
Luke. And Herod said, I beheaded John,  who is this about whom I hear such things? And he sought to see him.
Luke. And when the apostles returned, they related to him as many things as they did. And having taken them along, he withdrew in private into a desolate place of a city called Bethsaida.
Luke. But the multitudes having known, they followed him. And having received them, he spoke to them about the kingdom of God,  he cured those who had need of healing.
Luke. And the day began to decline,  the twelve having come near, they said to him, Send the multitude away, so that, after going into the villages and fields around, they may rest and find provision, because we are here in a desolate place.
Luke. But he said to them, Give ye them to eat. And they said, There are for us not more than five loaves and two fishes, unless, after going, we might buy food for all this people.
Luke. For there were about five thousand men. And he said to his disciples, Make them sit down in groups of fifty each.
Luke. And they did so,  made them all sit down.
Luke. And after taking the five loaves and the two fishes, having looked up to heaven, he blessed them,  broke in pieces,  gave to the disciples to set before the multitude.
Luke. And they ate,  were all filled. And there were taken up to them of the remaining fragments, twelve baskets.
Luke. And it came to pass, as he was praying privately, the disciples were with him. And he questioned them, saying, Who do the multitudes say that I am?
Luke. And having answered, they said, John the immerser,  others, Elijah,  others, that a certain prophet of the ancient men arose.
Luke. And he said to them, But ye, who say ye that I am? And having answered, Peter said, The Christ of God.
Luke. But having chided them, he commanded to tell this to no man,
Luke. saying, It is necessary for the Son of man to suffer many things,  be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scholars,  be killed,  the third day to rise.
Luke. And he said to all, If any man wants to come behind me, let him deny himself,  take up his cross,  follow me.
Luke. For whoever wants to save his life will lose it,  whoever may lose his life because of me, this man will save it.
Luke. For what is a man benefited, having gained the whole world,  having lost or having forfeited himself?
Luke. For whoever may be ashamed of me and of my words, the Son of man will be ashamed of this man when he comes in his glory,  of the Father,  of the holy agents.
Luke. But I tell you truly, there are some of those who stand here, who will, no, not taste of death, till they see the kingdom of God.
Luke. And it came to pass about eight days after these sayings, that after taking Peter and John and James, he went up onto the mountain to pray.
Luke. And as he was praying, the appearance of his face became different,  his clothing glistening white.
Luke. And behold, two men talked with him, who were Moses and Elijah,
Luke. who, having appeared in glory, spoke of his departure, which he was going to fulfill at Jerusalem.
Luke. But Peter and those with him were weighed down with sleep,  having become awake, they saw his glory,  the two men who stood with him.
Luke. And it came to pass, as they were departing from him, Peter said to Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here,  we could make three tabernacles, one for thee,  one for Moses,  one for Elijah, not knowing what he was saying.
Luke. And while he was speaking these things, a cloud came and overshadowed them. And they were afraid as they entered into the cloud.
Luke. And a voice came out of the cloud, saying, This is my beloved Son. Hear ye him.
Luke. And at the occurrence of the voice, Jesus was found alone. And they kept silent,  informed no man in those days any of the things that they have seen.
Luke. And it came to pass, on the next day, when they came down from the mountain, a large crowd met him.
Luke. And behold, a man from the crowd cried out, saying, Teacher, I beseech thee to look upon my son, because he is the only begotten to me.
Luke. And lo, a spirit seizes him,  he suddenly cries out,  it convulses him with foaming. And it departs from him difficultly, injuring him.
Luke. And I begged thy disciples that they might cast it out,  they could not.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said, O faithless and perverted generation, how long will I be with you and endure you? Bring thy son here.
Luke. And as he was still coming, the demon tore him,  he convulsed. But Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit,  healed the boy,  gave him back to his father.
Luke. And they were all amazed at the majesty of God. But while all were wondering at all the things which Jesus did, he said to his disciples,
Luke. Place ye these sayings into your ears, for the Son of man is going to be delivered up into the hands of men.
Luke. But they did not understand this saying,  it was concealed from them, so that they did not perceive it. And they were afraid to ask him about this saying.
Luke. But a thought entered among them, which of them may be greater.
Luke. But having perceived the thought of their heart, having taken a child, Jesus stood it beside him,
Luke. and he said to them, Whoever may receive this child in my name receives me,  whoever may receive me receives him who sent me, for he who exists smaller among you all, this man will be great.
Luke. And having answered, John said, Master, we saw a certain man casting out demons in thy name,  we forbade him, because he does not follow with us.
Luke. But Jesus said to him, Do not forbid, for he who is not against us is for us.
Luke. And it came to pass, while fulfilling the days for his ascension, that he also set his face to go to Jerusalem.
Luke. And he sent agents before his face,  they went. And having gone, they entered into a village of Samaritans, so as to make ready for him.
Luke. And they did not receive him, because his face was going to Jerusalem.
Luke. And his disciples James and John having seen, they said, Lord, do thou want that we should call fire to come down from the sky,  consume them, as also Elijah did?
Luke. But having turned around, he rebuked them,  said, Ye do not know what kind of spirit ye are.
Luke. For the Son of man came not to destroy the lives of men,  to save. And they went to another village.
Luke. And it came to pass while they went on the way, a certain man said to him, I will follow thee wherever thou may go, Lord.
Luke. And Jesus said to him, The foxes have holes,  the birds of the sky, nests,  the Son of man has not where he might lay his head.
Luke. And he said to another, Follow me. But he said, Lord, allow me first, after departing, to bury my father.
Luke. But Jesus said to him, Leave the dead to bury their own dead,  thou, after departing, proclaim the kingdom of God.
Luke. And also another said, I will follow thee, Lord,  first allow me to bid farewell to those in my house.
Luke. But Jesus said to him, No man, having put his hand to a plow,  looking to things behind, is fit for the kingdom of God.
Luke. Now after these things the Lord also appointed seventy other men,  sent them by twos before his face into every city and place where he himself was going to come.
Luke. Therefore he said to them, The harvest indeed is plentiful,  the workmen are few. Pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he would send forth workmen into his harvest.
Luke. Go ye. Behold, I send you forth as lambs in the midst of wolves.
Luke. Carry no bag, no pouch, no shoes,  greet no man on the way.
Luke. And into whatever house ye enter, first say, Peace to this house.
Luke. And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him,  if not, it will return to you.
Luke. And remain in the same house eating and drinking from their things, for the workman is worthy of his wage. Do not depart from house to house.
Luke. And into whatever city ye enter,  they receive you, eat the things that are set before you.
Luke. And heal the weak in it,  say to them, The kingdom of God has come near to you.
Luke. But into whatever city ye enter,  they will not receive you, after departing into the thoroughfares of it, say,
Luke. Even the dust that clings on us from your city, we wipe off against you. Nevertheless know ye this, that the kingdom of God has come near to you.
Luke. I say to you, that it will be more tolerable in that day for Sodom, than for that city.
Luke. Woe to thee, Chorazin! Woe to thee, Bethsaida! Because if the mighty works were done in Tyre and Sidon, which were done in you, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
Luke. But it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the judgment, than for you.
Luke. And thou, Capernaum, which was exalted to the sky, will be thrust down to Hades.
Luke. He who hears you hears me,  he who rejects you rejects me,  he who rejects me rejects him who sent me.
Luke. And the seventy returned with joy, saying, Lord, even the demons are made subject to us in thy name.
Luke. And he said to them, I beheld Satan fallen as lightning from the sky.
Luke. Behold, I give you authority to tread over serpents and scorpions,  over all the power of the enemy, , no, nothing will harm you.
Luke. Nevertheless do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are made subject to you,  rejoice because your names are written in the heavens.
Luke. In the same hour Jesus rejoiced in the Spirit,  said, I thank thee, Father, Lord of the heaven and the earth, that thou hid these things from the wise and astute,  revealed them to the childlike. Yea, Father, because it became pleasing this way in thy sight.
Luke. And having turned to the disciples, he said, All things were delivered to me by my Father. And no man knows who the Son is, except the Father,  who the Father is, except the Son,  he to whomever the Son wants to reveal him.
Luke. And having turning toward the disciples in private, he said, Blessed are the eyes that see what ye see.
Luke. For I say to you, that many prophets and kings desired to see what ye see,  did not see,  to hear what ye hear,  did not hear.
Luke. And behold, a certain lawyer stood up testing him,  saying, Teacher, having done what, would I inherit eternal life?
Luke. And he said to him, What is written in the law? How read thou?
Luke. And having answered, he said, Thou shall love the Lord thy God from thy whole heart,  from thy whole soul,  from thy whole strength,  from thy whole mind,  thy neighbor as thyself.
Luke. And he said to him, Thou answered correctly. Do this and thou will live.
Luke. But he, wanting to justify himself, said to Jesus, And who is my neighbor?
Luke. And having replied, Jesus said, A certain man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho. And he encountered bandits, who also, having stripped him and having beat him, departed having left him being half dead.
Luke. And by coincidence a certain priest was going down on that road,  when he saw him, he passed by on the other side.
Luke. And likewise also a Levite who happened upon the place, having come,  having looked, passed by on the other side.
Luke. But a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to him,  when he saw him, felt compassion.
Luke. And having come, he wrapped up his wounds, pouring on olive oil and wine. And having set him on his own beast, he brought him to an inn,  took care of him.
Luke. And on the morrow when departing, after taking out two denarii, he gave them to the innkeeper,  said to him, Take care of him,  whatever thou might spend more, I will repay thee at my return.
Luke. Which therefore, of these three, appears to thee to have become neighbor to the man who fell among the bandits?
Luke. And he said, He who did mercy with him. Therefore Jesus said to him, Go,  do thou likewise.
Luke. And it came to pass as they went, he also entered into a certain village,  a certain woman named Martha received him into her house.
Luke. And she was sister to this woman called Mary, who also, having sat at Jesus' feet, was listening to his word.
Luke. But Martha was encumbered about much serving. And having stood near, she said, Lord, do thou not care that my sister left me behind to serve alone? Speak to her therefore that she may help me.
Luke. But having answered, Jesus said to her, Martha, Martha, thou are anxious and troubled about many things,
Luke. but one thing is necessary,  Mary has chosen the good part, which will not be taken away from her.
Luke. And it came to pass as he was in a certain place praying, that when he ceased, a certain man of his disciples said to him, Lord, teach us to pray as John also taught his disciples.
Luke. And he said to them, When ye pray, say, Our Father in the heavens, hallowed be thy name. May thy kingdom come, may thy will happen on the earth as also in heaven.
Luke. Give us our bread sufficient for each day.
Luke. And forgive us our sins, for we ourselves also forgive every man who is indebted to us. And bring us not into temptation,  deliver us from evil.
Luke. And he said to them, Which of you will have a friend,  will go to him at midnight,  say to him, Friend, lend me three loaves,
Luke. since a friend arrived from the road to me,  I do not have what I would set before him,
Luke. and that man from inside, having answered, would say, Do not cause toils for me. The door is now shut,  my children are with me in bed. I am not able, after getting up, to give thee?
Luke. I say to you, though he will not give him, after getting up, because he is his friend, yet because of his persistence, having awaken, he will give him as many as he needs.
Luke. And I say to you, ask,  it will be given you. Seek,  ye will find. Knock,  it will be opened.
Luke. For every man who asks receives,  he who seeks finds,  to him who knocks it will be opened.
Luke. And which father of you, if the son will ask a loaf, will give him a stone, or also if a fish, in place of a fish will give him a serpent?
Luke. Or if he should ask for an egg, will he give him a scorpion?
Luke. If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more the Father from heaven will give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him?
Luke. And he was casting out a demon,  it was mute. And it happened when the demon was gone out, the mute man spoke. And the multitudes marveled,
Luke. but some of them said, He casts out the demons by Beelzebub, ruler of the demons.
Luke. And others, challenging, sought from him a sign from the sky.
Luke. But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them, Every kingdom that was divided against itself is made desolate,  a house against a house falls.
Luke. And if Satan also is divided against himself, how will his kingdom be made to stand? Because ye say that I cast out the demons by Beelzebub.
Luke. And if I cast out the demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your sons cast them out? Because of this they will be your judges.
Luke. But if by a finger of God I cast out the demons, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.
Luke. When the fully armed strong man guards his palace, the things possessed by him are in peace,
Luke. but when a stronger than he comes, after defeating him, he takes away his full armor in which he trusted,  divides his booty.
Luke. He who is not with me is against me,  he who does not gather with me scatters.
Luke. When the unclean spirit departs out of the man, it passes through waterless places seeking rest. And not finding, it says, I will return to my house from where I came out.
Luke. And when it comes, it finds it swept and put in order.
Luke. Then it goes,  takes along seven other spirits more evil than itself,  having enter in, it dwells there. And the last state of that man becomes worse than the first.
Luke. And it came to pass, as he said these things, a certain woman, having lifted up her voice out of the crowd, said to him, Blessed is the belly that bore thee,  the breasts that thou suckled.
Luke. But he said, Blessed rather, are those who hear the word of God,  keep it.
Luke. And when the multitudes gathered together he began to say, This generation is evil. They seek a sign,  no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah, the prophet.
Luke. For as Jonah became a sign to the Ninevites, so also the Son of man will be to this generation.
Luke. The queen of the south will awake in the judgment with the men of this generation,  will condemn them, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon,  behold, a greater than Solomon is here.
Luke. The men of Nineveh will rise up in the judgment with this generation,  will condemn it, because they repented at the preaching of Jonah,  behold, a greater than Jonah is here.
Luke. And no man, having lit a lamp, puts it in a concealed place, nor under the bushel,  on the lampstand, so that those who enter in may see the light.
Luke. The lamp of thy body is the eye. Therefore, when thine eye is sound, thy whole body is also bright,  when it is bad, thy body is also dark.
Luke. Watch therefore the light in thee not be darkness.
Luke. If therefore thy whole body is bright, not having any part dark, the whole will be bright, as when the lamp illuminates thee by the radiance.
Luke. Now as he spoke a certain Pharisee asks him that he might dine with him. And having entered in, he sat down.
Luke. And when the Pharisee saw, he marveled that he did not first wash before dinner.
Luke. And the Lord said to him, Now ye Pharisees cleanse the outside of the cup and of the platter,  your interior is full of plundering and wickedness.
Luke. Ye foolish men, did not he who made the outside also make the inside?
Luke. But give compassion, things that are inside,  behold, all things are clean to you.
Luke. But woe to you Pharisees! Because ye tithe mint and rue and every plant,  pass by justice and the love of God. It is necessary to do these things,  not to neglect those things.
Luke. Woe to you Pharisees! Because ye love the place of honor in the synagogues,  the greetings in the marketplaces.
Luke. Woe to you scholars and Pharisees, hypocrites! Because ye are like the unseen sepulchers,  the men who walk over them do not know.
Luke. And having answered, a certain man of the lawyers says to him, Teacher, in saying these things thou rebuke us also.
Luke. And he said, Woe also to you lawyers! Because ye load men with burdens difficult to bear,  ye yourselves touch not the burdens with one of your fingers.
Luke. Woe to you! Because ye build the sepulchers of the prophets,  your fathers killed them.
Luke. Consequently, ye testify and approve the works of your fathers, because they indeed killed them,  ye build their sepulchers.
Luke. Because of this also the wisdom of God said, I will send to them prophets and apostles. And some of them they will kill and persecute,
Luke. so that the blood of all the prophets that was shed from the foundation of the world may be required of this generation,
Luke. from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zachariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, I say to you, it will be required of this generation.
Luke. Woe to you lawyers! Because ye took away the key of knowledge. Ye did not enter in yourselves,  ye hindered those who were entering in.
Luke. And after he said these things to them, the scholars and the Pharisees began to harass him extremely,  to provoke him to speak impulsively about more things,
Luke. waiting to ambush him, seeking to catch something out of his mouth so that they might accuse him.
Luke. During which time the myriads of the multitude having gathered together so as to trample each other, he began first to say to his disciples, Take heed to yourselves from the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.
Luke. But there is nothing covered up that will not be revealed,  hidden that will not be known.
Luke. Therefore, as many things as ye have said in the darkness will be heard in the light,  what ye have spoken in the ear in the inner chambers will be proclaimed upon the housetops.
Luke. And I say to you my friends, Be not afraid of those who kill the body,  after these things not having anything more severe to do.
Luke. But I will show you whom ye should fear. Fear him, who, after killing, has power to cast into hell. Yes, I say to you, fear ye him.
Luke. Are not five sparrows sold for two copper coins? And not one of them is forgotten in the sight of God.
Luke. But even the hairs of your head are all numbered. Fear not, therefore, ye are superior to many sparrows.
Luke. And I say to you, every man who will confess in me before men, the Son of man will also confess in him before the agents of God,
Luke. but he who denies me in the presence of men will be denied in the presence of the agents of God.
Luke. And every man who will speak a word against the Son of man, it will be forgiven him,  to him who blasphemed against the Holy Spirit it will not be forgiven.
Luke. And when they bring you to the synagogues,  the principle positions,  the offices of authority, be not anxious how or what ye should answer in defense, or what ye should say,
Luke. for the Holy Spirit will teach you in the same hour what ye ought to say.
Luke. And a certain man out of the crowd said to him, Teacher, speak to my brother to divide the inheritance with me.
Luke. But he said to him, Man, who appointed me a judge or an arbitrator over you?
Luke. And he said to them, Watch,  keep away from greed, because to any man, life to him is not in the abundance of things possessed by him.
Luke. And he spoke a parable to them, saying, The land of a certain rich man brought forth well.
Luke. And he pondered within himself, saying, What shall I do, because I have nowhere I will store my crops?
Luke. And he said, I will do this. I will dismantle my barns,  I will build greater,  there I will store all my grain and my goods.
Luke. And I will say to my soul, Soul, thou have many goods laid up for many years. Take thine ease, eat, drink, be merry.
Luke. But God said to him, Thou foolish man, they demand thy soul from thee this night,  the things that thou prepared, whose will they be?
Luke. So is he who stores up for himself,  is not being rich toward God.
Luke. And he said to his disciples, Because of this I say to you, be not anxious for your life, what ye may eat, nor for the body, what ye may wear.
Luke. For the life is more than the food,  the body, the clothing.
Luke. Consider the ravens, because they do not sow, nor do they reap, for which there is no storehouse nor barn,  God feeds them. How much ye are worth more than the birds.
Luke. And which of you by being anxious can add one cubit to his age?
Luke. If then ye are not able to do even the least, why are ye anxious about the rest?
Luke. Consider the lilies, how they grow. They toil not, nor do they spin,  I say to you, not even Solomon in all his glory was arrayed like one of these.
Luke. And if God so clothes the grass in the field, which today is,  tomorrow being cast into the oven, how much more you, O ye of little faith?
Luke. And do not seek what ye may eat,  what ye may drink,  do not be unsettled.
Luke. For the nations of the world seek all these things,  your Father knows that ye have need of these things.
Luke. However, seek ye the kingdom of God,  all these things will be added to you.
Luke. Fear not, little flock, because your Father is well pleased to give you the kingdom.
Luke. Sell things possessed by you,  give charity. Make for yourselves purses not becoming old, a treasure unfailing in the heavens, where no thief approaches, nor moth corrupts.
Luke. For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
Luke. Let your loins be girded about,  the lights burning,
Luke. and be ye like men waiting for their lord, when he may return from the wedding festivities, so that when he comes and knocks, they may straightaway open to him.
Luke. Blessed are those bondmen whom the lord when he comes will find watching. Truly I say to you, that he will gird himself,  will cause them to sit down,  having come, will serve them.
Luke. And if he should come in the second watch,  should come in the third watch,  find so, blessed are those bondmen.
Luke. But know this, that if the house-ruler had known in what hour the thief was coming, he would have watched,  would not have allowed his house to be broken into.
Luke. Therefore, ye also become ready, because the Son of man comes at that hour ye do not suppose.
Luke. And Peter said to him, Lord, did thou speak this parable to us, or also to all?
Luke. And the Lord said, Who then is the faithful and wise manager whom his lord will appoint over his service to give the provision on time?
Luke. Blessed is that bondman whom his lord when he comes will find so doing.
Luke. Truly I say to you, that he will appoint him over the things being possessed by him.
Luke. But if that bondman should say in his heart, My lord is late to come,  should begin to beat the servant boys and the servant girls,  to eat and drink,  to be drunken,
Luke. the lord of that bondman will arrive in a day that he does not expect,  in an hour that he is not aware,  will cut him in two,  will place his portion with the unbelieving.
Luke. And that bondman who knew his lord's will,  who did not prepare, nor do according to his will, will be beaten much,
Luke. but he who did not know,  did things worthy of blows, will be beaten little. And to every man to whom much was given, much will be required from him. And to whom they entrust much, they will ask him more abundantly.
Luke. I came to cast fire upon the earth,  what I desire is if it were kindled already.
Luke. But I have an immersion to be immersed,  how am I constrained until it will be accomplished.
Luke. Do ye suppose that I came to give peace on the earth? I tell you, no,  rather division.
Luke. For henceforth there will be five in one house divided, three against two,  two against three.
Luke. A father will be divided against a son,  a son against a father, a mother against a daughter,  a daughter against a mother, a mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law,  a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.
Luke. And he also said to the multitudes, When ye see a cloud rising from the west, straightaway ye say, A shower is coming,  so it happens.
Luke. And when a south wind is blowing, ye say, There will be heat,  it happens.
Luke. Ye hypocrites, ye know how to examine the face of the earth and the sky,  how can ye not examine this season?
Luke. And also why do ye not judge yourselves what is right?
Luke. For when thou go with thine opponent to the magistrate on the way give effort to be delivered from him, lest he may drag thee to the judge,  the judge may deliver thee to the officer,  the officer would cast thee into prison.
Luke. I say to thee, thou will, no, not come out from there, until thou have paid even the last mite.
Luke. Now some were present at the same time who informed him about the Galileans whose blood Pilate mingled with their sacrifices.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to them, Do ye suppose that these Galileans became sinful above all the Galileans because they have suffered such things?
Luke. I tell you, no,  if ye do not repent, ye will all perish similarly.
Luke. Or those eighteen upon whom the tower in Siloam fell and killed them. Do ye think that these became debtors above all the men who dwell in Jerusalem?
Luke. I tell you, no,  if ye do not repent, ye will all likewise perish.
Luke. And he spoke this parable. A certain man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard,  he came seeking fruit on it,  found none.
Luke. And he said to the vine workman, Behold, three years I come seeking fruit on this fig tree,  find none. Cut it down, why also waste the ground?
Luke. And having answered, he says to him, Sir, allow it this year also until I may dig around it and cast manure.
Luke. Although surely it should bear fruit,  if not, in the coming year thou will cut it down.
Luke. And he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the sabbath day.
Luke. And behold, there was a woman who had a spirit of infirmity eighteen years. And she was bent over,  not being able to straighten up completely.
Luke. And when Jesus saw her, he called out,  said to her, Woman, thou are loosed from thine infirmity.
Luke. And he laid his hands upon her,  immediately she was made straight,  glorified God.
Luke. And having responded, the synagogue-ruler, being indignant because Jesus healed on the sabbath, answered and said to the multitude, There are six days in which he ought to work. Therefore coming in these, be healed,  not on the day of the sabbath.
Luke. But the Lord therefore answered him and said, Ye hypocrites, does not each of you on the sabbath loose his ox or his donkey from the stall,  after leading away, give to drink?
Luke. And ought not this woman, being a daughter of Abraham whom Satan has bound, lo, eighteen years, be loosed from this bond on the day of the sabbath?
Luke. And as he said these things all those opposing him were shamed,  all the multitude rejoiced for all the glorious things that were done by him.
Luke. And he said, What is the kingdom of God like,  to what will I compare it?
Luke. It is like a grain of a mustard plant, which having taken, a man cast into his own garden. And it grew and developed into a great tree,  the birds of the sky lodged in the branches if it.
Luke. And again he said, To what will I compare the kingdom of God?
Luke. It is like leaven that a woman having taken, hid in three measures of meal, until the whole was leavened.
Luke. And he went through by cities and villages, teaching,  making a journey toward Jerusalem.
Luke. And a certain man said to him, Lord, are they few who are being saved? And he said to them,
Luke. Compete to enter in by the narrow gate, because many, I say to you, will seek to enter in,  will not be able.
Luke. From the time the house-ruler has risen up,  has closed the door,  ye begin to stand outside,  to knock the door, saying, Lord, Lord, open to us,  having answered, he will say to you, I know not where ye are from,
Luke. then ye will begin to say, We ate and drank in thy presence,  thou taught in our thoroughfares.
Luke. And he will say, I tell you, I know not where ye are from. Depart from me, all ye workmen of unrighteousness.
Luke. There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth, when ye will see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God,  you being thrust out.
Luke. And they will arrive from the east and west,  from the north and south,  will sit down in the kingdom of God.
Luke. And behold, there are last who will be first,  there are first who will be last.
Luke. In the same day some Pharisees came, saying to him, Get thee out and depart from here, because Herod wants to kill thee.
Luke. And he said to them, Having gone, say to this fox, Behold, I cast out demons and finish cures today and tomorrow,  the third day I am fully perfected.
Luke. Nevertheless it is necessary for me to go today and tomorrow and the following, because it is not possible for a prophet to perish outside of Jerusalem.
Luke. O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, that kills the prophets,  stones those who are sent to her. How often I wanted to gather thy children together as a hen does her brood under her wings,  ye would not.
Luke. Behold, your house is left to you desolate. And I say to you, that ye will, no, not see me, until it will come when ye say, Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.
Luke. And it came to pass, when he went into the house of a certain man of the chiefs of the Pharisees on a sabbath to eat bread, that they were watching him.
Luke. And behold, there was a certain man in front of him afflicted with edema.
Luke. And having responded, Jesus spoke to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, Is it permitted to heal on the sabbath?
Luke. But they were silent. And having taken him, he healed him and released him.
Luke. And having responded, he said to them, Of which of you will a son or an ox fall into a pit,  he will not straightaway lift him out on the day of the sabbath?
Luke. And they could not answer him back to these things.
Luke. And he spoke a parable to those who were invited when he noticed how they chose out the chief places, saying to them,
Luke. When thou are invited by any man to wedding festivities, do not sit down in the chief place, lest there may be a more honorable man than thou who was invited by him.
Luke. And he who invited thee and him, having come, will say to thee, Give place to this man,  then thou will begin with embarrassment to take the last place.
Luke. But when thou are invited, having gone, sit down in the last place, so that when he who has invited thee comes, he will say to thee, Friend, go up higher, then it will be esteem to thee in the presence of those dining with thee.
Luke. Because every man who lifts himself up will be made lower,  he who makes himself lower will be lifted up.
Luke. And he also said to the man who invited him, When thou make a dinner or a supper, do not call thy friends, nor thy brothers, nor thy kinsmen, nor prosperous neighbors, lest they also invite thee in return,  a recompense be made to thee.
Luke. But when thou make a feast, call the poor, the maimed, the lame, the blind,
Luke. and thou will be blessed, because they do not have to recompense thee, for it will be recompensed to thee at the resurrection of the righteous.
Luke. And a certain man of those dining together having heard these things, he said to him, Blessed is he who will eat dinner in the kingdom of God.
Luke. And he said to him, A certain man made a great supper,  he invited many.
Luke. And he sent forth his bondman at the hour of the meal to say to those who were invited, Come, because all things are now ready.
Luke. And they all from one began to make excuse. The first said to him, I have bought a field,  I have need to go out and see it. I ask thee have me excused.
Luke. And another said, I bought five yoke of oxen,  I go to test them. I ask thee have me excused.
Luke. And another said, I married a wife,  because of this I cannot come.
Luke. And that bondman, having come, he informed his lord these things. Then the house-ruler having become angry, he said to his bondman, Go out quickly into the thoroughfares and lanes of the city,  bring here the poor and maimed and crippled and blind.
Luke. And the bondman said, Lord, as thou commanded it has happened,  yet there is room.
Luke. And the lord said to the bondman, Go out into the roads and hedges,  compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.
Luke. For I say to you, that none of those men who were invited will taste of my supper. For many are called,  few chosen.
Luke. Now many multitudes went with him,  having turned, he said to them,
Luke. If any man comes to me,  does not regard as inferior his father,  mother,  wife,  children,  brothers,  sisters,  besides his own life also, he cannot be my disciple.
Luke. And whoever does not bear his cross,  come behind me, cannot be my disciple.
Luke. For which of you wanting to build a tower, does not, having first sat down, count the cost whether he has the things for completion?
Luke. So that perhaps, having laid its foundation,  not being able to finish, all those who see begin to ridicule him,
Luke. saying, This man began to build,  was not able to finish.
Luke. Or what king going to encounter another king in war, will not, having first sat down, consult whether he is able with ten thousand to meet him who comes against him with twenty thousand?
Luke. And if not, while he is still far off, having sent a delegation, he asks the things about peace.
Luke. So therefore every man of you who does not renounce all things being possessed by him, cannot be my disciple.
Luke. The salt material is good,  if the salt material becomes tasteless, by what will it be seasoned?
Luke. It is fit neither for the land nor for manure; they cast it out. He who has ears to hear, let him hear.
Luke. Now all the tax collectors and sinners were approaching him to hear him.
Luke. And the Pharisees and the scholars murmured, saying, This man receives sinners and eats with them.
Luke. And he spoke this parable to them, saying,
Luke. What man of you, having a hundred sheep,  having lost one of them, does not leave behind the ninety-nine in the wilderness,  go for that which was lost until he finds it?
Luke. And when he finds it, he lays it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
Luke. And when he comes to the house, he calls together his men friends and his men neighbors, saying to them, Rejoice with me, because I have found my sheep that was lost.
Luke. I say to you, that thus there will be joy in heaven over one sinner who repents, than over ninety-nine righteous men who have no need of repentance.
Luke. Or what woman having ten drachmas, if she lose one drachma, does not light a lamp,  sweep the house,  seek diligently until she finds it?
Luke. And when she has found it, she calls together her lady friends and lady neighbors, saying, Rejoice with me, because I found the drachma that I lost.
Luke. Thus I say to you, there becomes joy in the presence of the agents of God over one sinner who repents.
Luke. And he said, A certain man had two sons,
Luke. and the younger of them said to his father, Father, give me the portion of goods that falls to me. And he divided to them his living.
Luke. And not many days after, the younger son, having gathered all together, journeyed into a distant country,  there he squandered his wealth living recklessly.
Luke. And when he spent all, a mighty famine developed in that country,  he began to be in want.
Luke. And having gone, he was joined to one of the citizens of that country,  he sent him into his fields to feed swine.
Luke. And he longed to fill his belly from the husks that the swine ate,  no man gave to him.
Luke. But when he came to himself, he said, How many hired men of my father's have abundance of loaves,  I am perishing with hunger.
Luke. After rising, I will go to my father,  will say to him, Father, I have sinned against heaven and in thy sight.
Luke. I am no more worthy to be called thy son. Make me as one of thy hired men.
Luke. And having risen, he went to his father. But while he was still distant, afar off, his father saw him and felt compassion. And having ran, he fell on his neck,  kissed him much.
Luke. And the son said to him, Father, I have sinned against heaven and in thy sight. I am no more worthy to be called thy son.
Luke. But the father said to his bondmen, Bring forth the best robe and clothe him,  give a ring for his hand,  shoes for his feet.
Luke. And having brought the fatted calf, kill it,  having eaten, we will be cheerful,
Luke. because this my son was dead,  became alive again. And he was lost,  is found. And they began to be cheerful.
Luke. But his elder son was in a field. And while coming, having approached the house, he heard music and dancing.
Luke. And having summoned one of the boys, he inquired what these things might be.
Luke. And he said to him, Thy brother arrived,  thy father has killed the fatted calf, because he received him back healthy.
Luke. But he was angry,  would not go in. Therefore, his father having come out, he called him.
Luke. But having answered, he said to his father, Lo, so many years do I serve thee,  I never passed by a commandment of thine,  yet thou never gave me a goat that I might be merry with my friends.
Luke. But when this thy son came, who has devoured thy living with harlots, thou killed for him the fatted calf.
Luke. And he said to him, Child, thou are always with me,  all my things are yours.
Luke. But it was needful to make merry and be glad, because this thy brother was dead,  became alive again,  was lost,  was found.
Luke. And he also said to his disciples, There was a certain rich man who had a manager,  this man was accused to him as squandering things possessed by him.
Luke. And having called him, he said to him, What is this I hear about thee? Render the account of thy management, for thou can no longer manage.
Luke. And the manager said within himself, What shall I do because my lord takes away the management from me? I am not able to dig. I am ashamed to beg.
Luke. I know what I will do, so that when I am removed from the management they may receive me into their houses.
Luke. And having summoned each one of his lord's debtors, he said to the first, How much do thou owe to my lord?
Luke. And he said, A hundred measures of olive oil. And he said to him, Receive thy document,  having sat down, quickly write fifty.
Luke. Next he said to another, And how much do thou owe? And he said, A hundred measures of wheat. And he says to him, Receive thy document,  write eighty.
Luke. And his lord commended the unrighteous manager because he did shrewdly. Because the sons of this age are shrewder in their own generation than the sons of the light.
Luke. And I say to you, make friends for yourselves from the mammon of unrighteousness, so that, when ye cease, they may receive you into the eternal dwellings.
Luke. The man faithful in the least is faithful also in much,  the man unrighteous in the least is unrighteous also in much.
Luke. If therefore ye did not become faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will entrust to you what is true?
Luke. And if ye did not become faithful in the alien, who will give thine to you?
Luke. No servant can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will hold to one and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Luke. And the Pharisees, being lovers of money, heard all these things,  they sneered him.
Luke. And he said to them, Ye are those who declare yourselves righteous in the sight of men,  God knows your hearts. Because what is lofty among men is an abomination in the sight of God.
Luke. The law and the prophets were until John. From that time the kingdom of God is proclaimed good news,  every man in it is treated aggressively.
Luke. But it is easier for the heaven and the earth to pass away, than for one tittle of the law to fall.
Luke. Every man who divorces his wife and marries another, commits adultery,  every man who marries her who has been divorced from a husband commits adultery.
Luke. Now there was a certain rich man,  he was clothed in purple and fine linen, faring sumptuously daily.
Luke. But there was a certain poor man named Lazarus, who had been placed near his gate, covered with sores,
Luke. and longing to be fed with the crumbs that fell from the rich man's table. But even the dogs that came licked his sores.
Luke. And it came to pass for the poor man to die and be carried by the agents to Abraham's bosom. And the rich man also died and was buried.
Luke. And having lifted up his eyes in Hades, being in torments, he sees Abraham from afar and Lazarus by his bosom.
Luke. And having cried out, he said, Father Abraham, be merciful to me,  send Lazarus, so that he may dip the tip of his finger in water,  cool my tongue, because I am in agony in this flame.
Luke. But Abraham said, Child, remember that thou in thy lifetime received thy good things,  likewise Lazarus evil things. But now here he is comforted and thou are in agony.
Luke. And besides all these things, between us and you a great chasm is fixed, so that those here who want to cross over to you are not able, nor may those go across from there to us.
Luke. And he said, I beg thee therefore, father, that thou would send him to my father's house,
Luke. for I have five brothers, that he may testify to them, lest they also come into this place of torment.
Luke. But Abraham says to him, They have Moses and the prophets. Let them hear them.
Luke. And he said, No, father Abraham,  if some man would go to them from the dead they will repent.
Luke. And he said to him, If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded if some man would rise from the dead.
Luke. And he said to his disciples, It is impossible for the stumbling-blocks not to come,  woe to him through whom they come!
Luke. It is better for him if a donkey-powered millstone were hanged about his neck,  he were thrown into the sea, than that he should cause one of these little ones to stumble.
Luke. Take heed to yourselves. And if thy brother should sin against thee, rebuke him,  if he repents, forgive him.
Luke. And if he should sin against thee seven times in the day,  seven times in the day turn back, saying, I repent, thou will forgive him.
Luke. And the apostles said to the Lord, Increase faith for us.
Luke. And the Lord said, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard plant, ye would say to this sycamine tree, Be thou uprooted and be planted in the sea,  it would have obeyed you.
Luke. But which of you having a bondman plowing or feeding livestock, who, when he comes in from the field, will straightaway say, After coming near, sit down?
Luke. Will he not rather say to him, Prepare what I may dine,  having gird thyself, serve me until I eat and drink,  after these things thou will eat and drink?
Luke. Does he have a favor for that bondman because he did the things that were commanded? I think not.
Luke. Thus ye also, when ye did all the things that were commanded you, say, We are unprofitable bondmen, because we have done what we are obligated to do.
Luke. And it came to pass as he went to Jerusalem, that he was passing through the middle of Samaria and Galilee.
Luke. And as he entered into a certain village, ten leprous men who stood from afar met him.
Luke. And they raised a voice, saying, Jesus, Master, be merciful to us.
Luke. And when he saw them, he said to them, After departing, display yourselves to the priests. And it came to pass, during their going they were cleansed.
Luke. And one of them, when he saw that he was healed, turned back with a great voice glorifying God.
Luke. And he fell upon his face beside his feet giving him thanks. And he was a Samaritan.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said, Were not the ten cleansed? But where are the nine?
Luke. Were there none found who returned to give glory to God, except this foreigner?
Luke. And he said to him, After rising, go. Thy faith has healed thee.
Luke. And questioned by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God comes, he answered them and said, The kingdom of God does not come with observation,
Luke. nor will they say, Lo, here! or, Lo, there! For behold, the kingdom of God is inside of you.
Luke. And he said to the disciples, The days will come when ye will long to see one of the days of the Son of man,  ye will not see it.
Luke. And they will say to you, Lo, here! Lo, there! Do not depart, nor pursue.
Luke. For just as the lightning, its flashing from under the sky to under the sky, illuminates, so will the Son of man be in his day.
Luke. But first it is necessary for him to suffer many things and be rejected from this generation.
Luke. And just as it happened in the days of Noah, so also it will be in the days of the Son of man.
Luke. They ate, they drank, they married, they were given in marriage, until the day that Noah entered into the ark,  the flood came and destroyed them all.
Luke. And likewise as it happened in the days of Lot. They ate, they drank, they bought, they sold, they planted, they built.
Luke. But in that day Lot went out from Sodom he rained fire and brimstone from the sky,  destroyed them all.
Luke. It will be according to these things in that day the Son of man is revealed.
Luke. In that day, he who will be on the housetop,  his vessels in the house, let him not go down to take them up. And let him who is in the field likewise not return for the things behind.
Luke. Remember Lot's wife.
Luke. Whoever will seek to save his life will lose it,  whoever will lose it will keep it alive.
Luke. I say to you, in that night there will be two in one bed. The one man will be taken,  the other man will be left.
Luke. Two will be grinding together. The one woman will be taken,  the other woman will be left.
Luke. This verse is not in the majority of the Greek manuscripts.
Luke. And having answered, they say to him, Where, Lord? And he said to them, Where the body is, there the vultures will be gathered together.
Luke. And he also spoke a parable to them about it being necessary to always pray,  not to give up,
Luke. saying, In a certain city there was a judge who did not fear God,  did not regard man.
Luke. And a widow was in that city,  she came to him, saying, Avenge me of my opponent.
Luke. And for a time he would not,  after these things he said within himself, Although I fear not God,  regard not man,
Luke. yet because this widow causes me a beating, I will avenge her, lest by no end of coming she give me a black eye.
Luke. And the Lord said, Hear ye what the unrighteous judge says.
Luke. And God, will he, no, not do the vengeance of his chosen who cry out to him day and night,  yet being patient toward them?
Luke. I say to you, that he will do their vengeance speedily. Nevertheless, when the Son of man comes, will he then find faith on the earth?
Luke. And he also spoke this parable to some of those who were persuaded in themselves that they were righteous,  disdained other men.
Luke. Two men went up into the temple to pray, the one a Pharisee,  the other a tax collector.
Luke. Having stood by himself, the Pharisee prayed these things: God, I thank thee that I am not as the rest of men, predatory, unjust, adulterers, or even as this tax collector.
Luke. I fast twice of the week. I tithe all things, as many as I acquire.
Luke. But the tax collector, having stood from afar, would not even lift his eyes to the sky,  beat upon his breast, saying, God, be thou merciful to me a sinful man.
Luke. I say to you, this man went down to his house justified rather than that man. Because every man who lifts himself up will be made lower,  he who makes himself lower will be lifted up.
Luke. And they were also bringing the infants to him, so that he would touch them,  when the disciples saw it, they rebuked them.
Luke. But having summoned them, Jesus said, Allow the children to come to me,  do not forbid them, for of such is the kingdom of God.
Luke. Truly I say to you, whoever will not receive the kingdom of God as a child, will, no, not enter into it.
Luke. And a certain ruler questioned him, saying, Good teacher, having done what, will I inherit eternal life?
Luke. And Jesus said to him, Why do thou call me good? None is good except one, God.
Luke. Thou know the commandments. Thou shall not commit adultery. Thou shall not murder. Thou shall not steal. Thou shall not give false testimony. Honor thy father and thy mother.
Luke. And he said, All these things I have kept from my youth.
Luke. And when he heard these things, Jesus said to him, Yet one thing is lacking from thee. Sell all things, as many as thou have,  distribute to the poor,  thou will have treasure in heaven. And come, follow me.
Luke. But when he heard these things, he became very sorrowful, for he was very rich.
Luke. And having seen him become very sorrowful, Jesus said, How difficultly those who have riches will enter into the kingdom of God.
Luke. For it is easier for a camel to enter in through the hole of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
Luke. And those who heard it said, And who can be saved?
Luke. And he said, The things impossible with men are possible with God.
Luke. And Peter said, Lo, we have left all and followed thee.
Luke. And he said to them, Truly I say to you, that there is no man who has left house, or parents, or brothers, or wife, or children for the sake of the kingdom of God,
Luke. who will, no, not receive back manifold more in this time,  in the coming age eternal life.
Luke. And having taken along the twelve, he said to them, Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem,  all the things that are written through the prophets about the Son of man will be completed.
Luke. For he will be delivered up to the Gentiles,  he will be mocked and insulted and spit upon.
Luke. And after scourging, they will kill him,  the third day he will rise up.
Luke. And they understood none of these things,  this saying was hidden from them,  they did not understand the things that were said.
Luke. And it came to pass as he approached Jericho, a certain blind man sat beside the road begging.
Luke. And having heard a multitude going by, he inquired what this may be.
Luke. And they informed him that Jesus the Nazarene passes by.
Luke. And he cried out, saying, Jesus, thou son of David, be merciful to me.
Luke. And those who went ahead rebuked him, so that he would be quiet,  he cried out much more, Thou son of David, be merciful to me.
Luke. And having stood still, Jesus commanded him to be brought to him. And when he came near, he questioned him,
Luke. saying, What do thou that I would do to thee? And he said, Lord, that I may receive sight.
Luke. And Jesus said to him, Receive sight. Thy faith has healed thee.
Luke. And immediately he received sight,  followed him glorifying God. And all the people when they saw it gave praise to God.
Luke. And having entered, he was passing through Jericho.
Luke. And behold, a man called by name, Zacchaeus. And he was a chief tax collector,  this man was rich.
Luke. And he sought to see Jesus, who he was. And he was not able because of the crowd, because his stature was small.
Luke. And having ran ahead, he climbed up in a sycamore tree so that he might see him, because he was going to pass that one.
Luke. And when Jesus came to the place, having looked up, he saw him,  said to him, Zacchaeus, after making haste, come down, for today I must lodge at thy house.
Luke. And having made haste, he came down and received him, rejoicing.
Luke. And all who saw murmured, saying, He went in to relax with a sinful man.
Luke. And having stood, Zacchaeus said to the Lord, Behold, half of the things possessed by me, Lord, I give to the poor. And if I defrauded any man of anything, I repay fourfold.
Luke. And Jesus said to him, Today salvation has come to this house, forasmuch as he also is a son of Abraham.
Luke. For the Son of man came to seek and to save that which was lost.
Luke. And as they heard these things, he spoke, adding on a parable because he was near Jerusalem,  because they thought that the kingdom of God was going to appear immediately.
Luke. He said therefore, A certain nobleman went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom,  to return.
Luke. And having called ten of his bondmen, he gave them ten minas and said to them, Do business until I come.
Luke. But his citizens hated him,  sent an embassy behind him, saying, We do not want this man to reign over us.
Luke. And it came to pass for him to return, having taken the kingdom. And he said for these bondmen to be called to him, to whom he gave the silver, so that he might know what any man gained by trading.
Luke. And the first came, saying, Lord, thy mina gained ten minas.
Luke. And he said to him, Well, thou good bondman. Because thou became faithful in the least, be thou having authority over ten cities.
Luke. And the second came, saying, Lord, thy mina gained five minas.
Luke. And he also said to him, And thou become over five cities.
Luke. And another came, saying, Lord, behold thy mina, which I had put away in a napkin.
Luke. For I was afraid of thee because thou are an austere man. Thou take up what thou did not lay down,  reap what thou did not sow.
Luke. He says to him, Out of thy mouth I will judge thee, thou evil bondman. Thou had known that I am an austere man taking up what I did not lay down,  reaping what I did not sow.
Luke. Then why did thou not give my silver into a bank,  having come I would have collected it with interest?
Luke. And he said to those who stood by, Take the mina from him,  give it to him who has the ten minas.
Luke. And they said to him, Lord, he has ten minas.
Luke. For I say to you, that to every man who has, will be given,  from him who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him.
Luke. Nevertheless those enemies of mine who did not want me to reign over them, bring here,  kill them before me.
Luke. And having spoke these things, he went ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
Luke. And it came to pass when he came near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount that is called Olives, he sent two of his disciples, saying,
Luke. Go ye into the opposite village, in which, having entered, ye will find a colt tied, on which no man ever sat. Having untied, bring it.
Luke. And if any man asks you, Why do ye untie it? Thus ye will say to him, The Lord has need of it.
Luke. And having departed, those who were sent found just as he said to them.
Luke. And as they were untying the colt, the masters of it said to them, Why do ye untie the colt?
Luke. And they said, The Lord has need of it.
Luke. And they brought it to Jesus. And having cast their garments upon the colt, they mounted Jesus.
Luke. And as he went, they spread their garments on the road.
Luke. And as he was now coming near, at the descent of the mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples began rejoicing to praise God in a great voice about all the mighty works that they had seen, saying,
Luke. Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven,  glory in the highest!
Luke. And some of the Pharisees from the multitude said to him, Teacher, rebuke thy disciples.
Luke. And having answered, he said to them, I tell you that if these were silent, the stones would cry out.
Luke. And when he came near, having seen the city, he wept over it,
Luke. saying, If thou knew, even thou, indeed even in this thy day, the things for thy peace. But now they are hidden from thine eyes.
Luke. Because the days will come upon thee,  thine enemies will build a barricade around thee,  will surround thee,  enclose thee on every side.
Luke. And they will raze thee and thy children within thee. And they will not leave in thee a stone upon a stone, because thou knew not the time of thy visitation.
Luke. And having entered into the temple, he began to cast out those selling and buying in it,
Luke. saying to them, It is written, My house is a house of prayer,  ye made it a den of robbers.
Luke. And he was teaching daily in the temple. But the chief priests,  the scholars sought to destroy him, even the foremost men of the people.
Luke. And they did not find what they might do, for the people all hung upon him, listening.
Luke. And it came to pass on one of those days, as he was teaching the people in the temple,  preaching the good news, the chief priests and the scholars with the elders stood near.
Luke. And they spoke, saying to him, Tell us, by what authority are thou doing these things? Or who is he who gave thee this authority?
Luke. And having answered, he said to them, I also will ask you one word,  ye tell me.
Luke. The immersion of John, was it from heaven or from men?
Luke. And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we should say, From heaven, he will say, Why did ye not believe him?
Luke. But if we say, From men, all the people will stone us, for they are convinced John is a prophet.
Luke. And they replied not to know from where.
Luke. And Jesus said to them, Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
Luke. And he began to speak this parable to the people. A man planted a vineyard,  leased it to farmers,  went abroad for a considerable time.
Luke. And at the season he sent a bondman to the farmers, so that they would give him from the fruit of the vineyard. But having beaten him, the farmers sent him away empty.
Luke. And he proceeded to send another bondman. And they, having beaten and shamefully treated, sent him also away empty.
Luke. And he proceeded to send a third. And they also having wounded this man, cast him out.
Luke. And the lord of the vineyard said, What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Perhaps they will be made ashamed after seeing this man.
Luke. But when the farmers saw him, they deliberated among themselves, saying, This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, so that the inheritance may become ours.
Luke. And having cast him outside of the vineyard, they killed him. What therefore will the lord of the vineyard do to them?
Luke. He will come and destroy these farmers,  will give the vineyard to others. And having heard it, they said, May it not happen!
Luke. But having looked upon them, he said, What then is this that is written, The stone that those who build rejected, this became the head of the corner?
Luke. Every man who falls on that stone will be broken,  on whomever it may fall, it will grind him to dust.
Luke. And the chief priests and the scholars sought to throw hands on him in the same hour. And they were afraid, for they knew that he spoke this parable against them.
Luke. And having watched him, they sent forth insidious men pretending themselves to be righteous, so that they might take hold of his word, in order to deliver him up to the rule and to the authority of the governor.
Luke. And they questioned him, saying, Teacher, we know that thou speak and teach rightly,  thou do not accept a personage,  teach the way of God in truth,
Luke. Is it permitted for us to give tribute to Caesar or not?
Luke. But having perceived their craftiness, he said to them, Why do ye try me?
Luke. Display to me a denarius. Whose image and inscription has it? And having answered, they said, Caesar's.
Luke. And he said to them, Then render the things of Caesar to Caesar,  the things of God to God.
Luke. And they were unable to lay hold of his word before the people. And having marveled at his answer, they were silent.
Luke. And some of the Sadducees having approached, those who say there is no resurrection, they questioned him,
Luke. saying, Teacher, Moses wrote to us, if any brother dies, having a wife,  this man dies childless, that his brother should take his wife,  raise up seed to his brother.
Luke. There were therefore seven brothers. And the first having taken a wife, died childless.
Luke. And the second took the woman,  this man died childless.
Luke. And the third likewise took her,  likewise also the seven; they left behind no children,  died.
Luke. And last of all the woman also died.
Luke. In the resurrection therefore whose wife of them does she become? For the seven had her as wife.
Luke. And having answered, Jesus said to them, The sons of this age marry,  are given in marriage,
Luke. but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age,  the resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage.
Luke. For neither can they die any more, for they are like the agents,  are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.
Luke. But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed at the Bush when he calls the Lord, the God of Abraham,  the God of Isaac,  the God of Jacob.
Luke. Now he is not God of the dead,  of the living, for all live to him.
Luke. And some of the scholars having answered, they said, Teacher, thou said well.
Luke. For they no longer dared to question him anything.
Luke. And he said to them, How do they say the Christ is David's son?
Luke. Even David himself says in the book of Psalms, The Lord said to my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand,
Luke. until I will place thine enemies a footstool of thy feet.
Luke. David therefore calls him Lord,  how is he his son?
Luke. And while all the people were listening, he said to his disciples,
Luke. Beware of the scholars, who desire to walk around in long robes,  love greetings in the marketplaces,  chief seats in the synagogues,  places of honor at the feasts,
Luke. who devour widows' houses,  in pretence make long prayers. These will receive greater damnation.
Luke. And having looked up, he saw the rich casting their gifts into the treasury.
Luke. And he also saw a certain poor widow there casting in two mites.
Luke. And he said, Truly I say to you, that this poor widow cast in more than they all.
Luke. For all these cast into the offerings of God from their abundance,  this woman from her poverty cast in all the living that she had.
Luke. And as some spoke about the temple, that it was adorned with fine stones and gifts, he said,
Luke. These things that ye see, the days will come during which there will not be left a stone upon a stone that will not be thrown down.
Luke. And they questioned him, saying, Teacher, when therefore will these things be? And what is the sign when these things are going to happen?
Luke. And he said, Watch that ye may not be led astray, for many will come in my name, saying, I am, , The time has come near. Go ye not therefore after them.
Luke. And when ye may hear of wars and tumults, do not be alarmed, for these things must first happen,  the end is not straightaway.
Luke. Then he said to them, Nation will rise against nation,  kingdom against kingdom.
Luke. And great earthquakes will be in various places,  famines and plagues. And there will be fearful sights and great signs from the sky.
Luke. But before all these things, they will throw their hands on you,  will persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons, being brought before kings and rulers for my name's sake.
Luke. But it will go out from you for testimony.
Luke. Settle therefore in your hearts not to premeditate to make defense.
Luke. For I will give you a mouth and wisdom that all those who oppose you will not be able to contradict or to resist.
Luke. And ye will be betrayed even by parents,  kinsmen,  friends,  brothers. And some of you they will condemn to death.
Luke. And ye will be hated by all men because of my name.
Luke. And, no, not a hair of your head will perish.
Luke. In your perseverance ye gain your souls.
Luke. But when ye see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then know that the desolation of it has come near.
Luke. Then let those in Judea flee to the mountains,  let those in the midst of it depart out,  let not those in the rural areas enter into it.
Luke. Because these are days of vengeance to fulfill all things that are written.
Luke. But woe to those who have in the womb,  to those who suckle in those days. For there will be great distress upon the land,  wrath to this people.
Luke. And they will fall by the jaw of the sword,  will be led away captive into all the nations. And Jerusalem will be trampled down by the Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.
Luke. And there will be signs in sun and moon and stars,  upon the earth distress of nations, with perplexity, roaring of sea and of tossing,
Luke. fainting of men from fear,  of anticipation of the things coming upon the world, for the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
Luke. And then they will see the Son of man coming in a cloud with power and much glory.
Luke. And when these things begin to happen, stand upright,  lift up your heads, because your redemption approaches.
Luke. And he spoke a parable to them. Behold the fig tree,  all the trees.
Luke. When they are now sprouting, ye know seeing for yourselves that summer is now near.
Luke. Even so ye, when ye see these things happening, know ye that the kingdom of God is near.
Luke. Truly I say to you, that this generation will, no, not pass away until all things happen.
Luke. The sky and the earth will pass away,  my words may, no, not pass away.
Luke. But take heed to yourselves, lest your hearts be weighed down in debauchery and drunkenness and mundane cares,  that day come upon you sudden.
Luke. For it will come like a trap upon all those who sit upon the face of all the earth.
Luke. Watch ye therefore, making supplication at all times, so that ye may be considered worthy to escape all these things going to happen,  to stand before the Son of man.
Luke. And during the days he was teaching in the temple,  going forth the nights, he lodged on the mount that is called Olives.
Luke. And all the people rose early in the morning to him in the temple to hear him.
Luke. Now the feast of unleavened bread was coming near, which is called Passover.
Luke. And the chief priests and the scholars sought how they might kill him, for they feared the people.
Luke. And Satan entered into Judas who was called Iscariot, being of the number of the twelve.
Luke. And having departed, he conversed with the chief priests and captains, how he might betray him to them.
Luke. And they were glad,  agreed together to give him silver.
Luke. And he consented and sought opportunity to betray him to them apart from the multitude.
Luke. And the day of unleavened bread came during which it was necessary to kill the Passover.
Luke. And he sent Peter and John, saying, After departing, prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat.
Luke. And they said to him, Where do thou want that we should prepare?
Luke. And he said to them, Behold, having entered into the city, a man will meet you carrying a pitcher of water. Follow him into the house where he enters.
Luke. And ye shall say to the house-ruler, The teacher says to thee, Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?
Luke. And he will show you a large upper room furnished. Prepare there.
Luke. And having gone, they found just as he said to them,  they prepared the Passover.
Luke. And when the hour came, he sat down,  the twelve apostles with him.
Luke. And he said to them, With desire I have desired to eat this Passover with you before my suffering.
