Luke. For I say to you, that I will eat of it no more, no, not till when it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.
Luke. And having taken a cup, having expressed thanks, he said, Take this,  divide it among yourselves.
Luke. For I say to you, that I will, no, not drink from the fruit of the grapevine till when the kingdom of God comes.
Luke. And after taking bread, having expressed thanks, he broke in pieces,  gave to them, saying, This is my body that is given for you. Do ye this in my memory.
Luke. Likewise also the cup after dining, saying, This cup is the new covenant in my blood being shed for you.
Luke. Nevertheless behold, the hand of the man who betrays me is with me on the table.
Luke. And the Son of man indeed goes according to that which has been determined, nevertheless woe to that man through whom he is betrayed!
Luke. And they began to question among themselves who then of them would be going do this thing.
Luke. And also a dispute develop among them, which of them is considered to be greater.
Luke. And he said to them, The kings of the Gentiles have dominion over them,  those who exercise authority over them are called Benefactors.
Luke. But ye are not this way. Rather, the greater among you, shall become as the newer,  he who leads, as he who serves.
Luke. For who ranks higher, he who sits dining, or he who serves? Is it not he who sits dining? But I am in the midst of you as he who serves.
Luke. But ye are those who have continued with me in my trials.
Luke. And I appoint to you, just as my Father appointed to me a kingdom,
Luke. that ye may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom,  sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
Luke. And the Lord said, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan demanded to have you to sift you as wheat,
Luke. but I prayed for thee, so that thy faith may not fail. And thou, when thou have returned, strengthen thy brothers.
Luke. And he said to him, Lord, I am ready to go with thee both to prison and to death.
Luke. And he said, I say to thee, Peter, a cock will, no, not sound today, before thou will thrice deny that thou know me.
Luke. And he said to them, When I sent you without bag and pouch and shoes, did ye lack anything? And they said, Nothing.
Luke. Then he said to them, But now, he who has a bag, let him take it,  likewise a pouch. And he who has no sword, let him sell his cloak and buy.
Luke. For I say to you, that this that is written is still necessary to be completed in me, And he was counted with lawless men, for these things about me also have fulfillment.
Luke. And they said, Lord, behold, here are two swords. And he said to them, It is enough.
Luke. And having come out, he proceeded according to his habit to the mount of Olives,  his disciples also followed him.
Luke. And when he came at the place, he said to them, Pray ye not to enter into temptation.
Luke. And he was withdrawn from them about a stone's throw. And he knelt down and prayed,
Luke. saying, Father, if thou want, remove this cup from me. Nevertheless not my will,  thine be done.
Luke. And an agent from heaven appeared to him, strengthening him.
Luke. And having become in agony he prayed more intensely,  his sweat became like drops of blood falling down to the ground.
Luke. And after rising up from his prayer, having come to the disciples, he found them sleeping from sorrow.
Luke. And said to them, Why sleep ye? Having risen, pray that ye may not enter into temptation.
Luke. While he yet spoke, behold, a multitude,  the man called Judas, one of the twelve, went before them. And he came near to Jesus to kiss him.
Luke. But Jesus said to him, Judas, thou betray the Son of man with a kiss?
Luke. And when those who were around him saw what would be, they said, Lord, shall we strike with the sword?
Luke. And a certain one of them struck the bondman of the high priest,  cut off his right ear.
Luke. But having answered, Jesus said, Allow ye as far as this. And having touched his ear, he healed him.
Luke. And Jesus said to the chief priests,  captains of the temple,  elders, who came to him, Have ye come out, as against a robber, with swords and clubs?
Luke. When I was with you daily in the temple, ye did not stretch forth hands against me. But this is your hour,  the power of darkness.
Luke. And having seized him, they led him,  brought him into the high priest's house. But Peter followed from afar.
Luke. And having kindled a fire in the midst of the court,  having sat down together, Peter sat in the midst of them.
Luke. But a certain servant girl having seen him sitting near the light,  having looked intently upon him, she said, This man was also with him.
Luke. But he denied him, saying, Woman, I do not know him.
Luke. And after a little while, another man having see him, said, Thou also are from them. And Peter said, Man, I am not.
Luke. And about one hour having passed, some other man insisted, saying, In truth this man was also with him, for he is also a Galilean.
Luke. And Peter said, Man, I do not know what thou are saying. And immediately, while he still spoke, a cock sounded.
Luke. And having turned, the Lord looked on Peter. And Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he said to him, Before a cock sounds thou will deny me thrice.
Luke. And having gone outside, Peter wept bitterly.
Luke. And the men who held Jesus mocked him, while striking him.
Luke. And having covered him, they struck his face,  demanded him, saying, Prophesy! Who is he who struck thee?
Luke. And they spoke many other things against him, railing against him.
Luke. And when it became day, the eldership of the people, the chief priests,  the scholars, came together,  led him into their council, saying,
Luke. If thou are the Christ, tell us. And he said to them, If I tell you, ye will not believe,
Luke. and if I also ask, ye will, no, not answer nor release.
Luke. From henceforth the Son of man will be sitting at the right hand of the power of God.
Luke. And they all said, Therefore thou are the Son of God? And he said to them, Ye say that I am.
Luke. And they said, What further need have we of testimony? For we have heard from his mouth.
Luke. And having risen, the whole company of them led him to Pilate.
Luke. And they began to accuse him, saying, We found this man perverting the nation,  forbidding to give tribute to Caesar, saying himself to be Christ, a king.
Luke. And Pilate questioned him, saying, Are thou the king of the Jews? And having answered him, he said, Thou say.
Luke. And Pilate said to the chief priests and the multitudes, I find nothing guilty in this man.
Luke. But they were emphatic, saying, He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, having begun from Galilee as far as here.
Luke. And when Pilate heard Galilee, he questioned if the man is a Galilean.
Luke. And when he perceived that he is from Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who was himself also in Jerusalem in these days.
Luke. Now when Herod saw Jesus, he was exceedingly glad, for he was wanting of a considerable time to see him, because of hearing many things about him,  he hoped to see some sign happening by him.
Luke. And he interrogated him in considerable words,  he answered him nothing.
Luke. And the chief priests and the scholars had stood, vehemently accusing him.
Luke. But Herod having disdained him with his soldiers,  having mocked him, having arraying him in a bright robe, he sent him back to Pilate.
Luke. And both Pilate and Herod became friends with each other on the same day, for they were formerly being at enmity toward themselves.
Luke. And Pilate having called together the chief priests,  the rulers,  the people,
Luke. said to them, Ye brought this man to me as turning away the people. And behold, I, having examined him before you, found nothing guilty in this man of what ye accuse against him.
Luke. But not even Herod, for I sent you back to him,  lo, nothing having been done by him is worthy of death.
Luke. Therefore, having scourged I will release him.
Luke. Now he had need to release one man to them at every feast.
Luke. But they cried out all together, saying, Take away this man,  release to us Barabbas
Luke. (a man who was cast into prison because of a certain insurrection that occurred in the city,  for murder).
Luke. Again therefore Pilate called out wanting to release Jesus,
Luke. but they shouted, saying, Crucify, crucify him.
Luke. And he said to them a third time, For what evil did this man do? I have found nothing guilty of death in him. I will therefore, having scourged, release him.
Luke. But they were relentless with loud voices demanding him to be crucified. And their voices and those of the chief priests prevailed.
Luke. And Pilate decreed their request to happen.
Luke. And he released the man who had been cast into prison because of insurrection and murder, whom they asked for,  he delivered Jesus to their will.
Luke. And when they led him away, having taken hold of a certain Simon, a Cyrenian coming from the countryside, they laid the cross on him to bring behind Jesus.
Luke. And a great multitude of the people followed him,  also of women who bewailed and lamented him.
Luke. But having turning to them, Jesus said, Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for me, instead weep for yourselves and for your children.
Luke. Because, behold, the days are coming, during which they will say, Blessed are the barren,  the bellies that gave no birth,  the breasts that did not suckle.
Luke. Then they will begin to say to the mountains, Fall on us,  to the hills, Cover us.
Luke. Because if they do these things in the green tree, what will happen in the dry?
Luke. And two other men, malefactors, were also led with him to be executed.
Luke. And when they came to the place called Skull, there they crucified him,  the malefactors, one at the right hand and the other at the left.
Luke. And Jesus said, Father, forgive them, for they know not what they are doing. And dividing his garments, they cast a lot.
Luke. And the people had stood watching. And also the rulers with them sneered, saying, He saved others. He should save himself, if this is the Christ, the chosen of God.
Luke. And the soldiers also mocked him, approaching,  bringing him vinegar,
Luke. and saying, If thou are the king of the Jews, save thyself.
Luke. And there was also an inscription over him written in letters, in Greek and Latin and Hebrew: THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Luke. And one of the malefactors who were hanged railed him, saying, If thou are the Christ, save thyself and us.
Luke. But the other man having answered, rebuking him, saying, Thou fear not even God, since thou are in the same condemnation?
Luke. And we indeed justly, for we receive worthy of what we did,  this man did nothing amiss.
Luke. And he said to Jesus, Remember me, Lord, when thou come into thy kingdom.
Luke. And Jesus said to him, Truly I say to thee, today thou will be with me in the paradise.
Luke. And it was about the sixth hour,  darkness occurred over the whole land until the ninth hour.
Luke. And the sun was darkened,  the curtain of the temple was torn in the middle.
Luke. And Jesus, having sounded out in a great voice, said, Father, into thy hands I entrust my spirit. And having said these things, he expired.
Luke. And when the centurion saw that which happened, he glorified God, saying, Certainly this man was righteous.
Luke. And all the multitudes who came together to this scene, watching that which happened, turned back, beating their breasts.
Luke. And all his acquaintances,  the women who accompanied him from Galilee, had stood from afar, seeing these things.
Luke. And behold a man named Joseph, a council member, being a good and righteous man
Luke. (this man not having consented to their purpose and deed), was from Arimathaea, a city of the Jews, who also himself awaited the kingdom of God.
Luke. This man having gone to Pilate, requested the body of Jesus.
Luke. And having taken it down, he wrapped it in linen,  laid it in a sepulcher cut in rock, of which no man was yet lain.
Luke. And the day was Preparation; sabbath was beginning.
Luke. And having followed closely, the women who were gathered to him out of Galilee, they saw the sepulcher,  how his body was laid.
Luke. And having returned, they prepared spices and ointments. And they indeed rested on the sabbath according to the commandment.
Luke. And on the first day of the week, very early morning, they came to the sepulcher bringing the spices that they prepared,  some women with them.
Luke. And they found the stone rolled away from the sepulcher.
Luke. And having entered in, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
Luke. And it came to pass while they were bewildered about this, that behold, two men stood near them in shining apparel.
Luke. And since they became frightened and bowing down their face to the ground, they said to them, Why seek ye the living among the dead?
Luke. He is not here,  was raised. Remember how he spoke to you when he was still in Galilee,
Luke. saying that the Son of man must be delivered up into the hands of sinful men,  be crucified,  the third day to rise.
Luke. And they remembered his sayings.
Luke. And having returned from the sepulcher, they reported all these things to the eleven,  to all the others.
Luke. Now they were Mary Magdalene,  Joanna,  Mary the mother of James,  the other women with them who told these things to the apostles.
Luke. And their sayings appeared before them as idle talk,  they disbelieved them.
Luke. But having risen, Peter ran to the sepulcher. And having stooped down, he sees the linen cloths laying alone. And he departed, wondering to himself at that which happened.
Luke. And behold, two of them were going the same day to a village that was sixty furlongs away from Jerusalem, which name was Emmaus.
Luke. And they conversed with each other about all these things that happened.
Luke. And it came to pass, while they conversed and discussed, that Jesus himself also having approached, went along with them.
Luke. But their eyes were held, not to recognize him.
Luke. And he said to them, What are these words that ye toss back to each other, while walking and are looking sad.
Luke. And one, whose name was Cleopas, having answered, said to him, Thou only visit Jerusalem and do not know the things that happened in it during these days?
Luke. And he said to them, What? And they said to him, The things about Jesus the Nazarene, who became a prophet, a mighty man in work and word before God and all the people,
Luke. and how our chief priests and rulers delivered him up for condemnation of death,  crucified him.
Luke. But we hoped that he is the man who is going to redeem Israel. But even with all these things, it brings this third day today from which time these things happened.
Luke. But also some of our women astonished us, having come to be at the sepulcher early morning.
Luke. And not having found his body, they came, saying also to have seen a vision of agents who say he is alive.
Luke. And some of those with us went to the sepulcher,  found it this way, just as also the women said,  they did not see him.
Luke. And he said to them, O foolish men,  slow of heart to believe in all that the prophets spoke.
Luke. Was it not necessary for the Christ to suffer these things,  to enter into his glory?
Luke. And having begun from Moses and from all the prophets, he expounded to them in all the scriptures the things about himself.
Luke. And they came near to the village where they were going,  he pretended to go further.
Luke. And they constrained him, saying, Remain with us, because it is toward evening,  the day has declined. And he went in to remain with them.
Luke. And it came to pass during his dining with them, that, having taken the bread, he blessed,  having broken in pieces he gave to them.
Luke. And their eyes were opened,  they recognized him. And he became invisible from them.
Luke. And they said to each other, Was not our heart burning within us while he spoke to us on the way, while he opened to us the scriptures?
Luke. And having risen up the same hour, they returned to Jerusalem. And they found the eleven gathered together,
Luke. and those who were with them who said, The Lord really was raised,  was seen by Simon.
Luke. And they reported the things on the road,  how he was made known to them during the breaking of the bread.
Luke. And as they spoke these things, Jesus himself stood in the midst of them,  says to them, Peace to you.
Luke. But having been startled,  having become frightened, they presumed to see a spirit.
Luke. And he said to them, Why are ye troubled,  why do thoughts arise in your hearts?
Luke. See my hands and my feet, that it is I myself. Handle me and see, because a spirit does not have flesh and bones, as ye see me having.
Luke. And having said this, he displayed to them his hands and feet.
Luke. And while they still disbelieved from joy and wondering, he said to them, Have ye anything to eat here?
Luke. And they gave him a piece of a broiled fish and from a bees honeycomb.
Luke. And having taken it, he ate before them.
Luke. And he said to them, These are the words that I spoke to you while still being with you, that it is necessary for all things that are written in the law of Moses,  the prophets,  the psalms about me to be fulfilled.
Luke. Then he opened their mind to understand the scriptures.
Luke. And he said to them, Thus it is written,  thus it was necessary for the Christ to suffer,  to rise from the dead the third day,
Luke. and to proclaim in his name repentance and remission of sins for all the nations, having begun from Jerusalem.
Luke. And ye are witnesses of these things.
Luke. And behold, I send forth the promise of my Father upon you. But stay ye in the city until ye are clothed with power from on high.
Luke. And he led them outside as far as to Bethany,  having lifted up his hands, he blessed them.
Luke. And it came to pass while he blessed them, he parted from them,  was brought up into heaven.
Luke. And having worshiping him, they returned to Jerusalem with great joy,
Luke. and they were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God. Truly.
John
John. In the beginning was the Word,  the Word was with God,  the Word was God.
John. This man was in the beginning with God.
John. All things came to be through him,  apart from him not even one thing came to be that has come to be.
John. In him was life,  the life was the light of men.
John. And the light shines in the darkness,  the darkness did not comprehend it.
John. A man came to be who was sent from God, his name was John.
John. This man came for testimony so that he might testify about the light, so that all might believe through him.
John. That man was not the light,  that he might testify about the light.
John. He was the true light coming into the world that enlightens every man.
John. He was in the world,  the world came to be through him,  the world knew him not.
John. He came to his own,  his own did not accept him.
John. But as many as did accept him, to them he gave power to become children of God, to those who believe in his name,
John. who were begotten, not from blood, nor from a will of flesh, nor from a will of man,  from God.
John. And the Word became flesh,  dwelt among us. And we beheld his glory, glory as of the only begotten from the Father, full of grace and truth.
John. John testified about him,  cried out, saying, This was he of whom I said, He who comes after me came to be before me, because he was before me.
John. And from his fullness we all received, even grace for grace.
John. Because the law was given through Moses. Grace and truth came to be through Jesus Christ.
John. No man has ever seen God. The only begotten Son, being in the bosom of the Father, that man reported him.
John. And this is the testimony of John when the Jews sent forth priests and Levites from Jerusalem so that they might ask him, Who are thou?
John. And he confessed,  did not deny,  confessed, I am not the Christ.
John. And they asked him, What therefore, are thou Elijah? And he says, I am not. Are thou the prophet? And he answered, No.
John. They said therefore to him, Who are thou, so that we may give an answer to those who sent us? What do thou say about thyself?
John. He said, I am the voice of a man crying out in the wilderness: Make straight the way of the Lord, just as the prophet Isaiah said.
John. And those who were sent were from the Pharisees.
John. And they asked him,  said to him, Why therefore do thou immerse if thou are not the Christ nor Elijah nor the prophet?
John. John answered them, saying, I immerse in water,  amidst you stands him whom ye know not.
John. He is the man who comes after me, who has become before me, of whom I am not worthy that I might loosen the strap of his shoe.
John. These things occurred in Bethany beyond the Jordan where John was immersing.
John. On the morrow John sees Jesus coming to him,  he says, Behold, the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world!
John. This is he about whom I said, After me comes a man who has become before me, because he was before me.
John. And I had not known him,  that he would be made known to Israel. Because of this I came immersing in water.
John. And John testified, saying, I have seen the Spirit descending like a dove out of heaven,  it remained upon him.
John. And I had not known him. But he who sent me to immerse in water, he said to me, Upon whomever thou will see the Spirit descending and remaining on him, this is he who immerses in the Holy Spirit.
John. And I have seen and have testified that this is the Son of God.
John. Again on the morrow John stood,  two of his disciples.
John. And having looked upon Jesus walking, he says, Behold, the Lamb of God!
John. And the two disciples heard him speaking,  they followed Jesus.
John. And Jesus having turned,  having seen them following, says to them, What seek ye? And they said to him, Rabbi (which says, being interpreted, Teacher), where do thou dwell?
John. He says to them, Come and see. They came and saw where he dwelt,  remained with him that day. It was about the tenth hour.
John. Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, was one of the two who heard from John and who followed him.
John. This man first finds his own brother Simon,  says to him, We have found the Messiah (which is, being interpreted, Christ).
John. And he brought him to Jesus. And having seen him, Jesus said, Thou are Simon the son of Jonah. Thou will be called Cephas (which is interpreted, Peter).
John. On the morrow he wanted to go forth into Galilee,  he finds Philip. And Jesus says to him, Follow me.
John. Now Philip was from Bethsaida, of the city of Andrew and Peter.
John. Philip finds Nathanael,  says to him, We have found him of whom Moses in the law,  the prophets wrote: Jesus the son of Joseph of Nazareth.
John. And Nathanael said to him, What good can be from Nazareth? Philip says to him, Come and see.
John. Jesus saw Nathanael coming to him,  says about him, Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom is no deceit.
John. Nathanael says to him, How do thou know me? Jesus answered and said to him, Before Philip called thee, being under the fig tree, I saw thee.
John. Nathanael answered,  says to him, Rabbi, thou are the Son of God. Thou are the king of Israel.
John. Jesus answered and said to him, Because I said to thee, I saw thee under the fig tree, thou believe? Thou will see greater than these things.
John. And he says to him, Truly, truly, I say to you, henceforth ye will see the heaven opened,  the agents of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man.
John. And the third day a wedding occurred in Cana of Galilee,  the mother of Jesus was there.
John. And Jesus also was invited,  his disciples, to the wedding.
John. And having lacked wine the mother of Jesus says to him, They have no wine.
John. And Jesus says to her, What is with me and with thee, woman? My hour is not yet here.
John. His mother says to the helpers, Whatever he may say to you, do.
John. Now there were six stone water pots laying there in accordance with the purification of the Jews, containing two or three measures each.
John. Jesus says to them, Fill the water pots with water. And they filled them until over.
John. And he says to them, Draw out now,  carry to the feast-ruler. And they carried.
John. And when the feast-ruler tasted the water that became wine,  had not known from where it was (but the helpers who drew the water had known), the feast-ruler called the bridegroom,
John. and says to him, Every man sets out the good wine first,  when they drank much, then the lesser. Thou have kept the good wine until now.
John. This is the beginning of the signs Jesus did in Cana of Galilee,  he manifested his glory. And his disciples believed in him.
John. After this he went down to Capernaum, he and his mother and his brothers and his disciples. And they remained there not many days.
John. And the Passover of the Jews was near,  Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
John. And he found sitting in the temple those who sell oxen and sheep and doves,  the moneychangers.
John. And having made a whip from cords, he drove all out from the temple, both the sheep and the oxen. And he poured out the coins of the moneychangers,  turned over their tables.
John. And he said to those who sell the doves, Take these things from here. Make not my Father's house a house of merchandise.
John. And his disciples remembered that it is written, Zeal for thy house will consume me.
John. The Jews therefore answered,  said to him, What sign do thou show us since thou do these things?
John. Jesus answered and said to them, Destroy this temple,  in three days I will raise it up.
John. The Jews therefore said, This temple was forty-six years being built,  will thou raise it up in three days?
John. But that man spoke about the temple of his body.
John. When therefore he was raised from the dead his disciples remembered that he spoke this,  they believed the scripture and the word that Jesus said.
John. Now when he was in Jerusalem at the Passover during the feast, many believed in his name seeing his signs that he did.
John. But Jesus did not trust himself to them, because he knew all men,
John. and because he had no need that any man should testify about man, for he himself knew what was in man.
John. Now there was a man of the Pharisees named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.
John. This man came to him by night,  said to him, Rabbi, we know that thou have come a teacher from God, for no man can do these signs that thou do if God is not with him.
John. Jesus answered and said to him, Truly, truly, I say to thee, If any man is not begotten from above, he cannot see the kingdom of God.
John. Nicodemus says to him, How can a man be begotten, being old? Can he enter a second time into his mother's belly,  be born?
John. Jesus answered, Truly, truly, I say to thee, If any man is not begotten from water and Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.
John. That which is begotten from the flesh is flesh,  that which is begotten from the Spirit is spirit.
John. Marvel not that I said to thee, ye must be begotten from above.
John. The wind blows where it will,  thou hear the sound of it,  know not from where it comes,  where it goes. So is every man who is begotten from the Spirit.
John. Nicodemus answered and said to him, How can these things happen?
John. Jesus answered and said to him, Thou are the teacher of Israel,  do not understand these things?
John. Truly, truly, I say to thee, we speak that which we know,  testify of what we have seen,  ye do not accept our testimony.
John. If I told you earthly things,  ye do not believe, how will ye believe if I should tell you heavenly things?
John. And no man has ascended into heaven, except he who came down out of heaven: the Son of man who is in heaven.
John. And just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of man be lifted up,
John. so that every man who believes in him would not perish,  may have eternal life.
John. For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, so that every man who believes in him would not perish,  have eternal life.
John. For God sent the Son into the world not that he might condemn the world,  that the world might be saved through him.
John. He who believes in him is not condemned. He who does not believe has been condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.
John. And this is the condemnation, that the light has come into the world,  men loved the darkness rather than the light, for their deeds were evil.
John. For every man who does evil hates the light,  does not come to the light, so that his works may not be exposed.
John. But he who does the truth comes to the light, so that his deeds may be made manifest that they are wrought in God.
John. After these things Jesus and his disciples came into the Judean country. And he remained there with them and immersed.
John. And John also was immersing in Aenon near Salim because there was much water there. And they came and were immersed.
John. For John was not yet cast into prison.
John. Therefore a debate developed from John's disciples with the Jews about purification.
John. And they came to John,  said to him, Rabbi, he who was with thee beyond the Jordan, about whom thou have testified, behold, this man immerses,  all men come to him.
John. John answered and said, A man can receive nothing unless it is given to him from heaven.
John. Ye yourselves testify that I said, I am not the Christ,  that I am sent ahead of that man.
John. He who has the bride is the bridegroom. But the friend of the bridegroom, who stands and hears him, rejoices with joy because of the bridegroom's voice. This therefore my joy is fulfilled.
John. It is necessary for that man to increase,  me to decrease.
John. He who comes from above is above all things. He who is of the earth is of the earth,  speaks of the earth. He who comes from heaven is above all things.
John. And what he has seen and heard, of this he testifies,  no man receives his testimony.
John. He who has received his testimony has set a seal that God is true.
John. For he whom God sent speaks the sayings of God, for God does not give the Spirit by measure.
John. The Father loves the Son,  has given all things into his hand.
John. He who believes in the Son has eternal life,  he who disobeys the Son will not see life,  the wrath of God remains on him.
John. When therefore the Lord knew that the Pharisees had heard that Jesus was making and immersing more disciples than John
John. (although Jesus himself did not immerse,  his disciples),
John. he left Judea,  departed into Galilee.
John. And it was necessary for him to pass through Samaria.
John. So he comes to a city of Samaria, called Sychar, near the place that Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
John. And Jacob's well was there. Jesus therefore being wearied from the journey, thus was sitting on the well. It was about the sixth hour.
John. A woman of Samaria comes to draw water. Jesus says to her, Give me to drink.
John. For his disciples had gone away into the city so that they might buy food.
John. The Samaritan woman therefore says to him, How do thou, being Jewish, ask to drink from me, being a Samaritan woman, for Jews do not associate with Samaritans?
John. Jesus answered and said to her, If thou had known the gift of God,  who it is who says to thee, Give me to drink, thou would have asked him,  he would have given thee living water.
John. The woman says to him, Sir, thou have not even a container,  the well is deep. From where then have thou the living water?
John. Are thou greater than our father Jacob who gave us the well,  drank from it himself,  his sons,  his livestock?
John. Jesus answered and said to her, Every man who drinks of this water will thirst again,
John. but whoever drinks of the water that I will give him will, no, not thirst into the age. But the water that I will give him will become in him a well of water springing up to eternal life.
John. The woman says to him, Give me this water, sir, that I may not thirst, nor come here to draw out.
John. Jesus says to her, Go, call thy husband,  come here.
John. The woman answered and said to him, I have no husband. Jesus says to her, Thou said correctly, I have no husband.
John. For thou have had five husbands,  he whom thou now have is not thy husband. This thou have said true.
John. The woman says to him, Sir, I perceive that thou are a prophet.
John. Our fathers worshiped on this mountain,  ye say that in Jerusalem is the place where it is necessary to worship.
John. Jesus says to her, Woman, believe me, that the hour is coming when neither on this mountain, nor in Jerusalem will ye worship the Father.
John. Ye worship what ye do not know. We worship what we know, because salvation is from the Jews.
John. But an hour comes,  now is, when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for also the Father seeks such kind who worship him.
John. God is Spirit,  those who worship him must worship in spirit and truth.
John. The woman says to him, I know that Messiah comes, he who is called Christ. When that man comes he will declare all things to us.
John. Jesus says to her, I who speak to thee am the man.
John. And upon this his disciples came. And they marveled that he spoke with the woman, yet no man said, What seek thou? or, Why do thou speak with her?
John. The woman therefore left her water pot,  departed into the city,  says to the men,
John. Come, see a man who told me all, as many things as I did. Is not this the Christ?
John. They went out of the city,  came to him.
John. In the meanwhile the disciples asked him, saying, Rabbi, eat.
John. But he said to them, I have food to eat that ye know not.
John. The disciples therefore said to each other, Did any man bring him to eat?
John. Jesus says to them, My food is that I do the will of him who sent me,  may finish his work.
John. Do ye not say, There are still four months and the harvest comes? Behold, I say to you, lift up your eyes and see the fields, that they are already white for harvest.
John. And he who reaps receives a wage and gathers fruit for eternal life, so that both he who sows and he who reaps may rejoice together.
John. For in this the saying is true, One is who sows,  another who reaps.
John. I sent you to reap what ye have not labored. Others have labored,  ye have entered into their labor.
John. And many of the Samaritans from that city believed in him because of the word of the woman, who testified, He told me all, as many things as I did.
John. So when the Samaritans came to him they asked him to remain with them,  he remained there two days.
John. And many more believed because of his word.
John. And they said to the woman, We no longer believe because of thy speaking, for we have heard ourselves,  know that this really is the Savior of the world, the Christ.
John. And after the two days he departed from there and went into Galilee.
John. For Jesus himself testified that a prophet has no honor in his own fatherland.
John. So when he came into Galilee, the Galileans received him, having seen all the things that he did in Jerusalem at the feast, for they also went to the feast.
John. Jesus therefore came again to Cana of Galilee where he made the water wine. And there was a certain nobleman whose son was sick at Capernaum.
John. This man having heard that Jesus comes out of Judea into Galilee, he went to him and besought him that he would come down and heal his son, for he was going to die.
John. Jesus therefore said to him, Unless ye may see signs and wonders, ye will, no, not believe.
John. The nobleman says to him, Sir, come down before my child dies.
John. Jesus says to him, Go, thy son lives. And the man believed the word that Jesus said to him,  he departed.
John. And as he was now going down, his bondmen met him and reported, saying, Thy boy lives.
John. So he inquired of them the hour in which he fared well. And they said to him, Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.
John. So the father knew that it was at that hour in which Jesus said to him, Thy son lives. And he himself believed and his whole house.
John. This again is a second sign that Jesus did, having come out of Judea into Galilee.
John. After these things there was a feast of the Jews,  Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
John. Now there is in Jerusalem by the place pertaining to sheep, a pool, which is called in Hebrew Bethesda, having five porches.
John. In these lay a great multitude of those who are feeble, blind, lame, withered, waiting for the movement of the water.
John. For an agent went down at a certain time into the pool,  agitated the water. Therefore the first man who stepped in after the agitation of the water became well from whatever affliction he had.
John. And a certain man was there who was thirty-eight years in the weakness.
John. When Jesus saw this man lying down,  knew that he fares now a long time, he says to him, Do thou desire to become well?
John. The infirmed man answered him, Sir, I have no man so that when the water is agitated he might put me into the pool,  while I am coming another steps down before me.
John. Jesus says to him, Arise, take up thy bed and walk.
John. And straightaway the man became well,  took up his bed and walked. Now it was sabbath on that day.
John. The Jews therefore said to the man who was cured, It is sabbath. It is not permitted for thee to take up the bed.
John. He answered them, The man who made me well, that man said to me, Take up thy bed and walk.
John. Therefore they asked him, Who is the man who said to thee, Take up thy bed and walk?
John. But the man who was healed had not known who he is, for Jesus withdrew, a multitude being in the place.
John. After these things Jesus finds him in the temple,  said to him, Behold, thou have become well. Sin no more, lest something worse may happen to thee.
John. The man departed and reported to the Jews that Jesus is the man who made him well.
John. And because of this the Jews persecuted Jesus,  sought to kill him, because he did these things on a sabbath.
John. But Jesus answered them, My Father works until now and I work.
John. Because of this therefore the Jews sought even more to kill him, because not only did he relax the sabbath,  also he called God his own Father, making himself equal to God.
John. Jesus therefore answered and said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, the Son can do nothing of himself, except what he sees the Father doing. For whatever he may do, the Son also does these things in like manner.
John. For the Father loves the Son,  shows him all things that he himself does. And he will show him works greater than these, so that ye may marvel.
John. For as the Father raises up the dead and makes alive, so also the Son makes alive whom he will.
John. For neither does the Father judge any man,  he has given all judgment to the Son,
John. so that all would honor the Son, even as they honor the Father. The man not honoring the Son, does not honor the Father who sent him.
John. Truly, truly, I say to you, that he who hears my word,  believes him who sent me, has eternal life. And he does not come into condemnation,  has passed from death into life.
John. Truly, truly, I say to you, that an hour comes,  now is, when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God,  those who hear will live.
John. For as the Father has life in himself, so also he gave to the Son to have life in himself.
John. And he also gave him authority to execute judgment because he is a son of man.
John. Marvel not at this, because an hour comes in which all those in the sepulchers will hear his voice,
John. and will come forth, those who have done right to a resurrection of life,  those who have practiced wrong to a resurrection of judgment.
John. I can from myself do nothing. As I hear, I judge. And my judgment is righteous because I seek not my will,  the will of the Father who sent me.
John. If I testify about myself, my witness is not valid.
John. There is another who testifies about me,  I know that the testimony that he testifies about me is valid.
John. Ye have sent to John,  he has testified to the truth.
John. But I do not take the testimony from man. However, I say these things, so that ye may be saved.
John. That man was the lamp that burns and shines,  ye were willing to rejoice for an hour in his light.
John. But I have testimony greater than of John, for the works that the Father has given me so that I might complete them, the same works that I do, they testify about me that the Father has sent me.
John. And the Father, he who sent me, has testified about me.Ye have neither heard his voice, nor have ever seen his appearance.
John. And ye have not his word dwelling in you, because ye do not believe that man whom he sent for this.
John. Ye search the scriptures, because ye think to have eternal life in them,  those are testifying about me.
John. And ye will not come to me, so that ye may have life.
John. I do not receive glory from men.
John. But I know you, that ye have not the love of God within yourselves.
John. I have come in my Father's name,  ye do not accept me. If another man should come in his own name, ye will accept that man.
John. How can ye believe, who receive glory from each other,  seek not the glory from the only God?
John. Think not that I will accuse you to the Father. The man who accuses you is Moses, in whom ye have hoped.
John. For if ye believed Moses, ye would have believed me, for that man wrote about me.
John. But if ye believe not the writings of that man, how will ye believe my sayings?
John. After these things Jesus went to the other side of the sea of Galilee of Tiberias.
John. And a great multitude followed him because they saw his signs, which he did on those who are infirmed.
John. And Jesus went up onto the mountain,  he sat there with his disciples.
John. Now the Passover, the feast of the Jews, was near.
John. Jesus therefore having lifted up his eyes,  having seen that a great multitude comes to him, he says to Philip, From where will we buy loaves, so that these may eat?
John. But he said this testing him, for he himself knew what he was going to do.
John. Philip answered him, Loaves of two hundred denarii of bread are not sufficient for them, so that each of them may take a little something.
John. One of his disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, says to him,
John. There is one child here that has five barley loaves and two fishes,  what are these for so many?
John. And Jesus said, Make the men sit down. Now there was much grass in the place. So the men sat down, in number about five thousand.
John. And Jesus took the loaves,  having expressed thanks, he distributed to the disciples,  the disciples to those who were sitting down, likewise also of the fishes as much as they wanted.
John. And when they were filled, he says to his disciples, Gather up the fragments that remain over, so that not anything may be lost.
John. So they gathered them up,  filled twelve baskets of fragments from the five barley loaves that remained over from those who have eaten.
John. When therefore the men saw what sign Jesus did, they said, This really is the prophet who comes into the world.
John. Jesus therefore having perceived that they are going to come and seize him, so that they might make him king, departed onto the mountain himself alone.
John. And when it became evening his disciples went down to the sea,
John. and having entered into the boat, they were going to the other side of the sea toward Capernaum. And it had already become dark,  Jesus had not come to them.
John. And the sea was being raised by a great wind blowing.
John. Therefore having impelled forward about twenty-five or thirty furlongs, they see Jesus walking on the sea,  coming near to the boat,  they were afraid.
John. But he says to them, It is I, fear not.
John. They were willing therefore to receive him into the boat,  straightaway the boat came to be at the land to which they were going.
John. On the morrow the multitude that stood on the other side of the sea, having seen that there was no other boat there except that one in which his disciples entered,  that Jesus did not go with his disciples into the boat,  his disciples went away alone,
John. and other boats came from Tiberias near the place where they ate the bread after the Lord expressed thanks,
John. when therefore the multitude saw that Jesus is not there, nor his disciples, they entered into the boats,  came to Capernaum seeking Jesus.
John. And when they found him on the other side of the sea, they said to him, Rabbi, when did thou become here?
John. Jesus answered them and said, Truly, truly, I say to you, ye seek me not because ye saw signs,  because ye ate of the loaves and were filled.
John. Work not for the food that perishes,  for the food that endures to eternal life, which the Son of man will give to you, for God the Father put a seal on this man.
John. They said to him therefore, What shall we do that we may work the works of God?
John. Jesus answered,  said to them, This is the work of God, that ye believe in that man whom he has sent.
John. They said to him therefore, What sign do thou, that we may see and believe in thee? What do thou work?
John. Our fathers ate the manna in the wilderness, just as it is written, He gave them bread out of heaven to eat.
John. Jesus therefore said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, Moses did not give you the bread out of heaven,  my Father gives you the true bread out of heaven.
John. For the bread of God is he who comes down out of heaven,  gives life to the world.
John. They said to him therefore, Lord, always give us this bread.
John. Jesus said to them, I am the bread of life. He who comes to me will, no, not hunger,  he who believes in me will, no, not ever thirst.
John. But also I said to you, that ye have seen me,  yet do not believe.
John. All that the Father gives me will come to me,  he who comes to me I will, no, not cast out.
John. Because I have come down from heaven, not so that I might do my will,  the will of him who sent me.
John. And this is the will of the Father who sent me, that of all that he has given me I would not lose from it,  I will raise it up at the last day.
John. And this is the will of him who sent me, that every man who sees the Son,  believes in him, may have eternal life,  I will raise him up at the last day.
John. The Jews therefore murmured about him because he said, I am the bread that came down out of heaven.
John. And they said, Is this not Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? Therefore how does this man say, I have come down out of heaven?
John. Jesus therefore answered and said to them, Murmur not among each other.
John. No man can come to me unless the Father who sent me draws him,  I will raise him up in the last day.
John. It is written in the prophets, And they will all be taught of God. Every man who hears from the Father,  having learned, comes to me.
John. Not that any man has seen the Father, except he who is from God. This man has seen the Father.
John. Truly, truly, I say to you, he who believes in me has eternal life.
John. I am the bread of life.
John. Your fathers ate the manna in the wilderness,  they died.
John. This is the bread that comes down out of heaven, that a man may eat of it,  not die.
John. I am the living bread, having come down out of heaven. If any man eats of this bread, he will live into the age. And also, the bread that I will give is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.
John. The Jews therefore contended with each other, saying, How can this man give us his flesh to eat?
John. Jesus therefore said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, unless ye eat the flesh of the Son of man and drink his blood, ye have no life in yourselves.
John. He who eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life,  I will raise him up at the last day.
John. For my flesh is truly food,  my blood is truly drink.
John. He who eats my flesh and drinks my blood dwells in me,  I in him.
John. Just as the living Father sent me,  I live because of the Father, also he who eats me, that man will also live because of me.
John. This is the bread that came down out of heaven, not as your fathers ate the manna and died. He who eats this bread will live into the age.
John. He said these things in a synagogue, as he taught in Capernaum.
John. Therefore many of his disciples having heard, said, This is a hard saying. Who can listen to it?
John. But Jesus, knowing in himself that his disciples are grumbling about this, said to them, Does this cause you to stumble?
John. Then if ye should see the Son of man ascending where he was before?
John. It is the spirit that makes alive. The flesh benefits nothing. The sayings that I speak to you are spirit, are life.
John. Nevertheless, there are some of you who do not believe. For Jesus had known from the beginning who they are who do not believe,  who he is who will betray him.
John. And he said, Because of this I have said to you that no man is able to come to me, if it is not given to him from my Father.
John. From this, many of his disciples went back at these things,  walked no more with him.
John. Jesus said therefore to the twelve, Do ye not also want to go?
John. Simon Peter therefore answered him, Lord, to whom will we go? Thou have sayings of eternal life.
John. And we have believed and know that thou are the Christ, the Son of the living God.
John. Jesus answered them, Did I not choose you the twelve,  one of you is a devil?
John. But he spoke of Judas Iscariot son of Simon. For this man, being one of the twelve, was going to betray him.
John. And after these things Jesus walked in Galilee, for he did not want to walk in Judea, because the Jews sought to kill him.
John. Now the feast of the Jews, the feast of tabernacles, was near.
John. His brothers therefore said to him, Depart from here,  go into Judea so that thy disciples also may see thy works that thou do.
John. For no man does anything in secret,  he himself seeks to be in public. If thou do these things, show thyself to the world.
John. For not even his brothers believed in him.
John. Jesus therefore says to them, My time is not yet here,  your time is always ready.
John. The world cannot hate you,  it hates me because I testify about it, that its works are evil.
John. Go ye up to this feast. I am not yet going to this feast, because my time is not yet fulfilled.
John. And having said these things to them, he remained in Galilee.
John. But when his brothers went up, then he also went up to the feast, not openly,  as in private.
John. The Jews therefore sought him at the feast,  said, Where is that man?
John. And there was much murmuring among the multitudes about him. Some said, He is a good man, others said, No,  he leads the multitude astray.
John. Yet no man spoke openly about him because of fear of the Jews.
John. And when it was now in the middle of the feast, Jesus went up into the temple and taught.
John. The Jews therefore marveled, saying, How does this man know scholarly material, not having learned?
John. Jesus therefore answered them and said, My doctrine is not mine,  his who sent me.
John. If any man wants to do his will, he will know about the doctrine, whether it is from God, or I speak from myself.
John. He who speaks from himself seeks his own glory,  he who seeks the glory of him who sent him, this man is true,  unrighteousness is not in him.
John. Did not Moses give you the law,  none of you does the law? Why do ye seek to kill me?
John. The multitude answered and said, Thou have a demon. Who seeks to kill thee?
John. Jesus answered and said to them, I did one work,  ye all marvel because of this.
John. Moses has given you circumcision (not that it is from Moses,  from the fathers),  ye circumcise a man on a sabbath.
John. If a man receives circumcision on a sabbath, so that the law of Moses may not be loosed, are ye angry with me because I made a man entirely well on a sabbath?
John. Judge not according to appearance,  judge righteous judgment.
John. Therefore some of the Jerusalemites said, Is not this he whom they seek to kill?
John. And lo, he speaks in public,  they say nothing to him. Perhaps the rulers really know that this really is the Christ?
John. However we know this man, where he is from,  when the Christ comes, no man knows where he is from.
John. Jesus therefore cried out in the temple, teaching and saying, Ye both know me,  know where I am from? And I have not come of myself,  he who sent me is true, whom ye know not.
John. I know him, because I am from him,  he sent me.
John. They sought therefore to seize him,  yet no man laid a hand on him because his hour had not yet come.
John. But many from the crowd believed in him,  they said, When the Christ comes, will he do more signs than these that this man did?
John. The Pharisees heard the crowd murmuring these things about him,  the Pharisees and the chief priests sent subordinates so that they might take him.
John. Jesus therefore said, Yet a little time I am with you,  then I go to him who sent me.
John. Ye will seek me,  will not find me,  where I am, ye cannot come.
John. The Jews therefore said among themselves, Where is this man going to go that we will not find him? Is he going to go to the Dispersion among the Greeks,  teach the Greeks?
John. What is this word that he said, Ye will seek me,  will not find me, , Where I am, ye cannot come?
John. Now on the last day, the great day of the feast, Jesus had stood and cried out, saying, If any man thirsts, let him come to me and drink.
John. He who believes in me, as the scripture has said, out of his belly will flow rivers of living water.
John. But he spoke this about the Spirit that those who believe in him were going to receive, for the Holy Spirit was not yet, because Jesus was not yet glorified.
John. Many from the multitude therefore, when they heard the saying, said, This is truly the prophet.
John. Others said, This is the Christ. Others said, For does the Christ come out of Galilee?
John. Has not the scripture said that the Christ comes of the seed of David,  from Bethlehem, the village where David was?
John. So there became a division among the multitude because of him.
John. And some of them wanted to take him,  no man laid hands on him.
John. The subordinates therefore came to the chief priests and Pharisees. And those men said to them, Why did ye not bring him?
John. The subordinates answered, A man never so spoke like this man.
John. The Pharisees therefore answered them, Have ye not also been led astray?
John. Have any of the rulers believed in him, or of the Pharisees?
John. But this multitude that does not know the law are accursed.
John. Nicodemus says to them (he who came to him by night, being one of them),
John. Does our law judge a man, unless it first may hear from himself and know what he does?
John. They answered and said to him, Are thou also from Galilee? Search and see, that out of Galilee arises no prophet.
John. And each man went to his house.
John. But Jesus went to the mount of Olives.
John. And at early morning he came again into the temple,  all the people came to him. And having sat down, he taught them.
John. And the scholars and the Pharisees bring to him a woman taken in adultery. And having stood her in the midst,
John. tempting, they say to him, Teacher, we found this woman committing adultery, in the act.
John. Now in the law, Moses commanded us such women are to be stoned. What therefore do thou say about her?
John. But they said this, trying him, so that they might have an accusation against him. But Jesus having stooped down, wrote on the ground with his finger, not pretending.
John. And when they continued asking him, after standing erect, he said to them, Let the innocent man of you first cast the stone at her.
John. And again having stooped down, he wrote on the ground.
John. And they, having heard and being convicted by their conscience, went out one by one, having begun from the elder until the last. And Jesus was left behind alone,  the woman being in the midst.
John. And Jesus, after standing erect,  having seen no man but the woman, he said to her, Woman, where are those accusers of thee? Did no man condemn thee?
John. And she said, No man, Lord. And Jesus said to her, Neither do I condemn thee. Go,  henceforth sin no more.
John. Again therefore Jesus spoke to them, saying, I am the light of the world. He who follows me would, no, not walk in the darkness,  will have the light of life.
John. The Pharisees therefore said to him, Thou testify about thyself. Thy testimony is not valid.
John. Jesus answered and said to them, Even if I might testify about myself, my testimony is valid, for I know where I came from and where I go,  ye do not know where I come from and where I go.
John. Ye judge according to the flesh. I judge no man.
John. But even if I judge, my judgment is valid, because I am not alone,  I and the Father who sent me.
John. And also it is written in your law that the testimony of two men is valid.
John. I am he who testifies about myself,  the Father who sent me testifies about me.
John. They said therefore to him, Where is thy Father? Jesus answered, Ye know neither me, nor my Father. If ye had known me, ye would have known my Father also.
John. Jesus spoke these sayings in the treasury as he taught in the temple,  no man seized him, because his hour had not yet come.
John. Jesus therefore again said to them, I go,  ye will seek me,  ye will die in your sin. Where I go, ye cannot come.
John. The Jews therefore said, Will he kill himself, because he says, Where I go, ye cannot come?
John. And he said to them, Ye are from below, I am from above. Ye are of this world, I am not of this world.
John. I said therefore to you that ye will die in your sins. For unless ye believe that I am he, ye will die in your sins.
John. They said therefore to him, Who are thou? And Jesus said to them, The beginning, something that I am even telling you.
John. I have many things to say and to judge about you. But he who sent me is true,  I speak to the world these things that I heard from him.
John. They did not understand that he spoke the Father to them.
John. Jesus therefore said to them, When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then ye will know that I am he,  I do nothing from myself,  I speak these things as my Father taught me.
John. And he who sent me is with me. The Father has not left me alone, because I always do things pleasing to him.
John. As he spoke these things of him, many believed in him.
John. Jesus therefore said to those Jews who believed him, If ye remain in my word, ye are truly my disciples,
John. and ye will know the truth,  the truth will make you free.
John. They answered to him, We are Abraham's seed,  have been in bondage to no man, ever. How can thou say, Ye will become free?
John. Jesus answered them, Truly, truly, I say to you, that every man who does the sin is a bondman of the sin.
John. And the bondman does not remain in the house into the age. The Son remains into the age.
John. If therefore the Son should make you free, ye will truly be free.
John. I know that ye are Abraham's seed, yet ye seek to kill me, because my word has no place in you.
John. I speak what I have seen from my Father,  ye therefore do what ye have seen from your father.
John. They answered and said to him, Abraham is our father. Jesus says to them, If ye were Abraham's children, ye would do the works of Abraham.
John. But now ye seek to kill me, a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God. Abraham did not do this.
John. Ye do the works of your father. They said therefore to him, We were not begotten from fornication. We have one Father, God.
John. Therefore Jesus said to them, If God were your Father, ye would love me, for I came forth and have come from God. For, neither have I come for myself,  he sent me.
John. Why do ye not understand my speech? Because ye cannot hear my word.
John. Ye are from the father, the devil,  ye want to do the desires of your father. He was a man-killer from the beginning,  he has not stood in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he speaks a lie, he speaks from his own, because he is a liar,  the father of it.
John. And I, because I speak the truth, ye do not believe me.
John. Which of you convicts me about sin? And if I speak truth, why do ye not believe me?
John. He who is of God hears the sayings of God. Because of this ye do not hear, because ye are not of God.
John. Therefore the Jews answered and said to him, Do we not say well that thou are a Samaritan,  have a demon?
John. Jesus answered, I have no demon,  I honor my Father,  ye dishonor me.
John. But I seek not my own glory. He is who seeks and judges.
John. Truly, truly, I say to you, if any man keeps my word, he will, no, not see death, into the age.
John. The Jews therefore said to him, Now we know that thou have a demon. Abraham died,  the prophets,  thou say, If any man keeps my word, he will, no, not taste of death, into the age.
John. Are thou greater than our father Abraham who died? And the prophets died. Who do thou make thyself?
John. Jesus answered, If I glorify myself, my glory is nothing. My Father is he who glorifies me, of whom ye say, He is our God.
John. And ye do not know him,  I know him. And if I should say that I do not know him, I will be a liar like you,  I do know him and keep his word.
John. Your father Abraham rejoiced that he could see my day,  he saw it,  was glad.
John. The Jews therefore said to him, Thou have not yet fifty years,  thou have seen Abraham?
John. Jesus said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, before Abraham came to be, I am.
John. Therefore they took up stones so that they might throw at him,  Jesus was hid,  went out of the temple, having passed through the midst of them,  thus passed on.
John. And as he passed on, he saw a man blind from birth.
John. And his disciples asked him, saying, Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he would be born blind?
John. Jesus answered, Neither this man sinned, nor his parents,  that the works of God might be manifested in him.
John. I must work the works of him who sent me while it is day. Night comes when no man can work.
John. When I am in the world, I am the light of the world.
John. Having said these things, he spat toward the ground,  made clay of the spittle,  rubbed the clay on the eyes of the blind man.
John. And he said to him, Go, wash in the pool of Siloam (which is translated, He who has been sent). Therefore he went and washed,  came seeing.
John. The neighbors therefore and those who saw him formerly, that he was blind, said, Is this not he who sits and begs?
John. Others said, He is this man,  others said, He is like him. That man said, I am.
John. They said to him therefore, How were thine eyes opened?
John. That man answered and said, A man called Jesus made clay,  rubbed on my eyes,  said to me, Go to the pool of Siloam and wash. And after going and washing, I received sight.
John. Therefore they said to him, Where is that man? He says, I do not know.
John. They brought him to the Pharisees-the former blind man.
John. Now it was a sabbath when Jesus made the clay and opened his eyes.
John. Again therefore the Pharisees also asked him how he received sight. And he said to them, He put clay upon my eyes,  I washed,  I see.
John. Therefore some of the Pharisees said, This man is not from God, because he does not keep the sabbath. Other men said, How is a sinful man able to do such signs? And there was division among them.
John. They say again to the blind man, What do thou say about him, that he opened thine eyes? And he said, He is a prophet.
John. The Jews therefore did not believe about him, that he had been blind,  had received sight, until they called the parents of the man who had received sight.
John. And they asked them, saying, Is this your son, whom ye say that he was born blind? How then does he now see?
John. And his parents answered them and said, We know that this is our son,  that he was born blind,
John. but how he now sees, we know not. Or who opened his eyes, we know not. He has maturity, ask him. He will speak for himself.
John. His parents spoke these things because they feared the Jews, for the Jews had agreed already, that if any man confessed him as Christ, he should become excommunicated from the synagogue.
John. Because of this his parents said, He has maturity, ask him.
John. So they called the man who was blind, for a second time,  said to him, Give glory to God. We know that this man is sinful.
John. That man therefore answered and said, If he is sinful, I know not. One thing I know, that being blind, now I see.
John. But again they said to him, What did he do to thee? How did he open thine eyes?
John. He answered them, I told you already,  ye did not listen. Why do ye want to hear it again? Do ye not also want to become his disciples?
John. They reviled him,  said, Thou are a disciple of that man,  we are disciples of Moses.
John. We know that God has spoken to Moses,  this man, we know not where he is from.
John. The man answered and said to them, For in this it is amazing, that ye know not where he is from,  yet he opened my eyes.
John. And we know that God does not listen to sinners,  if any man is a worshiper of God,  does his will, he listens to this man.
John. From the age, it was not heard that any man opened the eyes of a man who was born blind.
John. If this man were not from God, he could do nothing.
John. They answered and said to him, Thou were born entirely in sins,  thou teach us? And they cast him outside.
John. Jesus heard that they cast him outside. And having found him, he said to him, Do thou believe in the Son of God?
John. That man answered and said, And who is he, Lord, that I may believe in him?
John. And Jesus said to him, Thou have both seen him,  he is that man who speaks with thee.
John. And he affirmed, Lord, I believe. And he worshiped him.
John. And Jesus said, For judgment I came into this world, so that those not seeing might see,  those who see might become blind.
John. And those of the Pharisees who were with him heard these things,  they said to him, Are we also blind?
John. Jesus said to them, If ye were blind, ye would have no sin,  now ye say, We see, therefore your sin remains.
John. Truly, truly, I say to you, he who does not enter in by the door into the fold of the sheep,  goes up some other way, that man is a thief and a robber.
John. But he who enters in by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.
John. The gatekeeper opens to this man. And the sheep hear his voice,  he calls his own sheep by name,  leads them out.
John. And when he puts forth his own sheep, he goes before them. And the sheep follow him because they know his voice.
John. And they will, no, not follow a stranger,  will flee from him, because they do not recognize the voice of strangers.
John. Jesus spoke this allegory to them,  those men did not understand what it was that he spoke to them.
John. Jesus therefore said to them again, Truly, truly, I say to you, that I am the door of the sheep.
John. All, as many as came before me are thieves and robbers,  the sheep did not hear them.
John. I am the door. If any man enters in by me, he will be saved,  will come in and go out,  will find pasture.
John. The thief comes not, except that he might steal and kill and destroy. I came so that they might have life,  have it more abundantly.
John. I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.
John. But the hired man,  not being the shepherd, whose sheep are not his own, sees the wolf coming,  leaves the sheep and flees. And the wolf catches them,  scatters the sheep.
John. But the hireling flees because he is a hireling,  it is no care to him about the sheep.
John. I am the good shepherd,  I know mine,  I am known by mine.
John. Just as the Father knows me, I also know the Father,  I lay down my life for the sheep.
John. And I have other sheep that are not of this fold. I must bring those also,  they will hear my voice. And there will become one flock, one shepherd.
John. Because of this the Father loves me, because I lay down my life, so that I may take it again.
John. No man takes it from me,  I lay it down by myself. I have power to lay it down,  I have power to take it again. I received this commandment from my Father.
John. Therefore again there became a division among the Jews because of these words.
John. And many of them said, He has a demon,  is mad. Why do ye listen to him?
John. Others said, These are not the sayings of a man possessed with a demon. Can a demon open the eyes of the blind?
John. And the feast of the dedication happened at Jerusalem,  it was winter.
John. And Jesus was walking in the temple in Solomon's porch.
John. The Jews therefore surrounded him,  said to him, When do thou lift up our soul? If thou are the Christ, tell us plainly.
John. Jesus answered them, I told you,  ye did not believe. The works that I do in my Father's name, these testify about me.
John. But ye do not believe, for ye are not of my sheep, as I said to you.
John. My sheep hear my voice,  I know them,  they follow me.
John. And I give them eternal life,  they will, no, not perish into the age,  not any will snatch them out of my hand.
John. My Father who has given to me, is greater than all,  not one is able to snatch out of my Father's hand.
John. I and the Father are one.
John. Therefore again the Jews took up stones so that they might stone him.
John. Jesus answered them, I have shown you many good works from my Father. Because of them, which work do ye stone me?
John. The Jews answered him, saying, We stone thee not about a good work,  about blasphemy,  because thou, being a man, make thyself God.
John. Jesus answered them, Is it not written in your law, I said, ye are gods?
John. If he designated those men gods, for whom the word of God came to be (and the scripture cannot be broken),
John. whom the Father made holy and sent into the world, do ye say, Thou blaspheme, because I said, I am the Son of God?
John. If I am not doing the works of my Father, do not believe me.
John. But if I am doing them, even though ye do not believe me, believe the works, that ye may know and believe that the Father is in me,  I in him.
John. Therefore they sought again to take him,  he went forth out of their hand.
John. And he departed again beyond the Jordan into the place where John was first immersing,  he stayed there.
John. And many came to him,  they said, John indeed did not one sign,  all, as many things as John spoke about this man, were true.
John. And many believed in him there.
John. Now a certain Lazarus, from Bethany of the village of Mary and her sister Martha, was sick.
John. And Mary was the woman who anointed the Lord with ointment,  wiped his feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.
John. The sisters therefore sent to him, saying, Lord, behold, he whom thou love is sick.
John. But when Jesus heard, he said, This sickness is not about death,  for the glory of God, so that the Son of God may be glorified by it.
John. Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
John. When therefore he heard that he is sick, then he actually remained two days in that place he was.
John. Later after this he says to the disciples, Let us go into Judea again.
John. The disciples say to him, Rabbi, the Jews were now seeking to stone thee,  thou go there again.
John. Jesus answered, Are there not twelve hours in the day? If a man walks in the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.
John. But if any man walks in the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him.
John. He spoke these things,  after this he says to them, Our friend Lazarus has become asleep,  I go that I may awake him.
John. His disciples therefore said, Lord, if he has become asleep, he will be healed.
John. But Jesus had spoken about his death,  those men thought that he was speaking about the restfulness of sleep.
John. Therefore Jesus then said to them plainly, Lazarus died.
John. And I am glad for your sakes that I was not there, so that ye may believe. Nevertheless let us go to him.
John. Therefore Thomas, called Didymus, said to his fellow disciples, Let us also go, that we may die with him.
John. So when Jesus came, he found him already four days being kept in the sepulcher.
John. Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about fifteen furlongs away from it,
John. and many of the Jews had come to the women, about Martha and Mary, so that they might console them about their brother.
John. Therefore Martha, when she heard that Jesus was coming, met him,  Mary was sitting in the house.
John. Martha therefore said to Jesus, Lord, if thou were here, my brother would not have died.
John. But I know even now that as many things as thou may ask of God, God will give to thee.
John. Jesus says to her, Thy brother will rise.
John. Martha says to him, I know that he will rise in the resurrection at the last day.
John. Jesus said to her, I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in me, even though he died, he will live.
John. And every man who lives and believes in me will, no, not die, into the age. Do thou believe this?
John. She says to him, Yes, Lord, I have believed that thou are the Christ, the Son of God who comes into the world.
John. And when she said these things, she departed and called Mary her sister privately, saying, The teacher is here and calls thee.
John. When that woman heard, she rises quickly,  comes to him.
John. (Now Jesus had not yet come into the village,  was in the place where Martha met him.)
John. The Jews therefore being with her in the house and consoling her, having seen Mary, that she rose up quickly and went out, followed her, saying that she was going to the sepulcher that she may weep there.
John. Therefore when Mary came where Jesus was, after seeing him, she fell down at his feet, saying to him, Lord, if thou were here, my brother would not have died.
John. When Jesus therefore saw her weeping,  the Jews who gathered with her, weeping, he groaned in the spirit,  was himself troubled.
John. And he said, Where have ye laid him? They said to him, Lord, come and see.
John. Jesus wept.
John. The Jews therefore said, Behold how he loved him.
John. But some of them said, This man who opened the eyes of the blind man, was he not also able to cause that this man also would not die?
John. Jesus therefore again groaning in himself comes to the sepulcher. Now it was a cave,  a stone lay against it.
John. Jesus says, Take ye away the stone. Martha, the sister of the man who came to end, says to him, Lord, he smells now, for it is the fourth day.
John. Jesus says to her, Did I not to say thee, that if thou believed, thou will see the glory of God?
John. So they took away the stone where the man who died was laying. And Jesus lifted up his eyes,  said, Father, I thank thee that thou heard me.
John. And I had known that thou always hear me,  because of the multitude that stands by I spoke, so that they may believe that thou sent me.
John. And having said these things, he cried out with a great voice, Lazarus, come out.
John. And the man who died came forth, wrapped hands and feet with grave-clothes,  his face had been wrapped around with a face cloth. Jesus says to them, Loose him,  allow him to go.
John. Therefore many of the Jews who came to Mary,  who saw what Jesus did, believed in him.
John. But some of them went away to the Pharisees,  told them what things Jesus did.
John. Therefore the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered a council,  said, What are we doing? Because this man does many signs.
John. If we allow him this way, all men will believe in him,  the Romans will come and take away both our place and the nation.
John. And a certain one of them, Caiaphas, being high priest that year, said to them, Ye know nothing at all,
John. nor do ye consider that it is expedient for us that one man should die for the people,  not the whole nation should perish.
John. Now he said this not from himself,  being high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus was going to die for the nation.
John. And not for the nation only,  also that he might gather together into one the children of God who are scattered abroad.
John. So from that day they consulted together so that they might kill him.
John. Jesus therefore no longer walked openly among the Jews,  departed from there into the region near the wilderness into a city called Ephraim,  he stayed there with his disciples.
John. Now the Passover of the Jews was near,  many went up to Jerusalem out of the countryside before the Passover, so that they might purify themselves.
John. Therefore they sought Jesus,  spoke with each other as they stood in the temple, What does it seem to you? That he will, no, not come to the feast?
John. Now also the chief priests and the Pharisees had given commandment, that if any man knew where he is, he should disclose it, so that they might take him.
John. Therefore six days before the Passover Jesus came to Bethany where Lazarus was, the man who died whom he raised from the dead.
John. So they made a supper for him there,  Martha served,  Lazarus was one of those who sat dining with him.
John. Mary therefore, after taking a pound of ointment of very costly genuine spikenard, anointed the feet of Jesus and wiped his feet with her hair. And the house was filled of the aroma of the ointment.
John. Therefore one of his disciples, Judas Iscariot, son of Simon, the man who was going to betray him, says,
John. Why was this ointment not sold for three hundred denarii,  given to the poor?
John. Now he said this, not because it was a concern to him about the poor,  because he was a thief,  he had the purse and removed things that were put in.
John. Jesus therefore said, Let her alone. She has keep it for the day of my burial.
John. For ye always have the poor with you,  ye do not always have me.
John. Therefore a great multitude of the Jews knew that he is there. And they came, not only because of Jesus,  that they might also see Lazarus whom he had raised from the dead.
John. But the chief priests decided that they should kill Lazarus also,
John. since because of him many of the Jews were going and were believing in Jesus.
John. On the morrow a great multitude having come to the feast, when they heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem,
John. took the branches of the palm trees,  went forth to meet him,  cried out, Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord, the King of Israel!
John. And Jesus, having found a young donkey, sat on it, as it is written,
John. Fear not, daughter of Zion. Behold, thy King comes, sitting on a donkey's colt.
John. Now his disciples did not understand these things at first,  when Jesus was glorified, then they remembered that these were things written because of him,  they did these things to him.
John. Therefore the multitude, the one that was with him when he called Lazarus from the sepulcher,  raised him from the dead, testified.
John. Also because of this the multitude met him, because they heard of him doing this sign.
John. The Pharisees therefore said among themselves, Do ye see that ye accomplish nothing. Behold, the world has gone after him.
John. Now some Greeks were from those who came up so that they might worship at the feast.
John. These men therefore came to Philip, the man from Bethsaida of Galilee,  asked him, saying, Sir, we want to see Jesus.
