Acts. And Ananias departed and entered into the house. And having laid hands on him he said, Brother Saul, the Lord, he who appeared to thee on the road on which thou came, has sent me so that thou may receive sight,  be filled of the Holy Spirit.
Acts. And straightaway there fell from his eyes, like scales,  he looked up. And immediately after rising up, he was immersed.
Acts. And having received nourishment, he was strengthened. And Saul became with the disciples in Damascus some days.
Acts. And straightaway he proclaimed the Christ in the synagogues, that this man is the Son of God.
Acts. And all those who heard were amazed,  said, Is this not the man who destroyed those in Jerusalem who call on this name? And he has come here for this, so that he might bring them bound to the chief priests.
Acts. But Saul was strengthened more,  was confounding the Jews who dwell at Damascus, proving that this is the Christ.
Acts. And after considerable days were fulfilled, the Jews plotted to destroy him,
Acts. but their plot was known to Saul. And they watched the gates both day and night so that they might destroy him.
Acts. But the disciples, after taking him by night, let him down through the wall, having lowered him in a hamper.
Acts. And when Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he attempted to join with the disciples,  they all feared him, not believing that he is a disciple.
Acts. But Barnabas having taken him, he brought him to the apostles. And he related to them how he saw the Lord on the road,  that he spoke to him,  how he spoke boldly at Damascus in the name of Jesus.
Acts. And he was with them coming in and going out at Jerusalem,  speaking boldly in the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts. And he spoke and disputed against the Hellenists,  they attempted to destroy him.
Acts. But when the brothers knew it, they brought him down to Caesarea,  sent him away to Tarsus.
Acts. Indeed therefore the congregations throughout the whole of Judea and Galilee and Samaria had peace, being edified. And, going in the fear of the Lord and in the encouragement of the Holy Spirit, they were multiplied.
Acts. And it came to pass, Peter, passing through all parts, to also come down to the sanctified who dwell at Lydda.
Acts. And he found there a certain man named Aeneas, who was paralyzed, laying on a bed for eight years.
Acts. And Peter said to him, Aeneas, Jesus the Christ heals thee. Arise and make thy bed. And straightaway he arose.
Acts. And all those dwelling at Lydda and Sharon who saw him, turned to the Lord.
Acts. Now at Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha, which, being translated, is called Dorcas. This woman was full of good works and charities that she did.
Acts. And in those days, having been ill, she happened to die. And after washing her, they laid her in an upper chamber.
Acts. And since Lydda is near Joppa, the disciples, having heard that Peter is in it, they sent two men to him, exhorting him not to delay to go through to them.
Acts. And after rising, Peter went with them, whom, after coming, they brought into the upper chamber. And all the widows stood by him weeping,  exhibiting the coats and garments, as many things as Dorcas made being with them.
Acts. But Peter, having sent them all out, having knelt down, he prayed. And having turned to the body, he said, Tabitha, arise. And the woman opened her eyes. And when she saw Peter, she sat up.
Acts. And having given her a hand, he raised her up. And after calling the sanctified and the widows, he presented her alive.
Acts. And it became known throughout the whole of Joppa,  many believed in the Lord.
Acts. And it came to pass for him to remain considerable days at Joppa with a certain Simon, a tanner.
Acts. Now a certain man was in Caesarea, Cornelius by name, a centurion of the band called Italian,
Acts. a devout man,  fearing God with all his house,  doing many charities for the people,  beseeching God always.
Acts. He saw plainly in a vision about the ninth hour of the day, an agent of God coming in to him,  saying to him, Cornelius.
Acts. And after gazing at him,  having become afraid, he said, What is it, Lord? And he said to him, Thy prayers and thy charities have come up for a memorial before God.
Acts. And now send men to Joppa and summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter.
Acts. This man lodges with a certain Simon, a tanner, whose house is beside the seaside.
Acts. And when the agent speaking to Cornelius departed, having called two of his housemen,  a devout soldier of those who personally served him,
Acts. and after reporting all things to them, he sent them to Joppa.
Acts. Now on the morrow, while those men were traveling and approaching the city, Peter went up upon the housetop to pray, about the sixth hour.
Acts. And he became very hungry and wanted to eat. But while those men prepared, a trance fell upon him.
Acts. And he sees heaven opened,  a certain container descending to him, like a great sheet bound at four corners,  being lowered to the earth,
Acts. in which were all the four-footed things of the earth,  the wild beasts,  the creeping things,  the birds of the sky.
Acts. And a voice came to him, After rising, Peter, kill and eat.
Acts. But Peter said, Not so, Lord, because I have never eaten anything profane or unclean.
Acts. And a voice again for a second time, What God has cleansed, thou shall not make profane.
Acts. And this happened thrice,  again the vessel was taken up into heaven.
Acts. Now while Peter was bewildered in himself whatever the vision which he saw might be, that lo, the men who were sent from Cornelius, having inquired the house of Simon, stood at the gate.
Acts. And after calling out they asked whether Simon, who was surnamed Peter, lodges here.
Acts. And while Peter thought about the vision, the Spirit said to him, Behold, men seek thee.
Acts. But after rising, go down,  go with them, doubting nothing, because I have sent them.
Acts. And having gone down to the men, Peter said, Behold, I am he whom ye seek. What is the cause for which ye are here?
Acts. And they said, Cornelius, a centurion, a righteous man,  fearing God,  being well testified by the whole nation of the Jews, was divinely warned by a holy agent to summon thee to his house,  to hear sayings from thee.
Acts. So, having invited them in, he lodged them. And on the morrow Peter went forth with them,  certain of the brothers from Joppa went with him.
Acts. And on the morrow they entered into Caesarea. And Cornelius was waiting for them, having called together his kinsmen and close friends.
Acts. And when it came about for Peter to enter, Cornelius, having met him, after falling down at his feet, worshiped.
Acts. But Peter lifted him up, saying, Stand up. I am also myself a man.
Acts. And as he conversed with him, he went in and found many who came together.
Acts. And he said to them, Ye understand how it is unlawful for a Jewish man to fraternize or to visit with a foreign man,  yet God demonstrated to me not to call one man profane or unclean.
Acts. And so I came without objection when summoned. I ask therefore for what matter ye summoned me.
Acts. And Cornelius said, Four days ago I was fasting until this hour,  the ninth hour praying in my house. And behold, a man stood before me in bright apparel.
Acts. And he says, Cornelius, thy prayer was heard,  thy charities are remembered before God.
Acts. Send therefore to Joppa,  summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter. This man lodges in the house of Simon, a tanner, beside the sea, who, after coming, will speak to thee.
Acts. Immediately therefore I sent to thee,  thou did well having come. Now therefore we are all present in the sight of God, to hear all the things commanded thee by God.
Acts. And having opened his mouth, Peter said, In truth, I am overwhelmed that God is not partial,
Acts. but in every nation, he who fears him,  works righteousness, is acceptable to him.
Acts. The word that he sent forth to the sons of Israel, preaching good news, peace by Jesus Christ (this man is Lord of all),
Acts. ye know, the word having occurred throughout the whole of Judea beginning from Galilee after the immersion that John preached-
Acts. Jesus of Nazareth-how God anointed him with the Holy Spirit and with power, who passed through doing good,  healing all those who were oppressed by the devil, because God was with him.
Acts. And we are witnesses of all that he did both in the country of the Jews,  in Jerusalem, whom also they killed, having hung on a tree.
Acts. This man God raised up the third day,  granted him to become manifest,
Acts. not to all the people,  to witnesses who were previously chosen by God, to us, who ate and drank with him after he arose from the dead.
Acts. And he commanded us to preach to the people,  to solemnly testify that this is the man designated by God, judge of the living and the dead.
Acts. To this man all the prophets testify, that every man who believes in him, to receive remission of sins through his name.
Acts. While Peter still spoke these sayings, the Holy Spirit fell on all those who heard the word.
Acts. And the faithful men of circumcision were astonished, as many as came with Peter, because also on the Gentiles the gift of the Holy Spirit was poured out.
Acts. For they heard them speaking in tongues and magnifying God. Then Peter answered,
Acts. Can any man forbid the water for these not to be immersed, who have received the Holy Spirit as we also?
Acts. And he commanded them to be immersed in the name of the Lord. Then they asked him to remain some days.
Acts. Now the apostles and the brothers who were in Judea heard that the Gentiles also received the word of God.
Acts. And when Peter came up to Jerusalem, the men of circumcision contended against him,
Acts. saying, Thou went in to uncircumcised men, having also eaten with them.
Acts. But when Peter began, he expounded to them in order, saying,
Acts. I was in the city of Joppa praying,  in a trance I saw a vision, a certain container descending, as a great sheet being lowered from heaven by four corners,  it came as far as to me,
Acts. having gazed at which, I was examining. And I saw the four footed things of the earth,  the wild beasts,  the creeping things,  the birds of the sky.
Acts. And I heard a voice saying to me, Having risen, Peter, kill and eat.
Acts. But I said, Not so, Lord, because nothing profane or unclean has ever entered into my mouth.
Acts. But a voice answered me for a second time out of heaven, What God has cleansed, thou shall not make profane.
Acts. And this happened thrice,  all were drawn up again into heaven.
Acts. And behold, immediately three men stood at the house in which I was, who were sent from Caesarea to me.
Acts. And the Spirit told me to go with them, doubting nothing. And these six brothers also went with me,  we entered into the man's house.
Acts. And he informed us how he saw the agent in his house, who stood and said to him, Send forth men to Joppa,  summon Simon, the man surnamed Peter,
Acts. who will speak sayings to thee, by which thou will be saved, thou and all thy house.
Acts. And as I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as also on us at the beginning.
Acts. And I remembered the saying of the Lord, how he said, John indeed immersed in water,  ye will be immersed in the Holy Spirit.
Acts. If then God gave to them the identical gift as also to us who believed in the Lord Jesus Christ,  what power was I to hinder God?
Acts. And when they heard these things, they relaxed and glorified God, saying, Then God has also granted to the Gentiles repentance to life.
Acts. Indeed therefore those who were scattered abroad from the persecution that occurred against Stephen passed through as far as Phoenicia and Cyprus and Antioch, speaking the word to none except Jews only.
Acts. And some of them were men, Cyprians and Cyrenians, who, having come to Antioch, spoke to the Hellenists, preaching good news, the Lord Jesus.
Acts. And the hand of the Lord was with them,  a great number who believed turned to the Lord.
Acts. And the word about them was heard in the ears of the church at Jerusalem,  they dispatched Barnabas to pass through as far as Antioch,
Acts. who, having arrived,  having seen the grace of God, rejoiced. And he encouraged all, with purpose of heart, to remain in the Lord.
Acts. Because he was a good man,  full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a considerable multitude was added to the Lord.
Acts. And Barnabas departed to Tarsus to seek Saul,
Acts. and when he found him, he brought him to Antioch. And it came to pass a whole year for them to be assembled in the congregation,  to teach a considerable multitude,  to call the disciples Christians, first at Antioch.
Acts. Now in these days prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.
Acts. And one of them named Agabus, after standing up, signified by the Spirit there was going be a great famine in the whole world, which also happened under Claudius Caesar.
Acts. And the disciples, as any man prospered, determined, each of them regarding aid, to send to the brothers who dwell in Judea,
Acts. which also they did, having sent it to the elders by the hand of Barnabas and Saul.
Acts. Now about that time Herod the king threw on hands to harm some of those from the church.
Acts. And he killed James the brother of John with the sword.
Acts. And after seeing that it was pleasing the Jews, he proceeded to arrest Peter also (and those were the days of unleavened bread),
Acts. whom, having also arrested, he put in prison, having delivered to four quaternions of soldiers to guard him, intending after the Passover to bring him forth to the people.
Acts. Indeed therefore Peter was kept in the prison,  fervent prayer was being made by the church to God for him.
Acts. And when Herod was about to bring him forth, that night Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound by two chains. And guards in front of the door guarded the prison.
Acts. And behold, an agent of the Lord stood near,  light shone in the room. And after striking the side of Peter, he raised him up, saying, Get up quickly. And his chains fell off from his hands.
Acts. And the agent said to him, Gird thyself,  tie on thy sandals. And he did so. And he says to him, Throw on thy garment,  follow me.
Acts. And after going out, he followed him. And he had not seen that the thing happening by the agent was true,  presumed to see a vision.
Acts. And when they passed a first and a second watch, they came to the iron gate, the one leading to the city, which opened spontaneously to them. And after going out, they advanced one street. And straightaway the agent withdrew from him.
Acts. And when Peter came to himself, he said, Now I know truly, that the Lord dispatched his agent and delivered me out of the hand of Herod and all the expectation of the people of the Jews.
Acts. And having realized it, he came to the house of Mary the mother of John, surnamed Mark, where a considerable were gathered and praying.
Acts. And when Peter knocked the door of the gate, a servant girl named Rhoda came to hearken.
Acts. And after recognizing Peter's voice, she did not open the gate for joy,  having ran in, she reported Peter was standing in front of the gate.
Acts. And they said to her, Thou are mad. But she insisted to have it so. But they said, It is his agent.
Acts. But Peter continued knocking,  when they opened, they saw him,  were astonished.
Acts. But after motioning to them with the hand to be silent, he described to them how the Lord brought him out of the prison. And he said, Report these things to James,  to the brothers. And having departed, he went to a different place.
Acts. But having become day, there was no small stir among the soldiers what then became of Peter.
Acts. And Herod, who sought for him,  not having found, having examined the guards, he commanded them to be led away. And going down from Judea to Caesarea, he remained there.
Acts. Now Herod was angry at the Tyrians and Sidonians. But they came with one accord to him, , having persuaded Blastus the man over the king's bedchamber, they requested peace, because their country was sustained from the monarchy.
Acts. And at a set day Herod, having arrayed himself in royal apparel,  having sat on the tribunal, he made an oration to them.
Acts. And the populace shouted, The voice of a god,  not of a man.
Acts. And immediately an agent of the Lord struck him, because he did not give glory to God. And after becoming worm-eaten, he expired.
Acts. But the word of God grew and multiplied.
Acts. And Barnabas and Saul turned back in Jerusalem after fulfilling the service, also having taken along John who was surnamed Mark.
Acts. Now there were some men from the congregation that was in Antioch, prophets and teachers, including Barnabas,  Simeon called Niger,  Lucius the Cyrenian,  Manaen reared with Herod the tetrarch,  Saul.
Acts. And while they were serving the Lord,  fasting, the Holy Spirit said, Separate to me now Barnabas and Saul for the work that I have called them.
Acts. Then, having fasted and prayed and laid hands on them, they sent them away.
Acts. Indeed therefore these men, having been sent forth by the Holy Spirit, went down to Seleucia,  from there they sailed for Cyprus.
Acts. And after becoming in Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews,  they also had John for a helper.
Acts. And after going through the island as far as Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a Jewish false prophet, whose name was Bar-jesus,
Acts. who was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. This man, having summoned Barnabas and Saul, sought to hear the word of God.
Acts. But Elymas the sorcerer (for so his name is translated) opposed them, seeking to deviate the proconsul from the faith.
Acts. But Saul (the man is also Paul) having been filled with the Holy Spirit,  having gazed on him,
Acts. said, O man full of all deceit and all recklessness, thou son of the devil, thou enemy of all righteousness, will thou not cease distorting the straight ways of the Lord?
Acts. And now, behold, a hand of the Lord is upon thee,  thou will be blind, not seeing the sun until a time. And immediately there fell on him gloom and darkness,  going around he sought hand-guides.
Acts. Then the proconsul, who saw that which happened, believed, being astonished at the doctrine of the Lord.
Acts. Now those around Paul, having launched from Paphos, they came to Perga in Pamphylia. But John, having departed from them, returned to Jerusalem.
Acts. And they, having passed through from Perga, arrived at Antioch of Pisidia,  after entering into the synagogue on the sabbath day, they sat down.
Acts. And after the reading of the law and the prophets the synagogue rulers sent to them, saying, Men, brothers, if there is among you a word of exhortation for the people, speak.
Acts. And Paul having stood up,  having motioned with the hand, he said, Men! Israelites and those who fear God, listen.
Acts. The God of this people Israel chose our fathers,  raised up the people during the sojourn in the land of Egypt. And with a lofty arm he brought them out of it.
Acts. And for about a forty-year time he was patient with them in the wilderness.
Acts. And having destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan, he allotted their land to them.
Acts. And after these things he gave them judges about four hundred and fifty years until Samuel the prophet.
Acts. And afterward they asked for a king,  God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
Acts. And having removed him, he raised up David for a king to them, also about whom he said, when he testified, I have found David the son of Jesse, a man according to my heart, who will do all my purposes.
Acts. From this man's seed according to promise, God brought salvation to Israel,
Acts. John having earlier proclaimed, before his coming presence, the immersion of repentance to Israel.
Acts. And as John was fulfilling his course, he said, Whom do ye suppose me to be? I am not,  behold, he comes after me of whom I am not worthy to loose the shoes of his feet.
Acts. Men, brothers, sons of the race of Abraham,  those among you who fear God, to you the word of this salvation was sent.
Acts. For those who dwell in Jerusalem,  their rulers, not having known this and the voices of the prophets being read at every sabbath, they fulfilled, having condemned him.
Acts. And not having found one cause of death in him, they asked for Pilate to kill him.
Acts. And when they completed all the things written about him, having taken him down from the tree, they laid him in a tomb.
Acts. But God raised him from the dead,
Acts. who was seen for more days by those who came up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are witnesses of him to the people.
Acts. And we proclaim good news to you: the promise to the fathers, which happened because God has fulfilled this to us their children, having raised up Jesus,
Acts. as also it is written in the second psalm, Thou are my Son, today I have begotten thee.
Acts. And because he raised him from the dead, no longer going to return to decay, he has spoken this way: I will give to you the faithful holy things of David.
Acts. Therefore also he says in another, Thou will not give thy Holy Man to see decay.
Acts. For indeed David, who served his own generation in the plan of God, became asleep,  was added near his fathers,  saw decay.
Acts. But he whom God raised up saw no decay.
Acts. Be it known to you therefore, men, brothers, that through this man remission of sins is proclaimed to you.
Acts. And from all things of which ye could not be make righteous by the law of Moses, in this man every man who believes is made righteous.
Acts. Watch therefore, lest that which is spoken in the prophets should come upon you:
Acts. Behold, ye scoffers,  wonder,  perish, because I work a work in your days, which ye would, no, not believe, if some man should fully narrate it to you.
Acts. And as they went out from the synagogue of the Jews, the Gentiles urged that these sayings be spoken to them the next sabbath.
Acts. Now after the synagogue was dismissed, many of the Jews and of the devout proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas, who, while conversing, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God.
Acts. And on the coming sabbath almost all the city was assembled to hear the word of God.
Acts. But when the Jews saw the multitudes, they were filled of envy,  contradicted the things spoken by Paul, contradicting and slandering.
Acts. But having spoken boldly, Paul and Barnabas said, It was necessary for the word of God to be spoken first to you,  since ye thrust it away,  judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles.
Acts. For so the Lord has commanded us: I have placed thee for a light of Gentiles, for thee to be for salvation as far as the extremity of the earth.
Acts. And hearing this, the Gentiles were glad and glorified the word of the Lord. And as many as were appointed for eternal life believed.
Acts. And the word of the Lord was spread abroad through the whole region.
Acts. But the Jews incited the religious women,  the prominent women,  the principle men of the city,  raised up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas. And they threw them out of their boundaries.
Acts. But after shaking off the dust of their feet against them, they came to Iconium.
Acts. And the disciples were filled with joy and the Holy Spirit.
Acts. And it came to pass in Iconium according to the same thing, for them to enter into the synagogue of the Jews,  to speak so as for a great quantity to believe, both of Jews and of Greeks.
Acts. But the disobedient Jews aroused the souls of the Gentiles,  made them evil against the brothers.
Acts. Indeed therefore they remained a considerable time speaking boldly in the Lord-him testifying to the word of his grace, granting signs and wonders to occur by their hands.
Acts. But the majority of the city was divided,  verily there were those with the Jews,  those with the apostles.
Acts. And as a violent movement developed, both of the Gentiles and of the Jews, with their rulers, to denounce and to stone them,
Acts. having become aware of it, they fled to the cities of Lycaonia, Lystra,  Derbe,  the neighboring region.
Acts. And there they were preaching the good news.
Acts. And a certain man was sitting in Lystra, disabled in his feet, being a cripple from his mother's belly, who had never walked.
Acts. This man was listening to Paul speaking, who, having gazed at him,  having seen that he has faith to be healed,
Acts. said with a great voice, Stand correctly on thy feet. And he leaped up and walked.
Acts. And the multitudes who saw what Paul did, lifted up their voice, speaking Lycaonian, The gods came down to us, having become like men.
Acts. And they actually called Barnabas, Zeus,  Paul, Hermes, because he was the man who led the word.
Acts. And the priest of Zeus, being in front of their city, after bringing oxen and garlands to the gates, wanted to sacrifice with the multitudes.
Acts. But when the apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard, having torn their garments, they rushed into the crowd, crying out
Acts. and saying, Men, why are ye doing these things? We also are men of like nature with you, proclaiming good news to you, to turn from these vain things to the living God, who made the heaven and the earth and the sea,  all the things in them,
Acts. who in the generations that have passed allowed all the nations to go in their own ways,
Acts. although he did not leave himself without evidence, doing good and giving you rains from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts of food and gladness.
Acts. And saying these things, they scarcely restrained the multitudes not to sacrifice to them.
Acts. But Jews came from Antioch and Iconium. And having persuaded the crowds,  having stoned Paul, they dragged him out of the city, after presuming him to be dead.
Acts. But the disciples having surrounded him, after rising, he came into the city. And on the morrow he departed with Barnabas to Derbe.
Acts. And having preached the good news to that city,  having made considerable disciples, they returned to Lystra,  to Iconium,  to Antioch,
Acts. strengthening the souls of the disciples, exhorting them to continue in the faith,  that it was necessary for us to enter into the kingdom of God through many tribulations.
Acts. And having appointed elders for them in every congregation, having prayed with fasting, they entrusted them to the Lord, in whom they had believed.
Acts. And after passing through Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.
Acts. And when they spoke the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia,
Acts. and from there they sailed to Antioch, from where they were delivered to the grace of God for the work that they fulfilled.
Acts. And after arriving,  after gathering the assembly together, they reported as many things as God did with them,  that he opened a door of faith to the Gentiles.
Acts. And they remained there no little time with the disciples.
Acts. And certain men, who came down from Judea, taught the brothers, Unless ye will be circumcised in the custom of Moses, ye cannot be saved.
Acts. Therefore, no small dissension and debate having developed with Paul and Barnabas against them, they appointed Paul and Barnabas,  some other men from them, to go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and elders in Jerusalem about this issue.
Acts. Indeed therefore, having been helped for the trip by the congregation, they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, describing the conversion of the Gentiles. And they caused great joy to all the brothers.
Acts. And after arriving in Jerusalem, they were received by the church and the apostles and the elders. And they reported as many things as God did with them.
Acts. But some of the men who believed from the sect of the Pharisees rose up, saying, It is necessary to circumcise them,  to command them to keep the law of Moses.
Acts. And the apostles and the elders were assembled together to see about this matter.
Acts. And when much debate occurred, Peter having risen up, he said to them, Men, brothers, ye know that from past days among us, God chose the Gentiles to hear through my mouth the word of the good news,  to believe.
Acts. And God, who knows the heart, testified to them, having given them the Holy Spirit, just as also to us.
Acts. And he made not one distinction between both us and them, having purified their hearts by faith.
Acts. Now therefore why do ye challenge God, to place a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear?
Acts. But through the grace of the Lord Jesus, we believe to be saved, in the same way as those men also.
Acts. And all the multitude kept silent,  they heard Barnabas and Paul describing how many signs and wonders God did among the Gentiles through them.
Acts. And after they were quiet, James answered, saying, Men, brothers, hear me.
Acts. Simeon described how God first came to help, to take from the Gentiles a people for his name.
Acts. And to this the words of the prophets agree, as it is written,
Acts. After these things I will return,  I will rebuild the tabernacle of David that has fallen. And I will rebuild the things of it that have been demolished,  I will restore it,
Acts. so that the rest of men might seek the Lord,  all the Gentiles upon whom my name is called upon them, says the Lord, who does these things.
Acts. Known to God from the age are all his works.
Acts. Therefore I judge not to trouble those from the Gentiles who are turning to God,
Acts. but to write to them, to abstain from the pollutions of idols,  from fornication,  from what is strangled,  from blood.
Acts. For Moses from generations past, has from city to city those who preach him, being read in the synagogues on every sabbath.
Acts. Then it was decided by the apostles and the elders, with the whole assembly, to send men chosen from them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas, namely, Judas called Barsabbas,  Silas, leading men among the brothers,
Acts. after writing by their hand these things: The apostles,  the elders,  the brothers, to those down in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia, to the brothers of the Gentiles, greeting.
Acts. Since we have heard that certain men who went out from us have troubled you with words, disturbing your souls, saying to be circumcised,  to keep the law, to whom we did not command,
Acts. it was decided by us, having become unanimous, to send chosen men to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
Acts. men who have given over their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Acts. We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, themselves also declaring the same things by speech.
Acts. For it was decided by the Holy Spirit,  by us, to lay upon you not one greater burden than these necessary things:
Acts. to abstain from things sacrificed to idols,  from blood,  from things strangled,  from fornication, keeping yourselves from which, ye will do well. Be strong.
Acts. Indeed therefore after being dismissed, they came to Antioch,  having gathered the multitude together, they delivered the letter.
Acts. And after reading it, they rejoiced for the encouragement.
Acts. And Judas and Silas, being themselves also prophets, exhorted the brothers by much speech,  strengthened them.
Acts. And after spending some time, they were dismissed with peace from the brothers to the apostles.
Acts. [This verse is not in the majority of the Greek manuscripts.]
Acts. But Paul and Barnabas continued in Antioch, teaching and preaching good news, the word of the Lord, with many others also.
Acts. And after some days Paul said to Barnabas, After returning, surely we could help our brothers in every city in which we proclaimed the word of the Lord, how they fare.
Acts. And Barnabas wanted to take along John called Mark.
Acts. But Paul thought it not worthy to bring along this man who withdrew from them from Pamphylia,  not having gone with them to the work.
Acts. Therefore a provocation developed, so as for them to separate from each other,  Barnabas to sail for Cyprus, after taking Mark,
Acts. but Paul, having selected Silas, went forth after being delivered to the grace of God by the brothers.
Acts. And he passed through Syria and Cilicia, encouraging the congregations.
Acts. And he came to Derbe and to Lystra. And behold, a certain disciple was there, named Timothy, the son of a certain faithful Jewish woman,  of a Greek father,
Acts. who was well reported of by the brothers at Lystra and Iconium.
Acts. Paul wanted this man to go forth with him. And having taken him, he circumcised him because of the Jews who were in those regions, for they had all seen that his father was a Greek.
Acts. And as they were going through the cities, they delivered to them the decrees to keep, which were determined by the apostles and elders at Jerusalem.
Acts. Indeed therefore the congregations were strengthened in the faith,  increased in number daily.
Acts. But having passed through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia,
Acts. having come toward Mysia, they attempted to go toward Bithynia. And the Spirit did not allow them.
Acts. And after passing by Mysia, they came down to Troas.
Acts. And a vision appeared to Paul during the night. A certain Macedonian man was standing, imploring him,  saying, After crossing over into Macedonia, help us.
Acts. And after he saw the vision, straightaway we sought to go forth into Macedonia, concluding that the Lord called us to preach the good news to them.
Acts. Therefore, having launched from Troas, we took a straight course to Samothrace,  the next day to Neapolis,
Acts. and from there to Philippi, which is a principle city of the district of Macedonia colony. And we were in the same city remaining some days.
Acts. And on the sabbath day we went outside the city beside a river, where it was customary for prayer to be. And having sat down, we spoke to the women who came together.
Acts. And a certain woman named Lydia, a seller of purple of the city of Thyatira, a woman who worshiped God, was listening, whose heart the Lord opened to heed the things being spoken by Paul.
Acts. And when she was immersed,  her household, she urged us, saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, after coming into my house, remain. And she constrained us.
Acts. And it came to pass, as we were going to prayer, for a certain servant girl having a spirit of divination to meet us, who brought her masters much business by soothsaying.
Acts. This woman having followed Paul and us was crying out, saying, These men are bondmen of the Most High God, who proclaim to us the way of salvation.
Acts. And she did this on many days. But Paul, after being exasperated,  having turned, he said to the spirit, I command thee in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her. And it came out the same hour.
Acts. But when her masters saw that the hope of their business was gone, having seized Paul and Silas, they dragged them into the marketplace to the rulers.
Acts. And after bringing them to the magistrates, they said, These men, being Jews, disturb our city,
Acts. and proclaim customs that are not permitted for us to receive nor to do, being Romans.
Acts. And the multitude rose up together against them. And the magistrates, having torn off their clothes, commanded to beat them with rods.
Acts. And having laid many blows upon them, they cast them into prison, having ordered the jailor to guard them securely,
Acts. who, having received such an order, threw them into the inner prison,  fastened their feet in the stocks.
Acts. Now toward midnight Paul and Silas, while praying, were singing praises to God,  the prisoners were listening to them.
Acts. And suddenly a great earthquake occurred, so as for the foundations of the prison to shake. And immediately all the doors were opened,  the bonds of all the men were unfastened.
Acts. And the jailor, who became awake and who saw the prison doors opened, having drawn out a sword was going to kill himself, supposing the prisoners to have fled.
Acts. But Paul cried out in a great voice, saying, Do nothing harmful to thyself, for we are all here.
Acts. And having asked for lights, he rushed in,  having become trembling, he fell down before Paul and Silas.
Acts. And after bringing them outside, he said, Sirs, what must I do so that I may be saved?
Acts. And they said, Believe in the Lord Jesus,  thou will be saved, thou and thy household.
Acts. And they spoke the word of the Lord to him,  to all those in his house.
Acts. And having taken them in that hour of the night, he washed from the stripes,  was immersed, he and all those of him, immediately.
Acts. And having brought them into his house, he set out a table,  rejoiced, having believed in God with all his house.
Acts. But when it became day, the magistrates sent out the police, saying, Release those men.
Acts. And the jailor reported these words to Paul: The magistrates have sent out so that ye may be released. Now therefore after coming out, go in peace.
Acts. But Paul said to them, Having beaten us publicly, uncondemned men, being Romans, they cast us into prison,  now they thrust us out privately? Certainly not,  after coming, they shall lead us out.
Acts. And the police reported these sayings to the magistrates,  they were afraid when they heard that they were Romans.
Acts. And having come they besought them,  when they brought them out, they asked them to go out of the city.
Acts. And having departed from the prison, they came in to Lydia. And after seeing the brothers, they encouraged them,  departed.
Acts. Now after passing through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
Acts. And according to Paul's custom, he went in to them,  for three sabbaths he discoursed with them from the scriptures,
Acts. explaining and pointing out that it was necessary for the Christ to suffer,  to rise from the dead, , This Jesus, whom I proclaim to you, is the Christ.
Acts. And some of them were persuaded,  joined with Paul and Silas,  of the devout Greeks a great quantity,  of the prominent women not a few.
Acts. But the disobedient Jews having taken along certain evil men of the marketplaces,  having gathered a mob, were rioting the city. And having stood by the house of Jason, they sought to bring them out to the populace.
Acts. And not having found them, they dragged Jason and some brothers to the city rulers, shouting, The men who have agitated the world, these are present here also,
Acts. whom Jason has received. And all these men are acting against the decrees of Caesar, asserting another man to be king, Jesus.
Acts. And they disturbed the multitude and the city rulers when they heard these things.
Acts. And after taking bond from Jason and the other men, they released them.
Acts. And the brothers straightaway sent both Paul and Silas away through the night to Berea, who, when they arrived, went into the synagogue of the Jews.
Acts. But these were more noble than those in Thessalonica, who received the word with all willingness, examining the scriptures daily, if it has these things this way.
Acts. Indeed therefore many of them believed, also of the prominent Greek women,  of men, not a few.
Acts. But when the Jews of Thessalonica also learned that the word of God was proclaimed by Paul at Berea, they came there also, agitating the crowds.
Acts. But then straightaway the brothers sent Paul away to go as far as to the sea,  both Silas and Timothy remained there.
Acts. And those who brought Paul led him as far as Athens. And after taking a command for Silas and Timothy, that they should come to him quickly, they departed.
Acts. But while Paul waited for them in Athens, his spirit was aroused within him, seeing the city being completely idolatrous.
Acts. Indeed therefore he was discoursing in the synagogue with the Jews,  with those who worship,  in the marketplace every day with those who happened by.
Acts. And also some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers encountered him. And some said, Whatever does this babbler want to say? But others, He seems to be a proclaimer of strange deities, because he brought the good news-Jesus and the resurrection.
Acts. And having taken him, they brought him to the Areopagus, saying, Can we understand what this new doctrine is, being spoken by thee?
Acts. For thou bring some surprising things to our ears. Therefore, we want to know whatever these things aim to be.
Acts. Now all the Athenians,  the foreigners who dwell alien there, were at leisure in nothing else, than to tell or to hear something new.
Acts. And having stood in the middle of the Areopagus, Paul said, Athenian men, I perceive you as deity-fearing in all things.
Acts. For, passing through and examining your religious objects, I also found an altar on which had been engraved, TO AN UNKNOWN GOD. Whom therefore ye worship unknowingly, him I proclaim to you.
Acts. The God who made the world and all things in it, he, being Lord of heaven and earth, dwells not in temples made with hands,
Acts. nor is he served by the hands of men, as needing anything, since he himself gives to all life,  breath, with all things.
Acts. And he made from one blood every nation of men to dwell upon all the face of the earth, having determined prescribed times,  the limits of their occupancy,
Acts. to search for the Lord, if indeed perhaps they might grope for him and find him, although being not far from each one of us.
Acts. For in him we live,  move,  exist, as also some of the performers from you have said, For of him we are also offspring.
Acts. Being therefore offspring of God, we ought not think the Divine to be like gold, or silver, or stone handiwork of the skill and thought of man.
Acts. Indeed therefore having overlooked the times of ignorance, God now commands for all men everywhere to repent.
Acts. Because he appointed a day during which he is going to judge the world in righteousness by a man whom he appointed, having provided assurance to all men because he raised him from the dead.
Acts. But when they heard the resurrection of the dead, of course they mocked,  others said, We will hear thee again about this.
Acts. And so Paul departed from among them.
Acts. But some men, having joined with him, believed, among whom was also Dionysius the Areopagite,  a woman named Damaris,  others with them.
Acts. And after these things Paul having separated from Athens, he came to Corinth.
Acts. And having found a certain Jew named Aquila, a man of Pontus by origin, who recently came from Italy,  his wife Priscilla, because Claudius arranged for all the Jews to separate from Rome, he came to them.
Acts. And because he was of the same craft, he abode with them,  was working, for they were of the tentmakers craft.
Acts. And he was discoursing in the synagogue every sabbath,  was persuading Jews and Greeks.
Acts. And when both Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was being held by the Spirit, fully testifying to the Jews, Jesus the Christ.
Acts. But when they opposed and slandered him, having shaken out his clothes, he said to them, Your blood is upon your heads. I am clean. From henceforth I will go to the Gentiles.
Acts. And having departed from there, he went into the house of a certain man named Justus, who worships God, whose house was adjoining the synagogue.
Acts. And Crispus, the synagogue ruler, believed in the Lord with his whole household,  many of the Corinthians who heard believed,  were immersed.
Acts. And the Lord spoke to Paul by a vision at night, Fear not,  speak,  be not silent,
Acts. because I am with thee,  no man will lay upon thee to harm thee, because many people are for me in this city.
Acts. And he remained a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
Acts. But Gallio being proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one accord attacked Paul and brought him to the judgment seat,
Acts. saying, This man is persuading men to worship God against the law.
Acts. But when Paul was going to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, If therefore indeed it were some crime or evil reckless deed, O ye Jews, I would have tolerated you according to the matter.
Acts. But if it is an issue about a word and names and the law from you, look ye yourselves, for I do not intend to be a judge of these things.
Acts. And he drove them from the judgment seat.
Acts. But all the Greeks, having taken Sosthenes the synagogue ruler, were beating him in front of the judgment seat. And Gallio was not going to judge, even of these things.
Acts. But Paul, who still remained considerable days with the brothers, having separated, sailed away to Syria (and with him Priscilla and Aquila), having shaved his head in Cenchrea, for he had a vow.
Acts. And he came to Ephesus and left behind those there,  having entered into the synagogue himself, he discoursed with the Jews.
Acts. And when they asked him to remain on more time with them, he did not consent,
Acts. but separated from them, having said, I must definitely keep the coming feast at Jerusalem,  I will return again to you, God willing. And he launched from Ephesus.
Acts. And after coming down to Caesarea, having gone up and greeted the church, he went down to Antioch.
Acts. And after spending some time, he departed, passing through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, successively, strengthening all the disciples.
Acts. Now a certain Jew named Apollos, an Alexandrian by origin, an eloquent man, came to Ephesus, being mighty in the scriptures.
Acts. This was a man who was instructed in the way of the Lord. And being fervent in the Spirit, he was speaking and teaching accurately the things about the Lord, knowing only the immersion of John.
Acts. And this man began to speak boldly in the synagogue,  when Aquila and Priscilla heard him, they took him aside,  expounded to him the way of God more accurately.
Acts. And when he intended to pass through into Achaia, the brothers wrote, having encouraged the disciples to receive him, who, when he arrived, assisted much those who believed through the grace.
Acts. For he forcibly refuted the Jews in public, demonstrating by the scriptures Jesus to be the Christ.
Acts. And it came to pass while Apollos was at Corinth, for Paul, having passed through the upper regions, to come to Ephesus. And having found some disciples,
Acts. he said to them, Did ye receive the Holy Spirit when ye believed? And they said to him, But we have not even heard if there is a Holy Spirit.
Acts. And he said to them, Into what then were ye immersed? And they said, Into John's immersion.
Acts. And Paul said, John indeed immersed an immersion of repentance, saying to the people that they should believe in him who was coming after him, that is, in Jesus, the Christ.
Acts. And when they heard this, they were immersed in the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts. And Paul having laid hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them,  they spoke in tongues,  prophesied.
Acts. And all the men were about twelve.
Acts. And after entering into the synagogue, he spoke boldly for three months, discoursing and persuading the things about the kingdom of God.
Acts. But when some were hardened and disobedient, speaking evil of the Way before the multitude, having withdrawn from them, he separated the disciples, discoursing daily in the school of a certain Tyrannus.
Acts. And this happened for two years, so as for all those dwelling in Asia to hear the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.
Acts. And God was doing extraordinary miracles by the hands of Paul,
Acts. so as to even bring handkerchiefs or aprons from his skin to those who were incapacitated and to free their infirmities from them,  the evil spirits to go out from them.
Acts. But some of the wandering Jewish exorcists, attempted to name the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had the evil spirits, saying, We adjure you by Jesus whom Paul proclaims.
Acts. And there were some sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, seven doing this.
Acts. And having answered, the evil spirit said, I know Jesus and I recognize Paul,  who are ye?
Acts. And the man in whom was the evil spirit, leaping on them,  having overpowered them, he prevailed against them, so as for them to flee out of that house naked and wounded.
Acts. And this became known to all, both Jews and Greeks, to those who dwell at Ephesus. And fear fell upon them all,  the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
Acts. And many of those who have believed came, confessing,  reporting their practices.
Acts. And a considerable number of those who practiced magical things, having brought their books together, burned them in the sight of all. And they counted the price of them,  found it fifty thousand pieces of silver.
Acts. Thus the word of the Lord was growing mightily and was prevailing.
Acts. Now when these things were fulfilled, Paul decided in the spirit, after passing through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, having said, After becoming there, I must also see Rome.
Acts. And having sent into Macedonia two of those who help him, Timothy and Erastus, he himself stayed in Asia for a while.
Acts. And about that time there developed no small stir about the Way.
Acts. For a certain silversmith named Demetrius who makes silver shrines of Artemis, brought no little work to the craftsmen,
Acts. to whom also (having assembled the workmen about such things) he said, Men, ye know that our prosperity is from this work.
Acts. And ye see and hear, that not only at Ephesus,  almost in all Asia, this man Paul, having persuaded them, turned away a considerable multitude, saying that there are no gods made by hands.
Acts. And not only is this our part liable to come into disrepute,  also the temple of the great goddess Artemis is going to be regarded for nothing,  also her magnificence be destroyed, whom all Asia and the world worship.
Acts. And when they heard this, having become full of wrath, they cried out, saying, The great Artemis of Ephesians.
Acts. And the whole city was filled with the confusion. And they rushed with one accord into the theatre, having seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians, traveling companions of Paul.
Acts. And when Paul wanted to enter in to the crowd, the disciples did not let him.
Acts. And also some of the Asian officers, being their friends, having sent to him, implored him not to give himself into the theatre.
Acts. Indeed therefore some cried out one thing, some another, for the assembly was confused,  most had not seen why they had come together.
Acts. And they urged forward Alexander out of the multitude, having put him forward from the Jews. And Alexander having waved his hand, wanted to make a defense to the crowd.
Acts. But after recognizing that he was a Jew, one voice developed from them all, crying out for about two hours, The great Artemis of Ephesians.
Acts. And when the town clerk calmed the multitude, he says, Ephesian men, now who is the man who does not know the city of the Ephesians being temple-guardian of the great goddess Artemis,  of what fell from Zeus?
Acts. Therefore these things being undeniable, ye ought to be restrained,  do nothing rash.
Acts. For ye brought these men, who are neither sacrilegious nor blaspheming your goddess.
Acts. Indeed therefore if Demetrius,  the craftsmen with him, have a matter against any man, forums are brought,  there are proconsuls. Let them accuse each other.
Acts. And if ye seek anything about other things, it will be decided in the assembly within law.
Acts. For we are also in danger to be accused about the uproar today, there being no cause about which we can give account of this commotion.
Acts. And having said these things, he dismissed the assembly.
Acts. And after the uproar ceased, Paul having summoned the disciples and having embraced them, he departed to go into Macedonia.
Acts. And having passed through those parts,  having exhorted them with many words, he came into Greece.
Acts. And having spent three months there,  a conspiracy having developed against him by Jews, intending to go up into Syria, a decision developed to return through Macedonia.
Acts. And there accompanied him as far as Asia, Sopater a Berean,  of the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus,  Gaius a Derbean,  Timothy,  the Asians, Tychicus and Trophimus.
Acts. These men, who went ahead, awaited us at Troas.
Acts. And we sailed away from Philippi after the days of unleavened bread,  came to them at Troas within five days, where we stayed seven days.
Acts. And upon the first day of the week, the disciples having come together to break bread, Paul discoursed with them, intending to depart on the morrow. And he prolonged his speech until midnight.
Acts. And there were considerable lights in the upper floor where we were gathered together.
Acts. And a certain young man named Eutychus sitting in the window, being carried away by deep sleep (Paul discoursing on more), being carried away by sleep, he fell down below from the third floor,  was taken up dead.
Acts. But Paul having come down, he fell on him,  having embraced him he said, Be not troubled, for his life is in him.
Acts. And after getting up,  having broken bread and eaten,  having conversed for a considerable time, until dawn, thus he departed.
Acts. And they brought the boy alive,  were not a little comforted.
Acts. But we, having gone ahead to the ship, went up to Assos, intending from there to take up Paul, for so it was arranged, he himself intending to go on foot.
Acts. And when he met with us at Assos, having taken him up, we came to Mitylene.
Acts. And having sailed from there on the next day, we arrived opposite Chios,  the next day we came near to Samos. And having remained in Trogyllium, on the following day we came to Miletus.
Acts. For Paul determined to sail past Ephesus, so that he might not happen to lose time in Asia. For he was hastening, if it were possible, for him to become at Jerusalem the day of Pentecost.
Acts. And from Miletus having sent to Ephesus, he summoned the elders of the congregation.
Acts. And when they came to him, he said to them, Ye know, from the first day in which I stepped in Asia, how I became with you all the time,
Acts. serving the Lord with all humility,  many tears and trials that befell me by the conspiracies of the Jews.
Acts. How I kept back nothing of these things that are beneficial, not to inform you,  to teach you in public,  from house to house,
Acts. testifying both to Jews and to Greeks repentance toward God,  faith toward our Lord Jesus.
Acts. And now behold, I, bound in the spirit, am going to Jerusalem, not knowing the things that will happen to me in it,
Acts. except that the Holy Spirit testifies from city to city, saying that bonds and afflictions await me.
Acts. But I make nothing of the matter, nor do I hold my life precious to myself, so as to fully complete my course with joy,  the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to solemnly testify the good news of the grace of God.
Acts. And now behold, I have seen that ye will no longer see my face, ye all among whom I passed through preaching the kingdom of God.
Acts. Therefore I solemnly declare to you this day, that I am clean from the blood of all men.
Acts. For I did not withdraw from declaring to you the whole plan of God.
Acts. Take heed therefore to yourselves,  to all the flock, among which the Holy Spirit placed you guardians, to tend the church of the Lord and God, which he purchased by his own blood.
Acts. For I know this, that after my departure grievous wolves will enter in among you, not sparing the flock.
Acts. And from you yourselves men will rise up, speaking distorted things, to draw away the disciples after them.
Acts. Therefore watch ye, remembering that for three years, night and day, I did not cease warning each one with tears.
Acts. And now brothers, I commit you to God,  to the word of his grace, which is able to build up,  to give you an inheritance among all those who have been sanctified.
Acts. I coveted no man's silver, or gold, or apparel.
Acts. Ye yourselves know that these hands served my needs,  to those who were with me.
Acts. I gave you a glimpse of all things, that so laboring ye ought to aid the weak,  to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that he himself said, It is more blessed to give than to receive.
Acts. And having spoken these things, having knelt down, he prayed with them all.
Acts. And there developed considerable weeping of all. And having fallen on Paul's neck, they kissed him much,
Acts. sorrowing especially for the word that he had spoken, that they were going to see his face no more. And they accompanied him to the ship.
Acts. And when it came to pass to launch us, after being drawn away from them, after going a straight course, we came to Cos,  the next day to Rhodes,  from there to Patara.
Acts. And having found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, having gotten on, we launched.
Acts. And having sighted Cyprus,  having left it behind on the left side, we sailed to Syria and came down to Tyre, for there the ship was unloading the merchandise.
Acts. And having found disciples we remained there seven days, who said to Paul through the Spirit not to go up to Jerusalem.
Acts. And when it came to pass for us to finish the days, having gone forth, we were departing, all accompanying us, with women and children, as far as outside the city. And having knelt on the beach we prayed.
Acts. And having bid farewell to each other, we went up in the ship,  those men returned to their own things.
Acts. And when we finished the voyage from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais. And having greeted the brothers, we remained with them one day.
Acts. And on the morrow, after going forth, those around Paul came to Caesarea. And having entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, being of the seven, we dwelt with him.
Acts. Now four virgin daughters who prophesied were with this man.
Acts. And as we remained more days, a certain prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
Acts. And having come to us,  having taken Paul's belt, having bound both his feet and hands, he said, The Holy Spirit says these things: Thus the Jews in Jerusalem will bind the man whose belt this is,  will deliver him into the hands of Gentiles.
Acts. And when we heard these things, both we and those local men urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.
Acts. And Paul answered, What are ye doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I fare ready not only to be bound,  also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts. And since he was not persuaded, we were quiet, having said, May the will of the Lord happen.
Acts. And after these days, having made preparation, we went up to Jerusalem.
Acts. And also the disciples from Caesarea went together with us, bringing a certain Mnason, a Cypriot, an old disciple with whom we would lodge.
Acts. And when we came to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.
Acts. And on the following day Paul went in with us to James,  all the elders were present.
Acts. And having greeted them, he reported one by one what God did among the Gentiles through his ministry.
Acts. And when the men heard, they glorified God, having said to him, Thou see, brother, how many thousands there are of the Jews who have believed,  they are all zealots of the law.
Acts. And they were informed about thee, that thou teach all the Jews throughout the nations desertion from Moses, telling them not to circumcise the children nor to walk by the customs.
Acts. What is it therefore? Certainly the multitude needs to get together, for they will hear that thou have come.
Acts. Therefore do this that we say to thee. Four men are with us who have a vow on themselves.
Acts. Having taken these, be purified with them. And pay expenses for them, so that they may shave the head. And all may know, that things of which they have been informed about thee, are nothing,  thou thyself also walk orderly, keeping the law.
Acts. And about the Gentiles who have believed, we sent word, having decided for them to keep no such thing, except for them to guard against what is sacrificed to idols,  from blood,  from what is strangled,  from fornication.
Acts. Then Paul, having taken the men on the following day, having been purified with them, entered into the temple, declaring the fulfillment of the days of purification, until the offering was offered for each one of them.
Acts. And when the seven days were about to be completed, the Jews from Asia, when they saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people and threw hands on him,
Acts. crying out, Men, Israelites, help. This is the man who teaches all men everywhere against the people,  the law,  this place. And besides he also brought Greeks into the temple,  has defiled this holy place.
Acts. For they were men who saw Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they supposed that Paul brought into the temple.
Acts. And the whole city was moved,  there developed a running together of the people. And having taken Paul they dragged him out of the temple,  straightaway the doors were shut.
Acts. And while seeking to kill him, a report went up to the chief captain of the band, that all Jerusalem has been stirred up.
Acts. And immediately after taking soldiers and centurions, he ran down to them. And they, when they saw the chief captain and the soldiers, stopped beating Paul.
Acts. And the chief captain having come near, he seized him,  commanded him to be bound with two chains. And he inquired whoever he may be,  what it is he has been doing.
Acts. And some among the crowd shouted out one thing, some another. And not being able to know the certainty because of the uproar, he commanded him to be carried into the fort.
Acts. And it came to pass when on the steps (it happened for him to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,
Acts. for the mass of the people followed, crying out, Away with him),
Acts. and as Paul was going to be brought into the fort, he says to the chief captain, Is it permitted for me to speak to thee? And he said, Thou know Greek?
Acts. Then thou are not the Egyptian who revolted before these days,  who led out into the wilderness the four thousand men of the Assassins?
Acts. But Paul said, I am really a Jewish man of Tarsus of Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city. And I beg thee, allow me to speak to the people.
Acts. And having permitted him, Paul, having stood on the steps, motioned his hand to the people. And when a great hush developed, he called out in the Hebrew language, saying,
Acts. Men, brothers,  fathers, hear now my defense to you.
Acts. And having heard that he called out to them in the Hebrew language, they offered more silence. And he says,
Acts. I am indeed a Jewish man, born in Tarsus of Cilicia,  reared in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, reared accurately in the paternal law, being a zealot of God, as ye all are today.
Acts. And I persecuted this Way as far as death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women.
Acts. As also the high priest testifies about me,  all the senior council, from whom also having received letters to the brothers in Damascus, I was going to bring bound even those who were there to Jerusalem so that they might be punished.
Acts. And there happened to me, while going and approaching Damascus about noon, suddenly to flash forth from heaven a great light around me.
Acts. And I fell to the ground,  heard a voice saying to me, Saul, Saul, why do thou persecute me?
Acts. And I answered, Who are thou, Lord? And he said to me, I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom thou persecute.
Acts. And those who were with me indeed saw the light and became afraid,  they heard not the voice of him who spoke to me.
Acts. And I said, What shall I do, Lord? And the Lord said to me, After rising, go into Damascus,  there it will be told thee about all things that have been assigned for thee to do.
Acts. And as I was not seeing from the splendor of that light, I came into Damascus, being led by hand by those who accompanied me.
Acts. And a certain Ananias, a devout man according to the law, having a good report by all the Jews who dwell there,
Acts. having come near me,  having stood by, he said to me, Brother Saul, look up. And I looked up on him the same hour.
Acts. And he said, The God of our fathers appointed thee to know his will,  to see the Righteous Man,  to hear a voice from his mouth,
Acts. because thou will be a witness for him to all men of the things that thou have seen and heard.
Acts. And now what is it going to be? Having arisen, immerse and wash away thy sins, calling on the name of the Lord.
Acts. And it came to pass, my having returned to Jerusalem and while I prayed in the temple, for me to became in a trance.
Acts. And I saw him saying to me, Hurry and depart in haste out of Jerusalem, because they will not accept thy testimony about me.
Acts. And I said, Lord, they know that I was imprisoning and beating in every synagogue those who believe in thee.
Acts. And when the blood of Stephen thy witness was shed, I myself also was standing by,  approving his killing,  keeping the garments of those who killed him.
Acts. And he said to me, Depart, because I will send thee far away to Gentiles.
Acts. And they heard him until this word. And they lifted up their voice, saying, Away with such a man from the earth, for he is not fit to live.
Acts. And of them crying out,  throwing off their garments,  casting dust into the air,
Acts. the chief captain commanded him be brought into the fort, having said to examine him by scourging, so that he might know for what reason they shouted against him this way.
Acts. And as they stretched him out with the thongs, Paul said to the centurion who stood by, Is it permitted for you to scourge a Roman man,  uncondemned?
Acts. And when the centurion heard, having come to the chief captain, he reported, saying, Look! What are thou about to do? For this man is a Roman.
Acts. And the chief captain having come, he said to him, Tell me if thou are a Roman. And he said, Yes.
Acts. And the chief captain answered, Of a great sum I obtained this citizenship. And Paul said, But then I was born so.
Acts. Straightaway therefore those who were about to examine him withdrew from him. And the chief captain was also afraid when he learned that he was a Roman,  because he was who bound him.
Acts. But on the morrow, wanting to know the certainty of why he was accused by the Jews, he loosed him from the bonds,  commanded the chief priests and all their council to come. And having brought Paul down, he set him before them.
Acts. And Paul, after looking intently at the council, said, Men, brothers, I have been a citizen in all good conscience to God until this day.
Acts. And the high priest Ananias ordered those who stood by him to strike his mouth.
Acts. Then Paul said to him, God is going to smite thee, a whitewashed wall. Thou even sit judging me according to the law,  violating law, thou command me to be struck?
Acts. And those who stood by said, Thou revile God's high priest?
Acts. And Paul said, I had not known, brothers, that he is a high priest, for it is written, Thou shall not speak ill of a ruler of thy people.
Acts. But when Paul ascertained that the one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, Men, brothers, I am a Pharisee, son of a Pharisee. About the hope and resurrection of the dead I am judged.
Acts. And when he said this, there developed a conflict of the Pharisees and Sadducees,  the group was divided.
Acts. For in fact Sadducees say to be no resurrection nor agent nor spirit,  Pharisees acknowledge them all.
Acts. And there developed a great clamor. And some of the scholars of the Pharisees part having risen, they argued vehemently, saying, We find nothing wrong in this man. But if a spirit spoke to him, or an agent, we should not fight against God.
Acts. And a great conflict having developed, the chief captain, having been alarmed lest Paul might be torn apart by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him away from the midst of them,  bring him into the fort.
Acts. And the following night the Lord, having stood by him, said, Cheer up, Paul, for as thou have testified these things about me at Jerusalem, so thou must testify also at Rome.
Acts. And when it became day, some of the Jews, having made a conspiracy, put themselves under a curse, saying neither to eat nor to drink until they would kill Paul.
Acts. And there were more than forty who made this conspiracy,
Acts. who, having come near to the chief priests and the elders, said, We have put ourselves under a curse, a curse to taste of nothing until we would kill Paul.
Acts. Now therefore ye with the council report to the chief captain that tomorrow he may bring him down to you, as though going to inquire more accurately the things about him. And we, before he comes near, are prepared to kill him.
Acts. But the son of Paul's sister, having heard of the ambush, having come and entered into the fort, he informed Paul.
Acts. And Paul, having called one of the centurions, said, Take this young man to the chief captain, for he has something to inform him.
Acts. Indeed therefore having taken him, he brought him to the chief captain,  says, Paul the prisoner, having called me, asked me to bring this young man to thee, who has something to say to thee.
Acts. And the chief captain having grasped his hand,  having gone in private, he asked him, What is it that thou have to inform me?
Acts. And he said, The Jews have agreed to ask thee that tomorrow thou would bring Paul down to the council, as though going to inquire something more accurately about him.
Acts. Therefore thou should not be persuaded by them, for more than forty men of them wait to ambush him, who have put themselves under an oath, neither to eat nor drink until they have killed him. And now they are ready, expecting the promise from thee.
Acts. Indeed therefore the chief captain dismissed the young man, having ordered, Tell no man that thou have shown these things to me.
Acts. And having summoned a certain two of the centurions, he said, Prepare two hundred soldiers that they may go to Caesarea,  seventy horsemen,  two hundred spearmen at the third hour of the night.
Acts. And provide beasts, so that after mounting Paul, they may bring him safely to Felix the governor,
Acts. after writing a letter containing this form:
Acts. Claudius Lysias to the eminent governor Felix, greeting.
Acts. This man who was seized by the Jews,  was going to be killed by them, having stood by with the soldiers, I rescued him, having learned that he is a Roman.
Acts. And wanting to know for what reason they accused him, I brought him down to their council,
Acts. whom I found accusing about issues of their law, having not one accusation worthy of death or of bonds.
Acts. And when it was reported to me of a plot going to be against the man by the Jews, I immediately sent him to thee, also having commanded the accusers to speak before thee the things against him. Be strong.
Acts. Indeed therefore, the soldiers, according to that which was precisely arranged for them, having taken Paul, they brought him through the night to Antipatris.
Acts. But on the morrow they returned to the fort, having allowed the horsemen to depart with him,
Acts. who, after coming to Caesarea and having delivered the letter to the governor, also presented Paul to him.
Acts. And the governor having read it,  having questioned from what province he was,  having found out that he was from Cilicia,
Acts. he said, I will hear thee when thine accusers also will arrive. And he commanded him to be kept in the Praetorium of Herod.
Acts. And after five days Ananias the high priest came down with the elders,  a certain orator, Tertullus, who appeared to the governor against Paul.
Acts. And when he was called, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, Experiencing much peace because of thee,  worthy deeds happening to this nation because of thy foresight,
Acts. we welcome, both always and everywhere, eminent Felix, with all thankfulness.
Acts. But, that I may not detain thee on more, I entreat thee in thy clemency to hear us briefly.
Acts. For we have found this man a plague, who even instigates sedition among all the Jews throughout the world,  a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes,
Acts. who also attempted to profane the temple, whom also we took,
Acts. [This verse is not in the majority of the Greek manuscripts.]
Acts. from whom thou will be able, having examined him, to learn about all these things of which we accuse him.
Acts. And the Jews also agreed, claiming to have these things this way.
Acts. And when the governor gestured to him to speak, Paul answered, Knowing for many years thou being a judge to this nation, I gladly make a defense of these things about myself,
Acts. thou being able to learn that there are for me not more than twelve days from which I went up to worship in Jerusalem.
Acts. And they found me neither in the temple disputing against any man, nor making a gang of a group, nor in the synagogues, nor in the city.
Acts. Neither can they prove against me of which things they now accuse me.
Acts. But this I confess to thee, that according to the Way that they call a sect, so serve I the paternal God, believing all things written according to the law and the prophets,
Acts. having hope toward God, which they themselves also await, to come to be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.
Acts. And in this I fashion myself, having a conscience always non-stumbling before God and men.
Acts. Now after more years I came, going to make donations to my nation,  offerings,
Acts. during which certain Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, not with a crowd or with a tumult,
Acts. who ought to be here before thee,  to accuse, if they would have anything against me.
Acts. Or let these men themselves say what wrongdoing they found in me, having stood before the council,
Acts. or about this one voice that I cried out standing among them: About a resurrection of the dead I am judged by you this day.
Acts. Now Felix, having heard these things, having known more precisely the things about the Way, he deferred them, having said, When Lysias the chief captain comes down, I will determine the things toward you.
Acts. He also arranged for the centurion to guard Paul,  to have reduced confinement,  to forbid none of his own men to serve or to come to him.
Acts. And after some days, Felix having arrived with Drusilla, his wife being Jewish, he summoned Paul,  heard him about the faith in Christ.
Acts. And as he discoursed about righteousness,  self-control,  the judgment going to be, Felix, having become afraid, answered, Go now,  having a convenient time, I will summon thee.
Acts. He also hoped simultaneously that money would be given him by Paul so that he might free him. And so, summoning him more frequently, he conversed with him.
Acts. But two years having been fulfilled, Felix received a successor, Porcius Festus. And wanting to lay down favors to the Jews, Felix left behind Paul bound.
Acts. Festus therefore having entered into the province, after three days he went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea.
Acts. And the high priest and the principal men of the Jews appeared to him against Paul,  urged him,
Acts. asking a favor against him, that he would summon him to Jerusalem, making an ambush to kill him on the way.
Acts. Indeed therefore Festus answered to keep Paul in Caesarea,  he himself was going to go out quickly.
Acts. Therefore he says, Let the able men among you, after coming down together, accuse him if there is anything in this man.
Acts. And after remaining among them more than ten days, having gone down to Caesarea, on the morrow having sat on the judgment seat, he commanded Paul to be brought.
Acts. And when he arrived, the Jews who came down from Jerusalem stood around, bringing many and serious accusations against Paul, which they could not prove,
Acts. while he was defending, Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar, have I transgressed anything.
Acts. But Festus, wanting to lay down a favor to the Jews, having answered Paul, said, Are thou willing, after going up to Jerusalem, to be judged there about these things before me?
Acts. But Paul said, I am standing at the judgment seat of Caesar, where I ought to be judged. I did nothing wrong Jewish, as thou also very well know.
Acts. For if I am indeed wrong,  have done anything worthy of death, I do not refuse to die,  if there is nothing of what these men accuse me, no man can give me to them freely. I appeal Caesar.
Acts. Then Festus, when he conferred with the council, answered, Thou have appealed Caesar, to Caesar thou will go.
Acts. Now some days having passed, Agrippa the king and Bernice arrived at Caesarea, greeting Festus.
Acts. And as he was remaining there more days, Festus declared to the king the things concerning Paul, saying, There is a certain man who was left behind a prisoner by Felix,
Acts. about whom, when I became in Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews revealed, asking judgment against him.
Acts. To whom I answered, that it is not a custom by Romans to give any man freely for destruction, before the man being accused has the accusers in person,  receives an occasion of defense about the accusation.
Acts. When therefore they assembled here, not having made one delay, next in order, having sat on the judgment seat, I commanded the man to be brought.
Acts. About whom, when the accusers stood up, they brought not one cause of what I supposed,
Acts. but had certain issues against him about his own religion,  about a certain Jesus, who has died, whom Paul was claiming to be alive.
Acts. And I, being uncertain of the controversy about this man, asked whether he wants to go to Jerusalem and be judged there about these things.
Acts. But when Paul appealed to be kept for the decision of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept until I might send him to Caesar.
Acts. And Agrippa said to Festus, I also want to hear the man myself. And tomorrow, he says, thou will hear him.
Acts. Therefore on the morrow, Agrippa and Bernice having come with great pomp,  having entered into the courtroom,  with the chief captains and the men of prominence who were of the city,  Festus who commanded, Paul was brought in.
Acts. And Festus says, King Agrippa,  all who are present with us, ye see this man about whom all the multitude of the Jews appealed to me, both at Jerusalem and here, shouting he ought not to live any longer.
Acts. But I, having understood him to have done nothing worthy of death,  also him, this man, having appealed Augustus I decided to send him.
Acts. About whom I do not have anything certain to write to the lord. Therefore I brought him before you,  especially before thee, King Agrippa, so that, an examination having occurred, I may have something to write.
Acts. For it seems to me unreasonable, sending a prisoner,  not to specify the causes against him.
Acts. And Agrippa said to Paul, It is permitted thee to speak for thyself. Then Paul, having stretched forth his hand, made a defense.
Acts. Concerning all things of which I am accused by the Jews, King Agrippa, I consider myself blessed, being about to make my defense before thee today.
Acts. Especially thee, being an expert of all things regarding Jews, both habits and issues. Therefore I beg thee to hear me patiently.
