Cor. Was any man called circumcised? He should not become uncircumcised. Was any man called in uncircumcision? He should not be circumcised.
Cor. Circumcision is nothing and uncircumcision is nothing, instead, the keeping of God's commandments.
Cor. Each man, in the situation in which he was called, in this he should remain.
Cor. Were thou called being a bondman? It should not concern thee. However if also thou are able to become free, take advantage of it instead.
Cor. For he who was called in the Lord a bondman is a freedman of the Lord. Likewise also he who was called a free man is a bondman of Christ.
Cor. Ye were bought with a price, become not bondmen of men.
Cor. Brothers, each man, in what he was called, should remain in this before God.
Cor. Now concerning the virgins I have no commandment of the Lord,  I give an opinion, as having obtained mercy from the Lord to be trustworthy.
Cor. I suppose therefore this to be good because of the present distress, that it is good for a man to be this way:
Cor. Are thou bound to a wife? Do not seek separation. Are thou free from a wife? Do not seek a wife.
Cor. But also if thou did marry thou have not sinned,  if the virgin married she has not sinned. Yet such kind will have stress in the flesh,  I spare you.
Cor. But this I say, brothers, the time is shortened. It is the remaining, so that also those who have wives may be as not having,
Cor. and those who weep, as not weeping,  those who rejoice, as not rejoicing,  those who buy, as not possessing,
Cor. and those who use this world, as not making full use, for the form of this world passes away.
Cor. But I want you to be without worry. The unmarried man cares for things of the Lord, how he will please the Lord.
Cor. But he who is married cares for things of the world, how he will please his wife.
Cor. And the wife and the virgin are differentiated. The unmarried woman is concerned for the things of the Lord, so that she may be holy both in body and in spirit. But she who is married is concerned for the things of the world, how she will please her husband.
Cor. And I say this for your own benefit, not that I may cast restraint upon you,  for what is respectable and assiduous toward the Lord, undistracted.
Cor. But if any man thinks to behave improperly toward his virgin, if it is past the best time,  so ought to happen, she should do what she wants, she does not sin, they should marry.
Cor. But he who stands firm in his heart, not having necessity,  has power based upon his own will,  has decided this in his heart, to keep his own celibacy, does well.
Cor. And therefore he who gives in marriage does well,  he who does not give in marriage does better.
Cor. A wife is bound by law as long a time as her husband lives,  also if the husband should sleep, she is free to be married to whom she desires, only in the Lord.
Cor. But she is more blessed if she remains this way according to my opinion. And I also seem to have Spirit of God.
Cor. Now about the things sacrificed to idols. We know that all have knowledge. Knowledge puffs up,  love builds up.
Cor. If any man presumes to know anything, he knows nothing yet as he ought to know.
Cor. But if any man loves God, this man is known by him.
Cor. Therefore about eating the things sacrificed to idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world,  that there is no other God except one.
Cor. For also since there are things called gods, whether in heaven or on the earth, as there are many gods and many lords,
Cor. yet to us there is one God, the Father, from whom are all things,  we for him,  one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom are all things,  we through him.
Cor. Nevertheless the knowledge is not in all men,  some, with conscience of the idol until now, eat as sacrificed to idols,  their weak conscience is defiled.
Cor. But food does not present us to God, for neither if we eat are we ahead, nor if we do not eat are we behind.
Cor. But take heed lest somehow this privilege of yours becomes a stumbling-block to those who are weak.
Cor. For if some man sees thee, who has knowledge, dining in an idol-temple, will not his conscience, being weak, be strengthened to eat things sacrificed to idols?
Cor. And by thy knowledge the brother, being weak, will be ruined, for whom Christ died.
Cor. And sinning this way against the brothers,  wounding their weak conscience, ye sin against Christ.
Cor. Therefore if food causes my brother to stumble, I will no, not eat meat into the age, so that I may not cause my brother to stumble.
Cor. Am I not an apostle? Am I not free? Have I not seen Jesus Christ our Lord? Are ye not my work in the Lord?
Cor. If I am not an apostle to others, yet at least I am to you, for ye are the seal of my apostleship in the Lord.
Cor. My defense to those who examine me is this.
Cor. Have we no, not a right to eat and to drink?
Cor. Have we no, not a right to lead about a sister wife, as also the other apostles,  the brothers of the Lord,  Cephas?
Cor. Or have only I and Barnabas no right not to be occupied earning a living?
Cor. Who ever enlists in an army at his own wage? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat from the fruit of it? Or who feeds a flock and does not eat from the milk of the flock?
Cor. Do I say these things according to man, or does not the law also say these things?
Cor. For it is written in the law of Moses thou shall not muzzle an ox threshing grain. Is God concerned about oxen,
Cor. or does he speak altogether for our sake? For our sake, for it was written, He who plows ought to plow with hope,  he who threshes with his hope, with hope to share.
Cor. If we sowed spiritual things to you, is it a great thing if we will reap your carnal things?
Cor. If others are partakers of the right from you, are not we more? Nevertheless we did not use this right,  we cover all things, so that we may not give any hindrance to the good news of the Christ.
Cor. Know ye not that those being employed at the sacred things eat from the temple,  those who serve at the altar are partakers at the altar?
Cor. And so the Lord commanded those who proclaim the good news to live from the good news.
Cor. But I have used none of these things,  I did not write these things so that it should be done to me this way. For it is good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my boasting empty.
Cor. For if I preach the good news, it is not a source of pride for me, for an obligation is laid upon me. And woe is to me if I do not preach the good news.
Cor. For if I do this voluntarily, I have a reward,  if involuntarily, I have been entrusted with a commission.
Cor. What then is my reward? That, while preaching the good news, I may make the good news of the Christ without charge, in order not to make full use of my right in the good news.
Cor. For although being free from all men, I made myself a servant to all, so that I might gain the more.
Cor. And to the Jews I became as a Jew, so that I might gain Jews, to those under law, as under law, so that I might gain those under law,
Cor. to those without law, as without law (not being without law to God,  within law to Christ), so that I might gain men without law.
Cor. To the weak I became as weak, so that I might gain the weak. I have become all things to all men, so that by all means I might save some.
Cor. And I do this for sake of the good news, so that I might become a fellow participant of it.
Cor. Know ye not that those who run in an arena, indeed all run,  one receives the prize? So run that ye may seize it.
Cor. And every man who strives for mastery exercises self-control in all things. Indeed therefore those men do it so that they might obtain a perishable crown,  we an imperishable.
Cor. I therefore run this way, not as aimlessly. I fight this way, not as flaying air.
Cor. But I give my body a black eye and subdue it, lest somehow having preached to others, I myself might become disqualified.
Cor. But I want you not to be ignorant, brothers, that all our fathers were under the cloud,  all passed through the sea,
Cor. and all in Moses were immersed in the cloud and in the sea.
Cor. And they all ate the same spiritual food,
Cor. and they all drank the same spiritual drink, for they drank from a spiritual rock that followed them. And the rock was the Christ.
Cor. However with most of them God was not well pleased, for they were strewn in the wilderness.
Cor. But these things became our examples, for us not to be men who lust for evil things as those also lusted.
Cor. Neither become ye idolaters as some of them, as it is written, The people sat down to eat and drink,  rose up to revel.
Cor. Nor should we fornicate as some of them fornicated,  twenty-three thousand fell in one day.
Cor. Nor should we challenge the Christ as some of them also challenged,  were destroyed by the serpents.
Cor. And ye should not grumble as some of them grumbled,  were destroyed by the destroyer.
Cor. Now all these things happened to those men for examples,  they were written for our admonition, to whom the ends of the ages came.
Cor. Therefore let him who seems to stand take heed lest he fall.
Cor. No temptation has taken you except is common to man. But God is faithful who will not allow you to be tempted above what ye are able,  with the temptation will also make the way to escape, to enable you to endure.
Cor. Therefore, my beloved, flee from idolatry.
Cor. I speak as to wise men, judge ye what I say.
Cor. The cup of the blessing that we bless, is it not a participation of the blood of the Christ? The bread that we break, is it not a participation of the body of the Christ?
Cor. Because we, the many, are one bread, one body, for we are all partakers of the one bread.
Cor. Look at Israel according to flesh. Those who eat the sacrifices, are they not partakers of the altar?
Cor. What therefore do I say, that an idol is anything, or that a sacrifice to an idol is anything?
Cor. Rather, that which the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God,  I do not want you to become partakers of demons.
Cor. Ye cannot drink the cup of the Lord,  the cup of demons. Ye cannot be partakers of a table of the Lord,  of a table of demons.
Cor. Or do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he?
Cor. All things are permitted for me,  not all things are expedient. All things are permitted for me,  not all things are constructive.
Cor. Let not one man seek that of himself,  each man that of the other.
Cor. Eat everything being sold in a meat market, inquiring of nothing because of the conscience,
Cor. for the earth is the Lord's,  the fullness of it.
Cor. If any of those unbelievers invites you,  ye want to go, eat everything being set before you, inquiring of nothing because of the conscience.
Cor. But if any man says to you, This is a sacrifice to an idol, do not eat for the sake of that man who informed,  the conscience, for the earth is the Lord's,  the fullness of it.
Cor. And I say conscience, not the one of himself,  the one of the other man. For why is my liberty judged by another conscience?
Cor. If I partake with thankfulness, why am I maligned about which I express thanks?
Cor. Therefore whether ye eat, or drink, or anything ye do, do all to the glory of God.
Cor. Become ye inoffensive both to Jews and to Greeks,  to the church of God,
Cor. just as I also strive to please in all things for all men, not seeking my own advantage,  that of the many, so that they may be saved.
Cor. Become ye followers of me, even as I also am of Christ.
Cor. Now I praise you, brothers, that ye remember me in all things and keep the traditions, just as I delivered them to you.
Cor. But I want you to know that the head of every man is the Christ,  the head of a woman is the man,  the head of Christ is God.
Cor. Every man praying or prophesying having something upon his head dishonors his head.
Cor. But every woman praying or prophesying with her head uncovered dishonors her head, for it is one and the same thing as the woman who has been shaven.
Cor. For if a woman is not covered, let her also shear herself. But if it is an ugly thing for a woman to shear herself or be shaven, she should be covered.
Cor. For a man indeed ought not to cover his head, being an image and glory of God,  woman is a glory of man.
Cor. For man is not from woman,  woman from man.
Cor. For also man was not created for the woman,  woman for the man.
Cor. Because of this the woman ought to have authority over her head, because of the agents.
Cor. Nevertheless, neither is man independent of woman, nor woman independent of man, in the Lord.
Cor. For just as the woman is from the man, so also the man is through the woman. But all things are from God.
Cor. Judge ye among yourselves, is it proper for a woman to pray to God uncovered?
Cor. Or does not nature itself teach you that if a man actually wears long hair it is a disgrace to him?
Cor. But if a woman wears long hair, it is a glory to her, because her hair has been given for a cloak.
Cor. But if any man appears to be a lover of strife, we have no such custom, nor the congregations of God.
Cor. Now in this that is commanded, I do not praise you, because ye do not assemble for the better but for the worse.
Cor. For indeed first, when ye come together in a congregation, I hear divisions are present among you,  I partly believe it.
Cor. For there must also be factions among you, so that the genuine may become apparent among you.
Cor. When therefore ye come together in the same place, it is not to eat the Lord's supper.
Cor. For each man proceeds to eat his own meal,  one is hungry and another is drunken.
Cor. For have ye no houses to eat and to drink in? Or do ye disparage the church of God,  humiliate those not having? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you in this? I do not praise you.
Cor. For I received from the Lord what I also delivered to you, that the Lord Jesus in the night in which he was betrayed took bread,
Cor. and having expressed thanks, he broke in pieces,  said, Take ye, eat, this is my body broken for you. This do ye for my memorial.
Cor. Likewise also the cup after the supper, saying, This cup is the new covenant in my blood. This do, as often as ye drink it, for my memorial.
Cor. For as often as ye eat this bread and drink this cup, ye proclaim the Lord's death until he comes.
Cor. Therefore whoever may eat this bread or drink the cup of the Lord unworthily of the Lord, will be guilty of the body and the blood of the Lord.
Cor. But let a man examine himself,  let him so eat of the bread,  drink of the cup.
Cor. For he who eats and drinks unworthily, eats and drinks condemnation to himself, not discerning the body of the Lord.
Cor. Because of this many are weak and sickly among you,  a considerable sleep.
Cor. But if we were discerning ourselves we would not be judged.
Cor. But when we are judged by the Lord, we are chastened so that we may not be condemned with the world.
Cor. Therefore, my brothers, when ye come together to eat, await each other.
Cor. And if any man is hungry, let him eat at home so that ye may not come together for condemnation. And the rest I will set in order as soon as I come.
Cor. Now concerning the spiritual things, brothers, I do not want you to be ignorant.
Cor. Ye know that, while Gentiles, ye were being carried away to the voiceless idols, as ye were led.
Cor. Therefore I make known to you, that no man speaking by the Spirit of God says, Jesus is accursed,  no man can say, Jesus is Lord, except by the Holy Spirit.
Cor. Now there are varieties of gifts,  the same Spirit.
Cor. And there are varieties of services,  the same Lord.
Cor. And there are varieties of functions,  it is the same God who works all in all.
Cor. But the manifestation of the Spirit is given to each man toward that which is beneficial.
Cor. For to one, the word of wisdom is given through the Spirit,  to another, the word of knowledge according to the same Spirit,
Cor. to a different man, faith by the same Spirit,  to another, gifts of healings by the same Spirit,
Cor. and to another, workings of miracles,  to another, prophecy,  to another, discerning of spirits,  to a different man, kinds of tongues,  to another, the interpretation of tongues.
Cor. But the one and the same Spirit works all these things, distributing to each man individually as it wills.
Cor. For just as the body is one and has many parts,  all the parts of the body, being many, are one body, so also is the Christ.
Cor. For also by one Spirit we are all immersed into one body, whether Jews or Greeks, whether bondmen or freemen,  we were all made to drink into one Spirit.
Cor. For the body also is not one part,  many.
Cor. If the foot should say, Because I am not a hand I am not of the body, it is not by this not of the body.
Cor. And if the ear should say, Because I am not an eye I am not of the body, it is not by this not of the body.
Cor. If the whole body were an eye, where would be the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where would be the smelling?
Cor. But now God has placed the parts, each one of them, in the body just as he intended.
Cor. And if they were all one part, where would be the body?
Cor. But now of course there are many body-parts,  one body.
Cor. And the eye cannot say to the hand, I have no need of thee, nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.
Cor. Instead, much more the parts of the body that seem to be more feeble are necessary.
Cor. And those things of the body presumed to be without esteem, we place around these more abundant worth. And our unpresentable parts have more abundant propriety,
Cor. whereas our presentable parts have no need. Instead, God united the body together, having given more abundant worth to the part that lacks,
Cor. so that there would be no schisms in the body,  that the parts would have the same care for each other.
Cor. And if one part suffers, all the parts suffer together, or one part is honored, all the parts rejoice together.
Cor. Now ye are the body of Christ,  body-parts individually.
Cor. And in the church God has placed men who are first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, administrations, kinds of tongues.
Cor. Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all do miracles?
Cor. Do all have gifts of healing? Do all speak with tongues? Do all interpret?
Cor. But be zealous for the better gifts. And yet I show you a more excellent way.
Cor. If I speak with the tongues of men and of agents,  have not love, I have become sounding brass, or a clashing cymbal.
Cor. And if I have prophecy,  know all mysteries and all knowledge,  if I have all faith so as to remove mountains,  have not love, I am nothing.
Cor. And if I dole out all things possessed by me,  if I deliver my body so that I may be burned,  have not love, I benefit nothing.
Cor. Love is patient and is kind. Love does not envy. Love does not brag,  is not puffed up.
Cor. It does not behave improperly, does not seek the things of itself, is not made sharp, does not contemplate evil,
Cor. does not rejoice in wrong but rejoices in the truth,
Cor. covers all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
Cor. Love never fails. But whether prophecies, they will be abolished, whether tongues, they will cease, whether knowledge, it will be abolished.
Cor. But we know in part,  we prophesy in part,
Cor. but when the perfect comes, then what is in part will be abolished.
Cor. When I was a child, I spoke as a child, I understood as a child, I reasoned as a child,  when I became a man, I abolished the childish things.
Cor. For now we see by polished metal, in dimness,  then face to face. Now I know in part,  then I will know just as also I was known.
Cor. And now remain faith, hope, love, these three,  the greater of these is love.
Cor. Pursue love,  be zealous for the spiritual things,  more that ye may prophesy.
Cor. For he who speaks in a tongue speaks not to men,  to God, for no man hears,  in spirit he speaks mysteries.
Cor. But he who prophesies speaks to men edification and encouragement and comfort.
Cor. He who speaks in a tongue builds himself up,  he who prophesies builds up the congregation.
Cor. Now I want you all to speak in tongues,  more that ye may prophesy. For greater is he who prophesies than he who speaks in tongues, unless he interprets, so that the congregation may receive edification.
Cor. But now, brothers, if I come to you speaking in tongues, what will I benefit you, unless I would speak to you either in a revelation, or in knowledge, or in prophesying, or in doctrine?
Cor. Likewise lifeless things that give a sound, whether flute or harp, if they give no distinction in the sounds, how will it be known what is being piped or harped?
Cor. For also if a trumpet gives an uncertain sound, who will prepare himself for battle?
Cor. So also ye, unless ye give understandable speech by the tongue, how will that which is spoken be known? For ye will be talking into the air.
Cor. Since there are perhaps, so many kinds of voices in the world,  none of them is without significance.
Cor. If therefore I know not the force of the voice, I will be a foreigner to him who speaks,  he who speaks will be a foreigner to me.
Cor. So also ye, since ye are zealots of spirits, seek so that ye may excel for the edification of the church.
Cor. Therefore let him who speaks in a tongue pray that he may interpret.
Cor. For if I pray in a tongue my spirit prays,  my intellect is unfruitful.
Cor. What is it therefore? I will pray with the spirit,  I will pray with the intellect also. I will sing with the spirit,  I will sing with the intellect also.
Cor. Otherwise if thou would bless with the spirit, how will the man who fills the place of the unlearned, say the Truly at thy thanksgiving, since he knows not what thou say?
Cor. For thou indeed express thanks well,  the other man is not edified.
Cor. I thank my God that I speak in tongues more than all of you.
Cor. Yet in an assembly I would rather speak five words with my intellect, so that I might also make others understand, than countless words in a tongue.
Cor. Brothers, become not children in your thoughts. Instead be childlike in wickedness,  in your thoughts become mature.
Cor. In the law it is written, In other tongues and in other lips I will speak to this people,  not even so will they hear me, says the Lord.
Cor. Therefore tongues are for a sign, not to those who believe,  to the unbelieving. But prophesying is not to the unbelieving,  to those who believe.
Cor. If therefore the whole congregation comes together in the same place,  all speak in tongues,  unlearned or unbelieving men come in, will they not say that ye are mad?
Cor. But if all prophesy,  some unbelieving or unlearned man comes in, he is convicted by all, he is called to account by all.
Cor. And so the secrets of his heart are made manifest. And so having fallen down on his face he will worship God, declaring that God is really among you.
Cor. What is it therefore, brothers? When ye come together, each of you has a psalm, has a teaching, has a tongue, has a revelation, has an interpretation. Let all things be done for edification.
Cor. If any man speaks in a tongue, be according to two, or at the most three,  in succession. And let one interpret.
Cor. But if there is no interpreter, let him keep silence in an assembly,  let him speak to himself and to God.
Cor. And let two or three prophets speak,  let the other men pass judgment.
Cor. But if it should be revealed to another man who is seated, let the first be silent.
Cor. For ye can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn,  all may be encouraged.
Cor. And the spirits of prophets are subject to prophets,
Cor. for God is not a God of confusion,  of peace.
Cor. As in all the churches of the sanctified, let the women keep silent in the churches. For it is not permitted for them to speak,  to be subordinate, as the law also says.
Cor. And if they want to learn anything, let them question their own husbands at home, for it is an ugly thing for women to speak in an assembly.
Cor. Or did the word of God come forth from you? Or did it come to you only?
Cor. If any man presumes to be a prophet or spiritual, let him acknowledge what I write to you, that they are commandments of the Lord.
Cor. But if any man is ignorant, let him be ignorant.
Cor. Therefore brothers, be zealous for prophesying,  do not forbid to speak in tongues.
Cor. Let all things be done decently and in order.
Cor. And, brothers, I make known to you the good news that I preached to you, which also ye received,  in which ye stand,
Cor. by which also ye are saved if ye hold firm that word I preached to you, unless ye believed in vain.
Cor. For I delivered to you at first what I also received, that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures,
Cor. and that he was buried,  that he arose on the third day according to the scriptures,
Cor. and that he appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve.
Cor. Then he appeared to over five hundred brothers at once, of whom the greater part remain until now,  some also slept.
Cor. Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles,
Cor. and last of all, as to the untimely birth, he also appeared to me.
Cor. For I am the least of the apostles, who am not worthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
Cor. But by the grace of God I am what I am. And his grace for me did not become empty,  I labored more abundantly than them all, yet not I,  the grace of God with me.
Cor. Therefore whether I or those men, so we proclaim,  so ye believed.
Cor. Now if Christ is proclaimed that he has risen from the dead, how say some among you that there is no resurrection of the dead?
Cor. But if there is no resurrection of the dead, neither has Christ risen.
Cor. And if Christ has not risen, then our preaching is empty,  your faith is also empty.
Cor. And also we are found false witnesses of God, because we witnessed according to God that he raised up the Christ, whom he did not raise up, if therefore the dead are really not raised.
Cor. For if the dead are not raised, neither has Christ been raised.
Cor. And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is vain. Ye are still in your sins.
Cor. Then also those who slept in Christ have perished.
Cor. If we are men who have hoped in Christ in this life only, we are of all men more miserable.
Cor. But now Christ has been raised from the dead. He became the first fruit of those who are asleep.
Cor. For since death is because of a man, the resurrection of the dead is also because of a man.
Cor. For as by Adam all die, so also by Christ all will be made alive.
Cor. But each in his own order. Christ the first fruit, then those of Christ at his coming.
Cor. Afterwards the end, when he delivers up the kingdom to the God and Father, when he will abolish all rule,  all authority and power.
Cor. For he must reign until he will put all his enemies under his feet.
Cor. The last enemy abolished is death.
Cor. For he subordinated all things under his feet. But when he says that all things have been subordinated, it is clear that he who subordinated all things under him, is excepted.
Cor. And when all things are made subordinate to him, then the Son himself will also be made subordinate to him who subordinated all things to him, so that God may be all in all.
Cor. Otherwise what will they do who are immersed for the dead? If the dead do not rise at all, why then are they immersed for the dead?
Cor. And we, why are we in peril every hour?
Cor. By the pride that belongs to you, that I keep in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die daily.
Cor. If in respect to men I fought with beasts at Ephesus, what is the benefit to me if the dead are not raised? Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.
Cor. Be not led astray. Evil associations corrupt good habits.
Cor. Sober up rightly,  do not sin, for some have ignorance of God. I speak shame about you.
Cor. But some man will say, How are the dead raised,  with what kind of body do they come?
Cor. Thou foolish man, what thou sow is not made alive unless it dies.
Cor. And what thou sow, thou do not sow the body that it will become,  a bare grain, if it may happen of wheat, or of some other kind.
Cor. But God gives it a body as he wills,  to each of the seeds its own body.
Cor. All flesh is not the same flesh,  one of men,  another flesh of beasts,  another of fishes,  another of birds,
Cor. and heavenly bodies,  earthly bodies (but the glory of the heavenly is different,  the glory of the earthly is different),
Cor. another glory is of the sun,  another glory of the moon,  another glory of the stars, for star differs from star in glory.
Cor. So also is the resurrection of the dead. It is sown in the perishable, it is raised in imperishability.
Cor. It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness, it is raised in power.
Cor. It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body. There is a natural body,  there is a spiritual body.
Cor. And so it is written, The first man Adam developed into a living soul. The last Adam a life giving spirit.
Cor. Nevertheless the spiritual is not first,  the natural, then the spiritual.
Cor. The first man was of the earth, earthly. The second man is the Lord from heaven.
Cor. As is the earthly, such also are the earthly. And as is the heavenly, such also are the heavenly.
Cor. And just as we have worn the form of the earthly, we will also wear the form of the heavenly.
Cor. Now this I affirm, brothers, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, nor does the perishable inherit imperishability.
Cor. Behold, I tell you a mystery. We will actually not all sleep,  we will all be transformed,
Cor. in an instant, in the blink of an eye, at the last trumpet. For it will sound,  the dead will be raised imperishable,  we will be transformed.
Cor. For this perishable must put on imperishability,  this mortal put on immortality.
Cor. But when this perishable will have put on imperishability,  this mortal will have put on immortality, then will come to pass the saying that is written, Death was swallowed up in victory.
Cor. O death, where is thy sting? O Hades, where is thy victory?
Cor. The sting of death is sin,  the power of sin is the law.
Cor. But thanks is to God who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
Cor. Therefore, my beloved brothers, become ye steadfast, unmovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labor is not empty in the Lord.
Cor. Now concerning the collection for the sanctified, as I arranged for the congregations of Galatia, so also do ye.
Cor. Upon the first day of the week let each of you set something aside near himself, storing up whatever he may prosper, so that when I come no collections may be made then.
Cor. And when I arrive, whomever ye may approve by letters, I will send these men to bring your gift to Jerusalem.
Cor. And if it is fitting for me to go also, they will go with me.
Cor. But I will come to you when I pass through Macedonia, for I do pass through Macedonia.
Cor. And it may be that I will remain with you, or I will even spend winter, so that ye may set me on my way wherever I go.
Cor. For I do not want to see you now in passing,  I hope to remain some time with you, if the Lord allows.
Cor. But I will remain at Ephesus until Pentecost.
Cor. For a great and effective door has opened to me,  yet there are many who are hostile.
Cor. But if Timothy comes, see that he becomes without fear with you, for he works the work of the Lord, as I also.
Cor. Let not any man therefore disparage him,  send him forth in peace, so that he may come to me, for I expect him with the brothers.
Cor. And about Apollos the brother, I urged him much that he would come to you with the brothers,  it was not at all his will that he should come now,  he will come when he has opportunity.
Cor. Watch ye, stand firm in the faith, act like men, be strong.
Cor. Let all things of you be done in love.
Cor. Now I beseech you, brothers (ye know the house of Stephanas, that it is the first fruit of Achaia,  that they committed themselves to service for the sanctified),
Cor. that ye also be subject to such men,  to every man working together and laboring.
Cor. And I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because these men filled your lack.
Cor. For they refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore acknowledge ye such men.
Cor. The congregations of Asia salute you. Aquila and Priscilla salute you much in the Lord, with the congregation associated with their house.
Cor. All the brothers salute you. Salute each other by a holy kiss.
Cor. The salutation of Paul by my hand.
Cor. If any man does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be accursed. Maranatha.
Cor. The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ is with you.
Cor. My love is with you all in Christ Jesus. Truly.
II Corinthians
Cor. Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God,  Timothy the brother, to the congregation of God that is at Corinth, with all the sanctified who are in the whole of Achaia.
Cor. Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
Cor. Blessed is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all encouragement,
Cor. who encourages us in all our affliction, in order for us to be able to encourage those in every affliction, through the encouragement of which we ourselves are encouraged by God.
Cor. Because, as the sufferings of the Christ abound to us, so also our encouragement abounds through the Christ.
Cor. But whether we are oppressed, it is for your encouragement and salvation, which works by endurance from the same sufferings that we also experience (and our hope for you is steadfast), or we are encouraged, it is for your encouragement and salvation,
Cor. knowing that, as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also of the encouragement.
Cor. For we do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, about our affliction that happened to us in Asia, because we were extraordinarily weighed down, above strength, so as for us to despair even to be alive.
Cor. But we ourselves have had the sentence of death in ourselves, so that we should not be trusting in ourselves,  in God who raises the dead.
Cor. Who rescued us out of so great a death,  does rescue, in whom we have hoped that he will also still rescue.
Cor. And of you who help together by supplication for us (a gift for us from many persons, because of many), so that there may be gratitude about you.
Cor. For our pride is this (the testimony from our conscience), that we behave in the world in the simplicity and purity of God, not by fleshly wisdom but in the grace of God,  especially toward you.
Cor. For we write no other thing to you,  rather what ye read or also acknowledge. And I hope ye will also acknowledge until the end,
Cor. as also ye did acknowledge us in part, because we are your boast, just as ye also are ours in the day of the Lord Jesus.
Cor. And in this confidence I intended to come to you earlier, so that ye might have a second benefit,
Cor. and to pass through you into Macedonia,  to come again from Macedonia to you,  by you to be helped on the way toward Judea.
Cor. Therefore intending this, did I accordingly employ anything in lightness? Or what I decide, do I decide according to flesh, so that it would be with me the yes, yes and the no, no?
Cor. But God is faithful, because our word toward you became not, yes and no.
Cor. For the Son of God, Jesus Christ who was proclaimed among you by us (by me and Silvanus and Timothy) became not, yes and no,  in him has become, yes.
Cor. For as many as be promises of God, in him is the Yes,  in him the Truly, for glory to God through us.
Cor. Now he who establishes us with you in Christ,  who anointed us, is God.
Cor. He also is who put a seal on us,  who gave the pledge of the Spirit in our hearts.
Cor. But I call God for a witness upon my soul, that I did not yet come to Corinth, sparing you.
Cor. Not because we lord over your faith,  are co-workmen of your joy, for by faith ye stand.
Cor. But I determined this in myself, not to come again to you in sadness.
Cor. For if I make you sad, who then is he who makes me glad except he who is made sad by me?
Cor. And I wrote this same thing to you, so that when I came, I would not have sadness from whom I ought to rejoice, having been confident toward you all, because my joy is of all of you.
Cor. For out of much stress and dismay of heart, through many tears, I wrote to you, not that ye would be grieved,  that ye might know the love that I have so much more for you.
Cor. But if any man has caused sadness, he has not caused me sadness,  in part (that I may not bear down) you all.
Cor. Sufficient to such a man is this punishment by the many,
Cor. so that instead, for you rather to forgive and encourage, lest perhaps such a man would be swallowed up with too much sorrow.
Cor. Therefore I beseech you to affirm love for him.
Cor. For I also wrote for this, so that I might know the proof of you, whether ye are obedient in all things.
Cor. But to whom ye forgive anything, I too. For I also, whom I have forgiven (if anything), I have forgiven because of you in the presence of Christ,
Cor. so that we may not be exploited by Satan. For we are not ignorant of his methods.
Cor. Now having come to Troas for the good news of the Christ,  a door having been opened to me in the Lord,
Cor. I had no rest in my spirit, my not finding Titus my brother. But having departed from them, I went forth into Macedonia.
Cor. And thanks is to God who always causes us to triumph in the Christ,  who makes manifest the aroma of the knowledge of him in every place, through us.
Cor. Because we are a fragrance of Christ to God, in those being saved and in those perishing:
Cor. to the one an odor of death for death,  to the other an aroma of life for life. And who is adequate for these things?
Cor. For we are not as other men, huckstering the word of God,  as from purity. But we speak in Christ as from God in the sight of God.
Cor. Are we beginning again to commend ourselves? Unless we need, as some men, commendatory letters to you or commendatory from you?
Cor. Ye are our letter, written in our hearts, known and read by all men,
Cor. being seen that ye are a letter of Christ, administered by us, written not in ink,  in the Spirit of the living God, not in stony tablets,  in fleshly tablets, in hearts.
Cor. And we have such confidence toward God through Christ,
Cor. not that we are sufficient of ourselves to reckon anything as from ourselves,  our sufficiency is from God,
Cor. who also made us qualified helpers of a new covenant, not of a document,  of a Spirit, for the document kills but the Spirit makes alive.
Cor. But if the administration of death in writings engraved on stones occurred in glory, so that the sons of Israel could not gaze upon the face of Moses because of the fading glory of his countenance,
Cor. how will the administration of the Spirit not be more in glory?
Cor. For if the administration of condemnation has glory, the administration of righteousness excels much more in glory.
Cor. For also that which has been glorified, has not been glorified in this regard, because of the glory that transcends.
Cor. For if that which is abolished was through glory, much more that which remains is in glory.
Cor. Having therefore such a hope we use great boldness,
Cor. and are not as Moses. He put a veil over his face in order for the sons of Israel not to gaze on the end of the fading.
Cor. But their minds were hardened, for to this day the same veil remains at the reading of the old testament, not being uncovered, which thing is abolished in Christ.
Cor. But to this day when Moses is read, a veil lies upon their heart.
Cor. But whenever it turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.
Cor. Now the Lord is the Spirit,  where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.
Cor. But we all, with unveiled face seeing by reflection the glory of the Lord, are transformed into the same likeness from glory to glory, just as from the Spirit of the Lord.
Cor. Because of this (having this ministry), in as much as we received mercy, we do not become discouraged.
Cor. But we have renounced the covert things of shame, not walking in craftiness, nor misrepresenting the word of God,  by the disclosure of the truth, commending ourselves to every conscience of men before God.
Cor. But even if our good news is concealed, it is concealed in those who are perishing,
Cor. in whom the god of this age has blinded the minds of the unbelieving, in order for the light of the good news of the glory of the Christ (who is a likeness of God) not to shine forth to them.
Cor. For we preach not ourselves,  Christ Jesus as Lord,  ourselves are your bondmen through Jesus.
Cor. Because it is God who said, Out of darkness light is to shine, who shone in our hearts for an enlightenment of the knowledge of the glory of God in the presence of Jesus Christ.
Cor. But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, so that the excellence of the power may be of God and not from us,
Cor. restricted in everything, yet not confined, perplexed but not despairing,
Cor. persecuted but not forsaken, cast down but not destroyed.
Cor. Always carrying around in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, so that also the life of Jesus may be made visible in our body.
Cor. For we who live are always given over to death for Jesus' sake, so that also the life of Jesus may be made visible in our mortal flesh.
Cor. So death indeed works in us,  life in you.
Cor. And having the same spirit of faith, according to that which is written, I believed, therefore I spoke, we also believe,  therefore we speak,
Cor. knowing that he who raised up the Lord Jesus will also raise us up through Jesus,  will present us with you.
Cor. For all things are for your sakes, so that the grace, which has multiplied because of the thankfulness of the many, may abound for the glory of God.
Cor. Therefore we are not discouraged,  even if the outer man of us is perishing, yet the inner man is renewed day by day.
Cor. For our slight momentary affliction works for us an eternal weight of glory from extraordinariness to extraordinariness,
Cor. while we look not at things seen,  at things not seen. For things seen are temporal,  things not seen are eternal.
Cor. For we know that if the earthly house of our tent were destroyed, we have a building from God, a house not made by hands, eternal in the heavens.
Cor. For also in this we groan, longing to clothe ourselves with our habitation from heaven,
Cor. if indeed also having put it on we will not be found naked.
Cor. For also those who are in the tent groan, being burdened, not in that we want to undress,  to clothe ourselves, so that the mortal may be swallowed up by the life.
Cor. Now he who wrought us for this same thing is God, who also gave us the pledge of the Spirit.
Cor. Therefore always being confident,  knowing that while at home in the body we are absent from the Lord,
Cor. for we walk by faith, not by sight.
Cor. And we are confident,  are pleased rather to be absent from the body and to be at home near the Lord.
Cor. Therefore also we aspire, whether at home or away from home, to be well-pleasing to him.
Cor. For we must all appear before the judgment-seat of the Christ, so that each man may receive back about the things that he did through the body, whether good or bad.
Cor. Having seen therefore the terror of the Lord, we persuade men. But we have been manifested to God,  I hope also to have been manifested in your consciences.
Cor. For we are not commending ourselves again to you,  giving you an opportunity of boasting about us, so that ye may have for those who boast in appearance and not in heart.
Cor. For whether we are beside ourselves to God, or we are of normal mind, it is for you.
Cor. For the love of Christ holds us together, having judge this, that if one died for all, then all died.
Cor. And he died for all so that those who live would no longer live to themselves,  to him who died for them,  was raised.
Cor. So that henceforth we know no man according to flesh,  even if we have known Christ according to flesh, yet now we know him no longer.
Cor. So then if any man is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old things have passed away, behold, all things have become new.
Cor. And all things are from God who reconciled us to himself through Jesus Christ,  who gave to us the ministry of reconciliation.
Cor. How that God was in Christ reconciling the world to himself, not imputing to them their trespasses,  having committed to us the word of reconciliation.
Cor. We are therefore, ambassadors on behalf of Christ, as though God were calling through us. We plead on behalf of Christ, be ye reconciled to God.
Cor. For the man who knew no sin was made sin on our behalf, so that we might become the righteousness of God in him.
Cor. And working jointly, we urge you also not to receive the grace of God in vain
Cor. (for he says, At an acceptable time I heard thee,  in a day of salvation I helped thee. Behold, now is an acceptable time. Behold, now is a day of salvation),
Cor. giving not one cause of stumbling in anything, so that the ministry may not be criticized,
Cor. but in everything commending ourselves as helpers of God, in much perseverance, in afflictions, in necessities, in restrictions,
Cor. in stripes, in imprisonments, in tumults, in labors, in sleeplessness, in hungerings,
Cor. in purity, in knowledge, in longsuffering, in kindness, in the Holy Spirit, in non-hypocritical love,
Cor. in word of truth, in power of God, through the weapons of righteousness of the right hand and of the left,
Cor. through glory and disrepute, through slander and commendation; as deceitful,  yet true;
Cor. as unknown,  well known; as dying,  behold, we live; as punished,  not put to death;
Cor. as grieving,  always rejoicing; as poor,  making many rich; as having nothing,  yet possessing all things.
Cor. O Corinthians, our mouth has been opened to you, our heart has been enlarged.
Cor. Ye are not limited in us,  ye are limited in your bowels.
Cor. But I speak the same recompense as to children, be ye also enlarged.
Cor. Do not become unequally yoked with unbelievers, for what partnership has righteousness and lawlessness? And what fellowship has light with darkness?
Cor. And what agreement has Christ with Belial? Or what share have believers with non-believers?
Cor. And what mutual agreement has a temple of God with idols? For ye are a temple of the living God, just as God said, I will dwell in them,  will walk among them. And I will be their God,  they will be a people to me.
Cor. Therefore, Come ye out from among them,  be ye separated, says the Lord, And touch no unclean thing,  I will receive you
Cor. and will be for a Father to you,  ye will be for sons and daughters to me, says the Lord Almighty.
Cor. Having therefore these promises, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from every filthiness of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in fear of God.
Cor. Make room for us. We wronged no man, we corrupted no man, we exploited no man.
Cor. I speak not for condemnation, for I have said before that ye are in our hearts to die together and to live together.
Cor. Great is my boldness toward you, great is my pride for you. I have been filled with encouragement. I over-abound with joy in all our affliction.
Cor. For even when we came into Macedonia our flesh had not one relief,  being oppressed in everything: battles outside, fears within.
Cor. Nevertheless God, who encourages the lowly, encouraged us by the arrival of Titus.
Cor. And not only by his presence,  also by the encouragement with which he was encouraged by you, reporting to us your earnest desire, your mourning, your zeal for me, so that I rejoiced the more.
Cor. Because even though I grieved you in the letter, I am not remorseful (even though I was remorseful), for I perceive that that letter grieved you, even though for an hour.
Cor. Now I rejoice, not that ye were grieved,  that ye were grieved for repentance. For ye were grieved toward God, so that ye might suffer loss from us in nothing.
Cor. For sorrow toward God works repentance for salvation without regret,  the sorrow of the world works death.
Cor. For behold this same thing-your grieving toward God. How much eagerness it worked in you, even a defense, even indignation, even fear, even longing, even zeal, even vengeance! In everything ye demonstrated yourselves to be pure in the matter.
Cor. And so then, although I wrote to you, it was not because of the man who did wrong, nor because of the man who was wronged,  in order to reveal to you your eagerness for us in the sight of God.
Cor. Because of this we have been encouraged. And from your encouragement, we rejoiced to a greater degree more at the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been refreshed by you all.
Cor. Because, if I have boasted anything to him about you, I am not ashamed,  as we spoke all things in truth to you, so also our boast to Titus became truth.
Cor. And his bowels are more abundant toward you, remembering the obedience of you all, how ye received him with fear and trembling.
Cor. I rejoice that I have confidence in you in everything.
Cor. And, brothers, we declare to you the grace of God that has been given in the congregations of Macedonia,
Cor. that in a great trial of affliction the abundance of their joy, even from the depth of their poverty, abounded for the wealth of their generosity,
Cor. so that according to their ability, I testify,  beyond their ability, willingly,
Cor. with much exhortation, begging of us the favor, even the fellowship of service for the sanctified.
Cor. And it was not as we expected,  first they gave themselves to the Lord and to us through the will of God,
Cor. for us to urge Titus that, as he earlier began this kindness, so he would even finish it for you also.
Cor. But as ye abound in everything, in faith,  word,  knowledge,  all diligence,  in your love to us, so that ye may also abound in this kindness.
Cor. I speak not from commandment,  because of the zeal of others, also examining the genuineness of your love.
Cor. For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that although he was rich he became poor for your sakes, so that by that man's poverty ye might become rich.
Cor. And in this I give judgment, for this is expedient for you who earlier began, from a year ago, not only the doing but also the intending.
Cor. And now also finish the doing, so that just as was the willingness of the intending, so also to finish from the having.
Cor. For if the willingness is present, it is acceptable to the extent if some man has, not to the extent he does not have.
Cor. For it is not so that ease is for others and stress for you,  out of parity your abundance at the present time is for the need of those men.
Cor. So that the abundance of those men may also happen for your need, so that there may become equity,
Cor. as it is written, he of much did not abound,  he of little did not lack.
Cor. But thanks to God who gives the same eagerness for you in the heart of Titus.
Cor. Because he indeed accepted the exhortation,  his own will being more zealous, he went forth to you.
Cor. And we sent along with him the brother whose praise in the good news is throughout all the congregations.
Cor. And not only so,  who was also chosen by the congregations, a traveling companion of us with this gift administered by us, for the glory of the same Lord and our willingness.
Cor. Arranging this lest any man may criticize us in this bounty administered by us,
Cor. providing things right, not only in the sight of the Lord,  also in the sight of men.
Cor. And we sent along with them our brother whom we often proved being diligent in many things,  is now much more diligent (with much confidence toward you)
Cor. whether on behalf of Titus my partner and co-workman for you, or our brothers, apostles of congregations, a glory of Christ.
Cor. Therefore show ye the proof of your love and our boast about you, for them in the face of the congregations.
Cor. For indeed it is superfluous for me to write to you about the service for the sanctified.
Cor. For I know your willingness, which I boast about you to the Macedonians, that Achaia was prepared from a year ago. And your zeal provoked the majority.
Cor. But I sent the brothers so that our boast about you would not be empty in this regard. So that, as I said, ye may be prepared,
Cor. if somehow Macedonians should come with me and find you unprepared, we (that we might not say, ye) would be embarrassed in this confidence of boast.
Cor. Therefore I thought it necessary to exhort the brothers that they would go ahead to you,  arrange in advance your gift that was earlier announced, for this to be ready this way as a gift and not as an exaction.
Cor. But this, he who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly,  he who sows in blessings will also reap in blessings.
Cor. Each man as he purposes in his heart, not from regret or from necessity, for God loves a cheerful giver.
Cor. And God is able to abound all grace for you, so that always in everything having all sufficiency, ye may abound for every good work,
Cor. as it is written, He has scattered abroad. He has given to the poor. His righteousness endures into the age.
Cor. And he who supplies seed to the man who sows,  bread for eating, may he supply and multiply your seed,  may he increase the fruits of your righteousness,
Cor. being enriched in everything for every generosity, which works gratitude to God through us.
Cor. Because the service of this ministry is not only supplying the needs of the sanctified,  also abounding through many thanksgivings to God
Cor. through the evidence of this service, glorifying God at the subjection of your confession toward the good news of the Christ,  at the generosity of the participation, for them and for all,
Cor. and by their supplication about you, yearning for you because of the transcending grace of God in you.
Cor. And thanks to God for his indescribable gift.
Cor. Now I Paul myself entreat you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ, who indeed am lowly in presence among you,  am bold toward you when absent.
Cor. But I pray not to be bold when present with the confidence by which I consider to be valiant toward some who consider us as walking according to flesh.
Cor. For though walking in flesh, we do not war according to flesh.
Cor. For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal,  mighty in God for the demolition of strongholds,
Cor. casting down imaginations,  every high thing exalted against the knowledge of God,  bringing every thought captive into the obedience of the Christ,
Cor. and having in readiness to avenge every disobedience, whenever your obedience is fulfilled.
Cor. Do ye look at things according to appearance. If any man has convinced himself to be of Christ, let him consider this again of himself, that, as he is of Christ, so also are we of Christ.
Cor. For even if I also should boast somewhat more abundantly about our authority (which the Lord gave us for building up and not for tearing you down), I will not be shamed,
Cor. so that I would not seem as if to terrify you by the letters.
Cor. Because, The letters, he says, are indeed weighty and powerful,  his bodily presence is weak,  his speech is disdained.
Cor. Let such a man think this, that such kind we are in word by letters when absent, we are also such kind when present in the work.
Cor. For we dare not classify or compare ourselves to some of those who commend themselves. But they, measuring themselves by themselves,  comparing themselves to themselves, do not understand.
Cor. But we will not boast in things immeasurable,  according to the measure of the standard that God apportioned to us, of a measure to reach even as far as you.
Cor. For it is not as not reaching for you. We overextend ourselves. For we even reached as far as you in the good news of the Christ,
Cor. not boasting in things immeasurable, in other men's labors,  having hope of your faith growing in you to be enlarged according to our measure for abundance,
Cor. in order to preach the good news beyond you, not to boast in another measure, in things prepared.
Cor. But he who boasts should boast in the Lord.
Cor. For he who commends himself, that man is not approved,  whom the Lord commends.
Cor. O that ye tolerated a little of my foolishness,  tolerate me too.
Cor. For I am jealous for you with a jealousy of God. For I betrothed you to one husband, a pure virgin to present to the Christ.
Cor. But I fear lest somehow, as the serpent enticed Eve by his craftiness, so your thoughts might be corrupted from the simplicity in the Christ.
Cor. For indeed if a man who comes, preaches another Jesus whom we did not preach, or ye receive another spirit that ye did not receive, or another good news that ye did not accept, ye well tolerated it.
Cor. For I reckon to come short in nothing of those, superlative apostles.
Cor. But even if I am unskilled in speech, yet not in knowledge,  in everything made known in all things to you.
Cor. Or did I commit a sin lowering myself so that ye might be lifted up, because I preached to you the good news of God freely?
Cor. I robbed other congregations, having taken a wage in order for your service.
Cor. And being present with you,  when needy, I was a burden to no man. For the brothers who came from Macedonia, they supplied my need. And in everything I kept and I will keep myself non-burdensome to you.
Cor. The truth of Christ is in me that this pride in me will not be stopped in the regions of Achaia.
Cor. Why? Because I do not love you? God knows.
Cor. But what I do, I also will do, so that I may cut off the opportunity of those who desire an opportunity, that in what they boast, they might appear just as we also.
Cor. For such men are false apostles, deceitful workmen, disguising themselves into apostles of Christ.
Cor. And no marvel, for even Satan disguises himself into an agent of light.
Cor. Therefore, it is no great thing if his helpers also disguise themselves as helpers of righteousness, whose end will be according to their works.
Cor. I say again, let not any man think me to be foolish,  if otherwise-even if as foolish-accept me, so that I also may boast some a little.
Cor. What I speak, I speak not according to the Lord,  as in foolishness, in this confidence of the boast.
Cor. Since many boast according to the flesh, I too will boast.
Cor. For being wise, ye gladly tolerate the foolish.
Cor. For ye tolerate it if some man enslaves you, if some man devours you, if some man seizes you, if some man lifts himself up, if some man strikes you on the face.
Cor. I speak as from shame, that we were so weak. Yet in whatever any man may be bold in foolishness, I say I too am bold.
Cor. Are they Hebrews? I too. Are they Israelites? I too. Are they a seed of Abraham? I too.
Cor. Are they helpers of Christ? (I speak as being mad) I more: in toils, more abundantly; in stripes, countless; in prisons, more frequently; in deaths often.
Cor. From the Jews five times I received forty save one.
Cor. Thrice I was beaten with rods, once I was stoned, thrice I was shipwrecked, I have done a night and a day in the depth,
Cor. in frequent journeys, in perils of flowing waters, in perils of bandits, in perils from my race, in perils from Gentiles, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness, in perils at sea, in perils among false brothers,
Cor. in toil and hardship, in frequent sleeplessness, in hunger and thirst, in frequent fasts, in cold and nakedness.
Cor. Besides the external things, crowding upon me daily is the care of all the congregations.
Cor. Who is weak,  I am not weak? Who is caused to stumble,  I am not made fiery?
Cor. If it is necessary to boast, I will boast of the things of my weakness.
Cor. The God and Father of the Lord Jesus Christ, he who is blessed into the ages, knows that I do not lie.
Cor. In Damascus the governor under Aretas the king guarded the city of the Damascenes wanting to apprehend me.
Cor. And I was lowered in a hamper through a window through the wall,  escaped his hands.
Cor. (Really, to me boasting is not helpful.) For I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.
Cor. I know a man in Christ, fourteen years ago (whether in body, I know not, or whether outside the body, I know not, God knows) such a man was caught up as far as the third heaven.
Cor. And I know such a man (whether in body, or whether outside the body, I know not, God knows)
Cor. that he was caught up into the paradise,  heard inexpressible sayings that are not permitted for a man to utter.
Cor. For such a man I will boast,  for myself I will not boast, except in my weaknesses.
Cor. For if I should want to boast, I will not be foolish, for I will speak the truth. But I refrain lest any man should reckon to me above what he sees of me or hears anything from me.
Cor. And so that I might not be over exalted by the extraordinariness of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, an agent of Satan so that he would buffet me, so that I would not be over exalted.
Cor. I besought the Lord thrice about this, that it might depart from me.
Cor. And he said to me, My grace is sufficient for thee, for my power is made fully perfect in weakness. More gladly therefore I will boast in my weaknesses, so that the power of the Christ may reside in me.
Cor. Therefore I am pleased in weaknesses, in injuries, in necessities, in persecutions, in restrictions, for the sake of Christ. For when I am weak, then I am strong.
Cor. I have become foolish, boasting. Ye compelled me, for I ought to have been commended by you. For I came short in nothing of those, superlative apostles, even though I am nothing.
Cor. Indeed the signs of the apostle were performed among you in all perseverance, in signs and wonders and mighty works.
Cor. For what is there which ye were inferior to the other congregations? Except that I myself was not burdensome to you? Forgive me this wrong.
Cor. Behold, a third time I fare readily to come to you,  I will not be burdensome to you, for I seek not the things of you,  you. For the children ought not lay up for the parents,  the parents for the children.
Cor. And I most gladly will spend,  will be spent for your souls. Even though more earnestly loving you, the worse I am loved.
Cor. But let it be. I did not burden you. Nevertheless, being clever, I caught you with bait.
Cor. Any man of whom I have sent to you, did I exploit you through him?
Cor. I encouraged Titus,  I sent the brother with him. Did Titus exploit you in anything? Did we not walk in the same spirit, not in the same steps?
Cor. Again, do ye think that we are making defense to you? In the sight of God we speak in Christ. But all things, beloved, are for your edification.
Cor. For I fear lest somehow, having come, I may find you not such as I want,  I may be found by you such as ye do not want, lest somehow there be strifes, envyings, wraths, selfish ambitions, slanderings, whisperings, puffings up, turmoils,
Cor. lest having come again my God will make me low toward you,  I will bewail many of those who have sinned previously,  who did not repent from the trash and fornication and licentiousness that they committed.
Cor. This third time I am coming to you. In the mouth of two witnesses or three every saying will be confirmed.
Cor. I have told you before,  I say in advance, as present the second time,  now absent, I write to those who have previously sinned,  to all the others, that if I come to it again, I will not spare,
Cor. since ye seek proof of the Christ speaking in me, who is not weak toward you,  is mighty in you.
Cor. For even if he was crucified from weakness, yet he lives from the power of God. For we in him are also weak,  we will live with him from the power of God toward you.
Cor. Examine yourselves whether ye are in the faith. Test yourselves. Or know ye not yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you? Unless ye are test-failing something.
Cor. But I hope that ye will know that we are not test-failing.
Cor. Now I pray to God, to do you nothing harmful, not that we would appear test-passing,  that ye would do right, even like we might be test-failing.
Cor. For we do not have any power against the truth,  for the truth.
Cor. For we are glad when we are weak and ye are strong. And this also we pray for, your full qualification.
Cor. Because of this I write these things while absent, so that I may not act harshly when present, according to the authority that the Lord gave me for building up and not for tearing down.
Cor. Finally brothers, farewell. Be thoroughly prepared, be encouraged, think the same way, live in peace,  the God of love and peace will be with you.
Cor. Salute each other by a holy kiss.
Cor. All the sanctified salute you.
Cor. The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ,  the love of God,  the fellowship of the Holy Spirit, is with all of you. Truly.
Galatians
Paul, an apostle (not from men, nor through man,  through Jesus Christ and God the Father who raised him from the dead),
all the brothers with me, to the congregations of Galatia:
Grace to you and peace from God the Father,  our Lord Jesus Christ
who gave himself for our sins, so that he might rescue us, according to the will of our God and Father, out of the evil age that has come,
to whom is the glory into the ages of the ages. Truly.
I marvel that ye are so soon removed from him who called you in the grace of Christ to another good news,
which is not another, except there are some who confuse you,  who want to pervert the good news of the Christ.
But even if we, or an agent from heaven, should preach a good news to you contrary to what we preached to you, let him be accursed.
As we have said before, I now also say again, if any man preaches a good news to you contrary to what ye received, let him be accursed.
For do I now trust men or God? Or do I seek to please men? For if I were still pleasing men I would not be a bondman of Christ.
For I make known to you, brothers, the good news that was preached by me, that it is not according to man.
For I neither received it from man, nor was I taught it,  it was through revelation of Jesus Christ.
For ye heard of my former behavior in Judaism, that I persecuted the church of God to extraordinariness,  ravaged it.
I advanced in Judaism beyond many contemporaries among my race, being a more extreme zealot of my paternal traditions.
But when it pleased God who separated me from my mother's belly,  called me through his grace,
to reveal his Son in me, so that I might preach him among the Gentiles, I did not straightaway confer with flesh and blood,
nor did I go up to Jerusalem to the apostles before me,  I went into Arabia and returned again to Damascus.
Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to visit with Peter,  I remained with him fifteen days.
But I did not see another of the apostles except James the Lord's brother.
Now what I write to you, behold before God, I do not lie.
Later I came into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
I was unknown by face to the congregations of Judea in Christ,
but they were only hearing that the man who once persecuted us now preaches the good news, the faith that he once ravaged.
they glorified God in me.
Then after fourteen years I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, having taken along Titus also.
I went up according to revelation,  I declared to them the good news that I preach among the Gentiles,  privately to those who were of repute, lest somehow I might be running or ran in vain.
But not even Titus with me, being a Greek, was compelled to be circumcised.
But that issue was because of those false brothers smuggled in, who sneaked in to spy out our liberty that we have in Christ Jesus, so that they might enslave us,
to whom we yielded in subjection not even for an hour, so that the truth of the good news might continue with you.
But from those who were reputed to be something (what kind they were formerly, it makes no difference to me, God does not accept a personage of man), for those who were of repute added nothing to me,
but to the contrary, when they saw that I was entrusted with the good news for men of uncircumcision, as Peter for men of circumcision
for he who was working in Peter for the apostleship for men of circumcision was also working in me for the Gentiles),
James and Cephas and John, those who were reputed to be pillars, when they understood the grace that was given to me, they gave to me and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship. So that we were for the Gentiles,  they for men of circumcision,
only that we should remember the poor, which this same thing I also was eager to do.
But when Peter came to Antioch I opposed him to the face, because he was blameworthy.
For before certain men came from James he ate together with the Gentiles,  when they came, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing men of circumcision.
the other Jews also joined in hypocrisy with him, so that even Barnabas went along with their hypocrisy.
But when I saw that they did not walk uprightly toward the truth of the good news, I said to Peter before all, If thou being a Jew, live as a Gentile and not as a Jew, why do thou compel the Gentiles to live as Jews?
We are Jews by nature and not sinful men of the Gentiles,
knowing that a man is not made righteous from works of law, instead through faith of Jesus Christ. And we believed in Christ Jesus, so that we might be made righteous from faith of Christ,  not from works of law, because no flesh will be made righteous from works of law.
But if, while seeking to be made righteous in Christ, we ourselves were also found sinful, then is Christ an aide of sin? May it not happen!
For if I build again these things that I tore down, I demonstrate myself a transgressor.
For I, through law, died to law, so that I might live to God.
I have been crucified with Christ,  I no longer live,  Christ lives in me. And what I now live in flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God who loved me and gave himself up for me.
I do not disregard the grace of God, for if righteousness is through law, then Christ died in vain.
O foolish Galatians, who bewitched you not to obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ was earlier described among you, crucified?
I only want to learn this from you. Did ye receive the Spirit from works of law, or from a listening ear of faith?
Are ye so foolish, having begun in Spirit, are ye now made perfect by flesh?
Did ye suffer so many things in vain? If it is indeed in vain.
He therefore who supplies the Spirit to you and who works miracles among you, is it from works of law or from a listening ear of faith?
Just as Abraham believed God,  it was reckoned to him for righteousness.
Ye know therefore that those from faith, these are sons of Abraham.
the scripture having foreseen that God makes the Gentiles righteous from faith, proclaimed the good news in advance to Abraham: In thee all the nations will be blessed.
So then those from faith are blessed with the faithful Abraham.
For as many as are from works of law are under a curse, for it is written, Cursed is every man who does not continue in all things written in the book of the law, to do them.
But that no man is made righteous by law before God, is evident, because, The righteous man will live from faith.
the law is not from faith,  the man who does them will live in them.
Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us. For it is written, Cursed is every man who hangs on a tree.
So that the blessing of Abraham might occur for the Gentiles in Christ Jesus, so that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through the faith.
Brothers (I speak according to a man), in the same way of a man, no man annuls or adds to a contract that has been ratified.
Now the promises were spoken to Abraham and to his seed. He does not say, And to the seeds, as of many,  as of one, And to thy seed, who is Christ.
I say this, a covenant previously confirmed by God in Christ, the law, which happened four hundred and thirty years after, does not annul in order to make the promise useless.
For if the inheritance is from law, it is no longer from promise. But God has given it to Abraham through promise.
Why then the law? It was added on account of transgressions, until the seed would come to whom it was promised, which was arranged through agents in the hand of a mediator.
Now a mediator is not of one,  God is one.
Is the law therefore against the promises of God? May it not happen! For if a law was given that could make alive, truly righteousness would be from law.
But scripture confined all things under sin, so that the promise from faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.
But before faith came we were kept in custody under law, having been confined for faith that was going to be revealed.
So that the law became our schoolmaster for Christ, so that we might be made righteous from faith.
But faith having come, we are no longer under a schoolmaster.
For ye are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.
For as many as were immersed into Christ have put on Christ.
There is no Jew nor Greek, there is no bondman nor freeman, there is no male and female, for ye are all one in Christ Jesus.
if ye are Christ's, then ye are Abraham's seed and heirs according to promise.
But I say the heir, for as long a time as he is a child, differs nothing from a bondman though he is lord of all.
Instead he is under stewards and managers until the time appointed from the father.
so when we were children, we were in bondage under the rudiments of the world.
But when the fullness of the time came, God sent forth his Son, born from a woman, born under law,
so that he might redeem those under law, so that we might receive the sonship.
because ye are sons, God sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father.
So that thou are no longer a bondman but a son,  if a son, then an heir through Christ.
But of course not knowing God then, ye were in bondage to those in nature who are not gods,
but now knowing God,  rather being known by God, how is it ye turn again to the weak and destitute elements to which ye desire again to be in bondage anew?
Ye observe days,  months,  times,  years.
I am afraid of you, lest somehow I have labored toward you in vain.
I beseech you, brothers, become like me, because I also am like ye. Ye wronged me in nothing.
But ye know that through a weakness of the flesh I preached the good news to you the first time.
ye did not disdain, nor did ye reject my trial in my flesh,  ye received me as an agent of God, as Christ Jesus.
Where then is your satisfaction? For I testify to you, that if possible, having plucked your eyes out, ye would have given them to me.
So then have I become your enemy telling you the truth?
They are zealous for you but not honorably. They want to exclude you, so that ye may be zealous for them.
But to be zealous of is always good in a good thing,  not only when I am present with you.
My little children, of whom I suffer birth pains again until Christ is formed in you.
But I was wishing to be present with you now and to change my tone, because I am perplexed at you.
Tell me those desiring to be under law, do ye not hear the law?
For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one from the servant girl,  one from the freewoman.
But in fact, the man from the servant girl was born according to flesh,  the man from the freewoman through promise.
Which things are allegorized, for these are two covenants, indeed one from mount Sinai giving birth for bondage, which is Hagar.
For Hagar is mount Sinai in Arabia,  it corresponds to the present Jerusalem,  is in bondage with her children.
But the Jerusalem above is free, which is mother of us all.
For it is written, Rejoice, thou barren woman not giving birth. Burst forth and shout, thou not suffering birth pains, because many more are the children of the desolate than of her who has the husband.
Now we, brothers, who correspond to Isaac, are children of promise.
But just as then, the man who was born according to flesh persecuted the man according to Spirit, so also now.
Nevertheless, what does the scripture say? Send away the servant girl and her son, for the son of the servant girl will, no, not inherit with the son of the freewoman.
So then, brothers, we are not children of a servant girl,  of the freewoman.
Stand firm therefore in the liberty in which Christ freed us,  be not entangled again in a yoke of bondage.
Behold, I Paul say to you, that if ye are circumcised, Christ will benefit you nothing.
I solemnly declare again to every man who is circumcised, that he is obligated to do the whole law.
Ye were discharged from the Christ, ye who are made righteous by law. Ye have fallen from grace.
For we through Spirit, from faith, wait for a hope of righteousness.
For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision avails anything nor uncircumcision,  faith working through love.
Ye were running well. Who hindered you, not to obey the truth?
This persuasion is not from him who calls you.
A little leaven leavens the whole lump.
I have confidence toward you in the Lord, that ye will think no other thing. But the man who troubles you will bear the verdict, whoever he may be.
But I, brothers, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still persecuted? Then the stumbling-block of the cross has been abolished.
O that those who trouble you would even cut it all off.
For ye, brothers, were called to liberty, only not liberty for an opportunity to the flesh,  be servants to each other through love.
For the whole law is fulfilled in one word, in this: Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself.
But if ye bite and devour each other, watch out that ye be not consumed by each other.
But I say, walk in Spirit and ye will, no, not fulfill a lust of flesh.
For the flesh desires against the Spirit,  the Spirit is against the flesh. For these are hostile to each other, so that whatever these things are ye may want, ye may not do.
But if ye are led by Spirit ye are not under law.
Now the works of the flesh are apparent, which are, adultery, fornication, uncleanness, licentiousness,
idolatry, sorcery, hatreds, strifes, jealousies, wraths, selfish ambitions, dissensions, factions,
envyings, murders, intoxications, revelings,  things like these, of which I forewarn you, as I also did forewarn, that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
meekness, self-control. Against such things there is no law.
those of the Christ have crucified the flesh with its passions and the lusts.
If we live in Spirit, we should also march in Spirit.
Let us not become conceited, provoking each other, envying each other.
brothers, if a man is overtaken in some transgression, ye the spiritual, restore such in a spirit of meekness, looking to thyself lest thou also be tempted.
Bear the burdens of each other,  so fulfill the law of the Christ.
For if some man presumes to be something when he is nothing, he deceives himself.
But let each man examine his own work,  then he will have the boast in himself alone and not in the other man.
For each man will bear his own burden.
But let him who is taught in the word share in all good things with him who teaches.
Be not misled, God is not mocked, for whatever a man sows this he will also reap.
